sp.p: Oh, no, we will not be confused. So maybe we could do it that way, unless anyone else is getting -- is it difficult for you -- for your strategy to do it that way?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, it's difficult and it's perhaps also totally inconsequential to my case whether or not I deal with those general matters. And, as I say, they are matters -- they are matters I might, in the course of his testimony, just decide to leave out entirely. So, to start with it would be really prejudicial.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Okay, you may not even have to go into it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. Then -- and so the entire testimony of this witness in-chief will be for closed?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. It wouldn't to be terribly long, Your Honour. He is testifying in --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Approximately? About an hour would be --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: -- French and --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: -- I think about an hour would be --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: About an hour. So the public is informed of that, but then that would have repercussion on the cross-examination. So there may well be closed session for the rest of the day. At any rate, the Registry will announce whether we can go into open session later on. That is the situation. If the public will then kindly leave the gallery and we will proceed. Mr. Witness, you have listened to this discussion and I am sure you have seen that in order to protect your safety we will now close these proceedings. That implies that everything that's going to happen here now will only be heard by the parties and the staff. There is no one in the public gallery, and the transcripts of the proceedings will be kept under seal afterwards. So now you can speak freely.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 37 to 52] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)
Pages 25 to 36 by Gifty C. Harding)1745H

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, we will now start with the open session, Mr. Witness, and from now on you have to be careful, but we understand that the questions to be put to you by the Prosecution are of a general nature. But beware that you don't reveal your identity in any way.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, during your stay in Kibuye between April and June 1994, did there come a time when you attended a meeting at the Kibuye préfectural office, and, if so, when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, it was on the 3rd of May 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And do you know who convened this meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I don't know, but the prime minister was there, and other ministers were there as well. There were members of various political parties who were there, there were bourgmestres there as well.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And do you know the identities of any of the government ministers that attended this meeting, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, apparently they were all there, but mainly those from Kibuye, because the prime minister had come to visit Kibuye prefecture, and so those who were natives of Kibuye had to be there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And are you able to recall which particular ministers hailed from Kibuye who attended that meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: There was Agnes Ntamabariro, who was the minister of justice, I believe, N-T-A-M-A-B-A-R-I-R-O, first name Agnes, A-G-N-E-S; there was Eliezer Niyitegeka, N-I-Y-I-T-E-G-E-K-A, Niyitegeka, first name Eliezer; and there was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi. And I think those were the ministers who were from Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know why the three ministers who hailed from Kibuye had to have been present at the meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, they had to be there, because the prime minister, who was the one who had appointed them, had come to their prefecture, therefore there was no reason for them not to be there and to be where he was, especially as the visit dealt with Kibuye prefecture. So they had to attend the meeting.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know what the purpose of the meeting was, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, the main purpose -- at least this is what the prime minister said -- it dealt with pacification with respect to the killings, the massacres. And so the main word was pacification. And he spoke about the RPF, that RPF units had attacked the country, that we needed to fight, that we would defeat them, but he was saying that we had to stop the killings.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: At the time of this meeting, the 3rd of May 1994, were you personally aware, Mr. Witness, of any, any, massacres in Kibuye prefecture?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, there had been massacres everywhere, killings everywhere.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you mention some locations that you had become aware of where massacres had indeed occurred as at 3rd May 1994, Mr. Witness, in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: At that date, no.I'm not sure I understood your question.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I guessed as much. Can you tell the Court of any locations in Kibuye prefecture that you had become aware of as at 3rd May where massacres had occurred, just off the top of your head?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, not on that specific date, but between April and May there had been massacres in Kibuye at the Home St. Jean, at the parish, at Gatwaro stadium, at Nyange and Mugonero, and they had already started in Bisesero. But fighting still continued, so everywhere there were massacres and killings.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Whilst you were at the meeting on 3rd of May involving the prime minister and these other ministers who hailed from Kibuye, did you hear anyone condemn those massacres that you have just described as having been aware of? Anyone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, a person named Leonard Hitimana. He was a doctor. He was a member of the MDR party, but from the moderate MDR wing. He condemned the massacres. He said that small children remained in the stadium and at the Home St. Jean and had been taken to hospital, and that it was necessary to watch over them, to bring them food, to take care of them, because they were still there. And the person named Eliezer Niyitegeka said that was none of his business and was not his problem, even though he was a physician, these matters were none of his business. And this is why, after the meeting, Dr. Hitimana had to flee, because he was being persecuted. He had to flee the country. He went to Congo and did not come back until some time much later. And so there were persons who had bad intentions and did not want people to be saved.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The man you describe as Niyitegeka, who reacted to Hitimana's comments, was who? What position did he hold in government?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: He was the minister of information, I believe. The minister of information. He was a member of the MDR power wing.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did the prime minister himself react to the comments made by this Dr. Hitimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I don't remember. I don't remember his reaction.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, you also mentioned, Mr. Witness, that some bourgmestres attended the meeting on 3rd May. Do you recall if any of the bourgmestres made any speeches at that meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: There was a person -- I can't recall this person's name -- a person from Gisheta commune. I can't remember the name just now, but it will come back to me. Yes, it was Sikuwabo, and he said that there were RPF soldiers in Bisesero and he was asking for assistance, asking that soldiers be sent to fight them. And the prime minister said, "You must be watchful and see whether they were RPF soldiers, Inkotanyi, or if they were Batutsi who had fled to that location. If they were Batutsi, you should leave them, but if they were RPF soldiers, tell us, and we will provide assistance so that you can fight them".

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: To your knowledge, Mr. Witness, were there any RPF soldiers in Kibuye as at the 3rd of May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, who else was there? Let me think. I know that the Turquoise troops came, but I don't remember exactly when. I know they came to Kibuye. I don't know if it was then or later. I don't really recall. Turquoise was also in Kibuye, because I think it was towards the end of May when Turquoise went to Bisesero to try and save the survivors who had remained there after the massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: My question, rather, referred to RPF soldiers. Do you know, in your personal knowledge, whether there were any RPF soldiers active in Kibuye in May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, unless they had infiltrated, but they had not yet arrived. They were still in the Gitarama area. They were still fighting in Gitarama. They had not yet crossed the Nyabarongo.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So in your opinion, what -- who did you understand this bourgmestre Sikuwabo to be referring to when he referred to RPF or Inkotanyi? Who was he referring to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I wouldn't be able to know. I mean, they weren't wearing a uniform, they could not easily have been identified, so I don't know who he could have been referring to. I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well. Mr. Witness. Mr. Witness, if I asked you to identify Emmanuel Ndindabahizi this evening, would you be able to do so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes. He also would recognise me. I can see him over there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, may I seek your leave to have this witness perform a dock identification, or an identification, at least if he can, of the Accused.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, could you please stand up, look around this courtroom, and tell me if you can see the man you knew as Emmanuel Ndindabahizi here. If you do --

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, I can see him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you --

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I recognise him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you describe where he is seated in the courtroom, if you recognise him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: He is seated behind counsel. He's wearing a tie. He's balding; he has a few white hairs.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And do you recognise the colour of what he's wearing, if you are good with colours?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: He's wearing a black jacket.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Enough for me. Thank you very much, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, may the records reflect, in my opinion, it's been a positive identification of the Accused seated to the left of the witness box behind counsel, learned counsel for the Defence.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It's noted.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm grateful, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Finally, Mr. Witness, can you tell me, has anyone other than officers from the Office of the Prosecutor contacted you in relation to this trial, anyone at all apart from members of the Office of the Prosecutor? Has anyone contacted you in relation to this trial and, if so, who and when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you. It was during the month of August, I believe it was on the 10th or the 11th, I received a telephone call from someone who was claiming to know me and they wanted to meet me in a bar. I was busy, and I told this person that I could go there later. This person called me back, and so I went to see this person. I didn't know this person, but there is someone who knew me and knew the person. And when I reached the bar I had a drink, and I was expecting for someone to come and see me and say, "I have been looking for you." After approximately ten minutes this person said, "Well, where is so and so?" The person who knew me said, "Well, he's there." So this person came and greeted me. It was around 5 p.m. or 7 p.m., but we could see with the lamp. So we moved to one side of the road, and he told me that he was contacting me at the request of Ndindabahizi's counsel and that he wanted me to make a statement for Ndindabahizi's defence, and he told me that he had been sent by counsel. He gave me his name. His first name was Jean Pierre; I don't remember his surname. I know someone who had lived with this person. And he told me, "To confirm this, I can say that during the month of August you will be travelling to Arusha to testify." He showed me a document on which was written the names of all the persons who were going to come and testify here in Ndindabahizi's trial and their pseudonym. I believe that is the word that you used, was that. He said, "This is your name and this is your pseudonym." And he read the names. I recognised some of the names; these were some of the people I knew. And I told him, "I cannot speak double-talk. If you know that I am going to Arusha, then I go to Arusha. I will not change my testimony and I cannot give you a statement." And I know that subsequently he went to see other people who will perhaps come, and they contacted me and said, "Were you contacted by someone?" And they said, "Yes, I was contacted." And they said, "We met with this person as well." I thought this person was an employee of the ICTR, and when I mentioned this to someone they said, "No, it wasn't us because you know us." And when I reached Kigali before I came here, I spoke to ICTR employees in Kigali because if we are to be protected, then everything should be done in the strictest confidence. I mean, I've left my house, and now everyone knew I was coming to Arusha. And this is why I said this, in case there were any problems, so people would know how things actually took place. This is what I have to say.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Let the records reflect, Your Honour, that the 10th of August is three days after I made unredacted disclosure of my entire witness list to the Defence team in Paris, France. I have no further questions for this witness.Thank you, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. Before I lead the cross-examination with this witness, there was one point that I would like to clarify, and I would like to ask the Prosecutor to which part of the indictment he is referring to. When hearing this witness, what are the relevant parts of the indictment that pertain to this witness, because I have closely read the indictment and I do not see that Mr. Ndindabahizi is accused of having participated in a meeting on the 3rd of May, 1994, in Kibuye, and I do not see that he is accused of having had a meeting with the witness in June 1994. So from a legal perspective, I believe it is important to clarify which specific parts of the indictment are relevant to this testimony and to the testimony made by this witness.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's a very simple matter, Your Honour. They are factual allegations in any indictment and there's also something called specific intent to commit genocide. Genocide and intent, that's what it goes to, Your Honour. It doesn't have to be clearly stated in the indictment.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Well, I believe that we will have to go a bit further, but maybe we will do this in our closing argument. Mr. President, there's two points I would like to make. First of all, this witness was supposed to testify at a later time, and I have understood that we would only have three witnesses this week. Therefore, if we request that we -- that today's session be shortened, I believe that we will not lose -- that we will not get behind. And would it be possible for the Trial Chamber to order that cross-examination begin tomorrow afternoon, especially as it is now currently six -- ten minutes past six.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Chamber is, of course, like both parties, willing -- no, eager to move things forward and use court time in an efficient way, but this being said, we note, as mentioned by the Defence, that there has been a change in the witness sequencing. We also note the explanation of the Prosecution previously why that happened during the weekend. In view of the fact that there is a limited number of witnesses, at least for the time being, in the couple of days to come, we would see no problems in granting the Defence request and start tomorrow at two o'clock. Yes.Could we plan now a little bit forward, Prosecution? You have mentioned the witnesses. We have the investigators, we have the present one -- and I don't think there is any harm in the witness listening to this.Mr. Witness, we are now just discussing a few procedural issues. If you could kindly bear with us a couple of minutes. And as you understood, we will come back to you tomorrow at two o'clock, but before we close for the day, only a few practical arrangements.Now, the next -- please, Mr. Phillips, first let me ask the Defence the estimated time for the cross-examination of this witness, it being understood that it is certainly only an estimate.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: One hour to an hour and a half. I believe that it would take approximately an hour and a half to cross-examine this witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And the next witness, Mr. Phillips? Did you indicate --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Number one on our list, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, yes. Approximately two hours, one hour, three hours?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I actually don't have an indication of how well or how badly I did in relation to time today because of that break in between, but I think I spent, what, two hours?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You started --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have no idea how long it was.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Oh, we will shortly be able to -- you started 16:10 and finished 18:10 and then we lost 20 minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So I did better than I anticipated, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Not bad at all.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Oh, good, okay. So if we say two hours maximum for that witness and hopefully shorter than that, Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah. So the next witness, approximately two hours?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: At the very -- at maximum.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: At the maximum, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's two hours. Now, that implies that we will start with this one and we will start with cross-examination of that witness tomorrow.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Then it was -- that's Tuesday. Then the third one.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The third one is number four on your list, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And that is a very short witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Estimated time?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: One hour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: One hour.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: One hour maximum.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Say max one hour from the other side, and that's that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's that. I have no indication who has been brought today, if anyone. I would find out when I leave here, so ...

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, so please get in touch with the witness protection. And the problem is that GMZ didn't arrive, was that so?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, we're having problems with him, Your Honour, and he's -- he has indicated that he would not be available until November.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Which --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Which is -- which poses a problem practically.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But it's important, then, if you -- when you get in touch with Mr. Chappell to make sure that everyone is doing his and her very best, because the number is too limited.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, yes. You will come back to us on that one, then.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.Mr. Witness, this brings us to the end of today's session. You will continue tomorrow. You must not discuss your testimony with anyone until tomorrow.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The court is adjourned until tomorrow.

div.head: 2 SEPTEMBER 20031405H CONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Mr. Nouhou M. DialloMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi:Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Mr. Petrus ChijariraMs. Gifty C. HardingMs. Judith BaverstockMs. Trish GreigMs. Regina LimulaMs. Diane Hermann

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon. The Court is in session. Defence, you have the floor for cross-examination. Madam Witness, you are still under the - Mr. Witness, you are still under the obligation to tell the truth, and the headset will now be checked to make sure that the communication is efficient. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you. Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I am sorry, Mr. President, I didn't hear the beginning of what you said.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you will now be asked questions by Defence, Mr. Witness, in cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I am Ndindabahizi's counsel. I am going to ask you a few questions, not too many, on your testimony. I would like you to ask -- answer your questions as briefly and as precisely as possible. Let's begin with the multiparty era in Rwanda. That was the beginning of your testimony yesterday. You stated that from a given point in time, political parties were authorised and they were able to operate on the territory Rwanda; is that correct, and what time exactly was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Do you remember the Boule conference in France which enabled multipartyism to start? So I believe in Rwanda from 1991, that is when it started. I am not sure exactly, but I think it was in 1991 that multipartyism started.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. And can you tell which parties emerged from this Rwandan political class which this thus liberated?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you. Apart from the MRND which was already in place, there was the MDR, the PSD. There was the PL, PDC, PDI. There was also the DPR. In fact, there were several parties. There were many parties. PSD also was included.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, are we in a public, open session or are we in closed session?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We are, are we not, Registry, in an open session? The question arises now when you want to go into the closed session. Registry --

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. I have some questions of a general nature to put to the witness, but I am also concerned about the safety and the need to preserve the identity of our witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Just for the planning, do you have some questions which could be posed in a public session to start with before moving into a closed session?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, I have some questions of a general nature, but I would at least want to mention the name of the party to which the witness belonged. I wonder whether this would be of any problem if I were to ask him the party to which he belonged.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Phillips.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, the question my learned friend proposes to ask may not, on its own, be a problem but, when considered in the context of this gentleman's testimony, will reveal the identity, and I think the appropriate thing is to go into camera.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It depends a little bit on the -- on the question to be posed. Can we hear the question first? And we agree -- I mean, both parties are now actively searching not to divulge the identity of the witness, so that is something we are very eager to avoid, Mr. Witness. We are looking -- we are very careful now. Now, let me first hear the question. And Mr. Witness, you do not have to answer this question. We just want to hear the question, and we will then assess whether we can continue with that question or whether we go into closed. And at some stage, we will obviously have to go into closed. The only issue now is the timing. Yes, please, the question, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, you said yesterday that the PSD was a moderate party. Can it also be referred to as an opposition party, in opposition to the president and the MRND party?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That can be answered.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I believe it's true, that -

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness said that it's true that it was in opposition to the MRND.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You also said that the PSD was a party whose aim was to promote social progress. Can you please explain to us what you intend to mean by the term social welfare, social promotion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I rather said that the PSD was a moderate party whose objective was social welfare, that's what I said. I didn't say social progress, I said social well being. Now, in that context, with that term I mean that the PSD -- first of all, the MRND as it was, and had limited itself to some parts of the country where there were tendencies in various parts, depending on who the party official was or who the president was. The PSD in its party said that any Rwandan citizen, any Rwandan national, should enjoy social development and should be able to enjoy democratic rights. So the PSD had as an objective the fact that any Rwandan enjoy his or her social welfare without any restriction from any side whatsoever, because the MRND was biased. That's what I can say.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did all the members of this party adhere to that generous ideology?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes. The members all shared the same objective, because before they joined the party there was an ideology which was already prepared, and each member needed to read beforehand the text that governs the party. He had to adhere to those ideologies, and then he would join. If he does not agree, he wouldn't join.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. And as you have said, this party was opposed to any kind of discrimination?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes. What I said is that that happened before the 6th of April 1994, because subsequent to that date every changed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: On the 6th of April specifically, was -- did Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, as a member of the PSD party, share the ideologies you've just expressed and explained?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, Emmanuel Ndindabahizi was a member of the party, the PSD. He was living in Kigali. He was living in Kibuye, and he would regularly attend meetings, but most often he was rather more in Kigali than in Kibuye.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Mr. President, could we ask for more of a pause between the question and answer between counsel and the witness?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In 1994, was there any other parties in opposition to the MRND, apart from the PSD?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: There was the PSD, there was PL, there was the DPR. All these parties were opposed. And then the MDR in the beginning before -- it was also opposed before there was some forums which were created within parties against the MRND.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is a point of order here. When both counsel and the witness are talking the same language, it is very tempting to enter into a dialogue immediately, in other words, not allowing for translation; but both interlocutors must remember to pause for about four seconds so that we will get the rest of the sentence before you start. So if you will both observe this. And Defence counsel, this seems to have gone very well so far, but you will know when you are entering areas where we have to close.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. I will be on the lookout.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was the PSD party well-spread out throughout the territory of Rwanda, or was it better represented in certain préfectures?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The PSD was represented everywhere. Obviously since it was founded in such and such a préfecture, there would be more members there in that préfecture rather than elsewhere, but the PSD was well represented throughout the country, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you remind us in which préfecture the PSD was founded?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The first members of the PSD were living in Kigali, and there was Nzamurambaho, Frederic, who was a native of Gikongoro; Félicien Gatabazi was living in Kigali but was a native of Butare; Ngango, Félicien, was first vice-president, was living in Kigali but was a native of Kibungo.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The names have been mentioned and quickly, now. So, the first name was? Just take it a little bit more slowly, even if we went through it yesterday. You said that Frederic came from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Of Gikongoro, he was a native of Gikongoro.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And the second person you mentioned was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I mentioned Félicien Gatabazi from Butare. Ngango was from Kibungo also, yes, Kibungo. And then Gafaranga (phonetic) -- may I continue? From Gitarama. That was -- those were some of the members of the founding -- founding members of the PSD at national level, but they came from different préfectures.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, but you didn't quite answer my question. I am sorry, Mr. Witness, I wanted to know in which préfecture the party was the best represented just before the month of April 1994.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, thank you. Everywhere in the préfectures PSD existed. There had been elections for members of parliament throughout who were supposed to represent the PSD in the national assembly, but one can say that Butare, which even today hoists the PSD flag, was more represented than other préfectures.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And in Kibuye, what was the situation? Would you say that there was a party which was very well represented or a party which had few members in relation to the average numbers in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The PSD was well represented.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You spoke about the elections to the national assembly. Can you tell us whether all parties which were born of the multiparty era, all those you have mentioned a moment ago, were indeed represented at the national assembly of Rwanda before April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, following multipartyism, all the parties were represented, but the balance wasn't equally. This depended on the numbers of the members.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you please remind us when this legislature that you referred to was in effect? When were the elections that took place for appointing members of parliament to the national assembly in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The elections took place in 1993, but the specific date I do not recall.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The year will be sufficient. And when was that office to expire?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The transition was to last - I'm sorry, I do not know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If you do not know, that is okay, Mr. Witness. It's not too much of a problem. Very well, we have spoken a lot about the PSD. Let's now move on to the other parties. Would you say that some of the other parties born of the multiparty system were extremist parties?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I was in the PSD. I was dealing mostly with my own party, and I wasn't really interested in going to see whether the other parties were extremist or not. I do beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No. But Mr. Witness, as a citizen who is participating in the political life of the country and as a politician, you should have some observations, some point of view on the political nature of the other political parties, wouldn't you say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: In the beginning, the political parties, the opposition parties, the parties in opposition to the MRND, were unanimous. To start with, there was the MDR, which split into two. There was the power wing and the moderate wing. After that there was the PL, and that same thing happened to that party. Now, PSD also was later seen to divide or split up. As for the other parties, PSR and the other smaller parties, that wasn't so clear. But there were also some parties which didn't exist in our prefecture, so I wouldn't know what their behaviour or conduct was.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Let's go about this step by step. I believe I understood from your testimony yesterday that the PSD before April 1994 didn't split into power wings; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, you're quite right. Yes, but apparently -- that was the apparent situation.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, going back to the other political parties, do you know what happened to the most influential, as it was, of these opposition parties immediately after the 6th of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Which parties are speaking about?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I am speaking about political parties, opposition political parties, for instance, the PSD.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: That I know about.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What happened to them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: It happened that there was a matter of identifying who had killed the president. Others fled; some people remained behind.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: As for the people who were killed, they didn't only belong to the moderate parties, did they? They also belonged to the government in place. For instance, the prime minister of Rwanda, she was also assassinated, wasn't she?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, she also belonged to a moderate party. She was in the MDR. MDR was not - was moderate. It wasn't - it didn't have a power wing.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: There were other people belonging to the Habyarimana government who were killed on the morning of the 6th or 7th of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, mention was made of that, but they were not all killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Some of the victims were Hutu, were they not? Would you say that an atmosphere of terror existed on that day and days that followed in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: It is not only on that day, it was the case for a long duration of time. It was not only in Kigali, it went on also in the préfectures. It wasn't only limited to Kigali. Terror reigned for at least two or three months.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Thank you, Mr. Witness. Do you know when the interim government was formed after the death of President Habyarimana, what day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I know that it was in April, but he knows it better because he was part of it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I am asking you the question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: All I know is that it was in April. I wasn't in the government. I had fled, so I did not know what was happening.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. So I believe that you may not know this, but can you confirm it -- you may not know the circumstances under which the interim government was formed.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I wasn't there, but I know that it was Kambanda who formed the government, but I could not tell you why it was formed, what were the circumstances. But in my view, I believe it's clear because what the government did subsequently was clearly seen.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The question, rather, is strictly on the technical formation of the government, and I want to know whether you have any information.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I do not have any concerning the formation or the calling together of these ministers to form the government. I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know what parties were represented within that interim government?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I know that there was the MRND, there was the PSD, there was the PL. I think that's it. I don't know whether there were any others, but the major parties that I know were those. There could have been others that I was not aware of. But the RPF was not there, the DP was not there, the PDC was not included, so there were parties which were not included in the government.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In your opinion as a political observer, as a citizen, why was it necessary to bring together several parties in order to form the interim government, whereas it was unimaginable that a government of national unity be formed surrounding only those involved in the MRND?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: We are in April 1994; the president has just been assassinated. The first reflex which will come to one's mind is to constitute a strong government around the only political party which was strong at the time, at least, the party which represented the interests of the Rwandan people, the MRND. Why was that not done, and why did those who formed the government ask other parties to associate themselves with that government?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Thank you. The MRND -- which was still strong at that point in time because there were opposition parties which were counter-balancing, the major leaders had already been assassinated -- the MRND went back to its older form, and then, as I have said, there were factions in the parties. There power wings in the MDR, in the MRND. Those who left those parties joined the MRND again, and this happened in several of the parties and --

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you think that the interim government was only made up of ministers of the power tendency or with power leanings?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, the fact that there were Tutsis who were welcomed and a person who was in the government and who was able to lead, I don't know how -- that government could not be if it was excluding certain individuals whereas these people were for the formation of the government.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You do really believe that this government was able to have all of the powers it should have been able to draw from the constitution, more specifically with respect to security?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: When the government was formed initially it was in Kigali, then it went to Gisenyi, then it was -- the government was in flight. But to say that they were actually able to wield all of the power that the constitution entitled it to, the time in which it governed was such a short period of time, nevertheless it was able to accomplish what it sought to do, sought out to do. For example, on the 6th of April the president died. A few days later the government was formed, and the killings did not cease. The MRND had soldiers, militia from the MRND, and they should have wielded their power over the people. If the people had already started to kill their brothers, the soldiers that were everywhere in the country -- I mean, one word from the head of government or from the prime minister could have stopped the situation, and if they did not do so, then it is the government's fault.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you believe that the high-ranking officers in the army had any influence on the government, Rwandan government, between April and July 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: That's what I was saying, that's what I meant. The government had already been established, and there was a minister of defence whose job was to supervise the soldiers if they went above the government. If I had been in the government, I would have stepped down and I would have left the soldiers to work alone. If I was not allowed to have any power on them, I would have resigned.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, but that's not the question, Witness. I am not asking what you would have done, but I am asking about the events that have already taken place. I am asking you, would it be possible that the soldiers -- that the officers took decisions without referring to the government or to the minister of defence, whether that would be a classic case of rebellion?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I object to this line of questioning. You are either asking the witness to speculate on what he has no direct knowledge about, or you are asking for his opinion. You can't have your cake and eat it. You asked for his opinion; he gave you his opinion. You are now asking him to speculate. He wasn't part of the government. I object to that line of questioning.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, this is cross-examination. When -- he spoke at length yesterday of the interim government, and I believe that he had information on that subject. In any case, I would like to add that this was my last question on this matter.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The question is allowed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, I think -- I believe that the witness already answered that question. He said that if that there were the case, that that would be a rebellion.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, at least we got the answer now. It didn't come through in the first version. Are you moving on to a different area now?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I was going to move on to something else, Mr. President, but if you would like to put a question to the witness, then of course I shall pause and allow you to put your question to the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I have just been following the line of questioning, and at a certain point I think we have to close the session, and I wonder whether this will be a convenient moment in view of the issues you are about to get into now.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No, Mr. President. I will be moving on to another line of questioning, but I believe that we can still remain in open session.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, watch it very carefully. Mr. Witness, we are in an open session, as you know, so be careful with your answers.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness, let us now speak of the 6th and 7th of April 1997 (sic) and what you stated yesterday. You said that men and women involved in politics, especially those who were members of opposition parties, and specifically those who were members of the PSD, could be divided in a schematic form in three groups. There is the category of those who were killed during the first few days and the days that followed; secondly, there are those who fled, those who went into hiding; and finally, there are those who participated in the government. Have I summarised this properly?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. In your opinion, those who were killed on that day, they really didn't have much choice, did they?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Could you rephrase - could you clarify your question?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The persons who were killed, they had no choice, did they? It's because they were - they did not have the opportunity to flee, isn't that the reason why they died?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Please, ambiguous, totally ambiguous. Can my learned friend rephrase that question, specify which day and which people he is referring to. It's a very ambiguous question.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That objection is sustained. The question is too general, and it is difficult to answer it in a precise way when it is so generally formulated. Please reformulate it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The persons who fled, those who are part of the second category, in your opinion did they do this as a political gesture to show - were they taking a political stand to show that they were against what was happening in Rwanda, or did they proceed in this manner because they were trying to save their lives?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: They were trying to seek refuge. They could either go to the RPF or they could flee to another country, to Zaire, to the Congo; or they could join the Rwandan army, because those that went over to the Rwandan army did not die. If they joined the RPF, it is because they were sure that they would not be killed there. They would not be killed by soldiers or the Interahamwe, because it was alleged that there was a list saying who was -- specifying who was supposed to be killed. There was a list and people knew. You would go Ngango's house because there was a list, and then in the meantime you would be going to the houses of the other persons whose names appeared on the list. It wasn't just by chance that these killings took place, especially as far as important politicians are concerned. I specified -- I gave you the example of the PSD, and I mentioned the names of Hutus. I did not mention the names of the Tutsi because they were classified by ethnic group. I am speaking here of these persons' beliefs or their ideology, the fact that they were against the MRND. And if you had a Hutu person who was a member of the PSD and who is against the MRND, in another words, I mean, why would they die? Why would they be killed?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In other words, and then to summarise -- sum up what you've just said, those who fled did so because they were in danger and they could be killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, because their names were on the list.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Let us now move on to the third category of persons, those who participated in the interim government. Do you really believe that they had a choice to participate in this government?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Once again, Counsel, I will tell you that I was not a member of the government. I was not a part of that government. I know it was established. I do not know how these persons became a member of the government, and I cannot answer your question.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes. So you were not present at the meeting of the 8th of April 1994 at the ministry of defence when the government was formed, is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Therefore, you know nothing about what happened during the meeting when the government was formed. You don't know if people were threatened; you do not know if any pressure was brought about against them.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I did not go to the government -- to this meeting because I was not invited to attend this meeting.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Perfect. Very well, let us now move to a meeting that was held in Kibuye at the beginning of May 1994. Do you remember speaking of this meeting yesterday?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you think it would be possible to speak of this meeting in general terms and that your identity will not be revealed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: I think it would be okay.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I am referring to the transcript from yesterday, and this is what you said, Witness. You said the main purpose of the meeting was pacification, and pacification was to stop the killings, stop the massacres. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, that was the purpose of the meeting. That is what the prime minister stated.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And then a little bit - sometime after this you added that during the meeting, you realised that there were persons, and I'm quoting, "who had good intentions and others who did not want people to be saved." Is that correct? Is that what you said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In what category would you place Mr. Ndindabahizi when he attended that meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Well, I would have been able to put him in one group or another if he had spoken, but as -- you will recall that I did not mention what he said. I could not say where exact - I could not say in what position he was as I did not hear him speak and state his position.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you give us the names of the ministers or who attended this meeting, because I believe that I did not take proper notes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: There was Agnes. I will spell the last name, N-T-A-M-A-B-Y-A-L-I-R-O, Ntamabyaliro. Agnes,A-G-N-E-S for the first name, Agnes. There was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, N-D-I-N-D-I-B-A-H-A-Z-I (sic), Ndindabahizi. There was Éliezer Niyitegeka, N-I-Y-I-T-E-G-E-K-A, Niyitegeka.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is that it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Those are the names I mentioned.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Witness. Let us now speak of the conversation that you alleged that you had with Ndindabahizi in during 1994. I am not going to say where the conversation took place. I think that we might deal with that subsequently. Before the conversation took place, didn't the bourgmestre of your commune already warn you?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, this was something that took place in closed session yesterday, and I think that we will easily get into matters where the questions and answers will be so intertwined that it may become a little bit risky. And in view of the decision we took about that particular meeting yesterday, I think this is the time to close the session. It's logical. It's just the same regime we operated under last time we discussed this issue. So we have tried to keep this session open as far as possible, because we always prefer to keep transparency and openness, but when it comes to protecting the identity of the witness, we have also to be careful, and now we have reached a point where I am afraid we have to make the ruling that the public is kindly asked to leave the public gallery, and we will continue then in a closed session. Could we indicate approximately, Defence counsel, how much time you envisage for the rest of your cross-examination so that the public would know when to come back again, approximately?MR. BESNIER:It's difficult, Mr. President. I have taken 45 minutes so far, and I believe that I will only need a further 30 minutes to complete my cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, that's noted, and there will be possibly a re-examination.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 12 to 32] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, would I be correct in saying that you gave a statement to investigators from the ICTR in October 2000? Do you recall doing that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, I remember that. I remember that I made a statement.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I also be correct in saying, Mr. Witness, that on the 30th of April 1997 you testified as Witness M for mother in the trial against Clement, Dr Clement Kayishema at this Tribunal?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, I remember that also.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, would I be correct in saying that on the 6th of April, on or about the 6th or 7th of April, you and other members of your family became aware of the death of the Rwandan president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: It was the 6th, not the 4th.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's correct. And would I also be correct in saying that following the news of the president's death, you and other members of your family left your home to seek refuge elsewhere in Kibuye préfecture?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct; we went to seek refuge elsewhere.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did there come a time, Mr. Witness, during the month of April 1994, when you and other members of your family sought refuge at the location known as the Kibuye stadium or the Gatwaro stadium in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Yes, that's where we were.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall what date you arrived at the Gatwaro stadium in Kibuye with your family?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: It should have been the 13th of April 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And did you and other members of your family remain at Gatwaro stadium throughout the month of April or did there come a time when you left that location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: My two children and my wife went to ************ home on that day, but for the rest of the refugees, including myself, we remained at the stadium.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And did there come a time, Mr. Witness, when the stadium was attacked and, if so, can you help me with the date, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The stadium was attacked on the 18th.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And can you tell the Court how you survived the attack at the stadium on the 18th, as you put it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Mr. President, Your Honours, the circumstances under which I survived were the following: It was at about 1 p.m. the attackers came, they started throwing grenades into the stadium, they shot at the stadium. I tried to hide in a latrine in the lower part of the stadium. I remained there until about 6 p.m. It was at that time that I was able to leave to go to the forest. And when I reached in front of the stadium, I met a policeman whom I knew. I had met him at ********** house. I went towards him. I thought that******* had sent him to come and fetch me, and I asked him to take me back to *****home. He agreed to do so, and that's how I survived the killings. Thank you.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Mr. President, the witness is speaking rather fast. We would be grateful if you were to ask him to slow down.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If you could speak a little bit more slowly, Mr. Witness, that would assist the interpreters.

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: Very well, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, how long did the attack last at the stadium in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: The attack ended at about 5:40, and in the 20 minutes that followed, I left the stadium.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you testified earlier the attack started about one o'clock in the afternoon, did you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS GKH:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, Your Honour, I am really in your hands as to how to proceed with this witness. There is very little that I can build up -- upon without having -- I don't want to emphasise the situation, so that I don't draw further attention to it, but there is a problem in that regard.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Having listened to the way this witness responds to the questions, it seems to me that it's a risky course of action to remain in open session. So, unfortunately to the public, I think we have to close because of the protection of the witness, because we wanted to stay in open, but it's developing in a way which could be harmful. So let's now move again into closed session.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 35 to 66] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

div.head: 3 SEPTEMBER 20031400HCONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Mr. Nouhou M. DialloMs. Marianne Ben SalimoMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaMr. Peter TafahFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi:Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Ms. Gifty C. HardingMs. Judith BaverstockMs. Trish GreigMs. Regina LimulaMr. Petrus ChijariraMs. Diane Hermann

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Court is in session.Good afternoon, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and you will be referred to by your pseudonym, CTK, in these proceedings. When asked questions, you must be careful not to reveal your identity, and if any of the answers you are about to give could disclose your identity, then you must alert the Chamber so that we may proceed in a way to avoid it. You have to tell the truth, and the registry will now take your solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Raise your right hand and say after me:

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness CTK in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Now, Madam Witness, we know that there may be a need for you to take a break, depending on circumstances, but we will start with your testimony now, and you will first be asked questions by the Prosecution. Do you have a document in front of you, madam?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Is that your signature at the bottom of that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, it is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Does that imply that the information in that document, which is in English language, but that information was given by you and that it is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Thank you very much. That will then be --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I also wish to thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: P5, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, P5, under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed, Prosecution.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours. Before I ask the witness to give her testimony, she has expressed security concerns. She wishes to address you before she gives her testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Yes, is there anything you want to tell the Court, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Please do.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: We were in a certain place, and Mr. *********************** asked me whether I was going to come to testify in the Ndindabahizi case. I said I didn't know. He asked me my name - my surname, and he said he had seen my family name, and he told me that he had seen a list of people who were going to testify in the Ndindabahizi trial and my name was on that list.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Could you repeat the name of the person who told you that, please?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Would you be so kind as to spell that name, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, or maybe could you give a pen so that I can write it down?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: His name is ************************. Is that your handwriting, madam?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Then we have the spelling on record. Who is this person you have just referred to, madam?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It's a person who came to speak to me to tell me that he had seen my name on the list of witnesses who were going to testify in the Ndindabahizi trial.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Thank you. Now we may revert to this at the end of your testimony, but now we would prefer to hear the testimony first. Rest assured, madam, that we will come back to this issue. Is that clear?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I have understood.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Could you only indicate when is it you had this conversation with this person Manirunva? When was it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I do not remember the date, but it was in August.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Prosecutor.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

div.stage: WITNESS CTKfirst having been duly sworntestified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, in April 1994, were you living with your parents of Gitesi commune?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I was living with my parents.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Following the death of the President of the Republic on the 6th of April, could you briefly tell us what the security situation was in your secteur?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There were political parties and rallies were held regularly, and the killings started on the 12th. The conseiller held a meeting to stop Hutu from killing Tutsis, and they refused; they threw stones at him; and we fled on the 13th. My mother was killed, and I fled. I left the secteur. I went into Kayenzi secteur, and I remained in the house of one resident of that secteur. Three weeks later I left the secteur to go and hide in the bush. I spent two weeks there, and I saw vehicles, a car and a Daihatsu on the road. When these two vehicles came to the roadblock, they stopped --

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Witness, let us have your testimony in pieces, right? Now, you say that after the 12th, after your mother was killed, you fled and hid in a house of a named person. Would you tell us the name of the person in whose house you went to hide, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I do not think I can mention the name of that person because that person is known to many people.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: All right. Could you just tell us whether he was a Hutu or a Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He was Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: From that person's residence, where did you go?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I continued to wander around and I came to a place known as Fayer, spelt: F-A-Y-E-R

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us where Fayer is?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: In Kayenzi secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And could you tell us approximately the time you reached Fayer in Kayenzi secteur?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It is in the same secteur; the distance is not that great.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: All right. Could you tell us when you reached this place Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was in May.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And could you help us, please? What part of May? Was it the beginning of May, the middle of May or towards the end of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was in the beginning of May. I was quite close to that place, But I was still in that same location at the end of May -- in the month of May.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, could you tell us what you observed while you were at Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I saw a vehicle and a Daihatsu which were coming; the vehicle was black and the Daihatsu was green.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell us what time it was that you observed these two vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I was about 1 p.m., but I didn't have a watch, I am only giving you an estimate.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, thank you, Madam Witness. Could you not tell us what you observed when these two vehicles came to where you were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Three people came out these vehicles. There was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, and on the Daihatsu there were machetes, and there are were also people in the Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: From which direction did the vehicles come from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: The vehicles were coming from Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You have described several people who came out of those vehicles. Could you tell us which people came from which vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There were three people into the car and they were armed, and in the Daihatsu there were also three people, Interahamwe, who were armed with firearms.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You testified, Madam Witness, that one of the people who came from those vehicles wasMr. Ndindabahizi. From which vehicle did he come? Did he disembark from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He was in the car.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did you observe him driving that vehicle or he was one of the passengers in that vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He had a driver.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell us of those three people in that vehicle whether any of them were armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, they were armed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: All of them or some of them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: All the occupants of the vehicle were armed except Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, when the vehicles reached the place where they stopped, how far away were you from them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I didn't measure the distance, but I think the distance was about 5 metres, because I was in a place which was above the road and they were on the road; the vehicles had stopped on the road.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Was there anything significant at that particular place where the cars had stopped? Was there any activities that were going on?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There was a roadblock; people were stopped, and they were asked to show their identity cards.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Madam Witness, after the two vehicles had stopped, did you observe anything? Did you hear anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Emmanuel Ndindabahizi spoke to the people who were at the roadblock, asking them whether they had finished killing the Tutsis, and they answered: "We spared the women who -- Tutsi women who were married to Hutu men and their children." And he ordered them to get into vehicle -- vehicles, to go and kill them.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I didn't understand the last part of your question (sic). You say he ordered them to do what?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He ordered them to get into the Daihatsu and take the machetes that were on the Daihatsu and to kill the Tutsi women who were married to Hutus and children whose fathers were Hutu and mothers were Tutsi. So they got into the vehicle; they took the machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you observe how many machetes -- how many weapons or what type of weapons were off-loaded from that vehicle -- from the Daihatsu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There were only machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell us how many machetes you saw?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There were many machetes. I don't know how many there were.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: After that speech and the off-loading of the weapons, what else did you observe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: They continued on their way, and I remained in that place for some time, then I went towards the Nyabahanga River. After that I went to look for some food. I met people who were going to harvest sorghum. One person threatened to cut me with a spear, and I gave him money. I went back to Nyabahanga and I heard noises of a plane. And when I got to Nyabahanga, I asked what was happening with these planes -- the aircraft, and I was told that it was the French who were coming, and that was when the war ended.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, the people who were manning the roadblock at Fayer, do you know any of them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you shed some more light, Madam Witness. How far is it from Fayer to Nyabahanga Bridge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It's a distance of about 1kilometre.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Is it correct to say that FAYE and Nyabahanga are between Mabanza and Gitesi town; is that a correct statement?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, you have told us that in May l994, you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi at Fayer Bridge distributing arms. Had you known Mr. Ndindabahizi before May l994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us where you knew him and how?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He would come to his home and to a centre which was quite close to his parents' home.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, I think you can mention that centre without any problems.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was Gitaka centre in Gitesi commune -- Gitesi secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So, when was it that you saw him come to this place?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Let's go to 1990. How often did you see him in 1990 at Gitaka centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Every year I would see him only once.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: In 1990, under what circumstance did you see him at Gitaka centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There was nothing special. He had come to visit his parents and he went to that centre.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did you know where his parents lived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us how far it was from Gitaka centre to their house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: About 1 kilometre.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know the names of his parents?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes. His father is known as Hanyumbwa, and his mother is Nyirabarukwa.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: To your knowledge, are his parents still alive?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, they died before the war.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, in 1990 when you saw him at Gitaka centre, how did he come there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: When I saw him, he was on foot. He was standing at the centre in the company of other people.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you say whether he was doing anything that you noticed or you saw him do, or say anything that you heard him say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He was speaking with those people, but I do not know what they were talking about.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what were you doing at that time at that particular centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I came to the market.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When again did you say you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi in his secteur?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Okay, let's go to 1991. Where did you see him at the Gitaka centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: We met on the way on the road. He was being accompanied.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you help us? What was he doing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: For how long did you observe him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Are you referring to the first time or the second time? About 20 minutes only.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The first time or the second time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: This is the first time, because he was standing. On the second occasion it was for about ten minutes, because he was walking and I was also walking.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: And the location of this second occasion was at this location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: We met on the road. I was coming from the centre, and they were coming from there.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And on what other occasion did you see -- in which other year did you see Mr. Ndindabahizi after that second occasion?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Where were you? Can you tell us where you saw him this time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I saw him at Gitaka. I was passing through and I was coming from prayers.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us for how long you observed him this time in 1992?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: About 30 minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, on all the occasions you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi at Gitaka centre, were all these on one particular day or it was on different days of the week?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: What does that question mean?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What time I mean, Your Honour, is whether she saw him on Mondays or Tuesdays or Sundays.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Did you see him on the same week days these three years or on different week days?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: On different days.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, could you tell us what Mr. Ndindabahizi was doing in 1990, 1991 to 1992, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Did you know his profession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Did you know where he lived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: They used to say that he lived in Kigali, but I have never been in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Madam Witness, have you been to Fayer after May '94.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Are you referring to the period after May?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct. After May l994, have you had occasion to visit the Fayer trading centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: After the war?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us when you went there and why?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I went there on many occasions because it was on my way, but on other occasions I went there in the company of other people.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Was there a time when you went to Fayer with officers of this Tribunal, the ICTR?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us when, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: In 2001, but I don't recall the month.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell the Tribunal the purpose of your visit that year to that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was to show them where the roadblock was erected and where the vehicles were parked.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you recall the person you went with to show him those places?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When you reached the place, did you disembark from the car or how did you show him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: The vehicle slowed down and I showed them the position of the vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, when you went there in the year 2001, can you tell us what topographical differences you observed between then and 1994, conditions of the road, whether -- the vegetation and that kind of thing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, there were changes. The trees that were there had been cut off, buildings had been erected and there was a tarred road that didn't exist before then.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: This is all I have from this witness, Your Honour. Thank you, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What was the person you think is Mr. Ndindabahizi dressed in when you saw him in May, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He was wearing black clothes, a pair of trousers and a shirt.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: How could you describe this person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Are you referring to Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He was a very big person, with a big head and long ears with a flat nose.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Is he present in the Court today? Do you see him in the Court today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, he is in the courtroom.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Could you tell us where he is sitting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Since I hadn't seen him -- I have not seen him for a very long time, and let me recall that I was very young at the time, but I think it is the person wearing a white shirt and a tie.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Let the record reflect, Your Honour, that the witness has identified Mr. Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT.
sp.p: I am afraid we cannot let the record reflect that, Mr. Kapaya. Are you pursuing this?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. Then you have to do the homework.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, can you tell us where the person you say is Mr. Ndindabahizi is seated? Could you stand up and show us; with leave of the Chamber.Just to facilitate your identification, could you please stand up and look around and tell us where he is seated?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I see him. He is there seated behind the white people. He is wearing a white shirt and a tie. But I must add that I haven't seen him for a long time. He is also wearing a black jacket.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, let the record now reflect that the witness has identified Mr. Ndindabahizi -- she has identified the Accused person.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What is the colour of his trousers, Madam Witness? What is the colour of his tie, for instance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He is wearing a black tie.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It is noted, Mr. Kapaya.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Marçais will conduct the cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Currently, in Arusha, you are living in a protected house, in a safe house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Alone or with other persons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There are other persons in that house.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: People with whom you could have formal or informal discussions?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I do have conversations with them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And in particularly (sic), are you able to discuss the reasons for your trip to Arusha, matters relating to this case, the Ndindabahizi case with them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you share your experiences regarding the various -- your various testimonies?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Which persons are you talking about, Counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You did say a while ago that you were not alone in that house, and I wanted to be specific. You said there were people you could discuss with. Are they your compatriots?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: These are officers of this Tribunal.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
