sp.p: It appears you also said that these include witnesses in this case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I am talking about officers of the court.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Let me just finish. But you live in the same house as they?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, this is something that may disclose the location of the witnesses in this Tribunal. They are supposed to be staying in places which are referred to as safe locations. So I --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are quite right in raising the issue that we want to protect the witnesses, and also that, of course, we do not want to mention where the safe houses are, you are quite right in that. But it seems to be quite difficult to imagine that the question, whether there are other witnesses living in a safe house, that that can disclose anything which is sensitive. Would you agree with me?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Well, at least --

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I can only repeat the question of the President. The location is immaterial, but are there other witnesses living in the same house where the witness is living or in the neighbourhood where Madam Witness is currently living in Arusha, that is my question.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And if that's your objection, Mr. Kapaya, it is overruled. Answer the question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, there are other witnesses in the same house.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, are you able to tell me how it is that your first testimony on this case is taking place seven years after -- it's seven years later? You told the investigators that it is so important, why did you have to wait for so long before coming to testify?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Questions were put to me on events that I knew about, and I gave my testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, I understand. But did you not take the risk seven years after the facts? Because if I look at your date of birth, you were about 16 or 17 years at the time of the events, and you revealed them when you were 24 years old. I'm not doubting that your memory is no (sic) good, but why did you have to wait for so long? Madam, don't be afraid of showing your face.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can the curtains be drawn?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Fully, so that we can see the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, the question is the following: You -- are you listening?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, I am listening.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, the question is the following: This -- you were in touch with the investigators of the Tribunal in 2001. How is it that your information was given to them in 2001, more -- about seven years after the events?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, maybe that question should be clarified because it is our office that goes looking for witnesses.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Kapaya --

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I am sorry, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: -- that was improper.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I am sorry, Your Honour. MR. PRESIDENT: That was - please sit down.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence counsel, we are now waiting for the questions -- for the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, let me repeat my question, and I'll wish this time around that it is the witness who answers. Why is it that, given the fact that you have such an excellent memory, that you had to wait for seven years? And let me -- and you waited for the Prosecutors to come and look for you. One would have expected, one would have expected that this information would have been brought to the notice of the police. How come that you waited for seven years to make a statement on such serious events as you are making today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I did not do so because nobody interviewed me on them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, are you a member of a victims association?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I am not a member of any victims association.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And, Madam Witness, one last question: Have you ever entered the premises or had you ever entered the premises of this Tribunal before this afternoon?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You have never entered a courtroom?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I have been to a courtroom on another occasion, which is not today.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But a courtroom of this Tribunal or another judicial system?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It's a courtroom of the same Arusha Tribunal.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Then you have -- you had earlier entered the premises of this Tribunal?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I had already seen this courtroom, but it is today that I have entered to give my testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The Courts will evaluate that answer. Let's move on. There are two problems in this case, and we would like to know the conditions under which you know or did not know the first time you met in 1990, 1991, 1992, Mr. Ndindabahizi to your knowledge. If I compare your testimony of today and the one you made to the investigators, are you able to clarify where Mr. Ndindabahizi lived when you were born and grew up?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I did not know where Mr. Ndindabahizi lived, but I knew his parents' house.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. In your statement to the investigators, you said that Ndindabahizi lived in Kigali from January until '94, and do you know approximately what date where Ndindabahizi lived without you knowing him, and can you be more specific today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I knew that Ndindabahizi lived in Kigali, but these are things that other people told me. People told me he lived in Kigali, but I did not know exactly where in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I am sorry, that is not my question. My question was not to know his address in Kigali, which you do not know. My question is to know since when, to your knowledge, was he living in Kigali?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: When I got to know Mr. Ndindabahizi, he lived in Kigali. I was told that he lived in Kigali, but I did not see the locality in which he lived in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. Let's then go to a number of statements. You said that, "I know Ndindabahizi because we both hail from Gitesi. I got to know that he lived in Kigali up to the beginning of the genocide." As far as the circumstances that the Prosecutor referred to, you, before 1994, saw Ndindabahizi only three times?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Once in 1990, once in 1991 and once in 1992?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You said that on one occasion you saw him because he was visiting his parents?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In the family house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I believe the Court will be very indulgent with me because this is my baptism of fire. I might make some errors regarding the form. I am very sorry about that.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: When you met him, was he somebody you met together with other persons or you met him one on one? Was he introduced to you or was -- did somebody tell you that this is Mr. Ndindabahizi or the son of Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Ndindabahizi was pointed out to me. I was told that he is the son of so and so, so that he's the son of Hanyigwa, and he lives in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So such that you never spoke to him, you did not have any personal conversation with him, just that once or twice somebody pointed him out to you as Mr. Ndindabahizi, the son of so and so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that is how it happened.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But you yourself, you never approached him to ask him whether, "You are indeed Mr. Ndindabahizi, I am glad to meet you"? Did you do any such thing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I could not. I couldn't put such a question to him because I wasn't in the same age group as himself. I don't know how he would have reacted to such a question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So do you know what his profession was? Do you know what he was doing in Kigali?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You didn't know -- not his parents, but did you know his wife, his children? Do you know whether he had -- he was married, do you know whether he had children and, if so, how many?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I did not know his family.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And you say by that that you know someone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I know him individually.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Another small point on which I would like to ask you some questions, Madam Witness: In your written statement and also in your testimony today, you said that until the 12th of April, there was only one disquieting speech on the 7th of April 19 -- no, the 12th of April 1994, I beg your pardon. That's some days after the killing of the president, but that Mugemagango, at the end of his speech, was stoned, but until then there had not been any looting nor any killings. Can you confirm that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that was my testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But you didn't attend that meeting yourself, did you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So this Mr. Mugemagango was appealing for calm. So who told you about what happened at that meeting and this call for peace or calm?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It's people who attended the meeting who reported that to me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You say also that when you left - that at the end of the meeting, looting and killings began. How did you get to know about that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I was a witness of those activities. I would see people destroying houses and burning them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You situate the beginning of the killings after the 12th of April, is that correct, and --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, for -- as far as our secteur was concerned.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. And I refer to the killings. You say people started killing Tutsis.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No. It was rather on that date that the killings of the Tutsis in our secteur began.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Okay, very well. So at the beginning -- the beginning of these killings was on the 12th of April, and what is referred to as the killings is that Tutsis were being killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct. Yes, all the Tutsis who were found were killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Without any discrimination of age, children, men, women, all Tutsis were killed; is that what you are saying?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you testified that at that time, knowing the danger that you were running, you were risking, you left together with your mother. I am sorry, I am referring to your statement. You went to hide with your mother in two houses, and you didn't say whether they were distinct one from the other. And then furthermore, a little while later you got to know that your mother was killed in that house. Why did you not hide together with your mother?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was in order to avoid our -- us being killed at the same time.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In your written statement, when you say that the houses were not far from one another, in your opinion, how far away were they from each other, those two houses?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: About 40 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: During that attack and the killing of your mother, you didn't hear anything? You didn't hear anything, and you were only informed about it later? You didn't hear any cries, you didn't hear any noises accompanying that attack on your mother; did you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I didn't hear any noise. Earlier -- I came to that house in the evening after my mother was killed, and her body was shown to me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. Then you fled into Kibuye secteur, you went and sought refuge at (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) house. You didn't give his family name, but you were able to do so for his wife. I believe it is (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal).

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, I'll request that that certain name be deleted from the record --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: -- because the witness has said this is a name that is familiar in the area and --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, we agree that this name will be struck from the transcripts and deleted from the video system.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I do apologise. I can therefore not ask you any more specifics. Can I mention the first name, (By order of the court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal). Is it a family name? I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence counsel, you will remember that the witness asked specifically not to mention that name, and we have respected that, so now we strike it from the record for the second time. Now, we do not want that name mentioned, but you will easily be able to reformulate the question and achieve what you want.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Alternatively, Your Honour, he can use the writing method. He can write on a piece of paper, show it to the witness, and then ask the question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: No, no, I will not ask any more questions on that.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But on the first name, one of these two people, it would seem it's the woman -- I can use the writing method, but the second person mentioned, the second person mentioned, it seems that that was your baptismal witness; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you explain to me for my own personal information what is a baptismal witness, because I know that in the Catholic religion, you know that there are godparents and in marriages there are witnesses, but for baptismal, I do not know what you are referring to. What is it exactly that you mean by that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, this is my godmother.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I gave you the opportunity to make that correction. I am sure you are happy about that. You state a little later that you hid for some weeks in their house, and then other Interahamwe, led by Sinishunga, came to the house looking for Tutsis. So who is this Sinishunga? The name is not known to us. Who is this person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: This was a citizen of that area who was leading the attacks.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: If I were to put your testimony together with your written statement before the investigators, I place the scene, which makes Ndindabahizi appear in conditions which we will need to have explanations for, I place that in the middle of the month of May. Would I be correct in doing so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mid-May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: In other words, the end of the month of May.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: That's not quite correct, because if I look at what you say, this is what you stated. You stated -- I am trying to find the place -- that you hid for two -- for three weeks in the house of the persons whose names I should not mention, and then you say you spent three weeks, "And during that period I was being told that the Tutsi population had been exterminated," and you then spent two weeks hiding in bushes. And if we were to take that -- those periods of time, this takes us to the middle of May. Wasn't it the middle of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It's towards the end of May.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. After leaving the house of your godmother, you were chased by Sinishunga and his acolytes. You fled and you went to hide in bushes. That was a rather tragic situation, and everybody is aware of that. How were you able to survive, because this was practically one month? How were you able to survive for a whole month in the bushes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: When I left the place known as Fayer, I went to settle along Nyabahanga river. I left that place to look for food. When I came back, I met a group of people who were going to cultivate sorghum. One of these people came to me and attacked me with a knife on the head, but that person only wounded me. He did not kill me. I gave him a note of 5,000 shillings which I had with me. I went towards Nyabahanga River, and that's where I saw aircraft flying overhead. And I asked people why the planes were there, because I thought they were looking for Tutsis. I went back to the person who had provided me shelter. They opened the door. I told them, "I see there are planes circling in the sky. Why are they there?" And those people told me that they were French planes which had come to put an end to the war, and they asked me remain in the house because, they said, the war was coming to an end.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, is that the incident that you place at the end of May?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, do you hear us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I am listening.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, first of all, when you are asked questions, please listen carefully. The question posed by counsel some time ago was simply, "How did you survive hiding in the bushes?" He didn't want you to repeat all your evidence. But leaving that aside, now the question is this episode about giving a person a note and seeing the planes. When was that? Was it before or after the alleged episode with Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was after seeing Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And when was it? When did you make those observations about the planes and the person hurting you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I mentioned this in my written statement.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, we know, but we are asking you now orally. Do you remember now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I don't remember, but it was towards the end of the war. It was in June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: By your leave, Mr. President, I want to come back to this incident, and I want to go again back to the date for the last time because it's got a lot of inconsistencies.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So Madam Witness, I want to go back to the instance during which you claim you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi and the circumstances you spoke of a moment ago. So I want to come back to this one last time to remind you that in one instance you said that it was in the middle of May, and today you are saying that it was at the end of May. Now, can you remember exactly when it was that you saw this incident?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I object to that recitation. The witness has said it was towards the end of May, and at no time had she said that it was in the middle of May. Counsel is misleading the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, in fact, my note is that at the beginning she gave a different indication of time, but I don't want to recall that now. So Madam Witness, the point now is, there is some unclarity or lack of clarity as to exactly when this episode with Mr. Ndindabahizi took place. Now, you have told us it was in May. When in May, beginning, middle or end? Can you help us with that, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was at the end of May.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Therefore, that means that you spent a month in the bushes in Fayer, and I am repeating the question which you didn't answer: How did you survive? What did you drink, what did you eat during this whole month? Because if we were to look at your answer, this is a question which arises.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I went to dig in the fields. I went to dig up sweet potatoes, and I was eating wild fruits, and I was drinking the water from the Nyabahanga River.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And during this whole time you were hiding in the same bush close to the roadblock at Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I was on the shores of Nyabahanga River.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well, we'll come back to that incident. Where were you sleeping during that whole month?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: But I was sleeping in the bushes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So this is an area which is densely populated, as we were told by the investigator. Were you not afraid of being found out?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: What area are you talking about?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: We are dealing with the area near the roadblock near Fayer, and you said you lived there for a month.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I beg your pardon? When I was drinking the water from the Nyabahanga River, I was living on the banks of that river and not close to the place which was referred to as Fayer.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Is it an area which is highly populated or densely populated?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Which place are you referring to, which area?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, the secteur, the cellule about which we are speaking, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Are you referring to the area near the place called Fayer or are talking about the banks of the river, Nyabahanga River?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Wherever you were when you were hiding.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: But I am asking you whether you are referring to the area known as Fayer or are you referring to Nyabahanga?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, we will come to Nyabahanga a little bit later. Maybe it's a good idea to have known what was happening in the various areas, but we have to follow it all chronologically. I think we are speaking about the incident which you have referred to on the banks of Nyabahanga River. I am speaking about the time where, for about a month, you were hiding in bushes close to the roadblock at Fayer.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, but I didn't spend a whole month in that place.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How much time, then, did you spend there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Two weeks.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So we will have problems of chronology, chronology, which don't only contradict one another, but they are also inconsistent. You say you spent three weeks at your godmother's house. Unfortunately, I have to look at this chronology myself. After the -- on the 13th of April, you went to your godmother and you spent three weeks there. That takes us to the 4th of May. And you say, "I spent three weeks in my godmother's house." That takes you to the end of April. And then three weeks you went to the place which was close to the Fayer roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And I am saying, Mr. President, that there is inconsistency, and I want to determine where it arises from.MR. KAPAYA:Your Honour -MR. MARÇAIS:The witness has just said that she had spent two weeks there and not one month.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is a need to simplify the proceedings now. Defence counsel, you are using too many words and you are mixing the questions with argumentation, and that is not simplifying your communication with this witness. So it's important, for ease of communication, just to concentrate on the brief questions and receive, hopefully, the brief answers. And then you will later address the Bench on alleged inconsistencies. So if you would assist us in this way, then, as I say, it will become more efficient.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I shall repeat my question. I had thought I heard the witness said that she only remained for two weeks there. I am reading and I can hear, "I spent three weeks at my godmother's house and then two weeks in the bushes near the Fayer roadblock." This seems to take us to the middle of May, but the witness has just mentioned the end of May, and I want to have for clarification because this seems to me to be inconsistency.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: May I make a comment, Your Honour? The witness is talking of a period of "about". She is not saying exactly three weeks, she is not saying exactly two weeks. She is saying about two weeks, about three weeks. I think counsel should take this into account when posing his question to the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But in fact we have now, we have now been circling around this issue, beginning of May, middle of May and end of May, for quite some time. I think we know the witness's answer. The answer is the end of May. She has been asked many times now. The question, then, is whether that is inconsistent with a calculation based on the calendar, and that is something you will come back to later. You have made your point. You have made your point that there is an inconsistency, in your view.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It's the last answer given by the witness in which she said, when I asked her how she survived for a whole month, she said, "No, not a month, a fortnight." And I said at that time that if we were to do the arithmetic and look at the statement, this brings us to the middle of May. That was a mere observation I was making.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's braking in open doors. That we have understood. So what is the next question?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: When we read about your presence near the roadblock near Fayer, you state that you were about 5 metres away from the roadblock. A question arises here, Madam Witness: You are in great danger, great danger of death. Would it have been reasonable for you to be 5 metres away, even only just to hear everything, without considering the risk -- without considering the danger that you were risking?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you hear the question, madam? The question is, if you were afraid, why only be five metres away?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: These people were on the road, and I was above the road. There was a kind of mound, and I was overlooking the road. These people could not see me, and they didn't know I was there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You said two vehicles arrive at the roadblock manned by the Hutus and that there you recognised, from behind the bushes, Ndindabahizi that you had seen on about two occasions earlier. You -- he was not introduced to you. And you said, "I saw Ndindabahizi speaking to the Tutsi."

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: But counsel corrects that to say that, "He spoke to the people who were manning the roadblock."

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And the persons manning the roadblock could not see you, but they could hear you moving since you were close by.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: They could not see me. There were some eucalyptus trees, and I was uphill from them and they could not see me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The person that you claim is called Ndindabahizi allegedly said, "Have you finished with the Tutsis?" Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: He posed the following question: "Have you finished killing the Tutsi?"

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Apart from this scene, have you ever witnessed any other massacre scenes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You never went to Bisesero?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You give two different answers but quite similar. That was -- with regard to the answer that was given to Ndindabahizi, "They did not kill everybody. They did not kill women and children"; is that correct? Let me use your expression again. "They did not kill women and children of Hutu mothers." Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I said, and I repeat, he posed the following question: "Have you finished killing the Tutsis?" And they said, "Yes, we only -- we did not kill women who -- Tutsis who had married Hutus."

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So they did not kill Tutsi women if they had a Hutu husband; that is correct? But you said a while ago that on the 12th of April, to your knowledge, they had killed all the Tutsis.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, I did not say that they killed all the Tutsis. I said they were in the process of killing the Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, it appears -- I've been asked not to mix the questions and the arguments, but if you -- the issue was on a general question on men, women, and children. But on the 13th April, you did not indicate that they did not kill some category of people.When you said that they did not kill persons this day, who is it referring to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I don't follow your question, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Let me quote, madam. Ndindabahizi put the question, "Have you finished with the Tutsi? And they answered him." I don't know who the "they" are. Who are these "they"? Who are these "they" referring to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: The persons who answered his question were the Hutus who were at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So "they" referred to the Hutus who were at the roadblock. And the other "they," who does it refer to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: The Kayenzi secteur, Tutsi women who had Hutu husbands who were not killed, and as well as children who had Hutu mothers but Tutsi husbands -- Tutsi fathers, I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Let's continue with your testimony. Ndindabahizi came in a vehicle, in a small pick-up with about five persons -- Mr. Ndindabahizi was not driving his car himself -- in a green pick-up; is that correct? Witness, did you say 400 persons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No. Ndindabahizi came with four or five persons. His car was driven by a driver, and it was a small pick-up with four or five persons.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So that makes it four -- that makes it five or six persons; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I did say that there were three persons in the -- in Ndindabahizi's car, two persons plus Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Your Honour, can counsel wait for the interpretation.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The break -- please remember the pause between the answer and the question so we can have time for translation, for interpretation, please.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In a pick-up, a while ago you said that there were other persons, two, three persons in Ndindabahizi's private vehicle who came to the roadblock; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: No, that's not what I said.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I thought I understood you to say, and correct me if I'm wrong, that there was a roadblock manned by Hutus, and that the two vehicles we are referring to come to the roadblock under the conditions that you recounted. Did the roadblock already exist with the Hutus manning it when the vehicles, that you referred to as Ndindabahizi's vehicle and the pick-up --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: The roadblock was there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And manned by about how many persons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: There were many. About 15, but I didn't count them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were they -- or, who were these people? Did you know them? Were they holding their famous machete? How were they?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Well, I did not know them. I didn't live in that locality. They were wielding machetes and clubs, and that is clubs that we call ntampongano.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you saw the person that you call Ndindabahizi arrive together with another vehicle on a roadblock kept by 15 persons, about 15 persons wielding machetes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You said that in a green pick-up -- when you saw the green pick-up approaching --

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, the witness needs to tend to her baby.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Madam Witness, I think it is good if you could leave the courtroom for a moment and look after your baby, but I don't think we should close the session for today, we just take a little break. So shall we say about ten minutes? What is your view on the situation, Mr. Kapaya? What is the need?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Ten minutes would do, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, yes. Let's do that, then.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I shall defer to the wisdom of the Court. I have no question (sic).

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So we adjourn for ten minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed. And if we could finish this witness by seven, I think that would be preferable.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, I'll do that. I'll ask three quick questions.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It seems that there's a small confusion, Madam Witness. A moment ago I was speaking to you about where you were hiding in a mound or close to the roadblock near Fayer, and you say you were drinking water from the river. I think you may have confused this with the time when you had fled to the place close to Nyabahanga river.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, I did make that mistake. At the time when I was in that place, I didn't have anything to drink or eat. Sometimes I could have had bananas given to me by people who, like me, were fleeing.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I'm now coming to the last episode -- no, let me go back to the episode following the Ndindabahizi. At the roadblock you were saying Ndindabahizi was speaking to the Hutus, you are referring, undoubtedly, to the Hutus who were manning the roadblock, unless I am mistaken?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And it was to those Hutus that he was saying, "Take up the machetes and kill them all"?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. Now, on the episode dealing with the Nyabahanga river, you said in your written statement that you met a Hutu carrying a spear who struck you and wounded you, and today you talked about a Hutu who threatened you, so which is the truth? Which is which?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I said that he struck me with his spear on the head and that I gave him 5,000 Rwandan francs.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were they Rwandan francs?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You had kept this 5,000 francs throughout this very difficult time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you recall the colour of that note?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: It was a note of 5,000 Rwandan francs such as was used before the war.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I don't remember.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. President, I'm done.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: One question, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness --

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I don't see the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You were asked by counsel whether, apart from the Accused person and his parents, do you know any other relatives, blood relatives of the Accused person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I would see them as they went by, but I didn't know their names.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: That's fine, Your Honour. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, the persons manning the roadblock, I understood that you told us that before Mr. Ndindabahizi arrived, they were armed with machetes; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that's right.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, why would, then, Mr. Ndindabahizi give them machetes and give them the order, based on this provision of machetes, to go and kill Tutsi if they already had weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: But he had brought them the machetes. And some of these people did not have machetes, they only had clubs which are known as ntampongano.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So not all persons at the roadblocks had machetes, is that your testimony, before Mr. Ndindabahizi arrived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct. That's right.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. I have a question I think, rather, to the Prosecution, but the witness should be waiting in case we may need her.Now, this Fayer roadblock, in our bundle of documents which you produced as Prosecution Exhibit 2 there is a document which seems to be relevant to this episode, and this sketch seemed to have a link with that particular witness. Isn't that so, Mr. Kapaya?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yeah, that's right, Your Honour. Actually, that particular roadblock is referred to on page L0019875 of Exhibit P2, and sketch 3, sketch 3 on page L0019873.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Seven-eight?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Now, so sketch 3, and that coincides with the question to the investigators who mentioned the pseudonym of this witness in connection with sketch 3.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, the investigator (sic) went to show him where it was.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, so this -- where on the page L0019875 do we find this particular roadblock? Can you assist us with that?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: It's on R2, Your Honour. Sorry, R2, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: No, R2.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: R2 is the Fayer roadblock. R3 is the Nyabahanga river, Nyabahanga roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does this follow from the map itself?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, yes. It follows there on the right-hand side, "R2 roadblock, ref. sketch 3." That's the link, is it?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, yes. Okay, then, we have located that. And if you now compare this map L0019875 with the big map, with the bigger map, for instance, the map on the preceding page, would we find this on the same map in a more large scale?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, if we look closely, Your Honour, we can see it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, all right. If it's difficult to find right away, I still think it would be useful to make sure that we know exactly where the roadblock is. So if the parties could simply agree upon and, at a convenient moment, come back to the Bench and show us exactly on the big map where we are when we look at the small-scale map, that would be helpful.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yeah, we'll revert to Your Honour in due course.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Thank you very much, indeed.Madam Witness, your testimony has come to an end. We thank you very much for coming to the Tribunal and giving your evidence. We wish you a safe journey home and ask you kindly not to discuss your testimony with anyone.When it comes to the particular episode you mentioned, that you had been approached, that will be looked into in the appropriate forum. So we wish you a safe journey home. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CTK:
sp.p: I also wish to thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This was the last available witness, Prosecution, and I understand even that if we're short of witnesses, that is because one of the witnesses did not travel to Arusha from Kigali, in spite of the fact that you had asked that witness to come. Is that so, Mr. Phillips?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the reason why there is not the witness this time is because this was an unforeseen circumstance.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes. That's what they say. That's what they tell me. I have no way of verifying that.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It may well be as a direct result of the comments we've heard from witnesses this week, and that's a matter that I would address in due course. I have no way of verifying the circumstances that have led to this witness. As far as I'm aware, when we had a status conference, Your Honour was told that all was well.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, you did tell us, didn't you --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Not me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: -- in your e-mail of 1st of September that, "As you are already aware, this witness did not travel to Arusha last Friday"? And that was before the testimony started, wasn't it?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, I became aware of it on Friday.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. So in other words, I don't think there is a link between testimony given this week and the non-appearance of this witness because --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Well, the events that surround the testimony given this week happened before they came here, that's my point.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You're talking not about what happened in court.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You're talking about pre-trial issues.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. Well, we'll look into that. And this implies that when do we meet again, at 2:00 next Monday?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: On Monday, yes. Your Honour, there's a procedural matter that I need to address the Court on.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Before doing so, are we in a position now to indicate the order of the, say, five witnesses that have arrived in Arusha, or will you do that in 24 hours' time?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It would be as indicated, from number five down; in other words, five, six, seven, eight, nine, in that order.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. We have finished number one, two, three, and 18. So you are saying that it will be number five, six, seven onwards?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: In that sequence?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Now you have something you would like to raise.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes. It's a matter that troubles me very much.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour would -- is aware -- Your Honours are aware of the provisions of Rule 85, Rule 85 (B) in particular.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. We might excuse the witness?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, yes, she's been excused.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can we have the registry escort the witness out, please?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: -- you will now be escorted out of the courtroom because we are now addressing another matter which is not related to your testimony. Please, you have to draw the curtains, of course.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You referred to Rule 85, Mr. Phillips.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: 85 (B) in particular.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm interested in the provisions of that rule. And whilst I am mindful of the fact that Judges may at any stage -- Your Honours may at any stage put questions to witnesses whilst they're testifying in this courtroom, it has to be said on the record that such questions cannot be seen to compromise either the case of the Prosecution or, indeed, that of the Defence. Certainly that is not the idea behind Rule 85 (B). We're all officers of the court, and indeed, be us on the Bench or at the bar, my training suggests that we're all officers of the court. And as officers of the court, we have a duty to our clients, be you the Prosecution or the Defence, and in exercising that duty, we do it, at least my training tells me that we do it, with the utmost courtesy to the Bench and, perhaps, often expect that that courtesy be extended to us, be us the Prosecution or the Defence.Now, a situation arose this evening, Your Honour, which I find extremely regrettable, where my learned friend and colleague, a very senior member of the Tanzanian bar, was stopped and restrained and almost bullied from asking or objecting to a question which he felt was extremely pertinent and legitimate which -- the result of which may have ended up compromising the evidence of a Prosecution evidence.Now, the position is this: He makes an observation following a question from Your Honour, and he does it in good faith. He does it as a result of his duty, as an officer of this court, to protect that witness. He did so, being extremely courteous to the Bench. I would leave this courtroom this evening with the regrettable feeling that that courtesy may not have been extended to him as a result of the way Your Honour intervened and restrained him from asking that question, and I regret that. And I must say, as lead counsel representing the Prosecution, I regret that.I would also add that if I had a younger and more junior counsel assisting me today, the end result of which would have been such a lawyer may have been frightened out of his or her wits, unable to continue with the job that I have assigned him to do this evening, and that in itself would have compromised my case.I leave this courtroom this evening with a feeling that, unfortunately, somewhere along the line that courtesy, which I expect as Prosecution counsel, has not been extended to the Prosecution.I'm grateful for your attention.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much for drawing our attention to this issue, Mr. Phillips. I am now happy to make my contribution so that you will not leave the courtroom with that feeling; neither should Mr. Kapaya do so. What happened here was quite normally only the issue that there was, during a question by the Defence, an objection by the Prosecution. That is perfectly legitimate, and, as you just said, that is what any officer of the court is expected to do. What happened, however, was that that particular objection was formed in a way which could indicate the answer to that witness. Now, this happens on many occasions, and we all know that that is something that should be avoided.There was certainly no -- any intention to hurt anyone or to not express courtesy. And Mr. Kapaya and I, we have worked together in this courtroom for a long time and in many cases, and you know I have the utmost respect for Mr. Kapaya, and that respect is unchanged. And you will then note that after that particular episode where I had to stop him, because the objection was suggestive, that the cooperation in a very courteous manner continued, in my view, from both sides.So I do not think we should blow up this episode, and it's my absolute belief that we will continue, as we have done previously, to cooperate to the fullest extent. Thank you very much.Now, the Court is now adjourned to Monday at two o'clock.

div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Mr. John M. KiyeyeuMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaMr. Peter TafahFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi :Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Ms. Karen L. HolmMs. Verna ButlerMs. Donna M. LewisMs. Sithembiso MoyoMr. Haruna FarageMs. Judith Kapatamoyo

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon. The Court is in session. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This is Witness CGN?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's correct, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And you are a protected witness. We are in open session now, so when you are asked questions you must be careful not to reveal your identity.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You have to tell the truth and the registry will now administer the solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, please stand up, speak after me and raise your right hand.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness CGN in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, do you have a document in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there's a sheet of paper on which I see details concerning my identity.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature at the bottom of that page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, it is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you want this as Exhibit P --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: P6, I believe, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: P6, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P6 admitted, under seal)
WITNESS CGN,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, if you could look in my direction, this way. I'm going to ask you some questions in relation to your written statement that you gave to investigators from the ICTR. Do you understand that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I understand.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you recall how many times you met with investigators from the Office of the Prosecutor of this Tribunal?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I do recall.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you tell me how many times you met with such persons, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Twice.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Do you recall approximately when you met with those investigators, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I think that it was in the year 2001, but I do not remember the exact dates.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were both occasions in the year 2001, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Mr. Witness, do you know a man by the name Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you tell the Court how you know this man?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I knew him a long time ago, while he was still in school and I was a child. I was in primary school at the time. He was studying at the university, and we would meet sometimes during the holidays, as well as on other occasions. Subsequently, sometime after he finished his studies, I would see him at the Kibuye Trafipro -- I do not know whether he was working there or whether he was just passing by but I would see him in the building of the Trafipro, and I do not know whether he was carrying out any activities there. And then I would see him on the road. He was one of the great intellectuals of our region. We were saying that we were lucky to have someone in university because it was rare to have someone in university. So he was someone who was well known in our region and that's how I came to know him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you help us with the period, by that I mean the year that you saw him whilst he was at university? Can I start with that, first? Can you help us with that year, if you recall, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I'll give you an estimate because I do not remember the year very well. I believe it was between 1969 and 1971. I don't know whether he had finished his studies at the time or not.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And the period that you describe having seen him at Trafipro, can you also help me with that time frame, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I do not remember. It was at a time when one referred to as Trafipro in our country, in the 1980s or at least before 1980, when we had what we referred to as Trafipro in our country. I saw him but I do not remember the exact period of time. I didn't have any particular reason for me to remember the period of time during which I saw him. So, we had what were referred to as Trafipro cooperatives and it was during that period of time, when these Trafipro cooperatives existed, that I used to see him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I be correct in saying that the period when you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi at Trafipro was after the period when you saw him during his university days? Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is true, it was afterwards.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you know if Mr. Ndindabahizi belonged to any political party?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, he belonged to a political party.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know which political party Mr. Ndindabahizi belonged to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you tell the Court, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was the PSD party.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were you a member of the PSD party?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No. I did not belong to any political party.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How was it then that you became aware that the Accused belonged to the PSD party?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Some parties were represented in Kibuye, and in our commune of Gitesi and within our secteur and on Sundays the parties would have recruitment drive rallies. When they came it was said that he was living in Kigali; he came to see -- he came to see how the recruitment was being done amongst the people. I would see him at the stadium as we came back from mass and this would be on Sundays.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Roughly, how many times would you say you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi before April 1994, for instance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I think I saw him twice.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you, by your answer, mean that you saw him twice in your entire life from 1969 to 1994, or do you mean you saw him twice in relation to the political rallies?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was during the multiparty era between 1992 and 1993. It was during that period of time that I saw him twice; otherwise, I would see him earlier when he was walking around in Kibuye or if I came across him on the road as he was passing by.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So can you -- or are you able to give an approximate number of times that you might have seen Mr. Ndindabahizi since 1969 - '71, thereabout, until 1994, just roughly? Can you help us with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I would see him often, but I think I wouldn't have seen him for more than 10 or 11 occasions.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Turning to April 1994, Mr. Witness, would I be correct in saying that you heard of the news of the death of the president at some stage after the 7th of April, 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I also be correct in saying, Mr. Witness, that following some disturbances in your area of origin you fled to other locations within Kibuye préfecture during the month of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes. Yes, I fled elsewhere, that is true.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, during the month of April 1994, Mr. Witness, did you see a man known as Emmanuel Ndindabahizi at all and, if so, when did you see him and where?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I saw him in April in the hills close to Gitwa hill, to which we had fled. We had left our houses in order to go and flee, to seek refuge at the top of Gitwa hill, which was overlooking our houses. I saw him at that time and he was quite close to the place where I lived.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall a particular date or period when you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was between the 20th and the 26th of April, but the first time that I saw him was between the 20th and the 23rd or the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you say that you saw him whilst you were on a hill called Gitwa. Can you confirm to the Court whether or not Gitwa is in Gitesi commune, Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: That hill is in Gitesi commune.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Are you able, Mr. Witness, to describe to the Court the circumstances that led to you seeing Mr. Ndindabahizi at this time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I can do so.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Please do.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was between the 20th and the 24th. I do not remember the exact date, but two days later we were dispersed from that hill, but before that Ndindabahizi came and suddenly I saw a Daihatsu vehicle which was green. It was a type of vehicle which could use country roads, and it was this kind of vehicle that was used. On it were soldiers and people dressed in civilian clothing, and there was another white vehicle and the two vehicles stopped below a road -- below a woods on the road. The people who were in Gitwa could not see the vehicles because of the trees which were blocking their view, and there was also a mound, a kind of small hill, which made it impossible for them to see those vehicles.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you recall when you actually arrived in the area of Gitwa hill? Do you recall when you arrived there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I got there around the 14th. It was around that date that we were chased out of our houses; our houses were burnt down and the population -- the inhabitants went to seek refuge on that hill around the 14th.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You have just described seeing some vehicles arriving at Gitwa hill on or about the 20th -- between the 20th and 23rd of April. Now, can you tell me how many vehicles did you see on this day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: On that day I saw the vehicles; in other words, Ndindabahizi's vehicle and the Daihatsu vehicle and another one which came after it. In other words, there were three vehicles. There was a Hilux vehicle which was blue.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And apart from the Hilux vehicle which you describe as being blue, can you also help me with the colour of the other two vehicles, please; colours?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: The sedan was white and the Daihatsu was green.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In which of the three vehicles did you see Mr. Ndindabahizi, if at all?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I saw him inside the small, white vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And was Mr. Ndindabahizi alone in the small, white vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: At that time I was able to -- I was unable to know whether he was alone in his vehicle, but it was the vehicle he normally used. But at the time when we saw him, he wasn't in the vehicle. But when they left, he left together with a gendarme; in other words, we saw him getting into a vehicle -- the vehicle, and the gendarme also got into the vehicle together with him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What about the vehicle you describe as the green Daihatsu, what sort of vehicle was that, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was a large vehicle of the Daihatsu make and its colour was green.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Are you able to describe to the Court what the vehicle looked like, the green Daihatsu vehicle? Apart from being large, was there anything else about it that you recall, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I don't know if in their country they don't have that kind of vehicle but it was a Daihatsu-make vehicle and it had a back part which was used for transporting merchandise. It could also transport people. There were iron bars in the back which are supposed to hold in the cargo, if the car was to hold any cargo. But this is the type of vehicle that I saw. I don't know how to explain to you otherwise the kind of vehicle that it was.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You've testified that there were other people present with Mr. Ndindabahizi when you saw him. Do you know if they had travelled in any of these three vehicles and, if so, which one?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I didn't quite understand your question. Could you please repeat it for me?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: When you saw the Daihatsu vehicle which you've just described, do you know what that vehicle conveyed to that location, if anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: But those vehicles were parked in that place and afterwards the vehicles -- the gendarmes who were on those vehicles, as well as members of the population, came down from those vehicles. Suddenly, we saw them coming out -- bringing out a kind of box and throwing it onto the road. We were in the woods and we could see what was happening. We saw them sharing out knives -- or, rather, new machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. Let's go back to the gendarmes that you've talked about. Now, were you able to tell if the gendarmes had travelled to that location in any of those vehicles or had they gone there on foot?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They had come on board the Daihatsu vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And where on that vehicle were the gendarmes located, if you recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They were in the back, in the part I had referred to which is used for transporting merchandise; but in front, in the cabin, there was another gendarme and someone else, I presume, together with the driver.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Roughly, how many gendarmes did you see arriving at Gitwa hill on this day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: You are referring to the day on which those vehicles came to that place?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. Yes, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Listen, I will estimate that to be between 18 and 20. We really did not count them, but I will suppose that they were between 18 and 20 because the vehicle was full. This obviously is an estimate because nobody really counted them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And the civilians that you have referred to, did they travel in any of the vehicles? Can you help us with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: We thought some were hanging on the metallic bars at the back of the vehicle. They were behaving like mad people. They were travelling, hanging on the bars of the vehicle. We could see a large crowd of people dispersed in the area, some of whom had come on foot.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The people you have described as gendarmes, how were you able to recognise them as such?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They were wearing gendarmes' uniform.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were they armed and, if so, what were they armed with?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: The gendarmes were carrying guns.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The civilians, were they -- how were they dressed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They were wearing civilian clothes, just as all of us, since they were not soldiers. They were not soldiers.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were they armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They were carrying clubs, machetes, which were distributed to them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How were you able to identify the man you've described as Emmanuel Ndindabahizi amongst this crowd of people on this day, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: He was standing by his vehicle and talking to the people around. Besides, he was a leader. When a leader is standing with members of the population and soldiers, you cannot not notice him. He was talking to those people in his capacity as a leader.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, let's talk about where you were located at this time. Could you tell us how far you were from Mr. Ndindabahizi and his entourage, as you say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was very close to the forest. We were hiding. We were trying to see what those people standing there were doing. We came from the Gitwa hill. When we saw the vehicles, we got close to see what the vehicles were doing there. Because when the vehicles were coming up the hill, when the Interahamwe were coming up to the top of the hill, we would go down from the top of the hill to see what the vehicles and the Interahamwes were doing. We were in the bush on the hill, but I was with other people who unfortunately are dead now, and we were at the distance of about 25 to 30 metres from where these people were standing. Well, obviously, I did not measure the distance; I am only giving you a estimate of that distance.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And were you -- in terms of your position, were you the same level with these vehicles or were you below the vehicles or above the vehicles in terms of your position?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I was uphill from the vehicles, hiding in the forest.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So, would I be correct in saying that you were looking down at the vehicles and not up?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: That is correct. I was uphill from the street -- from the road, and I was looking at the vehicles from up.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Roughly, how many people were with you as you observed these three vehicles, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I was with two young men. Obviously, there were other people further on, but I was with two people when I saw them. But these people died subsequently, unfortunately.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you have testified that you witnessed or observed some items being removed from one of the vehicles. Can we go back to that part of your testimony, please? Do you understand that? What was it that you saw being offloaded from the vehicles, and which vehicle did you see this being offloaded from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There was something that looked like a box, a wooden box, which was offloaded from the Daihatsu vehicle. And this box was put on the road and it contained machetes, and the people around the Interahamwes shared these machetes among themselves.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How many boxes were you able to observe being offloaded?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There was one box, but it appeared that there were other boxes in the vehicle. One could observe that there were other boxes in the vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Having been offloaded from the vehicle then -- and can you help me again, which particular vehicle did you observe this box being offloaded from; do you recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was from the Daihatsu that I mentioned to you earlier on, the green Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall the persons who were responsible for offloading this box? Did you see who offloaded the box from the Daihatsu vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was the Interahamwe who were with him. They were the ones who offloaded the box.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was this box you saw being offloaded already opened at the time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Regarding the opening of the box, I did not observe that carefully. I only know that the box was offloaded, put on the ground, and I realised that they took out the machetes that I referred to, but I did not look at it properly to see if it was open at the time they were putting it on the ground.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Earlier on in your testimony, Mr. Witness, you described the machetes as being new. You used the word "new". How were you able to arrive at this conclusion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: You know, when a machete is new, you see it's shining. The people handling them and who were describing them, we could hear them. When a machete is old, it has been used, it has a black colour. But when it is white -- when it is new, it is whitish. You can therefore distinguish a new machete from an old, used one.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Having witnessed the box being offloaded, was there anything else that you saw at the time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I saw that they immediately distributed the machetes contained therein.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Where was Mr. Ndindabahizi at this time when the machetes were being distributed? Were you able to tell?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: He was still in the neighbourhood, close to the vehicles.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In your opinion, was he able to see what was going on as described by yourself?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, he could see. He was the one supervising the exercise as leader or the person in charge.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And how were you able to come to that conclusion, Mr. Witness, that he was supervising as the leader? Was there anything in particular that made -- indicated that to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: What led me to that conclusion is that I knew him at the time. He was somebody working for the government. He was a very important personality, and those other people present, they were ordinary members of the population and gendarmes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did Mr. Ndindabahizi speak at all during the time you saw him there, speak to anyone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Who did you see him speak to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: He spoke to those people and told them the following: "Go. There are Tutsis who have become difficult." And since the 14th, the Interahamwe would normally come to Gitwa carrying machetes and clubs. And since they did not have firearms, we tried to fight them back. He told them that, "There are Tutsis on the hill and they've proved to be difficult. You, therefore, have to kill them, and when you kill them, you will be compensated."

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You referred to "those people". Would I be correct in saying, Mr. Witness, that these were the people that had arrived -- you had seen arrive with Mr. Ndindabahizi when you say "those people"?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It is to those people that he distributed the machetes to. There were many. They came uphill and they invaded the area, and they were the people who attacked us. But he is the one who issued the order.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Those of you who sought refuge on Gitwa hill on this day, did you belong to any particular ethnic group and, if so, which of the ethnic groups did you belong to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There were only Tutsis there and the Tutsis were the target of the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Earlier on in your testimony, you described seeing a third vehicle which you described as a blue vehicle. Do you recall saying that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: This vehicle that looked like a Toyota or Hilux which came subsequently, it is therefore the third vehicle that I was referring to and which came later on. But the two vehicles I referred to came earlier.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And were you able to recognise those on board this vehicle -- or, sorry, I take that back. The third vehicle that you described, Mr. Witness, do you know if there was anyone on board this vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There's a man called Nambajimana who was the conseiller in our secteur who was aboard that vehicle. I also saw aboard that vehicle -- because that vehicle arrived but continued further uphill, I saw our conseiller. I also saw another man called Ruzindana who comes from Rwamatamu, as well as a former journalist called Niyitegeka. These people came after the first two vehicles. I don't know if they were travelling together as a convoy.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: For the record, the first name I believe is spelt N-A-M-B-A-J-I-M-A-N-A, Nambajimana, the first name he mentioned. I think that was then followed by Ruzindana, which is spelt R-U-Z-I-N-D-A-N-A, I believe. And the third name he mentioned was Niyitegeka, which for the record is spelt N-I-Y-I-T-E-G-E-K-A, Niyitegeka.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, what time of day was it when you observed Mr. Ndindabahizi's presence at Gitwa hill? What time of day was it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was approximately 10:30 or 11:00 a.m.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you've described being some 20, 25 metres or 30 metres -- I can't recall -- away from Mr. Ndindabahizi. Now, can you tell me, were there any obstacles between you and Mr. Ndindabahizi at this time? Were there any obstacles, big trees, branches?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, obviously, there was a thick forest. It was a thick forest. There were dense branches and we were hiding among them, like birds. So this was -- there was bush around.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So, how were you able to identify these things and these people if these branches and bush were all around you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: You see, if you want to see through an opening, you find an opening or you hide behind a tree and then you look, but since the other person you are looking at does not know you're hiding there, you try to see without being seen by the person in question.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did the branches and the bush obstruct your view of Mr. Ndindabahizi and the people around him, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, I could find an opening where there was no bush. Those people were not expecting anyone to be in the bush around, such that I could take a position from where I could observe what was happening.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you've described how you and other Tutsis sought refuge on Gitwa hill. My question to you is: were you not scared or afraid when you saw these vehicles arrive?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, we were afraid, but we plucked up our courage. But what we were afraid of were guns and we wanted to see if they had guns aboard those vehicles or if they were just ordinary civilians. That is why we came down, to come and see if they had soldiers among them to help them in their attack, and we realised that they had -- they were carrying machetes. Well, obviously, we were afraid but, you know, we had women and children among us. We were obviously afraid but what did you want us to do?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Having seen the arms being distributed, can you tell the Court what you saw happen next?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: These vehicles subsequently continued on their journey and the attackers attacked those on Gitwa hill. They climbed up the hill to launch their attack.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: When you say "these vehicles", do you refer to all three vehicles or only some of them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, all the vehicles continued.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did Mr. Ndindabahizi remain or did he leave Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, he also left aboard his vehicle; I mean the white vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What about the gendarmes that you describe arriving at that location earlier, did they remain or did they leave?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They left again in the same vehicle. Only the civilian population remained behind.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And were these the same civilians that the arms had been distributed to earlier, as you had testified earlier?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, those same members of the population.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You described an attack having occurred on Gitwa hill on this day. Were you able to resist the attack, Mr. Witness? The refugees, were they able to resist this attack?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Since they had no guns, we took stones and fought them off.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were you successful?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, we fought them off and they went back.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The vehicles that left Gitwa hill on that occasion, were you able to tell in what direction they headed, having left Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They went back on the road that goes to Gisovu.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did there come a time, whilst you sought refuge on Gitwa hill, that you witnessed other attacks? Sorry, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Before we move on, Mr. Witness, how many civilians were there you observed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Are you talking about the members of the population? I did not clearly understand your question, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You explained that there were three cars: two coming first; one afterwards. You observed civilians and gendarmes. I'm now asking you how many civilians you observed on that occasion.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There were very many. There were many attacks launched by many members of the population. There were very many. They invaded a whole area. I therefore cannot give a specific number.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Are you able to indicate how many civilians you observed in connection with those two, three cars, approximately?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Regarding the members of the population who came with those vehicles, I would say there were about 50 who came with the vehicles, but all around there were other members of the population who arrived and who were moving in all directions. So, I cannot recall the exact number, because I just cannot recall the number.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And they arrived in which vehicle or vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They came aboard the Daihatsu vehicle. At least, there were some members of the population who were at the back of this vehicle, this small vehicle, but on the road there were other members of the population, and when we saw these vehicles stop, all around there were members of the population who were getting ready to attack us. And normally, around eight o'clock, there are members of the population all along the road, so the vehicles arrived and found these other members of the population who were already there. There were very many.

div.stage: Pages 1 to 11 by Karen L. Holm)1500H

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you observe how Mr. Ndindabahizi, if it was him, how he was dressed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I saw that he was wearing a jacket which looked white. I really did not look closely to see what he was wearing. I limited myself to look at the -- at his face, but not what he was wearing.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, during the time that you remained on Gitwa hill, did there come a time when you witnessed other attacks at that location and, if so, when were these attacks?
