sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there were other attacks on the 26th. It was on that occasion that many gendarmes came; in fact, I think there were many more gendarmes than civilians. They were able to fend off the attack initially by the members of the population. It was on that occasion that the gendarmes came on the 26th of April, attacked us together with the other members of the population.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You testified that you had left your home early in April to seek refuge elsewhere. Did you do so with other members of your family, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And did there come a time when you left the area of Gitwa hill for some other location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They shot at us and we scattered in the bush. They chased us and in the evening we came back to the place and we continued hiding in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you ever leave the area surrounding Gitwa hill to go elsewhere?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: After the gendarmes shot at us, we dispersed. We went to hide. Several people were killed, but we were changing our hiding places continuously following the attacks against us. We kept moving in the forest and in the general neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How many members of your family survived the attack or attacks in and around Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, would you be able to recognise the man you describe as Emmanuel Ndindabahizi if you saw him today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It is very possible that I will recognise him, but let me make a comment right away. People went to various localities. It is possible that their faces will change, that they will lose weight or put on weight. If the opportunity were given to me, I will see if I would be able to recognise him from among the people present in this courtroom.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, may I ask your leave for the witness to identify the Accused -- try and recognise the Accused?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, if you could kindly stand up where you are presently located -- stand up and look around this courtroom and see if you can recognise the man that you describe as Mr. Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It must be that person, that person seated behind the white people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I ask that the records reflect that he is looking -- that the witness is looking to his left, right opposite me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you describe what that person that you referred to is wearing? How is he dressed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: He is wearing a jacket, a white shirt and a tie.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is there anything else about him that you can see that may help identify him, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It must be him. I believe that I have recognised him. The person I've described appears to me Mr. Ndindabahizi, in any case, based on what I know of him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours, if the record can reflect, I think, that Mr. Ndindabahizi fits that description. If the record can reflect that the witness has identified Mr. Ndindabahizi as being present in this courtroom.Your Honours, I hope I have kept to time. I have no further questions for this witness, and I would be very obliged if my learned friends for the Defence would make an effort to keep to the same time frame. I am grateful, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. The identification is noted for the record.There is a question.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you said you fled the Gitwa hill to the neighbourhood. Could you please name the neighbourhood; what was the area called?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Could you please reformulate your question? I didn't quite understand it.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: In your statement you said that you fled the Gitwa hill to the neighbourhood. What is the name of that area where you fled from the Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: We were scattered about and we ran into that forest. I continued to get further into the forest, but I didn't leave the area itself. We were moving about through the forest, but within the same area.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So does this imply that you remained at what is usually referred to as Gitwa hill, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, sometimes we would leave Gitwa to go into the areas near -- within Gitwa, but in the forest and in the bushes because in the bushes one can hide.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.Defence, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Good morning (sic), Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You said that you have already testified -- or you have been interviewed twice by the investigators of the Tribunal; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you meet those investigators in your home or elsewhere?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They found me elsewhere.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you go to that other place upon their invitation, or did you just happen to meet them in that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They invited me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you accompanied by other people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, I left alone.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it be correct to say that the investigators of the Tribunal, first of all, went to your home and then they accompanied you to the place at which you were interviewed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, yes, we left together.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why could you not be interviewed in your home?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Since this was something confidential the children or my wife would have been able to hear what I was saying, and that's not correct, is it?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Have you already visited this courtroom or a similar courtroom before today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: From the time of my birth I have never witnessed a trial, even in our local courts.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You mean you have never, ever gone into a courtroom here in Arusha at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda before your testimony today; is that what you are saying?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I have already come here.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And the officers of the Tribunal made you come and visit the courtroom, did they?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, not here. There's a vehicle which took us somewhere further away where we are housed. And that's when I arrived here, but I do not know this specific location.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you look around you in this courtroom and tell us whether there is any other male, black person, who is not dressed in courtroom robes and who is not an advocate of this Tribunal?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I can see women and I think that's the only persons whom I can see who are not wearing a uniform.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You would be in agreement with me, Mr. Witness, that the only person that you identified as being Emmanuel Ndindabahizi is also the only black male who is not wearing judges' or lawyers' robes or a uniform; am I not right?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Objection, my learned friend should look in the courtroom properly before he --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I know him from a long time -- I have known him for a long time. I saw him and identified him, and he was in the place where the events took place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That's not the question I put to you, Mr. Witness. But let's move to another question. Mr. Witness, just a small question: you stated that you witnessed -- you were interviewed twice on two different dates before the Tribunal's investigators; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You do not remember the exact dates on which you were interviewed, but were these dates close to one another or were they far apart?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: The dates were far apart; between the two dates were about one or two months, as far as I recall.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The Defence has two statements; one is dated 3rd April 2001 and the other one is the 27th April 2001. Do these dates correspond to the ones during which you were interviewed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, those were indeed the dates.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the second statement which the Defence has, that of the 27th April 2001, you stated, "This is the first time that I am being interviewed by the investigators from the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda". But it would seem that, in reality, it was the second; so why were you saying it was the first time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question, because I didn't understand it?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the statement dated 27th April 2001 --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Counsel said 1994; he means 2001, and he makes that correction.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: -- and, in fact, that is the second statement. You say in that statement that, "This is the first time I am being interviewed by the investigators from the Tribunal". I don't quite understand this contradiction. Can you please explain it to me?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There is no contradiction. I spoke to you of dates on which I was interviewed and I explained to you the subject matter of my statements; so what contradictions are you referring to? I spoke to you of the dates on which I was interviewed. I told them to you. I do not understand why you say there is a contradiction.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: This is a technical matter. In the statement that you made one month after your first statement, it is written that, "This is the first time that I am being interviewed by the investigators from the Tribunal". This is my question: were you interviewed once or twice but, nonetheless, why did you in your statement say --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I was interviewed twice. No; you are distorting what I said. I said that I was interviewed twice, and this is quite clearly written.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you read English or French, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Do you mean can I speak French or English?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Should I conclude from your answer that you are not -- that you do not understand either English or French?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: That's impossible. I am Rwandan and I can express myself in Kinyarwanda, and when I speak I speak in Kinyarwanda. You, yourself, express yourself in French. Had I been conversant in the French language, I would have used French.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the question is only, if you were asked to read a sentence or two in French, would you be able to understand it.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, in your statement you say that the situation in your area started to deteriorate around the 10th of April 1994; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct; it was around that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you specify how the situation deteriorated in your area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I have said this to you. Do you want me to repeat what I said? The attackers came and they killed people, and that's what I've told you. The Accused was not the only one. I have spoken of the situation from the month of April until the time when we went to hide in Gitwa hill. I do not know; maybe you know the situation better than I do. I do not want to repeat what I've already said. If you didn't understand what I said, maybe you can go to Kibuye and one could explain the situation better to you there. Maybe you can come with me. You certainly will be able to see, at least, one bone. My children, my six children were killed in that place.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the questions asked by both counsel are quite normal, legitimate questions. And now counsel simply wanted to ask you a question about the developments in 1994. So please listen carefully to the question now. Here it comes again.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, did you witness murders or killings from the 10th of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I witnessed killings. From the 10th until the 26th we were on Gitwa hill and we were targets of attacks by members of the population whom we tried to repel with stones until Ndindabahizi came with machetes which he distributed to the members of the population.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: My question was, and you have answered that -- when I asked you whether you had seen killings on the 10th of April 1994 -- please concentrate on that date -- did you also see houses being burnt down in your neighbourhood on April 10th, 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Let me explain to you briefly. From the 10th we were not spending nights in our house; we were at Gitwa. People who came to hide at Gitwa were fleeing attacks from members of the population and their houses had also been burnt down. I was one of the people who were lucky to survive those attacks. What I'm telling you is true. If you wish, we can go together and the members of the population who are still alive in Gitwa will be able to tell you how things happened. Otherwise you, yourself, can make a stop there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you fled towards Gitwa on the 14th of April 1994, is that correct, the 14th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: My question is dealing with the period of the 10th of April 1994 and, once again, I'm asking you to concentrate on that date, to focus on that date. Did you see on that date refugees who were leaving their houses?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you also personally witness killings or murders of Tutsis between the 10th and the 14th of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I saw Tutsis killed. We were chased away from our homes on the 10th of April and we found refuge on the hill; in other words, on the 14th when this situation became worse we went up the hill and we were targets of attack in our homes, so we were trying to face those attacks. Some people were killed; others fled. It was not only --

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I do beg you, Mr. Witness, let's move about this step by step. All the questions will come in their time. I wanted to find out from you whether, when you arrived on Gitwa hill on the 10th of April, there were already other refugees there.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there were other refugees.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you give us an estimate of their number?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: More than 10,000. I did not count the refugees who were there, but if I were to make an estimate, I would say that there were more than 10,000.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is Gitwa hill a very high hill? Can you give us a rough estimate of its altitude?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I did not do any studies which would enable me to get altitude. You are asking me questions on matters I have not studied. Maybe it's 1,500 metres, but I'm not very well versed in those issues of determining how high hills are in terms of altitude. I know that it's a high hill, and we sought refuge there in order to try and escape the attacks that were launched against us; otherwise, I do not know how altitudes of hills or mountains are measured.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it be correct to say that refugees had specifically chosen that hill because it overlooked -- it was higher than the other hills in the region and enabled them to see from whence the attacks were coming?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No; that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you on Gitwa hill on the 14th of April and were you able to see attacks on that hill between the 14th of April and the 20th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there were attacks against us.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was there an attack every day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, we were attacked every day.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Between the 14th and the 20th April, who attacked you; was it the civilian population or were they soldiers and gendarmes who attacked you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was the civilian population.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was the population armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: With traditional weapons, machetes, small hoes, as well as clubs.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Those people who attacked you, were they many?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, they were many. All the members of the Hutu ethnic group were part of those attacks.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would you say that between the 14th and the 20th of April the people who attacked you were larger in number than the Tutsi who were -- had sought refuge on Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would you say, Mr. Witness, that the civilian population attacking you between the 14th and the 20th April were larger in number than the refugees who were already on the hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, the number of the attackers was higher; in other words, the members of the secteurs which were in the neighbourhood, and there were even attackers who came from Rutsiro commune in Cyangugu préfecture who came on Ruzindana's vehicles, because we had always resisted these attacks and that's why the members of the local population sought assistance from people to reinforce their own attacks.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Since you said the refugees were approximately 10,000 in number, do you understand that every day more than 10,000 civilians came to attack you on Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They wanted to exterminate all the Tutsi in Rwanda. That's how they found reinforcements from other communes. They would give beer to the members of the population participating in these attacks, and it was Préfet Kayishema who compensated them. It was in order to send us away from this area so that they could eat our crops and our cattle. Where did you want them to go? They were there. They even had recourse to thousands and thousands of civilians, even 50,000.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How were the civilians -- how were the refugees resisting the attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Did they have guns? We would take stones -- we would pick up stones and throw them at the attackers. We didn't have any guns.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did the attacks continue during the night?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, not regularly. At night there was no consistent attack.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Should I understand that the civilian population attacking you would go back home to sleep and would come back the next morning in order to attack you; would that be correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Those who were near that area would spend the nights in their homes. Others who came from far would spend the nights, while dancing, drinking and eating our cows, and the next day they would come and attack us in a drunken fury.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did the population which was attacking meet at another -- at a specific place? Did they surround the hill, or did they scatter throughout the area surrounding that particular hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: They would surround us. There were two secteurs. This hill is between Rubazo and Kabingo secteurs - Kagabiro secteurs, and those who came from below, some came from all four corners and they would attack us. So we would divide ourselves into groups and we tried to go into the various parts so that we could repel the attacks because the attacks didn't come only from one direction.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it have been possible for you to flee from that hill, or the population which was surrounding the hill would have stopped you from doing so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: We could not flee because we were surrounded. There was no way out. We were surrounded and we were on the hill. There was no way out and the attackers were surrounding us throughout the night and we would not have been able to find anywhere to flee to because all the parts were well surrounded. There were roadblocks everywhere both during the day and at night. Because this was a plan which was drawn up by the higher-up leaders of the country, the members of the government.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were they so numerous in number that you wouldn't have been able to make a path through them in order to find a surer and more safe place to hide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Please don't tire me out, Counsel. Where could we go through? We were few. The others were scattered everywhere. Do you think that the Tutsis lived only in one area? Unless we were all in the same area.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: As you have testified before the Tribunal, the population was shouting, they were dancing, they were making a loud noise; were they not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, they were singing, they were saying, "Let's kill all the Tutsis wherever they are hiding in the forest".

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Right. When you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi between the 20th and the 24th of April -- according to you, that would be at around 10:30 to 11:30 -- did you see him accompanied by other people? Did the civilian population accompany these vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And these vehicles were completely full of civilians as well as gendarmes, were they not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, they were.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And when these vehicles arrived, were the people who were in them welcomed by the civilian population?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there was applause and shouting. When the civilian population which was there saw the vehicles, they were happy because they thought that the soldiers that had come there had come to kill us, and they were there themselves in order to help them exterminate us.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And when the box or trunk was offloaded, was the civilian population also happy?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, they rejoiced because they wanted to exterminate all the Tutsi. They were very happy. They were dancing. They were really extremely happy because they knew that they were going to exterminate us.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was Ndindabahizi congratulated or applauded when he showed the people the trunk which had been offloaded?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Even if you are not Rwandan or Tanzanian, I think at your home there are sports such as football. These people, the civilian population, were happy like football spectators -- or some spectacle or other.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You, yourself, Mr. Witness, you were about 25 to 30 metres from Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's vehicle; is that not so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you were hiding in a bush, you say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Actually, you explained that there was, initially, bush and then there was a clear patch in that bush in which you were hiding; is that right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, can the registry be requested to show the witness the photographs showing Gitwa hill which is in Exhibit No. 1 of the Prosecutor? It's document L0019886 and L0019887.Does the witness have this document?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I'm sure counsel meant P1.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Counsel meant P2, the green one with the photographs.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I don't have that document.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you please show the witness photograph No. 3 and 4, Mr. Registry, photograph No. 3 and No. 4?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, these photographs were taken by an investigator of the Tribunal. Do you recognise Gitwa hill on these pictures?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you tell us what you refer to as a forest or woods in either one of these pictures?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Objection, Your Honour. My learned friend is misleading the witness. It's very apparent and obvious from L0019883 that those pictures were taken on the 16th of August 2003. If Your Honours recall, the investigator did say that he had no indication what the vegetation was in 1994. It's a deliberate misrepresentation, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I do not claim that's exactly the same vegetation, but I think the question should be put to the witness, by your leave, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The vegetation on the field, as you see it on this photograph, is it similar to what existed in 1994 on Gitwa hill, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, there are several photographs in this folder. We will go one by one. Look first now at photographs Nos. 3 and 4. The place where you were hiding, did it look like this one -- or these two, or was it different?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: At the time it was covered by bush but, subsequently, the bush was burnt down to chase us out. Here, I see that there is very little bush. Regarding the photographs, I don't know if they took the photograph -- I don't know much about photography or the hills. All I can say is that at that time there was a lot of bush. Probably -- on the next photograph I see that there is a bit of bush but, later on, all this bush was burnt down. But -- well, maybe in the photograph, the third photograph, I realise that that looks more like what it looked like then. There are just some shrubs here. I don't know if a photograph of that place was taken. I would have shown them where I was hiding, but they chose to photograph this area.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Unfortunately, I do not think that the photograph the witness is referring to is in the exhibits.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Well, Witness, my question is that you found yourself in an opening in the middle of the forest and you are saying that you were 25 metres away from the vehicle of the Accused.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And, as you said, on this Gitwa hill there were several thousand refugees; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there was a great number.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And there was yet a greater number of attackers and people where you found yourself -- where you were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, there were many more.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How, then, were you able to identify Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, and were able to distinctively identify his voice, given the number of people who were present at that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I was able to hear what he was saying because he was asking the people there to keep quiet because he wanted to speak to them, and they obeyed his instructions.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he use a megaphone or any other equipment to amplify his voice?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, he did not use a megaphone. Because when you are respected you do not need to use a megaphone because people listening to you want to hear you and it is in their interests to listen to you and obey your orders.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he climb on the boot of a vehicle to be able to speak to the people around?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, he was standing on the road and people surrounding him -- they surrounded him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And are you able to recall the number of machetes distributed on that day, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There are questions you put to me which are not -- which are without any grounding.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If you see a box and you are a hundred metres way, are you able to count the number of machetes? Were you at a hundred metres from the site?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I told you that distance; it was between 25 and 30 metres, but I did not measure the distance. Whatever the distance at which I found myself, I was able to follow what was going to happen to us. Even at 200 metres, if you are in danger of death, you will be able to hear people who are planning against you. When somebody is in danger of death he is able to hear him from a great distance. His ears become very sensitive.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you saying, Witness, that fear gives you this extra capacity to hear from a great distance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, obviously, because in such situations, you want to hear what these people are saying so you can escape them or face them. When we saw them distributing the machetes and talking among themselves, we said to ourselves that they had no guns, and that reassured us to some extent because if they attack us without guns, they are not able to kill us. So we said since they did not have guns, we are going to be able to resist them.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is a question.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: I have a question to the witness: at Gitwa hill, where you were hiding, there was a forest, and I believe a road below where the vehicles were passing; which road was this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was an untarred road which led to the Gisovu tea factory in the Gisovu commune, going through the FM antenna at Karongi commune, leading all the way to the Gisovu commune.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: So would I be right if I called it Kibuye-Karongi road?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, you would be right.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, in your written statement dated 26 April 2001 you stated in the sixth paragraph of that statement: "Probably there were 50 of the machetes in that box". Do you confirm that, the number of 50?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Well, that was an estimate. I did not count the machetes. I did not get hold of the box to count the number of machetes contained in it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And only one box was brought down; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, only one.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Don't you find it strange that only one box be brought down for a crowd of 10,000 people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: But these were implements which were brought in reinforcement but, otherwise, people had their own weapons. These extra ones were brought for the indigent ones who did not have money to buy their own machetes; otherwise, the other people were well prepared with their own machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Witness, you stated that you knew Mr. Emmanuel Ndindabahizi before then; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you stated that you knew him -- you had known him for a long time.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know where Mr. Ndindabahizi studied, in which primary school Mr. Ndindabahizi studied?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It must have been in the Kirambo locality.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know where he did his secondary school?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, I do not know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: University, in which he studied?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was in Butare. It was said that he was at university, but I believe it must have been the Butare university. I was not closely following where he was studying. It was being said that he was at university. He was my neighbour, but I had no interest in finding out which university. And then at the end of his university studies -- he was one of few people who attended university in our region. And he was appointed a leader because he was one of the very few people in our region to have attended university.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What were you -- what were you doing when Mr. Ndindabahizi was at university?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I was a farmer.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What reason did you have to visit him at this time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: But I never visited him. We never visited each other. I just knew him the way you know someone -- when children are in school they know each other. When you visit a cousin or an auntie, paternal aunt, you hear that there is a child in school. But when a child of the secteur or commune attends a university or university (sic), it was known by everybody because it was something -- it was a rare event at the time.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Have you ever spoken to Emmanuel Ndindabahizi or has he ever spoken to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Speak to me? We were not of the same social standing. He is somebody who attended university. And what interests would he have to speak to a farmer? And, in any event, we did not live in the same secteur. We were in the same commune. I knew him as a leader, just the way you know any leader. When the préfet holds a meeting the members of the population will see and recognise him, but he does not see everybody except those who belong to the same class as he himself. When you don't belong to the same social class you do not know each other, and only the good leaders who do not plot against their country, who do not betray their fellow countrymen, are known by the citizens.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What leader was Ndindabahizi before 1994? What was he leading?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Well, in 1994, from what I was told, he was working somewhere before 1994; but I don't know exactly what he was doing, but at some point in time I went to the Trafipro cooperative and I found him there. Later on, I heard that he was in Kigali. I was not closely following the situation, but he was working in a department in Kigali. And later on in 1994 I heard that he was the minister of finance. I don't know whether he was given that position to be able to pay the Interahamwe.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You refer to Trafipro, can you explain to the Court what this Trafipro means?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: It was a cooperative. I don't know if it was a state-sponsored cooperative or a farmers' cooperative. They sold clothings -- clothing and other implements. I used to see him there, and when I saw him there, I thought he worked there, but I really do not know, but he was a very important person in that area. And I used to see him quite often because I used to go to Trafipro, but I really didn't closely monitor or follow his situation; besides, we never spoke to each other, he and I never spoke to each other. It was only because some events occurred and I have been called upon to testify in his trial.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You never visited Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, did you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, I just knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You confirm that you never spoke to him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: No, I never spoke to him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you were unable to recognise him in April of 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: What do you mean that I was unable to recognise him? Can you repeat your question?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETERS:
sp.p: Sorry, we missed the beginning of Counsel's question, if he can go over the question.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can you repeat your question, please? Please repeat the question.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: This is my last but one question, Mr. President. And I'm asking Witness -- I'm telling Witness he really does not know Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, and I don't even think he knows him at all. And I am putting it to him that he was unable to identify him during the events that he is referring to.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I'm not lying, I saw him. I'm not lying; I knew him before. Obviously, we were not visiting each other because he was rich and I was poor, and besides, he lived far away from me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: My last question, Witness, in your written statement you claimed that someone allegedly told you that Ndindabahizi distributed weapons at Gisovu; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I would wish you to tell us who this person is, but don't mention his name. I'm going to show you a piece of paper with the name of this person, and please tell the Court if this, indeed, is the person who told you that Ndindabahizi distributed weapons at Gisovu; do you understand?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I understand.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Can I have that piece of paper.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Please show the names to the Judges, the Prosecution and then to the witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, this is the person.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Mr. President, no further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is a name on the piece of paper, do you want that exhibited?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes. I'm sorry, Mr. President. Indeed, I would like to -- I would like it to be noted that the Witness has recognised the name that was presented to him by the Defence, and that this name be entered on the records of the Court.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And this becomes Defence Exhibit Number 6, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D6 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: That will be Defence Exhibit Number 6, My Lord.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's good. And your information there, Defence Counsel, it was based on information in the documents?The name mentioned on the piece of paper, could you just draw our attention to the particular paragraph where we should look?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Mr. President. It is a piece of information which appears in the statement of 3rd April, 2001 of Witness CGN at the end of his statement, sixth line from the bottom in the French version.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There it is, thank you.Thank you. Any re-examination?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: No, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, we have now come to the end of your testimony. Thank you, very much for coming to the Tribunal to testify. We wish you a safe journey home; and please, do not discuss your testimony with anyone.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Mr. President, I have a request, if you allow me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: There are lawyers or assistants -- assistants to some lawyers from other countries. And these people come and put questions to these people. But these are confidential matters, particularly concerning our security. But some of these people come to us, go to the hills, to the communal office, and in front of the public have someone's written -- I was interviewed in 2001. And before I came here, I met investigators, and that was done in a confidential manner. But these people I am referring to, come publicly. They write summons at the communal office. And we are summoned to the communal office as if we are criminals to be interviewed. And when we are interviewed to request us to come and testify here, we are told that it is confidential. I'm not criticising these people, but I am requesting that this does not -- is not repeated, or I request the Chamber to go after these people. I have a document here which has the communal stamp. And these are people that we do not know who bring you this document, present the document to you. This document was given to me on the 15th of July; that is the date on the document. These people receive -- people receive these summons from strangers. And these are people who want to interview us; whereas, they should be interviewing us in a confidential manner, they give this document to the communal secretary or to a third party, even to children. But it is written on this document, you can see, written, the International Criminal Tribunal of Arusha (sic). I think this issue needs to be looked at closely. Our security should be safeguarded. Maybe you should contact the Kibuye authorities. I don't know if you are thinking about ensuring our security after we have been killed. There are very few people who are ready to come and testify here and I think we ought to be protected.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the Tribunal is very anxious to protect the security of the witnesses. And we have a unit, a section which is particularly trained in these matters. And they usually proceed very discreetly in order to avoid exactly what you are indicating. Now, are you saying that Tribunal staff approached the communal authority in a transparent way so that it became transparent, then visible? Is that -- are you talking about Tribunal staff? Have you seen them, yourself? Who are these persons that you are referring to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: I don't know these people, but these must be officers of the Tribunal, and they want to interview you publicly, before the public, in a room at the communal office, everybody sees you. There was a Rwandan woman with these people. And let me add, to appoint somebody who is in Kigali, and for these people to go and look for people he knows; you should not be appointing just anybody to go and contact people, people that he does not know. It is not proper to proceed in that manner.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Phillips.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, there is a criticism directed specifically at my office, and the investigators that were involved in the re-confirmation exercise of this witness in the field. We regret the circumstances very much; but it certainly is not associated with what other witnesses have complained about before Your Honours prior to today. This is a separate matter that this -- that accord in relation to this witness and some other witnesses where they were, indeed, contacted through the local authorities. And we have -- we have established an independent investigation of this in our office, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Did you hear the explanation there, Mr. Witness; just answer yes or no whether it was translated to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: Yes, I followed the interpretation.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, with our words I confirm that the Tribunal is very anxious to protect your identity; and that if there were problems here, they will be looked into and an investigation is going on. And I will also be -- if I can keep this document, Mr. Witness, I will hand this over in connection with that investigation.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGN:
sp.p: You may keep that document, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That is very kind, thank you for assisting us. Now, we wish you a safe journey home, and you may now be discharged. And if the registry could kindly assist you and draw the curtain. And we will then move on, if we have the next witness available.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: CJY, Your Honour, CJY.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Thank you, Mr. Witness, we will look into the matter.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be asked questions now in an open session. Be careful when you answer the questions so as not to reveal your identity. Do you have a piece of paper in front of you now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I can see the document. I have it right here.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you recognise that document? Have you seen it before?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, this document was shown to me at the time when I signed it at the bottom.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The fact that your signature is at the bottom, does that imply that the information contained therein, in that document, is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, this document was read to me and I realised that the information on it was correct. I realised that the information on the document is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So that will be P7 under seal, now?

div.stage: EXhibit No. P7 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. So, please proceed, Mr. Kapaya.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: I'm sorry, Your Honour. The Witness has not yet been sworn by the registry, My Lord.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Will you kindly do the necessary arrangements then.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, please stand up and raise your right hand and say after me.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness CJY in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: You may be seated.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: WITNESS CJYfirst having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, were you working in Kibuye town in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And did you live outside of Kibuye town in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes. I was living outside of the town of Kibuye, but in the urban commune in which the said town is to be found.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And when you heard of the death of the president on the 7th of April, you were in Kibuye town; right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes. That is where I was when I learned of that news.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you briefly tell their Honours what the security situation was a week or so following the death of the president in Kibuye town?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: In the week following the death of the president, from the day after the death of the president the security situation deteriorated progressively. Little by little, and gradually the situation deteriorated.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What did you observe during this period? What was happening?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: To begin with, some people changed their behaviour; one could say that they were expecting to be doing something. Some members of the population were happy; others were sad.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, did you witness any attacks during this period, between members of the population?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: During this period of time, when I was in town, the attacks had not yet begun. But outside of the town in the surrounding communes, there were attacks and we could see smoke from far off because the houses had already begun to be burned down.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, could you tell us when you witnessed attacks in Kibuye town?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Personally, when I left Kibuye town people were already in groups, but the attacks had not yet been launched.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And when did you leave Kibuye town, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I finally left on the 11th of April; that is when I left Kibuye town.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell the Tribunal where you went after leaving the town?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I went to my native region.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When you talk of your native region, do you mean the place where you were raised at, where your family was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, that is where my family was. But it is the same urban commune where the town is located.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, when you talk of your family, Mr. Witness, you mean a wife and how many children, if any?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I'm referring to my wife, our children, there were three. I'm also referring to my mother; my older brothers, who were married. But amongst my brother, there was one who was still a bachelor.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Right. When you got to the area of residence, what was the situation like then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Where I lived, one could see clearly that there was security, but there were rumours coming to us from far off places.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did you make any security arrangements for your family, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, we tried to take some measures. We came together in groups in order to ensure our security together.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Witness CJY, did you stay at your residences throughout April, May, June, July, 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: No. We didn't remain there because at a given point in time the situation -- the security situation deteriorated and we were forced to flee.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell their Honours, what it is that forced you to flee?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: We decided to flee because there were numerous attacks targeting the neighbouring areas, there were other people who were seeking refuge by leaving their homes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us who was attacking whom at this particular period?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was people referred to as Interahamwe, people of the Hutu ethnic group who were attacking Tutsis, but it is not all of the Hutus who were -- who had become attackers.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know the reason why the Hutus were attacking the Tutsis, those particular Hutus who were attacking the Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I didn't quite understand the question, could you please repeat it for me.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you said that -- you testified that some Hutus were attacking Tutsis at that particular period. My question was whether you knew the reason why those particular Hutus were attacking the Tutsis at that particular period.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I know the reason. Mention had already been made of that; and then there was a radio which was heating up people's head, especially the RTLM. And there were others who were acting because of their sense of morality or their religious convictions.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, you haven't actually told us the reasons why, but what was said on RTLM about these attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: On RTLM, it was being said that the Inkotanyi had wanted to grab the country, to kill Hutus; and, therefore, Hutus needed to do everything in their power to try to protect themselves and try to ensure their safety and security.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what did you understand by the term, "Inkotanyi"?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: The word Inkotanyi referred to all Tutsis, without any distinction.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, could you tell us, Mr. Witness, whether there came a time when you went to seek refuge at any particular place?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are now approaching something slightly different?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could we take the 15-minutes break now.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: It is fine with me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you, very much. We are coming back in about 15 minutes, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: All rise.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed, Mr. Kapaya.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, following the detailed security situation of your area of residence, did you go somewhere to see refuge; if so, where?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I did not remain in my home. But first of all, what I would like to ask is that you had told me that I needed to be careful when answering questions because the name of the place which I'm going to mention in my answer may help in revealing my identity. So, if I say it -- because once I would have answered your question, maybe we will not be able to reverse the situation.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Are you about to refer to a hill in Bisesero or are you about to refer to a more specific place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, it is a specific area which may be recognised later as somewhere which is close to my home. I don't know, this may help reveal my identity.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: But I believe that the Witness went to seek refuge is a place where many people went there. So it is -- I think he can rest assured that his identity will not be known.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you for drawing our attention to this, Mr. Witness, that was the right thing to do, but you will not be identified, says the Prosecution.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you now kindly tell us, Mr. Witness, where you went to seek refuge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I went to seek refuge on Gitwa hill. But I left that place later on because my wife was expectant -- expecting, and moreover, it was raining a great deal; it was the month of April, I had small children with me. And I tried to take these people to a friend's house. As for myself, I remained on Gitwa. And from time to time, I would go to the home of the person I have just referred to. So when there was some fog, or at night, I would go to the house of that person who was hiding my family for me.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, let's focus on Gitwa hill. Is it true that Gitwa -- could you tell us where Gitwa hill is located, in which commune?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Gitwa hill is -- was in the commune formally known as Gitesi commune in Roboso (phonetic) secteur even now.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness. Do you recall the approximate date you went to seek refuge at Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I remember the date; I think it was on the 15th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And could you tell us for how long you stayed at Gitwa hill before you moved elsewhere?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I didn't remain there for a long time because I told you that I had to be on the move constantly because my wife was pregnant, and she delivered in the month of May. So as I was saying, I was at two places at the same time, so to speak. And it was -- and these two places are near each other.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Right. While at Gitwa hill, Mr. Witness, can you tell us what you observed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: On that hill, there were many refugees who had come from several places in Kibuye préfecture. There were, in fact, refugees who came from as far as Gitarama.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Was it safe to stay at that hill all of the time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, there were difficulties, but we didn't have any choice. These were people who had come together in order to resist, by the grace of God. But if death came, then we would all die together.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us whether there were any attacks mounted upon Gitwa hill, where you sought refuge in that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, there were attacks on Gitwa hill.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us who mounted those attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was those people whom I'd referred to, it was the Hutus who said they wanted to protect the country which was going to be captured by others. But I said that there were also Hutus who remained in their homes, who deplored the situation and who did not approve of these things that were happening.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Of the Hutus who attacked you; do you know of any people who -- do you know the names of any particular attackers who came there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I know some. There were particularly the leaders of the attackers who seemed to have been trained. One could see that these were people who were prepared. And they came from secteurs which I knew of, or secteurs which were neighbouring ours. It was not a matter of people who came from very far. There were some who came from far, but there were also neighbours among them.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know of any people of authority who came along with the attackers to that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you name them, those you recall -- those whose names you recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: There were authorities, people in authority at various levels. And maybe I will begin with the responsable right up to people of very high levels. All of these people came to attack. But now, Mr. Prosecutor, from where do you want me to begin.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You may begin from wherever, the identification of the responsable upwards.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I can mention from the responsables de cellule, but there, once again, there are going to be -- it is going to be necessary to make the remark that I made earlier, because if I mention specific names, my area of origin would be identified. Maybe you can give me a piece of paper on which I can write these names. I think that would be a better option.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I don't think by mentioning a person -- the person's position and his area of authority will ever -- will in any way identify you, unless you say you live there or you've lived there. All we want from you is just to mention those people and say where they worked, and that kind of thing. Don't necessarily link them with where you lived.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: If I understand you, it means that if I mention only the names that would be adequate for you, Mr. Prosecutor?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yeah, that may do, under the circumstances.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Let me begin with some names, especially people whom I consider to have been leaders; people who were considered to be valiant, courageous. There was one John Munyangeyo, Munyangeyo is spelt, M-U-N-Y-A-N-G-E-Y-O.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what was his position in society?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He didn't have any specific status. The fact of being considered courageous or valiant doesn't mean that you have a position of authority as such. This is someone who was considered to be courageous during that period of time, and who killed with no problem.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Okay. Who are the other people you can recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: There was Kanyamibwa, Martin. Kanyamibwa is spelt, K-A-N-Y-A-M-I-B-W-A; Kanyamibwa, Martin was his first name.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell us what position he held in society?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He was the responsable of the cellule

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And who else was there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Let me mention John Rwamasasu, which is spelt, R-W-A-M-A-S-A-S-U, Rwamasasu, first name John.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And did you tell us what he was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He was also a member of the cellule committee.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you tell us some other names you recall, at a different level now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: There was Nyagasaza. Nyagasaza is spelt, N-Y-A-G-A-S-A-Z-A, Nyagasaza.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what was this person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He is someone who can be considered as a vagabond, somebody who is always found in drinking bars.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, let's move to the communal level. Did you see anybody come who held positions at the commune level and the secteur level? Let's move at that level now.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, there was one Besingemana (phonetic), who was a veterinary officer. And he used to operate in the Rutsiro region.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, did you see any préfet or ministers come along with attackers at that time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: During the attack, there was an officer -- I think he was the officer in charge of the Gisovu tea factory, who came during the last large-scale attack.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And before that attack you described as a "large-scale attack", did you see other minister or préfets come at Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: No. There were no préfets or minister on the Gitwa hill. But before the large-scale attack that I referred to, some government officials came to give instructions, but they were not very visible, because people were staying -- in hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know the person by the name of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us how you got to know him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I knew him well before these events.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us when you knew him and under what circumstances, and in which years before these events?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: When I got to know him the first time, he was still a young man. I studied at the center close to his region, his native region, a centre called Kirambo, K-I-R-A-M-B-O.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And when was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: This was in 1968, '69, around that period. It was on that occasion that I got to know him. But since he was in the higher institution, I did not see him quite often. But in any event, it was during that period that I got to know him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us other periods, before the war, when you used to see or know Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Before the onset of the war, he used to come from time to time to Kibuye. This was after 1990, so this was after the advent of the multi-party system. It was then that he used to come to Kibuye and I used to see him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What would you see him doing in Kibuye, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: From time to time he would come to Kibuye. He didn't come quite often, but when he came there was PSD party rallies. And at that time, he was somebody who was a very well respected and who held a lot of clout at the national level within his PSD party.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What was the connection between him and the PSD party, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He was a member of that party; besides, he was an officer. But at that time, the PSD was a good party, but subsequently, things changed. But before things changed, people liked that party; people liked the PSD party.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Were you a member of any political party yourself, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I was not a member of any political party.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Then how did you know that Mr. Ndindabahizi came to attend these PSD political parties?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: The political parties use to hold their rallies where I worked. So whether you are a member or not, or whether -- even if you are not a member of any political party, you could still follow what was being said out of curiosity?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Just to wrap up this part, can you describe to the Honours, what Mr. Ndindabahizi looked like?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: At that time, most of the time he was not on foot, he was aboard a vehicle. People would be around the vehicle, and he would bring out his hand from the vehicle, in the direction of the people; people would applaud. And one could see that he was somebody who was well liked by the people. It was in those circumstances that I was able to observe him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you describe his physical features? Was he tall, short, brown, black, that kind of thing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: At that time he would be seated aboard a vehicle. But when the vehicle stopped, he would normally get out, greet people. He was of average height, not too fat; somebody of average height and not too fat.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And how would you place his age?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: About -- he was somebody who was about 42, 43 years, but that is just an estimate. The way I saw him, he must have had -- he must have been 42, 43 years. He was no longer a young man. He was an adult, a matured person.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Let's go back to 1994, now. When was it that you saw this man?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I saw him in 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Could you give us the approximate date and month when you saw him in '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: In 1994, I believe I saw him on the 23rd April. I don't think there should be any doubt about that.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what makes you think that you saw him on the 23rd and not the 22nd or any other date?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I confirm that date because under such difficult circumstances, I had a radio and I could listen to the news on that radio. So I am able to easily remember this date.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Okay. Mr. Witness, can you tell us how he got to the place where you saw him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He came in a vehicle, that is how he got to the place.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did he come in one vehicle or did he come in a convoy?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He came in his own vehicle, but he was accompanied by other vehicles. It was therefore clear that he was being accompanied.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you describe the vehicle in which he boarded, he came with?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was a white double-cabin vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And how many people came with him in that vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He was with his driver who was driving him as well as two soldiers who escorted him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And how did you know that the other two people were soldiers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: They were wearing military uniform with red berets. In fact, they were gendarmes and I knew by the uniform they were wearing.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us -- can you describe the second vehicle in which Mr. Ndindabahizi came?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was a blue Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know who owned it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you describe the people who were in that vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Among the people in there, there were soldiers wearing military uniform, other members of the population who had covered their heads with bananas leaves.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Was there a particular name which the members of the population with bananas leaves were referred to at that particular time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: These persons were referred to as Interahamwe.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell Their Honours how many Interahamwes and how many soldiers were there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It is clear that I did not count these people and that I was in hiding. We had to act with a lot of prudence, but if I have to estimate, I would say that the gendarmes were about six or ten. Let me say between six and ten gendarmes. Regarding the members of the population, there were many, but their number would not exceed 20 -- 20 people.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you describe the third vehicle in that convoy?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was an old model Toyota, the colour was between white and yellow. In fact, the colour is similar to the colour of the table in front of me here.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: What did you say -- this was the colour of the car, yellow?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I observed that the colour was close to yellow or let's say, a defaced yellow.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, may the record show that the colour of the desk the witness is describing is beige, sort of.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you tell us the occupants of this third vehicle, who were in that third vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Aboard that vehicle there were some gendarmes which -- what makes me say they are gendarmes is the fact that they were wearing military uniforms with red berets. So the uniform I have just described is the gendarmes' uniform. The gendarmes were few.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And were there other occupants in that vehicle apart from the gendarmes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, there were other persons who were sitting there and one could see that they were waiting for something because they stayed there for a long time.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I am still with the people who were in that third vehicle, you said some of them were gendarmes. My question is, who were the others, could you recognise them at least by their dressing or something?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: These were members of the population who were wearing banana leaves and there were some soldiers as well with them.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you estimate their number, how many of these were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: They were about six persons apart from those wearing the banana leaves.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now can you tell us the order in which these motor vehicles reached that place, which preceded the other?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: First of all, there was a white double-cabin vehicle, the second vehicle was a Daihatsu and the third one was this single cabin Toyota pick-up, the model was stout.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now after Ndindabahizi had reached that area, did you observe him say or do anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, when he got to the place people got up to greet him, and other people joined those who were already there, and it was as if they were waiting for the arrival of the vehicles to join those who were already there. So they got close to him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you now describe, Mr. Witness, in your own words what you observed, whether this man said anything or did anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Those who were there greeted Mr. Ndindabahizi. He asked them if people were still taking refuge on the Gitwa hill.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What did people reply and what did he say if anything else?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: They answered that people were no longer taking refuge at that place because people had already assembled there, they had left their houses.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What else did Mr. Ndindabahizi say or do, if anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He told them that the situation was similar and that there were no more people living in the forest to take refuge there, then they should implement the plan that was envisaged immediately.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: During that meeting, did you observe anything happening?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: There was a distribution of implements which were going to go used in the implementation of the plan.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you give us some background as to the distribution of implements? How did it come about that -- I mean implements were distributed, and which implements? Can you be more specific, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: The implements that were distributed were cartons of machetes which were distributed, they were not many. There were also cartons containing the camouflage uniforms of the leaders, those who were going to lead the attacks.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Were those uniforms and weapons accompanied by any explanation from anybody?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, it was explained that, that the weapons that had just been distributed were to be used in implementing the plan that had been drawn up, and that they should not just keep them without using them.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us, Mr. Witness, who gave that explanation?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And can you tell us what was the response from the people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: The people present were very happy because they had just received some assistance and then the people rejoiced.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you want to tell us that before the arms were brought by Mr. Ndindabahizi, there was nobody who was armed amongst the attackers on that particular day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, there were those who were carrying machetes; others were carrying clubs, and they came to look for weapons that they were going to use.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: All right. Can you tell us from which of the three vehicles that those weapons were off-loaded from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: The weapons were in the Daihatsu, that was the second vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And do you recall some of the names of the people who received those weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I remember these people, in fact, most of them were in fact the names that I had mentioned earlier.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you, for the record, just go through the names very quickly, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: There was one Jean Munyangeyo. I spoke of one Martin Kanyamibwa, I mentioned -- yes, Jean Munyangeyo, Martin Kanyamibwa, Jean Rwamasasu, Nyagasaza, who was unemployed, and one Mathias.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Right. What time of the day was it that you saw this particular incident on that day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: When vehicles arrived at about eleven in the morning, but the operation was underway very quickly because there was the matter of the distribution of weapons and then the vehicles left.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So how long did Mr. Ndindabahizi stay where you saw him distributing the weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It took less than 30 minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now from where -- how far were you from the place you were hiding to the place where weapons were being distributed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I did not measure the distance, but I would say that it was between 25 and 50 metres -- 25 to 50 metres. I didn't measure the distance, but I think that the distance wouldn't be more than 50 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And when you talk of 25 to 50 metres, how long would that be in relation to the place you are seated? can you point some place within this courtroom or farther beyond where you estimate 25 metres to 50 metres to be?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: From where I am seated, one who have to go beyond the glass and add maybe another five metres, beyond the glass to the end of this courtroom.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what was the vegetation like between the place where you were hiding and the place where the three vehicles stopped?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It wasn't either a valley nor was it a desert, but there was a slight slope. There was a kind of a small hill or mound.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, when you said that in order to give an indication of the distance, it was between you and even longer than the glass wall, which glass wall, which wall on which side of the courtroom, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: I gave the example of that distance from that side where that camera is suspended up to the other end where there are other glass, in other words, the opposite direction.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. So one glass wall to the other glass wall, and according to the courtroom measurements, document we have in front of us here, it has been measured by the Court Management Section and from the glass of the translators' booth to the wall of the video booth, is about 21 metres. So that is on record.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, I am still at the place where you were hiding. Were you on an elevated position in relation to where Mr. Ndindabahizi was or was it the other way round?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was above the road. I was above the road. There was a slope and I was looking downward towards the road.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now let's focus at the place where you said you saw him park those vehicles. Was there anything special with that place? Was there any activity going around at that particular place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: At the place where the vehicles were parked there was a crossroad. In that place, a roadblock had been setup.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know when that roadblock had been setup?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: That roadblock was setup after the 15th around the 16th, because it is at that point in time that they began stopping people who wanted to go and hide. That happened at night and then they were killed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: In relation to hills, can you tell us that roadblock was between which hill and which hill, if you can?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: It was a roadblock number one, which was situated between Gitwa Hill and FM antennae, but from where the roadblock was up to the antennae, there was a longer distance, if you were to compare that distance between the roadblock and Gitwa Hill.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Right. Can you tell us, Mr. Witness, which direction Mr. Ndindabahizi took after the distribution of the arms?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: He went northwards.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Is that the direction from which he had come?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: No, he took the Kibuye road going towards Gitwa, but he didn't go in the same direction from which he had come.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us, Mr. Witness, whether there were any attacks after that date, the area you were hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: The following day there was an attack. It was somewhat an attack to assess the strength of the refugees, but that attack did not succeed because they repelled the attack, the refugees repelled the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now during the attack, did you see Mr. Ndindabahizi that day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: No, he was not in that attack, rather, the people to whom he had distributed the weapons were involved in that attack.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you name some of them whom you saw, who taken the -- who had received the weapons and took part in the attack on the second day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, these people were indeed involved in the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us their names, please, if you can recall them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: Yes, I can mention their names. Among others, there were those whom I had mentioned, but if you wish, I can repeat their names but they were many. Given the fact that these people were my neighbours and we shared everything, I was able to recognise them.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did you witness any attacks subsequent to that one, the one which took place around the 24th?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
sp.p: On the 25th, another attack was launched, but that attack failed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us why it failed, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CJY:
