sp.p: You cannot fail to recognise your paternal uncle or your neighbour or your own father, someone whom you already know; you cannot fail to recognise that person, even after one or two years, someone who was a neighbour, who works at a place which you know, to which you regularly went yourself. Let me give you an example: nine years ago the war took place, but I never asked anyone to show me this man; I recognised him immediately.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I have no further questions, Mr. President, for this Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Any redirect?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, one question; one or two questions.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, from the time Mr. Ndindabahizi embarked from the white Toyota car to the time you observed him throw a grenade to the attackers, how long did you say that was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: When he threw the grenade, the Interahamwe did the same and we ran. Some people were hit and fell, the others who were not touched continued to run. That's what happened.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I am interested to know the time span. It's important for me to understand how long it took from the time you disembarked from the vehicle to the time the attack started. Can you please try to tell us, give us an idea of the time span, the time it took?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: Several minutes didn't pass. I would say two minutes, one, two minutes, not any more than that.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And finally, you testified here that you were on a slope and Mr. Ndindabahizi was on -- by the roadside. Now, can you help us with the distance please? Can you estimate? We know you are not an agronomist, you cannot measure, but can you tell us roughly what you think was the distance between where you were hiding and where Mr. Ndindabahizi's car was parked by the road?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: It was a place where there were -- there were steps. All I -- I'd never been in that place before, and all I did was to try and run. I never tried to remain in one place, as myself, like the other young men, we ran, and people were shooting at us. There were no bushes; grenades were being thrown at us, and bullets were being shot. Some people were hit, and they fell, and we ran, because there were no bushes in which we could have hidden, and since it was in the open there were many deaths. Many people were killed. There were no bushes for them to hide, and grenades were thrown on the refugees. That is the description of the facts.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: That's all, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President. Excuse me, Mr. President. I would wish to tender as an exhibit the two written statements made by the witness. On the one hand, there is a matter of dates, which is an important issue for the Defence, because we are going to be developing a defensive alibi based on the dates which we have seen in the statement. As for the second statement, I am not very happy with the reasons given by the witness for the additions made to the statement, and thus, I would wish that the two statements, in English, and in French, be accepted, admitted as Defence exhibits. Your Honours, by your leave.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. So the first Defence exhibit will be the statement of the 26th of April 2001. That is D - registry?

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Twelve.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Twelve. So, D12A for the French, which is signed by the witness, and D12B for the English. And then the next exhibit -- is under seal, of course.

div.stage: EXhibit Nos. D12A and D12B admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Then the next exhibit, D13 of the 4th of June. Here we have D13A, English, signature of the Witness, and D13B, translation, both under seal again. So these are the exhibits. Thank you.

div.stage: EXhibit Nos. D13A and D13B admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: We would -- Mr. Witness, we would seek a little clarification. In your statement you said that Mr. Ndindabahizi was known to you well before the war, being a manager of a Trafipro store where you went to make purchases. In reply to your question, put by the learned Defence counsel, you said when you used to visit the store in connection with the purchases, "The Accused was in his office." How could you see him, whether he would come out of his office to see you, or whether you would go and meet him in his office?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: I didn't have to go and see him. I didn't have any reason for so doing. I went to that location in order to purchase several items. His office was next door; sometimes he was in there. But since his office was close to the place where the sales were done, I could see him. As for his -- as for the clothing, I would buy material or fabrics from which I had children's clothes made; sometimes I would wait throughout the day while waiting for their clothes to be made. You know, when you stay in a -- you stay for a day in a place, in a particular place, you can't fail to see the people who work there. Those are the conditions under which I got to know that man. There was a tailor who was there, and when I would -- I would spend some time with the tailor. You wouldn't be unable not to know the people who work in at that place. I would spend -- spend some time there, and I was quite close to them.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I would like to come back to the white car which you observed at Gitwa Hill. Which make did you say that car was? Did you recognise it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: It was a vehicle of the Toyota make, which had bars.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, your testimony has now come to an end. Thank you very much for coming to Arusha and giving evidence. We wish you a very safe journey home. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGV:
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. President, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the Witness could then be accompanied.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Prosecution, would it be useful with a little break now and then we have the next witness after the break? Would that be the way to proceed?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, that would be well appreciated, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. We'll then take the 15-minutes break and then we start with the next witness whose pseudonym is, please?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: CGL.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Court is adjourned.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good morning, or good afternoon, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT :
sp.p: You will be referred to as Witness CGL in these proceedings, and you have to tell the truth. The registry will now make the necessary arrangement to take your solemn declaration. Please.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness CGL in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, do you have a document in front of you there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is it your signature there at the bottom of the page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the personal information on that sheet is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. P18, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P18 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Prosecution, please.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours. Good afternoon, Madam Witness. Your Honours, might we have that document admitted as exhibit of Prosecution? Obliged.

div.stage: WITNESS CGL,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, did you at any time after the death of President Habyarimana in April 1994 see Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I saw him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Where did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I saw him at Rubengera.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Where in Rubengera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At the market.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: What is the name of this market?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was the Kibirizi market.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In which commune?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At the time it was known as Mabanza commune.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: When did he -- did you see Ndindabahizi at this market; when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was in 1994, in May.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: What time in May, Madam Witness? Was it the beginning of May, mid-May, towards the end of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was at the end of May.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Witness. How did you know it was Ndindabahizi when you saw him at the market at the end of May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It's because I knew him even earlier.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How long had you known him earlier?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was from 1993 that I had been seeing him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Where did you see him in particular in 1993?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I had seen him in Kirambo.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Where is Kirambo, Kirambo? Kirambo is spelled K-I-R-O-A-M-B-O (sic).

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Kirambo is in Gitesi commune.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Can you describe how you saw him in Kirambo in 1993?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He came to that place. He found me there. He spoke with a certain number of individuals, and it was then that I came to know him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How did he come to the place, Kirambo?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How many times did you see him in 1993?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I saw him twice.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Was it at the same Kirambo that you saw him twice or you saw him at Kirambo once and somewhere else once?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was at that same place. I had family in that place and I was going there to visit the family, and it would be on those occasions that I would see him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: On this second occasion you saw him, how did he come to Kirambo?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was then with people who are older than me, and these people said, "There is Ndindabahizi, who is greeting someone, and who is standing over there with the person he is greeting."

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So on the two occasions you saw Ndindabahizi at Kirambo, he was identified to you by some other people who were present. Is that your testimony, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, when I got to know him the first time I knew him, you understand. It's not necessary for him to be pointed out to me again, whereas I had already met him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Witness. So it is your testimony that the first time he was pointed to you by some older -- other people who were present, but the second time when you saw him, you already knew him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I already knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, in your statement to the investigators of the Tribunal, you did not state these circumstances that you had known Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel, before the occasion you saw him at the market. Why did you not state this to the investigators?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The reason is that I wasn't asked any questions connected to that.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Witness. On the day you saw Ndindabahizi towards the end of May 1994 at this market, what time was it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Since I wasn't wearing a watch, I wouldn't be able to tell you the specific time.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So was it in the morning, in the afternoon, in the evening or in the night?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I would say that it was between 11 a.m. and noon.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In your statement to the investigators of ICTR you say it was around noon; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You can understand that I wasn't wearing a watch. It was only an estimate of the time I was making.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Witness. Madam Witness, can you describe the man, Ndindabahizi Emmanuel, you saw on this day at the market; describe the person you saw that day, as you saw him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Are you referring to the occasion about which we have already spoken?

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: I am referring to the May 1994 occasion at the markets, Kirimbi (sic) ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He was a man whose complexion was between dark and light. His nose is more or less large and he is of average size.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How was he dressed on that day, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He was wearing a black suit.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Apart from Ndindabahizi, did you see another person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: There were other people.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Apart from other people you saw, did you see light vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, there were vehicles.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Two. There was one vehicle of the Daihatsu make and a saloon car.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Were there people in these vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, there was no one in the vehicles.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: When you saw Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel, Madam Witness, on this day, what was he doing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: When I arrived, he was together with other people. Actually I was going to the market because I had been sent to make some purchases, and when I arrived there they told me, "Let's go and listen to the minister who is speaking to people at a meeting." When I arrived, I realised that it was Ndindabahizi and that he was someone I already knew.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Do you know how many people were at the meeting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I didn't really count the people there, but I would say that there were between 50, five zero, and 100; and let me repeat that I did not count the people who gathered there.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, in your statement to the investigators of ICTR, you said there were over a hundred people. Can you explain that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was only making an estimate, I didn't count the people.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Where -- how far were you, Madam Witness, from where Ndindabahizi was standing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It's like the distance between where I am, up to the point where the Judges before me are seated.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, the distance between the witness and the Presiding Judge is, according to the courtroom measurements, 4.50 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Pleasure.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, at what point were you standing at that place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was standing behind those people.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: On that day were you able to hear Ndindabahizi say anything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I heard some of the words that he said.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He said, "In Kigali Tutsis have already been all killed, including Tutsi women who were married to Hutu men."

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Before I go to the next question, Madam Witness, why were you standing so close to Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I wasn't that close to him. I was behind the other people in attendance.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, what is your ethnic group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I am Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: You are Tutsi. Were you not afraid that they would recognise you and kill you as they had other times?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Since in my native village my parents had already been killed I had left my native village to go to a place where no one knew me. Moreover, my looks don't enable people who do not know me to identify me as a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Is that all the reasons why you were standing so close to Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes. In fact, I'm not a native of Rubengera. The inhabitants of Rubengera do not know me.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So you were not afraid because you didn't come from that area, you came from a different area, a different locality. Is that what you are telling this noble Court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In your testimony you told this Court that Ndindabahizi addressed the people telling them that Tutsi in Kigali have been killed, including Tutsi women married to Hutu men. When he made that statement what happened?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The Interahamwe got onto the vehicle and they took off the machetes which were in there and put them on the ground. People then shared out those machetes under the watchful eye of the Accused.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Who asked the Interahamwe to take out the machetes?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did anyone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did anyone ask the Interahamwe to take out the machetes, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Ndindabahizi, he was the one who told them to get into the vehicle and to take out the machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In which vehicle were these machetes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: In the Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Do you know how many machetes there were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No. I do not know.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In your statement to investigators you stated that there were 15 -- I mean 15 machetes were distributed to Interahamwe. Can you explain that, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, the sentence reads, "I also saw the machetes being distributed to 15 Interahamwe militia," which is slightly different, huh?

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Obliged, My Lord, that is exactly what I wanted to state.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, in your statement you stated, "I also saw 15 machetes being distributed to 15 Interahamwe militia". Can you explain that?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the sentence is, Madam Witness, "I also saw the machetes being distributed to 15 Interahamwe militia." That's the sentence in your statement. Did you say that to investigators?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, I said, regarding the machetes, that it was not the Accused who distributed the machetes, the machetes were offloaded, they were put on the ground, and then he called out to the people who were there so that they could take the machetes, and each person who was in that place was able to take one.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But the question now is the number, that's what Prosecution wants to elicit from you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I wouldn't be able to give you the number of the machetes, because I didn't count them.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Did you know the number of Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, I did not know the Interahamwe.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The question is did you know the number of Interahamwe leaders, that's what he's asking.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, I didn't know them. I do not know who their leader was. Maybe it was that man who gave them the weapons with which to go and kill people.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So, Madam Witness, you did not count the Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I do not know the number of those Interahamwe.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So what you stated was an estimate, not the exact number?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, that was a little bit leading, wasn't it?

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, what role did Ndindabahizi play in the distribution of these weapons?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did Mr. Ndindabahizi play any role in the distribution of these weapons, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, he played a role in the distribution of those machetes, because these machetes were in his vehicle, he was present when they were offloaded from the vehicle, and when the machetes were distributed to those in attendance he was present.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: After Ndindabahizi saw that the machetes were distributed as per his instructions, what happened?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He was applauded, and that was a sign which showed that the people were happy.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: What did he do, then, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He, too, was happy. He rejoiced together with the members, the people who were there.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: After that what happened, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Subsequently -- actually that's all I saw, and then I left after having seen the incident I just described. I went back home. I went to where I was living.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Who left that place first; was it you or Ndindabahizi, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I left first.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Why did you leave?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I had just heard instructions he had given, and I was saying to myself that people were going to scrutinize the area and would attack anyone, and that's why I decided to go home.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: At the time you were at that meeting point where Ndindabahizi was addressing this population distributing weapons, did you observe him properly? Was there anything obstructing you from seeing him properly?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I saw him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was there anything or anybody between you and Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: But I saw him, and when the people got to the place they said they were coming to see the Minister Ndindabahizi, and I myself when I got to the place, I immediately saw him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How long were you at the place before you left?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Thirty minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: You say when you left the place you went to where you were hiding. Where were you hiding -- or where you were living? Madam Witness, did you say that when you left that you went to the place where you were hiding or where you were living? Let me clarify this to the Court.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was to my hiding place.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Where were you hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was close to the market place, which we referred to.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Were you hiding in the bush? How can you explain it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was hiding in a house belonging to a family friend.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: A family friend. What was the ethnic group of the family friend?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He was Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you testified to the effect that you left your locality to go to this locality, to this area where you saw Ndindabahizi. Why did you leave your area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I left my locality because of the war. The attackers had killed my parents and members of my family, and our house was destroyed.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: In which commune was your locality?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was in Gitesi commune.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: You say your house was destroyed and there was a war. Can you explain for us what was happening in your locality before you escaped, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I did not understand your question, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you very much. I'm asking, you say your house was destroyed and there was a war. I want you to explain further, when you say there was a war in your locality.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Well, I meant the attacks mounted by the Hutus against the Tutsis, and we were the Tutsis, this is the war I'm referring to.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Madam Witness. Madam Witness, do you know whether Mr. Ndindabahizi was once Minister of Finance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No. I do know that he worked in the Ministry of Finance, but I do not know that he was a Minister of Finance.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: When do you know he worked in the Ministry of Finance; was that before the death of Habyarimana or after the death of Habyarimana, the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: This was before the death of the president.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Do you know where he lived, before the death of the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Well, you will understand that I was still very young and I didn't know where he lived. I didn't know where he lived.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: You've told this noble Court, Madam Witness, that he worked for the Ministry of Finance before the war. Where was that, the Ministry of Finance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The Ministry of Finance was in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: How long did you stay at your hiding place after you left the marketplace where you met Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I didn't understand your question, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: I'm asking how long you stayed in your hiding place with your Hutu friend after you left the market where you met Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel? How long did you stay there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: After I saw Ndindabahizi and the plans he had I went back home where I was hiding. I left what I was sent to go and buy and I went elsewhere.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Why did you leave that your hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I left because I had just heard the plan that had been drawn up.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: And how did you survive thereafter?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I continued hiding and I was changing hiding places continuously until the French arrived in Rwanda and they took me to the place called Nyarushishi.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Do you know when was that, Madam Witness, when the French arrived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I met the French in July, but I cannot recall the exact dates on which they came to Rwanda, because I was not in a position to know.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, how many of your family members were killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Five persons.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: They were my brothers and sisters, my siblings.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Madam Witness, do you know whether some people were killed after this meeting by Mr. Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel, at the market and the distribution of weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, people were killed, because the killings continued in our locality until June.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: So you said you lost five members of your family, brothers and sisters. How many survived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: None survived except myself.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Let's come back to this day toward the end of May 1994 when you saw Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel. If you see the man, Ndindabahizi, Emmanuel, that you saw on that day, in this Court, would you identify him, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I can identify him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Your Honours, I will be seeking your indulgence for the witness to stand up and look around the court to see if she can identify Mr. Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Will you stand up, Madam Witness, and see if you see anyone you know in this courtroom.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I have identified him. I have identified him.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Can you describe where he is, what he's wearing, how he looks like? Mr. Ndindabahizi is in this court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He's seated at the back next to someone wearing a uniform, and the uniform has buttons that look white. That person is sitting next to Emmanuel Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: What is he wearing, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He's wearing a jacket, a tie, and a shirt, a white shirt. I believe the shirt is white.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, is that the person you saw towards the end of May 1994 at the market Kibirizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, he is the one, because if I had not seen him at that time, I would not have been able to recognise and identify him today.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Please take your seat, madam. Please, thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Would the records, Your Honours, reflect that the witness has identified the Accused.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Noted.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. President, here I would like to refer to Article 6 of the European Convention. Since the beginning, the identification of the witness is unfair, given the fact that in the courtroom coloured people are either in legal robe or in uniform. Only the Accused person is in civilian uniform, and this is a violation, a fundamental violation of the European Convention in relation to what we will refer to as a fair trial.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This goes on the record. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, have you at any time discussed your testimony you have given to this Court with anybody?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, I have not discussed my testimony with anybody.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: That will be all, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Defence, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, Your Honours, it's Mr. Marçais who will conduct the cross-examination, but I would like to draw the Court's attention to the fact that we are moving away from the indictment. Nowhere is Mr. Ndindabahizi accused of having made a speech or having gone to the Mabanza commune. I don't know where the Prosecution is going with this testimony, but I thought it was necessary to draw the Court's attention to this, that this testimony does not correspond to any paragraph of the indictment. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you for that remark. I'm sure the Prosecution will come back to that in due course, and so will you in your closing arguments. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you able to recall to the Court how you are able to remember on 27th of May, 2001, that is, seven years later, the Accused, and for the first time, given the testimony -- or the statement that you gave, not in your residence but in another place, that is, Bethany in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was not living with my parents.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Initially, did the investigators from the ICTR come to your parents or to your house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The ICTR investigators came where I was living.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And it is at that time that they told you that they were bringing a case against Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, it is the investigators who worked on that case.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was it the investigators who told you that they were bringing a case against Mr. Ndindabahizi and that they were inviting you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: They invited you to come to Bethany guest house in Kibuye to give a statement?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Regarding my testimony, my statement, I kept that in my heart. They were not the ones going to tell me what to say in my statement.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Have you ever testified -- had you testified in the Rwandan courts, in any of the courts of first instance, Gacaca court, before this interview?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I did testify in the court of first instance.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Had you already testified before the Gacaca court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, I never testified before any of the Gacaca courts.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: When you testified before the court of first -- the Kibuye court of first instance, were you a victim or did you indicate to the court that you had been a victim of the events of 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Which criminal events are you referring to?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you have just told me that you already testified before the court of first instance in Kibuye. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, I want you to indicate the acts that you denounced and the fact that you did not speak about the alleged acts of Mr. Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: In any event, I was testifying, an accused before that court. At that time, it was not Ndindabahizi. Today it's the turn of Ndindabahizi, and that's what I am doing.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you waited for the -- can you look towards me, Madam Witness? Don't look elsewhere.So you waited for the investigators of the ICTR to come and invite you to the Bethany guest house to testify and to recount the acts that you are recounting today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: In my testimony before the court of first instance, Kibuye court of first instance, I gave -- I made the statement -- I gave that testimony before (sic) the investigators of the ICTR came to interview me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, can you repeat under oath what you have just said? Can you repeat what you've just said under oath, with the knowledge that you are under oath?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Which answer are you talking about?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Please listen to me. You just said that you testified before the Kibuye court of first instance after testifying -- after you gave your statement to the ICTR investigators. I want you to repeat that with the knowledge that you under oath.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: My testimony before the Kibuye court of first instance was done after my statement in relation to Ndindabahizi. So I made a statement in relation to the Ndindabahizi case, and then I gave my testimony in the Rwandan courts, in the Kibuye court of first instance.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The Defence reserves the right to enter on the record a document indicating that witness is not telling the truth.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that something you are going to distribute now?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It's a document that I have only in the Kinyarwanda, which I will have translated. It was forwarded to me recently. I will have it translated into English and French, and it demonstrates that the witness is not telling the truth, and this under oath.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But if that's the case, I think you should show that document to the witness because she reads Kinyarwanda, of course, and then she can comment upon it.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I would like the registry to show this document to the Court and the witness for her to indicate if this, indeed, is her.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Here there are two yellow markings. Are you referring to those two yellow spots, Defence counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I am referring to the surname which has been highlighted in yellow, which is supposed to be the surname of the witness, and I want to know if that indeed is her name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I see number 20.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I do not have the document. I don't have a copy, Mr. President. I have only that copy which was given to me recently.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: This is really, really below the belt. This is so objectionable. It is untrue. My learned friend has deliberately laid an ambush for the witness, and it turns out that there is no relationship between this name and this witness, and he knows it. He knows it, too. There's absolutely no relationship whatsoever between the name here and this witness. Every other name mentioned here has a first name. Now, a first name is mentioned here that bears no relationship with this witness, and I ask that the Defence be sanctioned and disciplined. It is absolutely unprofessional behaviour to lay an ambush in such a manner, and we'll be looking to enter this as a Chamber exhibit, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, look at number 20 there. That seems -- don't mention that name and don't read it out loud, but is that your name in that document, yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That is not me. No, that is not me. This does not refer to me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Could we see this paper once again?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Kinyarwanda booth, what does mwene mean, M-W-E-N-E? What does it mean in English and French?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Mr. President, it depends on the person involved. It could be daughter of or son of.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I see, all right. That was, in itself, useful. If you could bring that back to the Defence, then. And we note the witness's answer, and we also note the Kigali booth's translation of the word mwene, and we note paragraph 8 of this witness's particulars.Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The issue is simple on this matter. Investigations will be conducted. We've concluded on that issue. The witness has already testified before courts -- the court of first instance.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, in the trial in which she testified, is it concluded today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: This case is not yet concluded, but I have given my testimony, and I went back to live at home.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I repeat my question -- withdrawn. Let me move on to the next issue.You did say a while ago, Madam Witness -- if I quote exactly what you said, are you able to clarify the following sentence which I find in your written statement: "I knew Emmanuel Ndindabahizi as a minister of finance in the government of President Habyarimana"?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I did not say he was a minister. I said he worked in the ministry of finance. I think the person who recorded my statement made a mistake. That was not my statement.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I realise I'm referring to your written -- your written statement, which is signed. What is your field of study, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I have not had any. I did not have any studies. I don't have any educational standard.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In April 1994, were you a student?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I attended the school called *************, but to my knowledge, there was nothing special about that kind of training.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You confirm what you said in your written statement, that you were still in the primary school in 1994?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Your statement said, "When I was in primary school in 1994." I'm only reading what you wrote -- what you said.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Can't you see that those who recorded the statement made a mistake? Were there students going to school during the war?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, I'm trying to understand your statement. You wrote, "I knew Emmanuel Ndindabahizi as the minister of finance in the government of President Habyarimana." You said I was wrong, it was wrongly recorded. "When I was in primary school in 1994," and you said that was wrong. The investigator got it wrong. Well, I think regarding this investigator, I think the Prosecutor needs to give us some instructions.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You understand that I saw him when I was still in primary school; however, in 1994 I was in the school called ****************.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. Now, let's move on to your meeting with Mr. Ndindabahizi. Well, there are three questions here: where, when, and on what occasion; that is, which date and what occasion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: We meet in Kirambo. Regarding the date and the month, I do not recall that; however, I recall the year. It was in 1993. That is when I met him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, on how many occasions? Once? Twice?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Are you referring to the pre-war period?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Counsel needs to pause, and we missed the beginning of his question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I would like to know where in Kirambo, when, and how many times, and on what occasion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: There was a health centre at that place, and he was greeting the people there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: On how many occasions in 1993 did Mr. Ndindabahizi come to that health centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The only occasion -- the only occasions that I -- I saw him only on two occasions. If he came there on other occasions, I am not aware.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In what capacity did he go there, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I don't, I don't know in what capacity he went there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, this gentleman allegedly came to the health centre. I don't want to put -- ask leading questions, but what did he come to do there? Was it to visit someone? Was he on mission, a mission that had been assigned to him? Explain yourself, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: How do you expect me to know the mission that he came to accomplish in that place?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What was his function at the time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I know he worked in Kigali. Beyond that, I don't know. I have no details on that beyond the fact that he worked in the ministry of finance.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were you introduced to him or was he introduced to you? On that question, did you see him among other persons or was he introduced personally to you, still based on your own assertions?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: There was someone who was with me. We were in Kirambo, you see. That's a health centre. So the person spoke to him -- spoke about him to me, spoke about him to me, and I knew about whom he was speaking.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did he speak to you personally, Madam Witness, or did he -- or did you speak to him personally?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, he didn't speak to me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This health centre, Madam Witness, what kind of centre was it? Why did people go there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: People go there to be treated. Maybe some people go there to meet people who work there, I believe.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you go there to be treated? Yes or no, no details.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you have any indication whether Mr. Ndindabahizi went there to be treated or was he there for some other reason?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: He wasn't there to get treatment.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: How you do know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was also there, but I didn't see him go into the consulting room for consultation. He was standing with people; he was greeting them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: All that seems to be surprising, Madam Witness. Did he work with the ministry of finance or the ministry of health?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Do you think that someone goes to a health centre because he works in the umbrella ministry, the ministry of health? One can also go there for some other reason.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Is a health centre, which is several hundred kilometres from the capital, a place to go and take a walk, somewhere which is so far from one's place of work?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Since he is a native of that commune, there could be people whom he wanted to visit.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So he was visiting the people who were at this health centre? Is it a health centre where one would be an in-patient in order to have treatment? Is it like a hospital? Do they have beds there for people to sleep in?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Well, in any case, I can say that he was a native of that area. Maybe he had relatives or family members whom he wanted to visit, I don't know. Those are the possibilities.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It's for my own information. My question is, was it somewhere like a hospital where one can sleep, where one must sleep if one is receiving treatment?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Prosecutor, allow me to conclude my question.

div.stage: Previous translation continues...) answer this question. I don't know. My colleague is just going around and around. The witness has answered the question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Non, non.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No, but it's -- answer that question, Witness, because that particular question hasn't been answered.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, there is a hospital.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So, there is a health centre; it's not only a dispensary or where you can get out-patient treatment. Maybe it's also a place where you can receive treatment over several days. That's my question. Do you understand it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I told you that it was a health centre; however, there is a hospital where seriously ill patients can be hospitalised before they are transferred to the central hospital in Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well, Madam Witness. So you do not know specifically on what occasion, but you have just given us some clarification on those theories. Madam Witness, you're a Tutsi, are you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please tell us the following: You stated that you went to the Kibilizi market, but now I want to know, on what date did you go to the market? I am specifying on what day -- date did you actually travel to that market?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You see, it's quite likely that I do not recall that date. It was a long time ago. Moreover, given the circumstances of the time, we were not even thinking that we would have to report on these incidents; therefore, I don't remember the date very well.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, this date is very important for me. I do understand your difficulties, but you did indicate that you lived in Gitesi and that you were going to the market, the Kibilizi market in Rubengera commune. Now, what I want to know -- I am not asking you about the date or day that you travelled there, that you be exact, but I want to know when it was that you travelled to Kibilizi market in Rubengera.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I do not remember the date.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: This is a question which is very important for the Defence. I don't want us to accept some kind of vagueness, and the Tribunal should take due note of this. The events of May - April 1994 are of such importance that such imprecision about this date should not be allowed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We know that the witness has said end of May. Next question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please tell me, Madam Witness, where you stayed in April and May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was staying in Mabanza at this specific place known as Kibilizi. Actually, are you asking me about this specific place where I lived?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, but also about people who provided you with shelter.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: There is the Kibilizi area and then there is the stadium. There was also Gitwa in Karongi area. It was in those places that I hid until the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: When you went to the Kibilizi market in Rubengera, did you take any particular precautions?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I do not quite understand that question, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: All right, Madam Witness. You were changing your commune. You travelled for more than 15 kilometres. The maps that the Tribunal has -- were there any roadblocks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, there were some, but I don't go by those roadblocks. I would, rather, go through the bushes. I didn't have any authority to go by the roadblocks.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I wouldn't say prudent, but wasn't it very dangerous to travel around these areas? You mentioned the place near the market. Wasn't it a bit dangerous on your part?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At the time, in order to get to the Kibilizi market, in fact, I was nearby that place and it was a place which -- at which no one knew me, and the fact that those people didn't know me enabled me to get rid of my fear, and that is why I was not afraid.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You don't even mention that in your statement, but a moment ago you said that you were hiding with Hutu friends, and now you're telling me that you're hiding elsewhere. What is the truth? Could you try and edify us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You are speaking about other places. What other places are you talking about? I am talking about Kibilizi, and the person in whose house I was, was in Kibilizi. Now, as for the stadium, when I refer to the stadium I am telling you that there's no house. And then in Karongi as well, I was hiding in the bushes. But, now, when I was hiding in someone's house, a Hutu, that was in Kibilizi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, when did you move from Gitwa to Kibilizi? I need to know that. Approximately, to the nearest day possible if you cannot --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: When I left Gitwa, I didn't go directly to Kibilizi. You see, I cannot remember the date, and I have told you that.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Give us the period or the specific date on which you left Gitwa to Kibilizi, during this period of time which was undergoing so many difficulties?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: When I left Gitwa, I didn't go immediately to Kibilizi. I hid elsewhere, someone -- someplace other than Kibilizi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It's unfortunate for the Defence, for us, not to obtain more preciseness about this movement, despite our thousand and one questions. Where was the rest of your family when you went to Kibilizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The members of my family were already dead.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So why were you at the Kibilizi market making purchases? For whom did you go there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was for the owners of the house in which I was living.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: People who are of Hutu origin are hiding you because you are in danger, and then they send you to the market?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: These people were not worried about that particular issue because they knew that I was not a native of the area; consequently, they thought that I was not in danger.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: That's not my question, Madam Witness. These people thought you were in sufficient danger for them to want to hide you. Is that true or not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, they were aware. They themselves knew the place from which I came.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I am putting my question to you back again. So, these people are aware of the danger you -- risks you were running and they agreed to hide you, but they send you to the market in full view of the rest of the population living around?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I think I have given my explanation on that, the reason why that was done. I have told you that I could move about because I was not a native of that secteur. It's only the person who was hiding me knew my origins.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, in that house, no one would have been able to denounce you as a Tutsi. The people who lived in that house or the neighbours couldn't have done that, could they?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: There was no mention anywhere that I was a Tutsi. Given my features, it's -- they are not different from those of others. And furthermore, I didn't have any identity papers.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At the marketplace, you say you had already met Mr. Ndindabahizi who may have recognised you, if we were to believe you. Now, you hear Emmanuel Ndindabahizi threaten Tutsis with death, and you continue to remain in that market for 30 minutes. Is that what you did?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I made reference to the 30 minutes, and that's when he held the meeting, after I had reached the place, but that does not include the duration which elapsed after the meeting was held. Moreover, he himself did not know my origins as a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I am not specialist, but I think Hutus and Tutsis know one another. In your written statement you state, "I was able to note that the majority of the attendants were of Hutu ethnic group." Let me repeat: "I was able to note that the majority of the attendants were of Hutu ethnic group." How were you able to do that? How would you have known that the majority of the people there were of the Hutu ethnic group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: During that occasion, no one else was suspecting except -- no one else, except for Hutus, could attend such meetings. Had a person from another ethnic group appeared at the meeting, that would have cost him or her his life - his or her life.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: If a Hutu came to such a meeting, he would be risking his life; is that what you are saying, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is the translation correct there?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I believe so, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you say -- what did you say?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I was repeating the question -- the witness's answer in the form of a question. Maybe I made a slip of the tongue.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You said that if a Hutu (sic) person had ventured at that meeting, that person would be killed. Is that what you were trying to say, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, you are attributing -- you are putting words in my mouth. I didn't say that. The persons who would have been killed were Tutsis, because it was the Tutsis who were targeted by the killings at that time.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You say, Madam Witness, that the majority were of Hutu ethnic group. You used the term "majority." Can you explain that term, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: What do you want to know with regard to that term "majority"? I do not understand what you are looking for.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you used the term and I am repeating your sentence. I don't have any comment on it. "I was able to note that the majority of the attendants were of Hutu ethnic group." So, I have two questions for you. How were you able to realise that difference? You gave me an answer, and I am inquiring from you to explain to me the word majority, which is not the same as the totality of the people who were there. So can you please explain that for me?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Let me give you an example. I was there as a Tutsi, whereas the others were Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The wording, Madam Witness, does this imply that you saw any Tutsi there, apart from yourself?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, on that occasion there was also another person of Tutsis origin who was with me, and it's possible that we were not the only ones to have been at that specific moment. Maybe there were other persons who were Tutsis whose features did not enable one to identify them as such.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you recognised at least one other person who was of Tutsi origin. Did you know that person, individually as a person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you write that person's name on a piece of paper today for us, because we may wish it verify what you are saying.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You understand that this was during the war. The war was ongoing at that time. So, we were together in that place, but that person died subsequently.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. Furthermore, you say, Madam Witness, that Ndindabahizi spoke to two Interahamwe. Can you specify and explain to the Court how you came by determining that they were Interahamwe? Were they wearing uniforms? Were they carrying any weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At any rate, I found them in a place where the meeting was taking place, and amongst the people who were there, I could distinguish between those who were Interahamwe and those who were not.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How did you make that distinction, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: First of all, they were happy of the fact that the Accused had just given them weapons, and I could see that they were happy. I could hear what was being said.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were they wearing any uniform, any disguise or any particular type of clothing for you to be able to identify them as being Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At the time when they were going to perpetrate the killings, they were wearing banana leaves. Now, they had come to attend a meeting. You understand that war attire is different from what one wears when one is going to attend a meeting.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: My question is, on that day, were they wearing banana leaves? So I'll repeat my question: Since that day they were not wearing banana leaves, how were you, from the outset, able to identify them as being Interahamwe? Was it because they were carrying weapons and the type of weapons they may have been carrying, if they were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was able to determine that they were Interahamwe because I had seen that their spirits were at their highest when they received the weapons.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you identified them. You understood or concluded that they were Interahamwe afterwards, but you didn't identify them previously, as you had indicated in your witness statement. Another question: Is it the reaction of satisfaction which makes you understand that they were Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, it's true. Add to that the fact that they left together with the machetes. They took the machetes away with them, and why would have taken those machetes with them?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did these Interahamwe not have machetes already, at least some of them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Maybe they had some, but at that time they had come to attend a meeting. They hadn't come to perpetrate killing, so they did not come armed with their machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But you did not recognise the Interahamwe by the weapons that they were carrying or the uniforms that they were wearing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I knew them. They were indeed Interahamwe. Tell me, if they were not Interahamwe, why did they then take those machetes? Why did he give them the instructions he gave them? Wasn't it because they were in a plan and they knew what they wanted to do?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At no time whatsoever were these machetes given to the persons that you identify as Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, according to what I saw, those people whom I saw were the only ones who received the machetes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Am I correct in saying that you found people who were not in uniform, not armed, at a marketplace, and you say from the outset that -- and also it's a commune where you are not native, and you immediately jump to the conclusion that they are Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: But, you see, there were other people at the meeting place and they did not take the machetes. So why were these persons taking the machetes, whereas others who were also there did not take the machetes?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you would define an Interahamwe by the fact that such a person takes up a machete?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No. I myself can take a machetes, someone else can take a machete without it being necessary that we be Interahamwe, but these people were Interahamwe. They carried out murderous expeditions and they had passed by where I was. I have told that you that was not my native region and people did not know me, and I could see everything that was happening, and I could see the actors, the perpetrators, and I was seeing them with my own eyes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, let's go to cars or vehicles, Madam Witness. Do you know types of vehicles, makes of vehicles?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: No, not really. I did not study mechanics or sciences of automobile, if there is any such type of science. I did do some primary education and I'm from a rural area, but I tried to identify the vehicles that I saw.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I'm sorry, Mr. President, we only got half of that question.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could you repeat your question, Counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What was the make of the vehicle in which Mr. Ndindabahizi sat?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: When I got there, there were two vehicles parked there next to where the people were; the people who were at the place were standing.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You claim you saw a car and you said it was Mr. Ndindabahizi's car. Can you tell the Court the make of the car?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: The make of the car? Well, I don't know it. I don't know. I know it was a saloon car and I know its colour, but I don't know its make.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You don't know makes of cars very well?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, when you stated -- when you stated that the car was blue, was it suggested to you that it was a Daihatsu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: How can you say that? You think the investigators would ask me questions and then they think in my place?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: No, I was just asking you if the investigators asked you whether the blue pick-up was of a Daihatsu make.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: They asked me the following question: "What was the make of that vehicle?" And I answered that it was a Daihatsu and that is the vehicle that I saw.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It is because a while ago you indicated that you did not know makes of cars and does not -- does that not look like a contradiction?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You are talking about make. Maybe I don't know what you mean by make, but I know Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you sure that you are not getting it wrong? There were all sorts of pick-ups; there is Toyota, there is Daihatsu. You did say that you don't know makes of the cars or models of cars but that it's a Daihatsu.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, because I know Daihatsu. But when you say in French the marke, meaning the make of the car, I don't know what you mean because I don't understand that kind of French.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, Daihatsu is not a French word, it's a Japanese word. I asked you a question a while ago about makes of cars and you said you didn't know about makes of cars and then suddenly you are talking about makes of cars. I think the Court will assess that evidence. That takes me to my last questions. Do you confirm that Mr. Ndindabahizi himself was not carrying a weapon?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: From what I saw, no.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Beginning of counsel's question, please.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What were the provisions that you bought?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Well, I was asked to buy provisions and that is what I did. I bought provisions which I was asked to buy.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you recall which provisions you bought?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I don't think you need to know that. I don't find that necessary.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I'm not asking you if it is necessary, I'm only asking you if you do remember.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you sure, Madam Witness, that during the tragic event of May 1994 that the Kibilizi market was operating, that farmers would go there and sell their produce?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, those who had the authorisation to go there and were not targets of the killings could go there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Am I right to say that the market was operating and that those people who were not targeted for killing could freely go to such -- to the market?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, people were going to the market.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You went to the market to buy provisions and then you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi. You got close to him, and then you went back home.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I bought my provisions, then I went back where I was hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In the house belonging to Hutus; that is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And you brought back the provisions that they asked you to buy?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How soon thereafter did you leave?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I left that family immediately and I went to hide elsewhere.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Beginning of counsel's question. We can't keep guessing what counsel is saying with each question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Given what I've just heard, I felt in a situation of insecurity. I felt insecure.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It is therefore based on the statement of Mr. Ndindabahizi, end of May 1994, that you decided to flee because you felt you were in a situation of insecurity?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes. I felt threatened. I was not feeling safe in the area in which I was hiding and I thought it was no longer proper for me to hide in that area.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And you confirm one last time that this was towards the end of May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you able to tell the Court when you left this Hutu house next to the market where you went?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I went to the Ruragwe secteur, R-U-R-A-G-W-E.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. President, I would like to request once again that the written statement of the witness be entered as an exhibit in relation to -- given the fact that the contradictions between the written statement and the oral testimony are extensive. I'm done, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Something coming out in my headphones but you want this exhibited?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, that is my request, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the English version is the "A" version and the French is the "B" version, and the number is 14. 14 A and B then, under seal.

div.stage: Defence Exhibit Nos. 14A and 14B admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I have concluded, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Thank you very much. Any re-examination?

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Just one question, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, would I be correct to say that you went to that place where Ndindabahizi was at the market because your facial look does not look like a Tutsi. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Are you talking to me, Prosecutor?

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: I'm talking to madam witness, yes. Can I repeat the question, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I did not understand your question, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Madam Witness, I was asking you that am I correct to say that it's your testimony that while you stood at the meeting place where Ndindabahizi was and you were not afraid, it was because you do not look like a Tutsi, your facial look is not like a Tutsi. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. TAFAH:
sp.p: Your Honours, I would pray Your Honours to remind themselves of the appearance of the witness throughout these proceedings. Most obliged. That would be all, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you were a stranger in this area and you had no identity papers. Is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Wasn't that a dangerous situation to move around without an ID paper in an area where you were not known?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Given my age, one could not suspect that I was of age where I needed to carry an ID document around with me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Why do you say that? I'm aware of the year when you were born and we know that this was in '94, why do you put it that way, please; can you help me?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I was short and one would take me for a child, and one cannot guess my real age.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Ah-ha, so you are saying you looked young. Is that your statement?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Ah-ha, I see.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Madam Witness, could you tell us, why did you go to the health centre where you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi? What made you to go to the health centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I accompanied somebody who was going to consult -- who was going for medical care.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Was that person Hutu or Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That person was a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You were not afraid of going to the health centre, both you Tutsi, in such a dangerous situation?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: But, Your Honour, this was in 1993; this was not in 1994.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Okay, thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When did you finish primary school? At what age did you finish primary school, Madam Witness? How old were you when you left primary school?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: You mean when I finished primary school? Well, I was 14 years old.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That was quite some time before you visited the health centre, wasn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I did not understand your question, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There were many years between the last year in primary school and when you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi at the health centre in 1993. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes. Yes, I was sufficiently grown up and sufficiently intelligent to be able to recognise him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And this other education -- did you say that you attended the *************, was that where you then moved to? What was your next educational step, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes, I attended ***************.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Just give us an indication what that is or at least the spelling of it. Could you do that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: ****************************. It's like a vocational school where you l*****************.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And for how many years would one usually spend? How many years would you usually be at that training centre until you have finished school there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I did only one year at *************** and I -- after that I did not continue with my training ********* is**********************

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you had then finished primary school at the age of 14, and then you went on for one year at the ***********. Is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And you would then be 15 years old when you finished the ***************?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But did I understand you to say that you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi when you were at the beginning of your post-primary education; in other words, at the beginning of the ******************? Was that what you testified?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: I don't think I understood the question clearly.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When you saw the person at the health centre who may have been Mr. Ndindabahizi in 1993, were you then in primary school?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: At one point in time, I left school and then I went back, such that while in school I was virtually an adult. Such that in 1993 I was, as I said, undergoing a training **********************.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This may not be significant, Madam Witness, but I do not understand this. First I understood you to say that you finished primary school at the age of 14, and that you then started immediately afterwards at ***************, and that would bring us to 15. But previously it was my understanding that it was during your education at primary school or ****** that it was that you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi. Now, what is it that I do not understand?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was at the beginning of ************* that I saw him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And didn't that start when you were 14?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: In fact, I do not recall because I had to repeat some classes, and at some point in time my parents withdrew me from school. In fact, I was -- I didn't think clearly about the years when I was answering.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So does this imply that you are not quite sure of the year you saw Mr. Ndindabahizi or are you maintaining that it was in '93? Are you uncertain about the year you saw him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: It was in 1993.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, thank you very much for coming to the Tribunal. Your testimony has come to an end. We wish you a very safe journey home. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGL:
sp.p: Thank you, too.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If you could just wait for a little moment while we wind up here for about one minute. So this was the third witness?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: This was the third witness, Your Honour, and in relation to this witness we do have an application to make to the Court.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: In the presence of the witness?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Not necessarily.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No. Madam Witness, if you could -- Registry if you could kindly assist the witness. Yes, Mr. Phillips.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Grateful, Your Honour. Your Honour, I make a very quick application under the provisions of Rule 46 of Rules of Procedure and Evidence of this Tribunal. The basis for my application is that counsel for the Defence's conduct in this courtroom this evening warrants a warning under that rule, and that the trial Chamber is at liberty to consider sanctions as may deem appropriate. The factual basis for my motion under Rule 46 is as follows: that today, the 16th of September 2003, during the cross-examination of Witness CGL, a witness called by the Prosecution, counsel for the Defence put improper questions to that witness in cross-examination. We submit, respectfully, to Your Honours that the questions put to Witness CGL were not put to her in good faith, and more importantly, they were not made in the legitimate -- with the legitimate objective of impeaching Witness CGL's credibility. Rather, we submit to Your Honours that those questions, those improper questions, were posed to slander that witness, to destroy her reputation before this Trial Chamber and, more seriously, to mislead Your Honours into believing that that witness had made false representations before this Chamber. We say that the representations were not made in good faith because counsel for the Defence had witness statements before them. In that regard, I refer Your Honours to paragraph 1 of page 176 of your witness bundle. You would find there a witness statement dated the 27th of February 2001 in English, and if you are looking at your French bundle it would be paragraph 1 at page 180 of the French version. It clearly states the witness's name. I further refer Your Honours to paragraph 8 on page 177 of the English bundle, and paragraph 8 of page 181 of the French bundle, which refers to the particulars of her parents. My learned friend for the Defence had a document in his hand which clearly indicated not only the witness's name but, indeed, that of either of her parents. We there say -- we therefore say that having been faced with such material, it was improper and a deliberate attempt to mislead the Trial Chamber to represent falsely to both the witness, Your Honours, and, indeed, the Prosecution, that the witness had indeed made a false representation. We ask Your Honours to consider the sanctions available under Rule 46A, B and C of the Rules of Procedure of this honourable Court. Those are my submissions, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Defence, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President. Very respectfully, we do not believe that Mr. Marçais had conduct which was offensive or harmful to warrant a warning pursuant to Rule 46A. Therefore, we are relying on this rule, but no warning has been given to Mr. Marçais; however, we are in a trial which is very special, Mr. President, Your Honours, one in which we need to determine on a daily basis and on an early basis, the evidence. And we also -- it is up to us to determine the credibility of the witness. That is our duty. Sometimes we do this rather hurriedly. And it is true that we have obtained this morning a ruling on this matter, but what is the harm done? The witness had the opportunity to express herself and verify and to tell us that the name was -- her name was not the one on the statement in question. It is also a possibility that the Prosecution does make mistakes from time to time and the document -- and sometimes they say that the witnesses they have not arrived. Mr. Marçais was trying legitimately to carry out he is duty in relation to this witness and he did not have the intent to be offensive or misleading and he did not wish to mislead the Tribunal either. And I, therefore, on that basis, wish to you to dismiss the application made by the Prosecutor because it has no basis whatsoever. I thank you, Mr. President, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And did the Defence, when these questions were asked, know that he word Umwena means son or daughter of?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone for counsel, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The answer is no, Mr. President. We only knew it a few -- we only received the document a moment earlier and we had not had the opportunity to have it translated and, therefore, we were misdirected possibly by the similarity in the names -- of the surnames of the witness and the name on the document we had in hand.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
