As far as that witness is concerned, she will talk about things that occurred in a small cellule of the Kibuye préfecture. It's a cellule where she always lived in, and she lives there still, and it's a location of crimes described in the indictment. Now, the person we are referring to could be easily identified. That person is one of the survivors, and there are not many survivors from that préfecture -- from that cellule, but I do remember that the Prosecutor, on the basis of these very same circumstances, had applied for a sitting in camera, which was granted. I shall therefore question the witness concerning the location at which the witness was, and probably these questions may reveal the witness's identity, so that I will be compelled to apply for a sitting in camera for this particular witness as compared to the others. We shall try to limit ourselves in time to ensure that the sitting in camera is done properly, but I would not be able to assure you that we will exhaust all the questions in this sitting in camera, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, your application for the closed session under Rule 79, does it apply to the entire testimony of the witness, because of the particular nature of the evidence, or are you only saying that you want to start in closed session?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I shall try for as much as possible to limit the closed session. I shall try to finish with the closed session and go on to more general questions, but I'm not quite sure this will be possible, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Any problems, Prosecution? Could you indicate approximately for how long we would have to close this session so that the public could come back again at a certain time? Approximately?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Well, 45 minutes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much for that indication. Well, I must say then that we have to close this session in pursuance of Rule 79, but you have heard the indication of Mr. Besnier, and we will open as far as this will be possible in the interests of the witness. So Registry, make sure that the public gallery is being closed. Thank you very much.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 6 to 37] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who informed you of the existence of a roadblock in Gasharu cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: It was my mother; in other words --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness has mentioned the relationship between himself.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, please remember that we are in a closed session, so you never, for instance, mention names of your close relatives. Now, please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: From your observation, Mr. Witness, what did Emmanuel Ndindabahizi do or say during his visit to that cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: When he came into the cellule he made the killings to be stopped. He asked the members of the population why they were killing people. He even arrested one person, one man, and put him in detention. And this person was put into detention because it had been said that that person had killed people; Ndindabahizi had been informed of that. And from that day onward no one else was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you, yourself, remember the date on which you left your hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I was hiding in two different places. I left the first hiding place in the beginning of June after Ndindabahizi's departure from the cellule, and I left the second hiding place on the 4th of July.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the cellule you were living in, were there any other Tutsi survivors?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, there are.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Have you had discussions as genocide survivors regarding the events that took place in Rwanda in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, we speak a lot about these events.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: From the end of the war did you ever hear the name of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi mixed with killings, or did you ever hear his name being mentioned as being a perpetrator of whatever crimes during the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No. Sometimes on the radio one hears that he is in prison, but we are saying that these allegations are false. His name has never been involved with any responsibility whatsoever for crimes committed during the genocide.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What I meant to say, Mr. Witness, is that you are indeed a Tutsi, are you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, I am a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And your father was indeed killed during the genocide, was he not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are there any reasons why you would wish to be testifying on behalf of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi and not necessarily have anything to do with the respect for the truth?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question, Counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would you have any personal reasons for defending Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, despite the fact that you are a Tutsi and that you were nonetheless a genocide survivor?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, I do have reasons, and the reason is that I am defending him because if he hadn't come to the cellule all the Tutsis who survived would not have remained alive.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, Your Honours, I have no further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Prosecution, please. Can you start in open for a while, Mr. Phillips?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is it your testimony, sir, that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi visited Gasharu cellule in the month of June 1994 and not before then in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Actually, Ndindabahizi visited the cellule in the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, that's what I thought you said. How come is it then that the Tutsis alive owed their good fortune to him? The last thing you said a few minutes ago was that he -- his intervention saved the lives of Tutsi. Now, at the beginning of June, how many Tutsi who were alive were walking the streets of Gasharu? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: After Ndindabahizi's departure, there were Tutsis who were still alive in Gasharu.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, certainly. And I'm sure those Tutsis were walking around, walking through roadblocks, were they not, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No. As for moving around, around roadblock (sic), nobody would go there, but in July all Tutsis could come out of their houses.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. And that's thanks to Mr. Ndindabahizi, is it not, as far as you are concerned?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, with regard to our cellule that is indeed my statement.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well. Mr. Witness, how old were you in 1994, in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I think I was 22 years old.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you were certainly aware that Tutsis were being sought following the president's death in April 1994, are you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Will do. Were you aware, Mr. Witness, that Tutsis were sought following the death of the president in Rwanda in 1994? Were you aware of this fact?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, I knew.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know why Tutsis were being sought at this time, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Could you please repeat that question for me?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you have any idea, Mr. Witness, why those Tutsis were being sought in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Tutsis were being pursued because there was a government which hated Tutsi, but all the government members were not harbouring the same hatred for Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was Ndindabahizi a member of that government, by any chance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was he a member of that government from April 1994 until July 1994, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, he was part of that government.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you have any discussion with him between April and July 1994 as to how he felt about Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No, I didn't converse with him on that subject.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So how are you able to tell us that he was not against Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Can you please repeat the question for me, because I think there is background noise which is prohibiting me from hearing you properly? I am please requesting you to repeat your question for me. I didn't quite understand you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you hear me now?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: We do indeed hear background noise which is very disturbing. We cannot really hear the Prosecutor's questions. Can the technician please come to our aid?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could we have that sorted out? There was a little dash of noise also in the English for a moment.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Registry. Now, is everything more quiet now? If we all hear, let's proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So, Mr. Witness, did you speak to Mr. Ndindabahizi between April and July 1994 about his feelings for Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: As for any discussion whatsoever regarding ethnic groups, I do not believe that Ndindabahizi said at any moment whatsoever when he was sharing a glass with other people that he was against any such group or other.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You haven't answered my question. I will ask you that question again: did you speak with Mr. Ndindabahizi about his feelings for Tutsis between April and July 1994; a simple yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I did not discuss that matter with him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were you, yourself, a member of the cabinet of the government of Rwanda between April and July 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I cannot clearly understand your question. Can you repeat it?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you work for the government, yourself, between April and July 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No, I was not a leader.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you attend any cabinet meetings between April and July 1994, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You described that government that was in power between April and July 1994 as a government that hated Tutsi and that not everybody in that government hated Tutsi. How are you able to come to that conclusion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No. What you are saying is not true. I am not the one who said that. I said that government existed, and I added that not all members of that government had evil intentions towards the Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Wasn't it your testimony in this courtroom only two minutes ago that that government hated Tutsis; yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Up until this minute that I'm speaking to you, I am confirming that not all members of that government hated Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you were able to come to that conclusion because you, yourself, in fact, were a member of that government, were you not? You sat down through their meetings, deliberated with them, therefore, you are able to come to that conclusion, Mr. Witness. Is that not your testimony?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Relying on what Ndindabahizi said when he came into our cellule, I'm able to assert that all members of the then government were not against the Tutsi because when he came into the cellule he asked them to stop the killings.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You have only come here to tell us a pack of lies this morning, have you not, Mr. Witness? You were not at that meeting were you?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which meeting?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The meeting he has just referred to. He referred to the meeting, himself, and he knows the meeting he is talking about.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Are we in June now?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have no idea. I am about to find out, Your Honour, if he would answer my question in due course.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I have not lied.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Right. Now, you said that, based on what he said when he came to Gasharu, you came to the conclusion that he was not against Tutsi. Is that not what you mean?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: All right. So there was only one meeting, according to you. Your testimony is that you only saw him once there. Is that not your testimony; you only came there once in June, in the beginning of June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, that is my testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: And he organised a meeting to stop the killings, but not to encourage them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Right. And you attended that meeting from your position in the ceiling of your mother's house, several metres away, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Those who attended that meeting can testify to it, but I did not attend that meeting because I was in hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So, if you did not attend the meeting, how can you testify as to what was said at the meeting? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Let me try to explain to you: those who attended the meeting -- among those who attended the meeting there was a brother of Ndindabahizi, and when he came back he told me what was said at the meeting and when he was telling me this, Ndindabahizi was with him. Ndindabahizi came to his sister and then -- and said that from that day on no one was to kill the Tutsi. And it was his sister who was telling me what Ndindabahizi told her.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I understand that, Mr. Witness. So why isn't that brother of his sitting in the box where you are now, telling us about what he heard his brother saying? Why are we having to rely on your evidence? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I don't seem to understand you. Can you repeat your question?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You said that you based your information on what you were told by Ndindabahizi's brother after the meeting. Do you understand me thus far?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, I understand. Ndindabahizi himself came to the sister soon thereafter and told the sister that no one should kill the Tutsi, once again, and that, "I do not want people to continue killing the Tutsi". My impression -- I did not understand the last part of your question. If you want to repeat that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you understood every question put to you by my learned colleague for the Defence, did you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, I understand your questions, but I just want you to repeat this last one.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, so that you can think about the answer in your head before you speak it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So what is the question?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm still waiting for an answer to my question.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I want the answer -- I want your question again, Mr. Phillips, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, were you, or were you not, at the meeting that Ndindabahizi addressed in June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I was not at that meeting and the reason for which I did not attend that meeting was that I was in hiding. I also told you that the brother of Ndindabahizi attended that meeting and that in the company of Ndindabahizi they came to Ndindabahizi's sister. Ndindabahizi spoke to the sister, telling her that from that moment on no one was going to kill Tutsi anymore.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yeah, right. And this was in June 1994, was it not? Just yes or no would do.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is correct; at the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It is your testimony that all the Tutsi who survived in Gasharu thereafter owed their survival to this man, Mr. Ndindabahizi, is it not, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, that is my testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good. Now, how many witnesses for the Defence have you met or do you know personally, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I did not understand your question. Are you talking about Defence witnesses, and for which Defence?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: There is only one Defence in this courtroom, and you know it, Mr. Witness. How many Defence witnesses do you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I believe I met seven of them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It's a substantial amount of witnesses. Do you know how many witnesses are in this case, in total?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I cannot know the number of witnesses.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Isn't it the case, Mr. Witness, that there are indeed seven witnesses from the location where you hail from in this Defence case; there are actually seven of you from that location? I don't want to mention the location, but I am trusting that you understand what I'm talking about; the cellule.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And isn't it the case, Mr. Witness, that you had a hand in inviting those seven persons, or six persons including yourself, to be witnesses in this case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No, I'm not the one who looked for these witnesses. However, let me give you this explanation: in the search for the witnesses that you are referring to, I saw some white people come who were investigating into the Ndindabahizi case. They asked me if I knew Ndindabahizi. I said yes. I told them how I knew him and they asked me if there were other people who could say the same thing that I was saying and I said, yes, there were people in my cellule who would be able to say the same thing.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And do you know if any of those seven persons that come from your cellule have any prior relationship with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, relationship either by blood or by marriage? Do you have any idea if any of those seven individuals had a relationship with him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Two of them, yes. These are the children of Karegeya and these two people have the relationship with Ndindabahizi. Now regarding the others, out of the seven, they don't have any relationship with Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's your evidence, Mr. Witness, isn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now let's go to your location during the events of 1994, April 1994. It's your testimony, Mr. Witness, that you were hiding at your mother's residence. Is that not so?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And is it also your testimony, Mr. Witness, that you remained at that location until sometime in June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I remained in that house. In fact, I told you that, first, I was hiding in the ceiling, and when the situation became worse I came out and I was hidden under sorghum stems in the compound, and I only came out of this hiding place when Ndindabahizi reassured the people, and then I went back to the house and I only came out of that house in July, more specifically 4th July, and that was when I started moving about in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Now, do you remember where Cyprien Karegeya was killed, according to your information?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: He apparently was killed in the centre of Gitaka, according to the information I got.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And, roughly, how far away was that location from where you were located, in distance now? Don't mention names, just the distance.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Approximately one kilometre from the centre to where I was; the distance was about one kilometre.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So you are one kilometre away from the alleged crime scene, hiding in a ceiling or under sorghum grass or whatever you call it, and you, to the best of your knowledge, believed that everything that you were told about the death of Karegeya was true and reliable enough for you to repeat it here. Do you think so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is true and I'm ready to swear on that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Let's talk about Mukantabana. Do you know where she was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I also learnt that he was allegedly killed at the Gitaka centre.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Again, a kilometre away from where you were located, was it not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, in your statement you describe that you were an eyewitness to Higiro's death, Simon. Do you recall saying that in your statement, or was that a mistake?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Let me give you an explanation. I told you that I saw -- I saw, myself, Simon when the killers were taking him away. They passed in front of Ndindabahizi's house. He was being led to his death. I see him pass, but I did not say that I witnessed his killing, his execution.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were you expecting this procession to pass by where you were, or was this just an accident, you seeing this procession go past?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: It was just incidental that I saw the killers led Simon by.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you saw this whilst you were covered with dry grass or whilst you were in the ceiling? In which location were you at this time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Let me explain to you: when Simon was being led to his death, they had not yet started killing the Tutsis. In fact, it was the day he was led to his death that they started killing the Tutsis and it was from Ndindabahizi's house that I saw Simon passing by with the killers.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. But you still haven't told me where in Ndindabahizi's house you were. Were you in the ceiling at the time, or standing at the window, or covered by grass?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Let me continue explaining to you. And I'm saying that I saw him pass by together with the killers, and the day he was being led to his death, the Tutsis were not yet threatened. It was from that day that they started killing the Tutsi. It is to tell you that all the Tutsis were not hiding at that time. I was, therefore, (By order of the Court, these words have been struck from the record and filed under seal) when the killers passed by with Simon.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was Simon a Tutsi or a Hutu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Simon was a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So why was he being led to his death if Tutsis were not being sought at that time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I told you that it was on that day that the killing of Tutsis started. This was about three days after the death of Habyarimana.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The reference to the house, this precise location where the witness observed this, will be deleted both from the transcripts, where it will be placed unseal, and from the court video system.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, would I be correct in saying, Mr. Witness, that the information you gave us as to those who were responsible for Karegeya's death and that of Mukantabana were things that were told to you, the people who were responsible for their death? You didn't see that; it's just things that were told to you, was it not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Also, you were not present when Ndindabahizi visited Gasharu cellule and, again, his visit was reported to you, was it not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I told you that I was in the cellule and it is in that cellule that Ndindabahizi's house is located.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's correct. Sorry; you were not at the meeting that he held with other people from the cellule. That's what I meant. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: It is correct. I did not attend the meeting. But I told you that it was not a meeting to incite killings; it was, rather, intended to stop the killings. That is one point that you need to understand.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I certainly, do, Mr. Witness. Now, how much of the evidence that was adduced in the Prosecution's case were you aware of before you became a witness for the Defence?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I don't clearly understand your question. Can you please repeat it?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How much of the evidence of Prosecution witnesses had you become aware of before you travelled to Arusha; in other words, the evidence against Ndindabahizi, how much of it were you aware of before you came here to Arusha?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I have no idea. I don't know about that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: When my learned friend for the Defence asked you to mention those Tutsis who had been victims of the attacks in Gasharu cellule, was it then a coincidence that you mentioned only the names of victims that have been mentioned already before this Court? What do you say about that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Your question is very long. Can you reformulate it more concisely? Your question is too long. Is there no way of shortening that question?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: There certainly is. Now, when the lawyer for Ndindabahizi asked you about the names of the victims, people who had been killed in Gasharu cellule, you only mentioned the names of Karegeya, Mukantabana and other people who had already been mentioned in this case. How did you know that those were the names to mention? Is it a coincidence that you just happened to mention the same names?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: If I mentioned the names of these people, it's because these were people I knew and whose names I remember. You will understand that this happened nine years ago and that -- it would be difficult for me to recall the names of other victims.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: When you were asked to mention the names of those who were responsible for their death, is it also a coincidence that you only mentioned names of assailants who had been mentioned already in this case, or are these just the names that you remembered from your hiding place at the time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: If I mentioned names of other people mentioned, this will not mean that these were names of attackers; there were many attackers and it would not be easy to mention all their names.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You were not an eyewitness to any of the attacks, how come then that you were able to recollect the names of not only the victims but indeed the assailants, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is due to the fact that when we are in our various cellules, we talk. We talk about names of persons that killed other people during the events and names of victims for the purpose of reassuring ourselves as to what -- as to whether what we say about the responsibilities of such and such a leader is true or not, because some of the attackers are now in prison or at the time were in prison. So we try to refresh our memories as to what we say about the attackers, and some of the attackers are in prison and they are said to be guilty.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Have you testified against any of the attackers that you mentioned in this courtroom this morning? Have you ever been to any of their trials and testified against them for the bad things they did at Gasharu; if so, which ones and when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Personally, I was a prosecutor's witness for Rukundakuvuga but that trial had not yet started; the other two Accused pleaded guilty.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So you say you were Prosecution witness for Rukundakuvuga; is that what you say, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How did you go about being a Prosecution witness when you just told us that you were not an eyewitness to any of these activities? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I do not get the question clearly. Could you kindly repeat?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How can you be a witness against Rukunda at his trial, if you were not an eyewitness to any of the crimes that he committed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Now, I am in a position of accusing him because he came to seek me and my mother hid me, and on that day, Rukundakuvuga beat up my mother.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you testified that before the events of 1994, Ndindabahizi often visited your location, your location in --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I didn't say that. I didn't say that he came often. I said that he did not come often. I said that he came approximately once a year. I did not say what you just said.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That is precisely my point. Now in your --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No, sir. He said that he came often, that was not what I said.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In your witness statement, you described knowing him from childhood and state that he came back frequently to greet his family and then you go on and on and describe your relationship with him. How do you explain that in your witness statement; it is no longer frequently now?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which line is this?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have a --

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Well, I said that he came frequently but not every year. The frequency was not the same every year. On that particular year, he did not come frequently, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Second page, I can see now.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have a different statement in English, there has been a re-text --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness, for answering my question.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours, I have no further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Any redirect?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, you came from your country to Arusha. Were you alone or were you with other countrymen or women on your journey to this place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I came with other people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you in Arusha guesthouse or a house in Arusha; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And also those people are housed in the same house. Are they in the same house, they live in the same house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, we stay at the same house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And how many other people are there with you in that house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: We are eight in that house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is that the right reason that when the Prosecutor asked you whether you had met other Defence witnesses, you said that you had met seven other people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: No, it is not that reason, sir. I didn't get the question very clearly.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Earlier on, I asked you whether you had met other witnesses for the Defence, and I wanted to know whether you had answered that question because you thought that you met them here in Arusha or probably you may have met them in Rwanda.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Well, we met in Arusha, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No other questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: I have a few questions for you, Mr. Witness. What was the relationship -- was there any relationship between the Accused and Karegeya, the father of the son with whom you were hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, there was a relationship, a relative.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: How were they related?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: They were cousins, madam.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And to what ethnic group did he belong, Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Karegeya was Tutsi, madam.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: But he was a cousin of the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: I have another question. You stated that you had two hiding places, in the ceiling and in the garden, and that you left one, the first one in June after Accused's visit and the second in July, is that what you said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, madam, on the 4th of July.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Okay. And when did Accused come to your place of hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I didn't understand that question clearly.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Did he come at the beginning, middle or end of June, to your place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: He came at the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And, so that brings me to my next question. If he stopped the killings as you allege, why did you remain in hiding until the beginning of July?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: After his departure, I left my first hiding place and I went to the house, and nobody came into the house to look for anybody after that. He had already made the statement and after his departure, we couldn't have been absolutely sure that we were safe. We could not therefore go out, but what is certain is that after his departure, nobody went around seeking people out in houses any more.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And initially, you stated that you hid in the ceiling, then you left and went out in the garden. Now, you are adding that you returned to the house in the ceiling again, or generally in the house.

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Well, let me explain. I didn't go hiding in the ceiling; I was in the house. I could move around the house but I did not go out of the house. I went out of the house and remained in the compound. I remained in the compound. I never went outside the compound, and after that, I no longer hid in the ceiling as was the case before.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, would it be correct to believe that you survived because of your close relation with the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is not the reason why I survived.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You were hiding in ... ... ... ..., idn't you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: So it means that you were protected by the Accused ... ... ... ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: That is correct, madam.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Were there other relatives of Tutsi origin of the Accused who were also protected by him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, madam, some of them, for example, Karegeya's child.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Karegeya was also related to him; why was he not protected?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Karegeya had gone to seek refuge in other families, but his child came to the same house as I was hiding.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Who told you about the killing of Karegeya? How did you come to know about the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I heard it through my mother.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Had she herself seen the killing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: From her house, you can see the Gitaka centre and the killers took us to the centre of Gitaka. My mother never went too far away from her house, but from her house, you could very well see what was happening at the Gitaka centre where Karegeya was killed.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You were, I think, .... ... ... ... .

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: I have told you that I was hiding in that house. I was with my mother.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness is talking about relationships.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now this has happened three times. Isn't it possible to avoid this? Now, Mr. Witness, please do not mention where you were hiding in terms of the Accused because that could reveal your identity.Now, could video system -- all the references to the house in which the witness hid will be deleted, same with the Court video system. Next question, please?

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: From the house where you were hiding, you could not see the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Are you referring to me personally? No. Personally, I was not an eyewitness of the killing of Karegeya

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: From the same house your mother could see or witness the killing. How come that you could not witness the killing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: My mother could go out. You see, I was hiding, I couldn't have seen anything. I didn't want to show myself.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Okay. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, did you mention the name Nkurunziza earlier today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, madam (sic).

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Why did you mention his name, what was his significance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Mr. President, I talked about him because I knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What happened to him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: He was also killed during the war, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, did you mention any other names of persons that were killed? And now we will not talk about Karegeya. We will not talk about Tatiane, and we will not talk about Simone Higiro. Did you mention any other persons that were killed when you were asked about victims earlier today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, I gave other names.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could you repeat those names, please? Would you repeat those names, please, in case there was a lack of clarity?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Karegeya. Mr. President, do you want other names that I did not mention?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No, only the names that you mentioned in view of the examination so far. So you have now mentioned Karegira, Nkurunzira. Did you mention everyone else today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Karegeya, Mutemberezi, Nkurunziza, Karegira and Habimana, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So what was Habimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Do you want to know his ethnic group, sir?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Habimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Habimana was one of our neighbours and he was Tutsi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Nkurunziza?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Nkurunziza was also a neighbour, a Tutsi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you mention the name Mutemberezi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I talked about Mutemberezi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was he?

sp.speaker: WITNESS CGC:
sp.p: He was also a Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Mr. Witness, your testimony has come to an end. Thank you very much for having come to Arusha and testify. We wish you a safe journey home and ask you kindly not to discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you very much. We may well now have the lunch break. The next witness then, Defence pseudonym is?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The next witness will be DH, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You said DH, didn't you?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I am not sure that we have received the DH documentation so far. We have some intimation from another witness including DU, but we were -- we will then need DH. I have DG and DU.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the document we submitted to the Tribunal, isn't it in that stapled document?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Of course, it is in the main document, like all your other documents, we have it in the main document. But since your technique so far has been in addition to this binded folder also to provide us with a separate document for exhibiting purposes. I just draw your attention to that kind of documentation concerning the next witness, we have not received.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, I understand. We tried to situate that the witnesses for this morning, their documents be submitted to you. That is what we tried to do. And for this afternoon, the document will also be sent to you before the beginning of the afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That is quite understandable. So why I am raising this is that in front of us, we have DU and another one which does -- and these two do not form part of this morning's session, and that is why we just draw your attention to the fact that we got, of course, the two documents for this morning session, but we did not -- but in addition, we got something which could appear to be for this afternoon session. But now, we know that it is DH which is the next one and that is the one we need at 2:30.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes. Mr. President, what happened was, there was a mistake on the part of witness protection or probably it's on my part. Witness DU was confused with DJ. The letter was not clear, this is why there was this confusion error and I should like to apologise for it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The matter is simply to avoid confusion, but we will resume at 2:30. So the Court is adjourned until 230.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Court is in session. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, you are a protected witness and you will be referred to with a pseudonym Witness DH in these proceedings. You have to tell the truth and the registry will now make the necessary arrangements to that effect.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Would you please stand up, raise your right-hand and say after me.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DH in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And, Mr. Witness, we are now in an open session, and that implies that you have to be a bit careful when you respond to questions. So please do not reveal your identity when questions are being posed which may imply particulars relating to your identity. Do you have a document in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature at the bottom of the document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It is indeed my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, the information is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence D20, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 20 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, I have to request a motion under Rule 79 (D) because we are going to have to question the witness closely on his identity. So we are requesting for a closed session for the next ten minutes of our session this afternoon, by your leave.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you are simply asking for about ten minutes. Any problems with that, Prosecution? No.And we have to grant that motion, but the public will note then that in about ten minutes we will revert to the open session. And the purpose of this closed session is simply to protect the identity of this witness. Thank you very much.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 56 to 58] was extracted and sealed under separate cover as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Witness, we are now in open session and you must be careful, and do not mention the two persons' names, just refer to the hiding places as we just did. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, who took you away from hiding place No. 1?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: My father.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why did he take you to that place, specifically?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He was a family friend.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you stated that you remained there for two weeks in that hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Apart from yourself, were other Tutsi refugees hiding in this hiding place No. 1?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, they were.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How many others?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you tell us the names of the people who were hiding together with you in hiding place No. 1?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: There was Mukantabana and her daughter.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was Mukantabana's first name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I do not remember. Yes, it was Tatiane. Yes, Tatiane was the name.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Counsel, I am requesting the witness to move closer to the microphone, because I cannot hear him properly. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You stated that you remained for two weeks in your hiding places No. 1, why did you have to leave it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It is because people had just discovered that hiding place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: After hiding at hiding place No. 1, did you go immediately to hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is where I went.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did someone accompany you there or did you go there alone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I left together with the members of that family who accompanied me there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The Tatiane we referred to, did she also accompany you to hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, I left her in the first hiding place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know the owner of the house in which it was located, hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I knew the man.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Had you known the person for a long time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was he living in that house in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, he was living in Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did that person go frequently to that house or to the cellule in which that house was located?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He would come there about twice a year.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That owner whom we are referring to, was he present when you went to hide in his house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He was not there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who was present in that house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I think his sister was there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Apart from his sister, did you notice anyone else being there when you reached hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I only found one person there who was also hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, not verbally but in writing, can you also tell us the names of the other persons that you had been hiding with?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I will do so.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Ask Mr. Witness to write this on a piece of paper.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, if you are about to mention two persons, please use numbers. If you are about to write more than one name, please call it No. 1 and No. 2. If there is only one name you don't have to use the numbers.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Registrar, can you show the document to the Bench and to the Prosecution? Could this be admitted as Defence exhibit, Mr. President, Your Honours?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: D21 so admitted, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 21 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you have written two names on this piece of paper. The first name that you wrote, does that belong to the sister of the owner of the house that we were referring to as hiding place No.2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the second person whose name you have written down doing in that hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That person was living with the family, but at that point in time, the person was hiding and was remaining in his or her hiding place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: This person you have mentioned as No. 2, was that person hiding in the same hiding place as yourself or somewhere else?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: We were not hiding in the same hiding place; we were not side by side, but we were within the same compound.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For how long did you remain at this hiding place, if you can recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I think that I stayed there for a month or for a month and a half.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you know, Mr. Witness, that this house that you were hiding in belonged to a person who was having a high position and that he was Hutu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I knew that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did that not make you feel afraid?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, I wasn't afraid. And I was saying to myself that nothing could ever happen to me. He couldn't do anything to me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why did you believe that he couldn't do anything to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It is because this person had very good relationships with my parents; they were friends, so I understood therefrom (sic) that he couldn't do me any harm.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Isn't it correct, Mr. Witness, that during the genocide some friends turned against their friends and against people who were close to them, that people even killed their friends?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That is indeed true, that did happen but I didn't think that could happen to me, and I didn't think it could happen to me because these people welcomed me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During your stay at hiding place No. 2, was that house ever searched?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: The house was searched.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know by whom?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It was people whom I wasn't able to know. I didn't know their names; there were people who were moving around and they were scattered over the hill, I wasn't able to see them, I didn't even -- I didn't know them. I heard them shouting and making a lot of noise.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How is it that these people did not find you, they did not discover you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: These people were unable to see me because I was hiding, it is quite simple.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, thank you, Mr. Witness. Let's now go back a little. Do you know how your father was killed.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was not a witness of his death. I was only told about the circumstances that led to his death.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what were you told about those circumstances?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was told that he was arrested, that he was taken away and that he was killed. I was told, "Your father was killed", that is all. I was told, "Your father was killed".

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know of any eyewitnesses to your father's death?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I came to know one person, Karara, who was quite close to the place. I think that he saw the people who took my father away, maybe he would be aware of the circumstances that brought about his execution or his death, but I am unable to tell you anything.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In this Chamber, we know of two Kararas. Now the Karara you are referring to, would that be the former bourgmestre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That is quite adequate. Do you have any information about the place where your father was killed? Was it within the same cellule, the one in which is located hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, it was in that cellule that he was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would you have had any information on the identity of those who killed your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was able to know the persons who were in the group of attackers, especially Everiste Baphakurera. Baphakurera is spelt B-A-P-H-A-K-U-R-E-R-A, Baphakurera.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness. Do you know whether someone by the name Emmanuel Ndindabahizi came to that cellule that we have been referring to between the beginning of April 1994 and the end of June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He came to Gasharu cellule at the very beginning of June, the first days of June he came to Gasharu.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you an eyewitness to his visit?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I did not see him; I heard people talk about it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who told you? Is it one of the -- if it is one of the persons whose name you have written on a piece of paper, you can say so. If it is another person, then you can give us his name directly?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He is the first name on the paper who gave me the information.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And this person who gave you the information, did he tell you what Emmanuel Ndindabahizi might have done or said during that visit?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That person told us that Ndindabahizi told him that, "There are children hiding here. Can I ask them to come out before the end of the war"? And he said, "Wait". But after his departure, we came out but we stayed within the compound, we did not go out.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Let's take it one at a time. Witness, do you have any reason to think that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi knew that you were hiding there and knew where you were hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, he knew because that person mentioned it to him and Ndindabahizi asked for explanations.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you have reason to believe that Mr. Ndindabahizi approved the fact that you were hiding in that hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I believe he accepted it because I didn't have any problem later on, not even after his departure.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you have reason to believe that you were hiding in this second hiding place, hiding place No. 2, with the agreement of Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, he had accepted it. If he did not, we would have come out of our hiding place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you know, to your knowledge, or based on discussion you had with other people, if Emmanuel Ndindabahizi came to this cellule on other occasions in April or May 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, after June he did not come back.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: A question was before, Mr. Witness. Do you know whether he was there before June in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No. No, he did not come.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When were you able to leave your hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It was around the 4th or 5th of July that I was able to come and wander about outside.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you able to walk around outside the house, but you were not able to -- did you come out directly from your hiding place and went outside?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: On the dates that I gave earlier in July, I wasn't going too far. I was not -- I could walk about within the premises but on the dates that I gave, I would walk about even outside the compound.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When you were in this house, you said you were in a hiding place, what was this hiding place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I began by hiding inside the house. It was after his departure that we came out and went into the house, and at the beginning of the month of July around the 4th or 5th, we were able to come out of the compound because the war was over and we were able to walk about outside.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. I wanted to know what was the hiding place in the house, for example, when people came to search, were you in the house or did you have a corner, a particular place where you could hide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, I was not in the house. I was not in the room, I was in the house. But if I say it, people might be able to know. I could put it on a piece of paper, Counsel, if you so wish.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, were you inside the house or outside the house, just tell us that first?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was hiding outside the building not inside the building but within the compound.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And now you want to give us further particulars by writing the exact place on a piece of paper; is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is what I want to do.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We will now have that document translated from Kinyarwanda. Could we have that from the booth, English and French, please. While that is being done, Mr. Witness, when was your father killed, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: My father was killed downhill from the bar which is located near the Nyabahanga river.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When, can you tell us the month?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: He was killed during the last few days of the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you have any questions while this document is being translated?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you know when Tatiane Mukatabana died?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: She died on the same day.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know who killed her?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was not an eyewitness to her killing but I heard it was one Rukundakuvuga who killed her.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And your father, who killed him? I have already put this question to you, but can you repeat the answer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It was Everiste Baphakurera.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness. Now let's come back to Emmanuel Ndindabahizi. Do you know or did you hear what Emmanuel Ndindabahizi did or say during his stay in the cellule that we referred to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: From what I was told when he got to Gitaga, he asked the people who decimated members of his family. Some people ran, but from that day, nobody died and the attackers no longer searched houses of people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it not be possible, Witness, that on the contrary, Mr. Ndindabahizi went to that cellule to incite people to kill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, that is not possible; that was not his purpose for coming there, otherwise he would have come to that cellule much earlier than that date.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it not be possible that he came to the cellule earlier without you knowing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That is not possible. If he had come to that cellule he wouldn't have left before -- without saying hello to his sister and his sister would have been aware.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, Witness, let's come back to the owner of a hiding place No.2 that we referred to. Does that person have any blood relations with your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, there is family relationship between that person and my father.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what is the nature of this relationship?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Counsel, but if I answer your question, it would disclose my identity.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you able to write the nature of the relationship between your father and the owner of the house on the paper? We do not want you to mention the name of the owner of that house, but if that can reassure you, write the nature of the relationship between that person and your father on the paper.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I will write it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, have the interpreters translated that piece of -- that document?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The document is being translated into English, says the Kinyarwanda booth.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now have you finished the interpretations of these two words? Is it done? Please give it now to the registry.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Mr. President, the document is being translated and it will be ready in a moment.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Meanwhile, Mr. Witness, have you finished writing on the other piece of paper you have in front of you there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I have finished, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do we have any other questions? In the meantime, I think you have to do that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, when the war ended, did you still remain with the owner of hiding place No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I stayed there at the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For how long did you stay there at the end of the war with that man?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Since July l994 up until 3rd March 2001, I still lived in that house. I only left to get married.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. I can see on this paper the description of the witness's hiding place in house No. 2. And we would like to enter this document as Defence exhibit.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No. 22, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 22 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I have still not seen the description of the relationship between -- between the owner of the house and the father.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The document is ready in the Kinyarwanda booth.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, it's very clear. I can see that on this paper. There's a relationship between these two people and I would like to enter this document as Defence exhibit.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No. 23 admitted, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 23 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I have three more questions for you, Mr. Witness. Witness, did the investigators of the Prosecutor contact you after the genocide to find out from you the conditions under which your father died?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, they contacted me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And did you tell them the same thing as what you said before this court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is what I told them.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Have you ever been called as a Prosecution witness in any trial in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, on one occasion I was called to testify against someone.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And that occasion you are referring to, did it have anything to do with the killing of your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes. Questions were put to us on the killing of our father, and on that occasion we went to Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In that case in Rwanda, the case you are referring to, did the name of Ndindabahizi come up?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, the name of Ndindabahizi was not mentioned during that trial.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, you are a Tutsi, aren't you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know Emmanuel Ndindabahizi here present is accused of having very important share of the responsibility in the killing of your father? Are you aware of this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That is not true. I cannot come to testify in favour of somebody who killed my father. It is obvious -- it's not possible that anyone would testify in favour of the person who murdered his father. It's not possible.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would it not be possible, Witness, that the Accused did this without your knowledge by inciting other people to do this without you knowing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I would have known in any event, because Ndindabahizi has good relations with people and I would have known anyhow.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Look me in the eyes, Witness, are you sure that Ndindabahizi had no hand in the killing of your father? Have you conducted your investigations, and you can say with a clear conscience that you know Ndindabahizi had no hand in the killing of your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, absolutely. What I have said is the truth, Ndindabahizi played no role whatsoever in the death of my father. He did not take part in the killing of my father because he was not present.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No further questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Prosecution please?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Hello, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Prosecutor.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What do you do for a living now, Mr. Witness? Tell me whether you work or you are a student, that sort of thing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I do handwork here and there as a mason.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And are you currently married?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I am married.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How old were you in l994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I was 12 years old.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you manage to complete your education?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I finished six-year primary school but one term after it. That is after only one term of six-year primary school.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is it your testimony that both your parents were killed in l994, is that not the case, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How was your education funded from the year l994, the year you finished?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: In Rwanda, the genocide survivors didn't pay fees for education.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: But did you currently live on your own or did you live with someone else from 1994 until you got married? How did you sustain yourself?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I still lived at the house where I survived.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you lived at house location No. 2, from the age of 12, in 1994 until the present time, is that not correct, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: At present I live at my parent's but I do have my own house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I thought your parents died? Can you help me with that, which parents do you live with?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I repaired the house that belonged to my parents and it is in that renovated house that I now live.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And as a 12- year old, where did you, after your parents were killed, up until you were able to renovate the house, that's what I want to know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It was later on that I repaired the house. We were given corrugated sheets and I found doors that I stored and I moved into that house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's correct but in l994 before you were old enough to find the corrugated sheets and move into the house, was it not the case that you continued to live in house No. 2, and, if so, tell us when you left the house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I stayed at the house in which I survived, but my name was listed among people whose houses had been destroyed. And before I repaired my parent's house, I continued to live in hiding place No. 2, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I want to know when you ceased to live at house No. 2, one year, six months ago, two months ago? Help me to answer that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: It was in March 2001 that I left house No. 2 to move into my house. It was at the time that I was to get married.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, that's what I thought, and whilst you lived in house No. 2, you lived there with the person whose name is on Defence Exhibit 20-- let me recall it, 21. Is that not the case? The two people you listed on Defence Exhibit 21, you lived in the same house with them, did you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct, I still lived with those two people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How many wives did your father have, Mr. Witness? Just give me the number. One, two, three, four, five?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: My father had two spouses.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And how many siblings did you have in total, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: We had a sister, three boys with the first wife. We were four boys and one girl.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So four boys and one girl from the first wife, is that your testimony or in total, children your father had?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, we were four boys.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now where is your sister today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Are you referring to my sister that is still alive?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's correct. Where is she?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: My sister got married but she is still in our area, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So is it your testimony that she is in your area at the present time as we speak or is she elsewhere?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, sir, she lives in our area. They left the house of the husband to come and repair the parent's house where they now live.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall how old your sister was in l994, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: The one who died, who came just after me, indeed she came just after me but I can't remember her age.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, your father had one first wife. Now from that marriage, is it the case that there were one sister and four boys you included, is that the result of the first marriage?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now that sister of the first marriage is she still alive or is she not still alive.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: She died, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now this sister who is now married, living in our (sic) area, did she come from the second wife then, is that the situation?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, sir, she is my half sister.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There were children, which other children were born from that other second marriage?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, sir there were two boys.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, you testified that you at some stage sought refugee at the location you described as house No. 1. Now why isn't that mentioned in your statement?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I did not mention that house because I didn't stay there for a long time.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And why would you have to stay there at all, if you continued to stay at the house where you survived until very recently? Why did you bother going to the first house at all? It's not in your statement.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I did not talk about the first hiding place because I didn't stay there for a long time. I only mentioned the hiding place where I stayed for a longer period of time, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The information in your statement is a little bit more intriguing, Mr. Witness, because in your statement, you state clearly that you have no specific information to give about the owner of house No. 1. Don't you? You actually speak about the owner of house No. 1 and you conclude your testimony in that regard by stating that you have nothing specific to tell us about him, is that not the case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I do not have explanations to give concerning house No. 1; indeed, because when the situation got complicated I was no longer in that house. All I can say is, those who occupied that house accompanied me to house No. 2, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Isn't it not the case, Mr. Witness, that the reason why you brought up staying in house No. 1 is because you know that that's where Tatiana stayed and you want us to believe that you know about Tatiana and what happened to her, is that not true, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No sir, that is not the reason. As a matter of fact, it was not at that house that she was killed. She was taken out of the house to be killed. So, that couldn't have been the reason to prevent me from talking about that house. No. 1, Tatiana was not killed in that house, she was taken out of that house to be killed outside, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You are extremely well informed, Mr. Witness, for a man who spent three months hiding under sorghum leaves in a location out of reach from house No. 1. How do you know this? Has anyone told you about the evidence in the Prosecution's case by any chance, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Nobody talked to me about it, sir, rather, as a matter of fact, nobody told me about the evidence that the Prosecutor's witness is to give or has given here in this court.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Apart from your father and the lady you mentioned staying at house No. 1, how many Tutsis to your knowledge, were killed in your cellule during the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: The other Tutsis that died in our cellule were, as far as I am concerned, they were quite many because our cellule was in the majority, inhabited by Tutsi. I cannot tell you all their names. I can only tell you a few names, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's indeed very correct. And, therefore, you must be particularly grateful to be alive, Mr. Witness, is that not the case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I thank God for being still alive.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Apart from thanking God, Mr. Witness, and being grateful to God, is it not also that you are also particularly grateful to the owner of house No. 2 and his relatives for saving your life, yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Yes, I am grateful to those people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: No further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Any re-direct?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the sources of the information about your father's death come from Mr. Augustin Karara; is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: No, sir. It was not Karara that told me about the death of my father. It was the person that I mentioned in the piece of paper, that person gave me the information, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now that person -- from where did that person on the piece of paper get his or her information?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That person heard people shouting out and said: "Well, the person has been found, the fellow has been found", and when that person heard people shouting out like that he came and told me, "Look, your father has been found".

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Are you able to indicate any name or names of the persons that witnessed the death of your father and then informed the person on the piece of paper who then told you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: Regarding the persons that informed me, the person whose name I mentioned on the piece of paper, that I do not know. That person on the piece of paper told me that he heard people shouting out the words that I have just repeated here before you, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the person on the piece of paper did not inform you who actually witnessed the killing of your father. Is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: That is true. That person only heard people shouting out. That person did not witness the killing of my father, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, your testimony has now come to an end. We would like to thank you for having come a long way to Arusha to give a testimony and wish you a very safe journey home. And please do not discuss your testimony with anyone.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DH:
sp.p: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We have a document relating to Witness DI, in front of us, Mr. Besnier; is that correct?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, it is DI. Witness DI, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, registry if you can make sure that Witness DI is being brought in, please. Good afternoon, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now you are a protected witness and you will be referred to as Witness DI in these proceedings. Please be careful as not to reveal your identity. Did you have that piece of paper in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, I have this piece of paper in front of me, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you see a signature at the bottom of that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It is my signature, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence Exhibit 24, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 24 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence, please.We have to swear in the witness first. Madam Witness, you have to tell the truth.The Registry will now make the necessary arrangements to take the solemn declaration

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, please stand up, raise your right hand and say after me.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DI in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you will now be asked questions first by the Defence and then by the Prosecution.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The Defence would like to make the same application as just before. We would like a closed session for ten minutes, lest we make the witness easily identifiable.
