I am worried about justice and we shall simply go to particulars that is addressed -- certain particulars and immediately go on to open session, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We have to grant that application but we know that it will only be for ten minutes, and then we are back in open session again.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 73 to 74] was extracted and sealed under separate cover as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, we are now in open session. So now you have to be careful. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Witness, could you remind us and tell us how you learnt about the death of President Juvernal Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I learnt about it over the radio, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember approximately at which date that was, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I do not remember the date, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember the -- what are the events -- what happened security wise during the day following the death of the president, what happened as far as security was concerned?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Now in the day following the death of the president, in our area people started killing cows, destroying houses, burning down houses and killing people.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you mean that looting erupted and massacres as well of people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, the massacre of the Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now more precisely, who were the victims of such crimes? You are saying that those that belonged to which ethnic group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The Hutu were killing the Tutsi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now to kill the Hutu - rather, to kill the Tutsi, one went to seek them in the houses or in the countryside, which is which?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: First of all, the houses were destroyed and people ran away to hide in the bush. It is there that they were found or sometimes they were found in neighbour's houses.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: My questions may rather be brutal compared to the compassion that you may need. What were the arms used to kill the Tutsi, madam? What sort of weapons were used?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They used machetes, clubs and even daggers.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you tell us as far as the Gasharu commune was concerned, where did the killers come from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The killers came from the Kayengi sector among others, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The killer came from Kanyegi, were there killer that came from any other areas?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They came from all the areas.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you tell us as far as you were concerned, face to face with those killings since you are Tutsi, could you tell us what you did to avoid being killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I hid myself in the bush initially and then late a neighbour of mine hid me in his house or her house until the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You hid in the bush alone or with members of your family?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Initially I was with my mother and my younger brother and then later when my mother was killed, I stayed with my younger brother, and then much later my younger brother was killed and one week after that, I met the assailants that took me to the Gitaka centre. A neighbour called ... paid moneyto the assailants for them to spare my life. So that since day I went to that neighbour's house where I stayed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, let us go over this chronology again, ma'am. It is correct to say initially you hid in the bush with your mother; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And your younger brother?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And then very quickly, initially your mother was found, caught and killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Your younger brother and yourself were able to escape?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: We stayed together in that hiding place. And one week after that, my younger brother was arrested. He was taken to the Gitaka centre. He was thrown into a latrine -- into a cell that Karara was going to pull him out of the latrine. And for that matter it was the same people that pulled him out of the latrine and killed him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you mean that because they feared that Karara would save your younger brother they withdraw him from the latrine in which they had thrown him and then killed him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, they were afraid that Karara, who was a friend of the family, may save my younger brother.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, when was your mother killed, in which month?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: April, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was she killed in the first half or the second half of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: In the middle of the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now this incident with your brother, did that also happen in April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, it was in April; there was one week between the two events.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So your brother and yourself were taken to the Gitaka village centre -- I'm trying to reconstitute the events -- this is after you were flushed out of your hiding place, then comes in what you just told us about regarding how your brother was killed. He was removed from the latrine and then killed, and you -- well, what happened to you, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They arrested my brother but I was able to escape from them. But later on I said to myself that it would be better for me to go and look for him. And on my way I met a group of assailants who also took me to Gitaka centre. And it was at that point in time that Karara gave money to the leader of the attackers. They released me, and they said they were going to come back for me the following day to kill me but they didn't do so.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What happened to your father, Madam Witness, during this period of time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: During this period of time when I reached this neighbour's house, Karara's home, my father came there and I was able to see him. And about two days later I learned that he too was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: If I were to recount the event, would I be faithful to your retelling of the story that the death of your mother is placed in the first half of the month of April or even --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Who is the witness; who is testifying here, the witness or counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Counsel, I presume -- I think that when the witness answered my question she didn't really say the first half, so even if you are trying to recapitulate you must do it accurately.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So there were the death of three persons, Mr. President, the death of her mother, her brother and her father. All I'm trying to do is place these events, which I believe all took place in the month of April, and I wanted some specifics in terms of chronology. Even if that is disturbing the Prosecutor, we need to establish what the chronology of events is.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, can you please specify to me regarding these three events, the death of your mother, the death of your brother and the death of your father, I want you to tell us about them chronologically speaking?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: There was space of one week between the three killings. First of all my mother was killed, then my brother and finally my father; and between one event and the next there was a week.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: A moment ago --

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can I ask the following question, Mr. President, Your Honours?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The death of your mother, you placed it a moment ago in the middle of April. So, where would you place the death of your younger brother, would that be the third week of April, and the death of your father the last week of April; would that be correct, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You did not witness your father's death, so how were you --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It is true, I was not an eyewitness of my father's death.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How were you then informed, and by whom, of your father's death? How were you informed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I was at Karara's house and it was Karara who told me that my father was dead.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did Karara -- well, without going into detail, did he tell you how your father was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He told me that my father had been arrested and that he had been clubbed to death.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: From what Karara said or through investigations that you yourself may have made, do you know who killed your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, I know that my father was killed by Évariste Bapfukurera.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And where was he killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He was killed at the Gitaka centre.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Does that mean that he was found at the Gitaka centre and killed there or was he brought there to be killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He was found in the bush where he was hiding and he was taken to the Gitaka centre, and that is where he was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, this Karara, what was his position in society?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Karara was a farmer and at the same time he was a trader.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And throughout these events of April, May 1994 did you lose any other members of your family, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, I lost other members of my family, in particular my paternal uncles.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, do you know the Accused, Mr. Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The last time I saw him I was very young; I'm not sure I would be able to recognise him today.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you see him during the events of any 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I heard it said that he had come.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you be a bit more specific, Madam Witness? You heard it said that he came when, Madam Witness, when did he come?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He came in the beginning of the month of June; that is what I was told.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Would I be correct in saying that this was more than one death -- one month or at least one month between the death of (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) and the arrival of Ndindabahizi at Gitaka?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, he came after my father's death.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We do now have to delete the reference to the name. So the reference to the name of the person killed will be deleted from the Court video system and it will be placed under seal in the transcripts. Please be careful.Yes, please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you were told about the presence of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi at the beginning of June, 1994. Were you also told about Mr. Ndindabahizi's reaction to what had happened, to what was happening and the questions that he asked?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I was told that he came and that when he reached the Gitaka centre he was saddened to learn that people had been killed, and he had asked why people were killing others. He was shown a man known as Gatete and he ordered that the man be arrested, but that man was able to escape. At that point in time there was another man called Karara, and Mr. Ndindabahizi arrested this Mr. Karara and took him away for him to be imprisoned.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Am I correct in saying that Mr. Ndindabahizi was angry when he learned of the deaths committed against Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Am I correct in saying that he had tried to bring about the arrest of those who had killed Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, this Karara that was arrested, is this the same Karara that you referred to previously in your statement or a different one?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was the same, one and the same, Karara.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, in your written statement you said the following to the investigators, and I am quoting: "It is absurd to state that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi can have any kind of responsibility whatsoever in the crimes committed in our region."

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you confirm that what you said about Emmanuel Ndindabahizi being accused of such crimes would be absurd?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: For me they are lies.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You also state that you yourself and members of your family, your parents and some of your brothers and sisters, were victims of the genocide. And you said that you've heard mention made of that, yet you say Ndindabahizi was innocent of the crimes or the allegations made against him.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: After the war a certain number of investigations were carried out; was Ndindabahizi -- was Ndindabahizi's name ever mentioned regarding the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I didn't quite understand your question, Counsel; can you repeat it for me, please?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I withdraw that question. Madam Witness, your family -- you are from a farming family. What are the traditional tools agricultural tools used by Hutu and Tutsi farmers, traditionally?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Rwandan cultivators use hoes and machetes to tow the land.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: One last question, Madam Witness; do you think it is reasonable to say that in April, May, 1994 a Tutsi woman could go on foot, even in hiding, from Gitesi to Kibirizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: That was not possible.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Is it reasonable or possible for a Tutsi woman to make purchases at a market place during this period of time in 1994 and particularly in Kibirizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: That was not possible.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you, very much. Counsel, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know why Tutsis were being sought in Rwanda in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Tutsis were being sought because of their ethnicity.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you carry an identity card in 1994, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I didn't have one.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know how Tutsis were identified in 1994 apart from the use of identity cards?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: For those who had identity cards, they were checked, but for those who didn't, they could be identified because they were known. It was known that this person or this child was a Tutsi; that was the only way of identifying anyone.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Could Tutsis also be identified by their facial attributes and features in 1994, as far as you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: When you reached a region which was not your own and if you didn't have an identity card on which it was said that you were Hutu, you could be killed because of your physical features.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would you describe yourself, Madam Witness, as having typical Tutsi features?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: All people look alike.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is that a yes or a no to my -- answer to my question, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I told you that all people look alike; there is very little difference between individuals, so one cannot say that one person is Hutu and another is Tutsi on the basis only of physical traits.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, Madam Witness. Madam Witness, you were 17-years old in 1994, were you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And since the genocide, would I be correct in saying that you have moved on with your life and gone on to do other things, including getting married?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I also be correct in saying that following the death of your parents, the unfortunate death of your parents in 1994, certain individuals assumed responsibility for your upkeep; could I be correct in saying that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, there was a neighbour, that neighbour took me in and took care of me until I got married.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, can you tell me who that neighbour is without actually saying it out, if you could write it down or something; or is it somebody we have talked about already? Can you answer me that way if it is?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Are you referring to the person who took care of me after my parents died?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, I want to know, Madam Witness, but I don't want you to say it out if you can avoid that. Please, can you write it down for me?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you help her in doing that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Please give me a piece of paper, I will give you the name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, the name you have written on here, does that person have any relationship with the accused person, Emmanuel Ndindabahizi? And I just want you to answer me yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: We enter this document, Your Honour, please, as the next Prosecution exhibit -- actually, before that, Mr. Registry, can you give it to the witness to spell out the relationship. I don't want her to say and I don't want to take the chance, write it in Kinyarwanda and we will have it translated. I think I know -- we can have it translated, we think we know.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, thank you for helping me with that exercise. Now, would I be correct in saying, Madam Witness, that having sought refuge at Karara's house, you also sought refuge at the house of the person who you wrote down on that piece of paper in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: After the war when life was becoming more and more difficult for me, I went to this lady's house, the lady whose name I mentioned, but that was after the war.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. And at the time you went to the lady's house -- the lady you mentioned on that piece of paper, would I be correct in saying, Madam Witness, that your half brother was also staying at that lady's residence, was living there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, my brother was also living in that lady's house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And it was -- it is, therefore, your evidence that this lady took care of both you and your half brother following the death of your parents until you all got married?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, you then got married, Madam Witness -- is your husband also a witness in this case, and by that I want you to answer yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, I want you to write your husband's name on this same piece of paper. Can you draw a line, can you give it to me, please -- write it on the reverse, actually, just write your husband's name for us, please.

div.stage: Pages 77 to 83 by Donna M. Lewis)1630H

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Witness, for helping with that little exercise. Now, can you tell me whether your husband is Tutsi or Hutu.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He's Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Okay. Now, when I asked you to write the relationship that you have or had with the first person you wrote, whose name you wrote on the paper, you described that person as your sister. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Who are you talking about, Counsel?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: If you look at me, Madam Witness. Look at me. This name you've written here, do you recall telling us that that person is (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: No. I said (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal). You asked me about the relationship between that person and Ndindabahizi. You asked me the relationship between the two persons, the person on the paper and Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam Witness, yes, that is indeed correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So then we will delete this as well.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The last reference to the link between the Accused and the relationship, but under seal. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, why do you think that the man you describe as ... , why do you think that person allowed you to stay at his house during the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He allowed me to live in his house because he was a neighbour, he was a family friend. And when he was in a position to shelter me, he did so.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And do you have a relationship with that man's wife? Is that man's wife something to you? And just answer me yes or no, initially.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Whose wife?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: ... . A relationship with his wife.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: No, no relation.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Okay. Would I be correct in saying, Madam Witness, that whilst you sought refuge at ...'s house you never left the premises to go elsewhere during the genocide; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I used to take refuge in his house and sometimes he would take me to his trading place, where he conducted his trading activities, and come back.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How was he able to do that without risking your life, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: We used to move during the night.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The trading centre was open at night, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: We would go through the bush along the road and then we would get to the centre.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And whilst you were at this centre, did you only operate your business at night or did you do it in daytime?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: You mean, for me to hide at the centre?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I don't know what you were doing at the centre. You help me with that. What were you doing there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He used to take me there and keep me in a house. In fact, it was a trick to hide me and people did not suspect that I could be hiding there. So he would keep me in a house, and when people heard that I was in that house at the centre, he would take me away from there to his house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So you criss-crossed between ...'s house and the centre throughout the months of April, May of and June?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is what we did.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Why did Mr. ... go out of his way to protect you at this time and have to ferry you from his house to the centre? Why did he go out of his way to do that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: He knew I was being sought, and if he didn't do that I would be killed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: He was also good friends with your father, was he not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They were friends.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you also know a man by the name Joel Ndabukiye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: He was also a family friend, was he not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, he was also a family friend.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I be correct in saying that prior to April 1994 your father had lived side by side with Karara and Ndabukiye without any problems?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They lived very well and had no problem between them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Why then was it, Madam Witness, in your opinion, that Ndabukiye and Karara were not able to protect your father? Why were they not able to protect him in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I'm unable to explain to you how people changed during that period. What I know is that Karara did his best and ... ... ... .

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I'm sorry, we didn't hear. There was a rectification from there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, could you repeat your answer, please. We're having some problems in getting your answer across.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: ... hid me. And I cannot tell you what Ndabukiye was thinking; I can only say that he changed during that period.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What do you mean by stating that Ndabukiye changed during that period? Can you help us with that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Ndabukiye did not give refuge to anybody, and even my brother who took refuge in his house, he chased him out subsequently, and my brother had to go and live with a women that I referred to earlier.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That being the case, do you know whether Ndabukiye had any hand in your father's death?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I wouldn't know.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You describe him as a changed man who chased your younger brother out of your house at some stage. Would it have been possible, would it have been possible for him, Madam Witness, for him to have a hand in your father's death, in your opinion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: You know, during the war, any person who gave refuge to a Tutsi person was afraid of either being killed or being looted. Probably that was why my brother was chased away, because he probably thought that if my brother was discovered he would lose his property.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The location where your half-brother eventually ended up, why was he not chased out of that location, do you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I don't know, but I believe these were people who had pity of him and were very kind people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You must consider yourself extremely lucky to be alive after the events of 1994, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You must feel particularly grateful to the men and women who went out of their way to save your life; is that not the case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct. I'm grateful to these people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: When you eventually got married to your husband, did somebody give you away, as is traditionally the case in Africa? Did you have representatives from your family who gave you away, stood in place for your parents?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was my maternal uncle who survived the genocide.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you ever know who killed your mother in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you also find out who killed your younger brother in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Have you been able to testify in the trials of any of these people in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you intend to do so at a future stage, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What are you going to base that testimony on, if and when you do so? Are you going to tell that court that you were an eyewitness to those killings, or are you going to tell that court that you were told that they were involved in their death? What do you intend to do?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I'll tell the court that I got information regarding the circumstances of their death. I will not say that I was an eyewitness.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know how many Tutsis were killed in Gasharu cellule in 1994, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: There are very many, and I wouldn't know of the exact figure.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And are you able to tell us how you came to be a witness for the Defence in this case? Did anybody ask you to come to Arusha and, if so, who and when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know who asked you to come here? Do you want to write it down or do you want to tell me?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The person who asked me?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The person who contacted us is called (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal).

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. And I -- would I be correct in saying that that person that you've just mentioned is the (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) ? Just yes or no, don't expand any further.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Are you referring to (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) ?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, I am. Just confirm whether I would be right in saying --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It's (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal).

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Right. It's the (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) the Accused person in this case, Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Madam Witness, for being so kind.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours, if I could enter this piece of paper as Prosecution Exhibit -- it would be two exhibits. Actually, we could do it in one. We have one name on one side which belongs to her husband, and we have the name of the lady with whom she lived until she got married, and that person's relationship to the Accused on one side.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Maybe we could make two copies, and on the one have OTP Exhibit 31. Will that settle the dispute? That is the relationship?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's the name of the lady with whom she lived until she got married. And also on that page is that person's relationship to the Accused.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And then on the other sheet would be the name of the witness's husband.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, and that would be No. 32, and both under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit Nos. P. 31 and P. 32 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I am grateful, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Maybe the last interchange should also be under seal, between you and the witness. So, court register video system, if you will delete that last reference when it comes to the link between the person who asked the witness to testify and the relationship to the Accused. Any re-examination?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Just one question, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam Witness, your conviction of the conduct of Mr. Ndindabahizi during the genocide, Prosecutor is trying to link that to the fact that the (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) of Ndindabahizi gave you shelter. Will this conviction not, rather, flow from the totality of the information that you were able to gather on the conduct of Mr. Ndindabahizi, on information that you got, research that you conducted, which enabled you to assert that we're all victims of this genocide? We're in a better position to know the perpetrators, and I can assure that you Mr. Ndindabahizi is not one of them. Is this conviction this, and not a way of saying thank you, as it is being inferred?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It is not because somebody gave me shelter, who is related to him. I'm saying this because when he came he was very shocked by the killing of the people, and he was very angry. And they showed him one person who had killed a lot of people and he asked that person to be arrested, but that person fled. But subsequently he had Karara arrested, had him detain. But for me, this is evidence that Mr. Ndindabahizi did not have any responsibility in the genocide.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You came to testify -- did you come to testify to tell the truth or to show your gratitude?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I came here to tell the truth about the event that I experienced and events that I heard about.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Again, the reference to the person who lived in the house must be placed under seal and struck from the video system.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I'm sorry, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: We seek a short clarification from you, Madam Witness. ... had sheltered you; is that right? Is this the same ... who was accused of killing, and later on arrested by the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It is the same person who was detained. But later on he got to know that they were false accusations against ... and he had been released.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You said that your husband was a Hutu; is that right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Is he in any way related to the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: No, no blood relation.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Are you related to the Accused? If so, could you please write it down for us, your relationship with him.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: They were related, but it's a distant relation.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Who was related? You and the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes. It is said that my (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal).

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You mean to say that (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Okay, thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, I suppose we have to place that under seal as well. So that will be done and struck from the record. Madam Witness, who told you who killed your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was Karara.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: How did he know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was Karara who had him buried.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was Karara present during the killing of your father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I don't know if he was present or not.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What is your source for saying that Évariste Bapfakurera was one of your father's killers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It's because he pleaded guilty in the Rwandan courts, and he accepted that he committed this crime.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was that when he found out that he was one of the killers, when you heard about his conviction?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes, it was when he confessed that I got to know.

div.stage: Before then, you did not know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I did not know.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When did he confess?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I don't know, but I was told that he confessed his guilt.

div.stage: Before the normal Rwandan courts or some other mechanism?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I heard he admitted that he killed my father. That is what I know.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you know whether he confessed before the courts, or have you only heard that he has admitted it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was before judges.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When were you told about this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: His testimony is even available. This was a while ago, and I can therefore not remember the year nor the month.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Are you talking about two years ago, four years ago, six years ago?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: You mean, since I got this information, Mr. President?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, please, that's the question, exactly.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I think it must have been eight or nine months ago since I got this information.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, you heard Judge Khan ask you about Mr. ... and she asked you whether ... was the same person, on the one hand the person who sheltered you, and on the other hand the man whom Mr. Ndindabahizi sought or ordered arrested. Did you say that he was the same person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: It was the same person.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, why would this person on the one hand be a Tutsi-saver and on the other hand be ordered arrested by Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: These were persons who spoke to Ndindabahizi and Ndindabahizi caused his arrest, had him detained. But it was when he got to know later on that these were false accusations against ..., who just spent one day in prison, he had him released.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But why did Ndindabahizi order this person arrested?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Ndindabahizi was told that ... was involved in the killings.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The killings of whom?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Of Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When did he order his arrest?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: The same day he arrived. When he arrived on that same day, he had him arrested, and took him away for detention. And a day later he was released.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And this all happened in June '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you, very much, Madam Witness. Your testimony --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: I would like to thank you too, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Your testimony has come to an end. We would like to thank you for having come the long way to Arusha to testify and wish you a very safe journey home. Thank you very much, and do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DI:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This will bring us to the end of the day also. And tomorrow, Defence, we start with DL?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, in fact, Mr. President, I'm in a position to give some information to the Court on the proceedings. We currently have 13 witnesses here in Arusha. We have called four. Things are moving very fast and that's very good. Out of the 13 witnesses, we have seen and prepared eight. The Defence team has not yet met the remaining five. Other witnesses should be arriving at the end of the week, and the expert can come here only from the 17th of November. If tomorrow we are able to hear four witnesses, we would have heard all the witnesses that we've prepare, and we would need a day or two to meet the remaining witnesses. Therefore, I think that if we are able to hear four witnesses tomorrow, to adjourn for a day or two, or a day and a half, to enable us to meet other witnesses so that before the end of the week we could hear other witnesses. Today, I can say that we'll be able to hear ten witnesses in the course of the week. It is possible that we would need a day of Thursday, Wednesday or Thursday, to be able to prepare the witnesses that we intend to hear on Friday. Will this be agreeable to the Court?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Well, if you do not have more witnesses, there is no choice. But as I indicated previously, this is exactly the situation that the Court would wish to prefer -- to avoid. Now, but what we note now is that we have four witnesses for tomorrow, and that is very well and good, and then let's see how it proceeds from then. But I'm a bit worried about next week. How many witnesses do you have for next week?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The week after, it would depend on how many witnesses we are able to call this week. We are going to call Witnesses 9, 14, 15, 16, and 17, plus possibly some witnesses who are already here that we have not yet heard. But here I would not like to make any pronouncements on that. In any event, Mr. President, we have sufficient witnesses for next week.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. So that's where we are now. Thank you very much for that clarification. And, tomorrow, could you just indicate the order for the four witnesses, tomorrow. Will you do that, please, the ones you have already had occasion to interview, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Tomorrow we would hear Witnesses DL, DU, DV and DB. In other words, we are respecting the order as set out in the list.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. That's very helpful. Thank you very much, indeed. So the Court is adjourned until tomorrow at 8:30.

div.head: 28 OCTOBER 20030835HCONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Mr. Nouhou M. Diallo Ms. Marianne Ben SalimoMr. Carlos Javier Ortega Mr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi:Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Ms. Judith Baverstock Mr. Petrus ChijariraMs. Trish GreigMs. Gifty C. Harding Ms. Diane Hermann Ms. Roxane LaneMs. Rex LearMs. Regina Limula

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good morning to everyone in the courtroom. Good morning, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to as Witness DL in these proceedings. You have to tell the truth, and the registry will now take your solemn declaration.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DL in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, we are now in open session, Mr. Witness. That implies that you have to be careful when you answer the questions so as not to give information that may reveal your identity.Defence, please.

div.stage: WITNESS DL,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Good morning, Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Good morning, Counsel.

div.stage: Microphone not activated) ... do you have that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir. Those are my particulars?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This document, is that your signature at the bottom of that page, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir, the information is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That is exhibit 25, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 25 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is your present occupation, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am a businessman.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you a businessman in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir. I stopped for a while during the war, but it was the same type of work I used to do.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What type of trade were you involved in?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I have a small bar and a restaurant.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you write on a piece of paper the name of the cellule in which you lived in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Could you say the name of the cellule, the secteur of the commune, and the préfecture, on the piece of paper, please? Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, could we have this as an exhibit, that is, the piece of paper the witness has indicated his address, sir?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That would then be entered as Defence Exhibit 26, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 26 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, have you ever been a political responsable in the region from which you come?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes. Before the war I was one of five members of the cellule's committee.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you still a member of the cellule's committee in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Let us focus on April 1994 now, if we may. How did you learn about the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I heard about it over the radio the day following the death of the president.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you remember the date on which you learned about the death of the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was perhaps the 5th of April. I believe it was the 5th of April -- the 7th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To which ethnic group do you belong, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am Hutu, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, in the days following the death of President Habyarimana, how would you describe the situation in your cellule so far as security was concerned?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The security situation was not good because of the war that had erupted covering the whole country.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When you say that the situation was not good, could you explain what you mean by that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There were killings, massacres, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who was being killed during the massacres?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was the Tutsi that were being killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, who killed the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They were being killed by the Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was it that all the Hutu killed all the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir. No, sir, not all the Hutu took part in the massacre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, in the cellule in which you were, was there a roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, there was a roadblock in our cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And could you tell us where the location of the roadblock was, without identifying yourself, of course, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The roadblock was erected in the middle -- the centre of Gasharu, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who erected that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was one Mbonyubwe, and another one called Somayire. Both were from Kayenzi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The family names, could you spell them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Mbonyubwe is spelt -- the other name was Somayire. Mbonyubwe is spelt, M-B-O-N-Y-U-B-W-E. Minani is spelt M-I-N-A-N-I; and Somayire is spelt S-O-M-A-Y-I-R-E.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So these were three persons that erected the roadblock, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am referring to two persons, sir. Minani, Somayire -- Somayire is the first name; Somayire Minani.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And do you know the first name of Mr. Mbonyubwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was not a Christian; he had not been baptised.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And are you saying that these persons were from outside the commune in which you lived, that is, they were not original inhabitants?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They came from a neighbouring secteur, but they were from the same commune.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Now, why did they erect that roadblock; why did they set it up?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They erected the roadblock in order to be able to control the population. When people went by, they asked them to pay a fee; it was a manner of stealing.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Couldn't the population defend itself against these people; couldn't it repel these people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Those thieves were very powerful, sir. And among the population, there were honest people that didn't want to put up a fight against thieves. They say to themselves, "I cannot dare confront them because they might attack me in my own house". This was the type of situation that was prevalent at the same -- at that period in terms of security.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, people were killed at that roadblock; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Personally, I didn't see anybody being killed at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You said earlier on that Tutsi were killed in your area. Where were the Tutsi killed, precisely?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They were killed in that cellule, but not at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: At which location, at which site, precisely?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Now, if I gave the names of persons that were killed, wouldn't that be preferable?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I want to know the precise location at which those people were killed.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There were persons that were killed at Gitaka, but not near the roadblock at all.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was it very far from the roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir. It was at around 25 metres from the roadblock, that is, 25 to 30 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The persons you referred to earlier on, Mbonyubwe and Minani Somayire, were those same people that killed -- that were killing the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir. They did not kill anybody. They just made do with stealing, except they killed people elsewhere, but on that site they did not kill anybody at that site.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now let us focus on the people who killed -- who were killing the Tutsi. Who were these people; could you say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I could do that. There was a team that was headed by Rukundakuvuga, Alphonse, who was from Kayenzi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is it necessary for us to have it spelt, Mr. President?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It's a name that we have heard before.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Rukundakuvuga and the people with him were they natives of your own cellule or were they from another cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They were from a neighbouring secteur, that is the Kayenzi secteur. All those people were from the neighbouring secteur of Kayenzi. We weren't many and we didn't have strength.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: So, if I get you correctly, there were two distinct events; on the one hand, a group of thieves that were at the roadblock, and on the other hand, there was a group killing the Tutsis; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, the killers, the Tutsi killers, where were they located or stationed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They came in from their secteur and came into our cellule and spent the day chasing people, and when they caught somebody they killed that person. This is what they did.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Now, you yourself, could you tell me about your activities during the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I tried to hide some people, but since I wasn't strong enough, those people were chased away and some of those people died. I do not know where they were killed, but personally I was able to save one child. This was one of the things I did.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, during the genocide in 1994, did you travel out of your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: With the exception of one day when the minister came to our cellule -- he's a native of that cellule -- when he came he realised that members of his family had been killed. He realised that his cousins had been killed and he got enraged, and he thought that perhaps I was one of the killers of his cousins. He wanted to arrest one of the murderers who fled, and he said, "I will arrest you. I will arrest you because I am not sure of your behaviour. I will take you back to the commune so that you explain what happened, because you were there." He took me to the commune and when we got to the communal office I spent a night in the communal cell, but I didn't have any problems. It was a matter of making investigations to ensure whether or not I was one of the murderers. And when he realised that I didn't participate in the killings, and that, rather, I tried to save a child from his own family, because it was the child of his cousin, I was released the next day. In the morning I went back home.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, we shall come back to that episode later. You have talked about a minister. What's the name of the minister? Which minister was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you know Emmanuel Ndindabahizi before that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I used to know him. I knew him because he was a native of our secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For how long a period did you know him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I knew him since his wedding. When he got married, I was living at the centre and I used to see him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi living in Gasharu in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, he used to live in Kigali at that time.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he come to Gasharu frequently?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir, he came about once a year; he didn't come often.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know, since you lived in that area, do you know whether Ndindabahizi ever had functions in the Kibuye préfecture?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir, not to my knowledge, no. When I knew him he used to work in Kigali, and since his wedding he had been working in Kigali, he had never worked in Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: So, you are saying that Mr. Ndindabahizi came to your cellule during the genocide. At what precise date was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I do not remember the date, but it was at the beginning of the month of June when the interim government had moved away from Kigali.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You are saying the beginning of the month of June; is that correct? Very well.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, it was in June. It was either the 30th --

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The 31st, you are saying, I heard you saying the 31st; and was it May or June?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am talking about the end of the month of May. I do not remember the precise date. I cannot give you a precise date, but it was around the end of the month of May or at the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. I do understand that. Now, before that day, did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi in your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That was the only time that he came to our cellule, that is, after the eruption of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, when he came on that day, did you see him arrive?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am telling you that -- I was just saying that he took me to Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, but do you know how he got there in terms of means of transport?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He came on a vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you remember the type of vehicle? Could you give us the make of the vehicle, or can you describe it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was a minibus.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were there other persons accompanying Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was with a soldier that drove him. He was his driver and he was also in the company of two children and one other person.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Two children, you say, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Those are the people I was able to see.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know who those children were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Perhaps they were his own children. I saw that there were small bags in the vehicle, and perhaps they were running away. Perhaps they were his children or his friend's children, but I had the impression that he had some special relations with those children.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did Ndindabahizi alight from his vehicle; did he come out of his vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what did he do when he came out of the vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He came down from the vehicle and went to visit his sister, and then we went together to Kibuye, so that you went foot by foot.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, we will proceed gradually. Where was the sister living?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: In Gisharu, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Please refrain from calling the names of those locations.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was his sister that lived in the family house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, kindly listen to my questions properly, and please be careful not to identify yourself in answering my questions. Now, the question is the house in which the Accused's sister lived, was it far away from the place that the Accused parked his vehicle?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, there was some distance because the road didn't go up to the house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is the distance you are talking about here, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It will take about 15 minutes on foot from the centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Did you accompany Ndindabahizi when he went up to visit the sister?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Did he then come back, and did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I believe he stayed with the sister for about an hour; I believe it was an hour. I went to church and when I came back from church he was coming back from the sister's.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. What did he say or do when he came back and when you saw him again?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: When he came back he said, "Who gave you the orders to kill people? Who killed Tutsi? Where are the members -- where are my relatives who live here?"

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was talking to Equinico (phonetic) who is also called Gatete, because members of the population had just told him that this was the man who killed the people, and this person fled immediately.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Had the people gathered at that time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was a Sunday and most people were coming back from church.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Sorry, we didn't get the beginning of Counsel's question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, it was on the road when people were coming back from church. They go through that centre to get to other secteurs such as Kayenzi and our own secteur, so this was -- people necessarily had to go through here when they are coming from church.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This person called Gatete, what was his other name you said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Augustin.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Let me take you to a little before Gatete. Ndindabahizi went back to the home where he visited a sister, and then he meets a number of people; were you yourself present?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I was there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you said Ndindabahizi asked who -- asked about who killed his relatives?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Had his -- had his relatives been, in fact, killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, they had been killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you able to mention names of relatives of Ndindabahizi who were killed during the war?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I know Karegeya, Cyprien, who was his cousin.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How was Cyprien Karegeya killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He gave me the piece of land on which I built my house. There were many people involved in the attack, but I was able to identify the person who was leading the attackers, and his name is Évareste Bapfakurera; he was leading the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When to your recollection was Cyprien Karegeya killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was during the month of April; however, I have no specific recollection of the dates.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you an eyewitness to this killing; did you see this killing yourself?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. When they took him away there was a good person who came and told me that, "Your boss has been arrested. He's been taken to the Buye secteur." There was a young girl that I was hiding, and when they took him they said, "These same people will come for the girl and kill her along -- together with Cyprien." I could not defend her. I run, took the girl and hid her elsewhere, and when they came to my house to look for her, they could not find her because I had taken her elsewhere. That was the only person that I could save. But today she is a married woman, and I believe she was before Your Honours yesterday in this courtroom.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can you go a bit slower with this part of the evidence, Defence Counsel? It went too fast.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you want us to come back?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If you could follow the witness step by step in relation to this episode.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, let's backtrack to the killing of Karegeya. You said you were not an eyewitness; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It is true, I was not an eyewitness, but I saw him being taken away by the leader of the attackers whose name is Évareste Bapfakurera.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where was Cyprien Karegeya when he was taken away by Bapfakurera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Évareste arrested him in the Buye secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you present when Évareste -- when Évareste identified Karegeya and arrested him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, but I saw Évareste take Karegeya away, and I believe he is the one responsible for his death, because he took him away to be killed. Évareste, who is the leader of the attackers, is still alive and I believe he should be held responsible, together with his accomplices who should all be held responsible for the killing of Mr. Karegeya.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You say that Évareste took Karegeya away; where did they take him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They killed him at the Gitaka centre. It is a bit uphill in Nyakabungo.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was Bapfakurera alone on this occasion or were there others?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was leading a massive attack. There were many, but I was careful enough to be able to identify who the leader of the attackers was, so that later on I could give explanations with regard to the death of my boss.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why do you refer to Karegeya as your boss?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I say that because he is giving me a lot of things. I did say that he gave me the piece of land on which I built my house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In summary, if I understood you well, would it be correct to say that you did not witness the arrest of Karegeya, that you also did not witness his killing, and that you only witnessed that episode during which Karageya was being taken away?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, you are right.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And when did you witness that episode, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: During the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can you be more precise?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I have no specific date.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: First or second half of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was in the middle of the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, what did you do next? What did you witness in relation to the killing of Karageya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: What I managed to see is that when I heard about his death, they showed me where his body was lying, and I myself organised his burial. I called the people around and we buried him; we buried him decently.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where did you bury him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I asked Atami Siborami (phonetic), who is a trader at Rubengera, he has a house in Gitaka. He gave me a piece of land where we could bury him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. I believe this episode is quite clear. Now, you made reference to a young girl that you gave -- that you were hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For how long did you hide this young girl?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Since the death of her father and her mother, I told her that, "Since your parents are dead, let us accept that we die together; instead of spending all the time running around in the bush and hiding come and stay with me and, God willing, our lives will be saved." Fortunately, God was on our side, and I was able to hide her. We survived, and today she has two children.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is the relationship between this young girl that you were hiding and Cyprien Karageya, if any?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: She was the daughter of Karageya.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, I believe that is very clear.Now, regarding Tutsis, were there a lot of Tutsis in your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, there were.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What would be the proportion? Were there more Tutsis than Hutus or more Hutus than Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There were more Tutsis than Hutus.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Now, let's go back to Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's visit to the cellule. We got to the stage where he was talking to the people and asking questions regarding the death of some of his relatives. Do you recall that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I do, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What did he say or do after these questions?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He did nothing else. He got angry and told me, "You have to give some explanations and say how these people died, because they were your neighbours." We could see that he was very angry. You cannot get to a place, realise that your relatives had been killed and not get angry, and you say that the person who was present should explain the death of these people. So he was furious, but we understand his fury. You yourself would have had the same reaction if your relatives were exterminated. When you go to the site where they were exterminated, I believe you would have reacted in the same manner. Subsequently, he conducted an investigation and realised that I was not involved in the death of his relatives, and that's how come I was released.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: But why did he arrest you in particular?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was because I was living there. Most of the other people were just passing by; they were passers-by, and the other person had just fled. He had been told that the killer was there, but that he had fled. And, besides, this murderer lived in another secteur. I was the only person who lived in that place, and I was the only person who could explain the death of his relatives.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Sorry, we only heard "barrier" out of that question from Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You said there was a murderer who was present; who was this murderer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am talking about Augustin Turukinkintu Gatete (phonetic).

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: We only heard Gatete from Counsel's question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, Gatete fled; he fled.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Ndindabahizi was -- Karara's name was -- Ndindabahizi was told that Karara is innocent and this is Gatete. Gatete fled. He fled towards his secteur; they were not able to get him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It has happened on a few occasions now, Mr. Besnier, that because the French translation comes quicker than the English, that the English booth is not able to hear your question, and then we lack the context of the answer. So, please, remember the pause.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I shall do that, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: So, Witness, we are at a stage, if I understood you clearly, the people have told Mr. Ndindabahizi -- they have pointed out to Mr. Ndindabahizi, a certain Gatete; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What did Ndindabahizi do in relation to this Gatete?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Gatete fled; Ndindabahizi was not able to get him. He was not able to arrest him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Before Gatete fled, did Ndindabahizi attempt to arrest him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They went -- many people were greeting Ndindabahizi because many people hadn't seen him for a long time. Those who knew were saying, "This is the person who killed the wives of the Hutus." When Gatete heard this, he fled immediately.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did Ndindabahizi chase him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There were many houses around; he could not get him. There were a lot of houses around. It was impossible to give him a chase and arrest him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who had Gatete killed, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He led attacks in his secteur. He killed a lot of people. I could, for example, talk about my nephews, eight of my nephews that he killed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And Mr. Ndindabahizi first arrested you and you were released after --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, the following day I was released. In fact, if I was arrested, it was to enable him to conduct his investigations for him to know if I knew how his relatives were killed. And I explained to him that I was able to save a child and that if we had the means -- if he had the means, he could take this child with him so that she's not killed. And when he heard that, indeed, I was hiding the child, and when he heard that the child was still alive, the following day I believe he ordered that I be released. A policeman came to tell me that I could go to him. I believe he was able to conduct his investigations. He found out that I was hiding the child, and so he sent a policeman to release me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did Mr. Gatete play any role in killing relatives of Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This episode with Mr. Gatete, when did that take place compared to the day when you were accused of having been involved?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. Soon after the death of President Habyarimana, Gatete started killing people.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But now Defence Counsel is, I understand, questioning you about when Mr. Ndindabahizi was seeking Mr. Gatete; is that correct, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Gatete fled.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did Mr. Ndindabahizi try to get Mr. Gatete?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I believe that if Gatete had stayed there, Ndindabahizi would have arrested him. He asked about the whereabouts of Gatete; nobody knew where he had gone. He was somebody who was not used to that neighbourhood, but I believe that if Gatete had stayed Ndindabahizi would have arrested him.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, why Mr. Ndindabahizi wanted to arrest Gatete when he was not involved in the killing of his relative, Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: You know a minister has authority over the entire territory; no one can prevent him from doing what he wants to do. He was somebody who was defending the entire population. He is like a father to the entire population.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KAHN:
sp.p: Did he want to arrest the entire killers, all the killers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: If he was able to find them, he would have arrested them --

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: -- because what they did was shocking.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness. You are talking about two different episodes. In the first one, Mr. Ndindabahizi arrests you, in the second one; he is trying to arrest Gatete. Did these two events take place the same day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, the same day.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Did he, first of all, try to arrest Gatete, or he first arrested you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The people came to greet him. Gatete did not know the minister and the minister did not know Gatete. But the minister asked, "Who ordered you to kill other people? Are you not ashamed to kill?" He told me, "I know you. You were a neighbour to my relatives, and you are going to explain to me how he was killed -- how they were killed." And people said, "This person is innocent. This is the guilty one; he is the one who killed the people. Gatete, Augustin, he is the one who killed a lot of people." When he heard that, when Gatete heard that, he fled immediately. He did not hail from that cellule. He went to his native Kayenzi secteur, and we did not see him again.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And then, why did Mr. Ndindabahizi turn against you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was so that I can explain the death or the circumstances of the death of his cousins, because I was their neighbours.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the lapse of time between the flight of Gatete and your arrest?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The minister wanted to go home, and this happened around 14 hours; it was a Sunday, after church services, and he left at 14 hours.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was there a lot of -- a long time, a lot of minutes between the sudden flight of Gatete and your arrest?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I was there. I was talking to Ndindabahizi, and Gatete left. So I was arrested immediately after his flight.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where did you go, together with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He took me to the commune office.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To what place in particular?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The commune office of Gitesi commune.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was that a prison? What room did he take you to in particular?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, he took me to the jailhouse of the communal office.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For how long did you remain in that jail?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I spent a night there, and the following day I went back home.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who released you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: A policeman.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, thank you, Mr. Witness. I think that's quite clear. Let's now move on to another subject.Since you were living in that cellule, can you tell us whether persons of authority came to supervise or coordinate the killings of the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, there were none; no person of authority came. The only authority, and only once by the way, was the former bourgmestre of Gitesi commune, he came at the beginning of the war. He came in order to have people flee, and his vehicle left with some people. When he went further away, he found that there was a lot of insecurity and that made him not come back. In fact, he had come as a saviour. He had wanted to have these people to flee towards Kibuye, but when he got to Kibuye, he found that the security situation was bad, and for this reason he never came back.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When you speak of a former bourgmestre of Gitesi commune, can you mention his name for us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was Mr. Augustin Karara.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No, I do apologise. Would you by chance have gone to the home of this bourgmestre, this former bourgmestre of Gitesi commune?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. No one as big as myself could move around. If I had done so, I would have --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I am sorry, Mr. President, could Counsel state that again. The interpretation had not been completed in the other booth so I missed the beginning of his question.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: My previous question is that -- did you -- my previous question was, did you ever go to that former bourgmestre's home in order to give him a message?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you quite certain about never having -- one moment, please, Mr. Witness, I haven't quite finished with my question. Are you quite sure that you never left your cellule between the beginning of the events of the genocide and the end of those events, except when you went to the Gitesi commune office?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was only on that day that I moved about.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the cellule where you were, Mr. Witness, can you please tell us whether Tutsi refugees were hiding nearby?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I didn't see any.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were Tutsi refugees able to hide near you without -- near the house where you were without being identified by the killers or flushed out by the killers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There was no hiding place. There was no hiding place close by where I lived. Had there been, I would have told you that it would have been possible for those Tutsis to hide there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Wouldn't it have been a good idea for the Tutsis to hide in the bushes near the roadblock so that they could see what was happening?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. The roadblock was on the road and we were above the road, and there were no bushes where those people could hide, and my house was about two metres away from the road.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. In your written statement you spoke of one Gatwa, spelt G-A-T-W-A, who helped you to bury Karageya. Could you please tell us who this Gatwa was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was a trader at that centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was he married?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To which ethnic group did his wife belong?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: She was Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did she survive?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, she was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was she killed before or after Ndindabahizi's visit?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was before Mr. Ndindabahizi's visit.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
