sp.p: In the cellule to which we are referring, do you know whether Europeans constructed a building before the war?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, the Swiss had built a building there in -- around 1978, and there were people who were studying at Nyabahanga who came there to take courses.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was that building still having activities taking place in it during the war?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. No, that building was very old. There were no activities taking place therein. The activities in that building stopped around 1980-1982.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did that building have a kitchen?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There was a kitchen next to the building.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If you were to concentrate on the roadblock, can you tell us how far the kitchen, would have been?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I would say about 150 metres, between 120 and 150 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If you were now able to put yourself inside that kitchen would you be able to see what was happening at the roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. And that's because the kitchen is in a corner, and even when one is at the marketplace, one cannot see neither the house nor the kitchen.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can one hear words being spoken at the roadblock if one is in the kitchen?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. It's far away; you cannot hear people speaking at the roadblock. If you cannot see the building itself, you wouldn't be able to hear people who are discussing at that place.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, Your Honours, I have concluded with my examination-in-chief of this Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Prosecution, please.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Prosecutor.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When did you move to the cellule in which you are now resident?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I lived in that cellule when I was very young. In 1971 -- I began my trading activities in that cellule after 1971, but it was in 1984 that I married while I was still living in that cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So, by 1994, how long had you been staying in that cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I had just spent 10 years there, and I am telling you 10 years of marriage in that cellule, because even before I got married I was living in that cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Right. You testified that Mr. Cyprien Karageya is the person who gave you a piece of land; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Did he give you freely or did you buy it from him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He gave me that piece of land free of charge.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, following the death of the president, you -- you have told this Tribunal that the security situation was not good in that cellule; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, during that period you were the con -- you were the responsable of that cellule; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I was not the responsable de cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, at what time in the course of your life were you a responsable of a cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I was never a responsable of that cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So when your counsel -- when the Defence show in some documents that you were formally a responsable, they are not reflecting the truth of your position -- as regards your position; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I was a member of the cellule committee, but I was never a responsable of any cellule, so you need to make a distinction between a member of a cellule committee and a responsable of a cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: My question was: If somebody showed that you were formally a responsable, they couldn't possibly be telling the truth?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, on the document mentioned that I was responsable de cellule, that wouldn't be correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, as a member of the cellule, the committee of the cellule, it was part of their responsibilities to oversee security matters in the cellule; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, but during the period in question, I was not a member of the cellule. Elections had been organised before the war, and I was no longer a member of the cellule committee.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us who was the responsable for the cellule in which you were living in April '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was Simeon Sengimana. Sengimana is spelt S-E-N-G-E -- G-I, I am sorry, G-I-M-A-N-A, Sengimana.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, when - following the death of the president when the war broke out, did the responsable organise -- take any defensive measures against the attacks in the cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, he was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: As for the rest of the population, did you hold any -- did you conduct any night patrols because of the -- because of the war in April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, we couldn't organise night patrols because there were thieves who came from more or less everywhere. Neighbours were trying to come together in order to protect the houses in their neighbourhood, but we didn't have any night patrols.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Who was responsible for organising the neighbours to come together to repel the attacks from -- the external attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, there was no one really responsible as such. People could decide to remain by the house of one neighbour, maybe numbering five, and the next morning they would probably decide to go and spend the time next to someone else's house. This is because we didn't have enough means to ensure our protection. It's more by the grace of God that people were able to survive and protect their property.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, in the -- the violence that erupted following the death of the president, who -- can you tell us who was attacking whom, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It's the Tutsis who were being attacked.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And why were the Tutsis being attacked?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It's because it is the Tutsis who were being pursued. They were the ones who were being sought.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us the reason why they were being sought?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: How do you want me to know that? Violence took place everywhere in the country. Sometimes you were told it's the Tutsis who were the target of the attacks, but I cannot tell you that it was for this or that reason. It was just bad chance which was -- it was just a curse which was playing in -- against the Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So it's your testimony that it was because of the curse that the Hutu were seeking for the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, they were the attackers who were attacking the Tutsis. I would rather say that it was the Hutus who were cursed because they were unjustly attacking the Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, did some Tutsis seek refuge at Kirambo church? Are you aware of that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, there were Tutsis who took refuge in that church, but when the bourgmestre came to fetch them in order to take them to Kibuye, all he did was to take some of them. But when he went back, he realised that there wasn't any security, and he was unable to move the rest, the remaining Tutsis. Given that situation, the Tutsis dispersed. Some tried to go to Kibuye on foot, others were killed, but there were some who managed to reach Kibuye on foot.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, how did the bourgmestre know that there were some people seeking refuge in Kirambo? Could you help us with that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There was a telephone line in that place. The bourgmestre was called by phone.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, did you also go to Kirambo, to Kirambo church at any time during the course of the war?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I didn't go there that day.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness was it -- is it not true that the roadblock was part of the security measures that was taken by the cellule leadership to protect itself against the attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, roadblocks were erected in order to limit banditry. And when you approached a roadblock, you were asked to show your identity documents, and people tried to find out who you were. But let me tell you that the Tutsis were afraid. They couldn't go near anywhere where there were roadblocks.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the roadblock was hardly ... ... from your business centre; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And at what point in time exactly was it erected in April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was at the end of the massacres when the Hutus began to attack their, their Tutsi countrymen by taking their property. I will tell you that it was around the 20th that the roadblock was erected, and it was only up for about two weeks.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, because --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Twentieth of which month?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The 20th of April, around the 20th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, because of the roadblock was quite close to your business enterprise, you could see who the people were manning that roadblock, couldn't you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, can you tell us who those people were?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There was one Mbonyubwe, which is spelt M-B-O-N-Y-U-B-W-E, and the other was known as Minani, Somayire. Minani is spelt M-I-N-A-N-I.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, was Joël Ndabukiye not one of people who were manning that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, Joël didn't go to that roadblock. Rather, Ndabukiye -- or rather, Minani and Ndabukiye's brother, whose house was just next to the roadblock?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: How about Emmanuel, the son? Do you know Emmanuel, the son of Mr. Ndabukiye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Was he one of the people who were manning that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, it was, rather, his uncle who was at the roadblock with one Somayire Minani, who lived in Kayenzi, but the house belonged to Ndabukiye.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, do you know that Joël Ndabukiye is in prison now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I know that he is detained at the Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And are you aware that he is detained because of his activities at that particular roadblock in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I don't know why he is in detention.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And that he has made a confession to some of the activities that he undertook at that particular roadblock? Are you aware of that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I don't know about that.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, with --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What were the other names you referred to, Mr. Witness, concerning those manning the roadblock? We have, of course, Mbonyubwe and Somayire, but then you came up with a few others. Could you repeat those names, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I mentioned Minani.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was that the only one that you mentioned in addition to these two?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Those were the only names I mentioned.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You see, we have Mbonyubwe and Minani Somayire. These are two names. But didn't you, responding to a question from Mr. Kapaya, mention some other names in connection with the roadblock, or did you not? I have heard, for instance, you say his uncle was there, his uncle was there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I only mentioned Mbonyubwe, who was not baptised. It was only Minani that had another name or first name, that is, Sumiyarire.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Just to avoid confusion, you remember you were asked whether Emmanuel, son of Joël, was at the roadblock, and you said no. Isn't that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I said he wasn't there. I didn't see him at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, did you then continue saying that his uncle was there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that was his uncle, because Mbonyubwe is the young brother of Joël.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know one Rukundakuvuga, and tell us whether or not he was at that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I know Rukundakuvuga.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, did you or did you not see him at the roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He came by the roadblock during the time he was participating in the attacks, and it was the time he was leading the attacks, so that he passed by the roadblocks with the attackers as the leader of the attackers' group.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: My question is, Mr. Witness, is whether this individual participated in the manning of the roadblock? Did he or did he not, according to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know Sendiragora?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I know Sendiragora very well.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Sorry. What is the relationship between him and Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I don't know the relationship between him and Ndindabahizi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You don't know the relationship between the two or -- are you saying that you do not know the relationship between the two or there is no relationship between the two?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I don't know where Sendiragora is from to be able to tell you what type of relationship there may be, but I do know the sister who takes care of his property.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: We'll come to the sister later on. I was asking about Sendiragora first. Now, could you tell us whether or not these --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I know Sendiragora; I do not know the relationship between himself and Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us whether he participated in the manning of the roadblock at Gitaka?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I don't know whether he collaborated with the people that were manning the roadblock, but the people I saw quite often were the two that I mentioned to you. Those are the two people that were there all time throughout the day at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you know a person by Tatiane Nyiramaritete?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I know that person.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Can you tell us what she did for a living?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was a teacher - rather, she was a teacher.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, during the course -- during the genocide, did she seek refuge at Joël Ndabukiye's?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I didn't monitor the events to determine whether he went to his (sic) house, but I saw the attackers who led him (sic) and who had just led him (sic) out of Pascal Ruhara's, and it was through Rukundakuvuga who was leading the attackers. I saw these people pass by. I saw Rukundakuvuga in the group that was leading that person away, but I was not able to identify all the people that were in the group of attackers. It was only Rukundakuvuga that I was able to identify because it was during the daytime.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, did that lady at any time in April or May seek refuge at the residence of Joël Ndabukiye, yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I don't know whether she sought refuge at Ndabukiye's. I saw the attackers lead him (sic) out of Pascal's house. Pascal's house had been looted. His chairs were taken away, and it was Rukundakuvuga who led the attackers that led that person away. I don't know whether he was at Joël Ndabukiye's at one time or the other.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Pascal, Mr. Witness? Why did you refer to Pascal now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: This Pascal Ruhara and it was at his house that Tatiane had kept some furniture. And the attack led by Rukundakuvuga was led to loot the furniture that she had kept at Ruhara's. Now, when I saw the attackers pass by, the attackers were carrying the furniture.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And when was this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That was the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, what kind of business did you run close to the roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: At the beginning of the war activities ceased so that I was unable to carry on with my activities, but before that I had a restaurant, and at a given time I had a shop, a small shop. At the beginning of the war, people could come and borrow goods without paying, and I decided to stop my activities up to the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Is it your testimony that in April-May you were not operating your business?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So what's the answer now, that you did not have any business from April to June '94, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: From June there was some semblance of security that I gradually resumed my activities.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But from April to June you did not, is that so?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, during the --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We would like a translation.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Sorry, the microphone was off.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: During that period, there was nobody from whom I could buy goods to sell in my shop so that I had to stop my operations.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you had a bar in April-May, and the attackers who ran the roadblock used to go to that bar and drink; is that not correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir. I had stopped my activities so that I was no longer operating.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, during the genocide, say in April-May, you saved some Tutsi in your residence. Is that correct, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You have told us that one of them was the child of Karegeya; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Who were the other ones that you saved in your house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was only that person that I was able to keep or save.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Sorry, I didn't get the answer, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was only that girl that I was able to save.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Wasn't there a relative of the bourgmestre for Gitesi who stayed at your house for some time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, in your area, people knew that you were staying with the child of Karegeya; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And that was the reason why she had to move to another location; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: She didn't go anywhere else. She stayed there. Sometimes I would take her around. I took her to hide in the sorghum fields, and in the evening she would come back home.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I am not getting you quite well, Mr. -- is it your testimony that that lady stayed in your house throughout April, May and June? Is that your testimony?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, she stayed there. She didn't go anywhere else.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: She stayed in your house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: April, May and June '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, there was a time, Mr. Witness, you spent -- there was a time you were in prison, were you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And when was that and for what, for what crimes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I was being interrogated about the father of that child. The minister thought that I had taken part in the massacres and that I was one of the persons that killed his cousin.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When? When was that, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was at the beginning of June, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, while staying with the child of Mr. Karegeya, did you tell her who killed her father?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I explained to her who the leader of the attackers was because I did see him, but I couldn't tell whether it was that person that killed the father or whether it was another attacker, but I told her who the leader of the attackers was that took his father -- her father away.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And what is the name of the leader of the attackers you told this lady?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: There was Evareste Bapfakurera who was from the Buye secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, you also testified that -- in response to a question from my learned friend, you were asked whether who was responsible for the killings in Gasharu secteur. Do you recall that question?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Do you mean the persons that killed people in Gasharu? Yes, I did explain that it was Rukundakuvuga who was the leader of the attackers in Gasharu.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So is it your testimony that in April, May, June, it was Rukundakuvuga who was the leader of the killers in that cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, sir. But after May, there were no more massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, was there a time, Mr. Witness, you were interrogated by the IPJ at Kibuye in 1998 in connection with what transpired in your cellule of residence?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Interviewed by?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: A prosecutor in Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Rwandan prosecutor?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: The Rwandan prosecutor, I mean.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He asked me questions about things that happened in our cellule, no, sir. No, sir. He didn't come to ask questions, like questions.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Is it your testimony that at no time were you taken to the IPJ in Kibuye and interrogated about your activities in your cellule of residence?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I will show you a document and ask you whether you recognise your signature and what is contained in, in that document.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: With leave of the Chamber, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is this a new document?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, a new document, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: In Kinyarwanda?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, I don't know what my learned friend is talking about. I didn't see this document -- it is in Kinyarwanda -- before the trial. The Prosecutor is asking whether the witness was interrogated as a witness by the judicial police. I see here written minutes of the interview of the suspect. I think it is a trap for the witness, and they want to confuse him, but I should like a translation made to me so that --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What is --?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone, please.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What is now being stated must not be interpreted to the witness. That's good, thank you very much. I am pleased that you didn't do that. Now, your wish, Mr. Besnier, was simply that you wanted this document to be translated? Was that what you were about to say, or what was the problem? Please go ahead.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, three things, Mr. President. Firstly, this document was not disclosed to the Defence. Secondly, it is in Kinyarwanda, and we don't understand it. And three, there is only one word in French in this document -- one sentence. This sentence is, "Minutes of the hearing of the suspect," whereas earlier on, the Prosecutor asked witness whether he was heard by the judicial police as a witness. Now, the witness different from the Accused. I think that the question was not properly put to the witness, and if we are to come back to this issue, we should ask witness whether he was heard in the past as an accused.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If I could get that document back. Which paragraph are you referring to the French document, please? Just before you give it to me, which paragraph of that document do we find this reference to the French information, please?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the first third of the document there is a sentence in capital letters in French, in the upper part of the document.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you have any copies of this document, Mr. Kapaya, so that we could all have it in front of us? Because we are a bit at a loss now because we don't really know what this is, and we will need, as Defence indicated, some kind of translation. And the booth has the booth a document (sic) of this?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have to address the Court on this. I don't see what the cause for alarm is. My learned friend has asked questions of this witness extensively and seeks to impeach his credibility with a document. Now, whether it's in Kinyarwanda, French or English, in my respectfully submission is completely, you know, not so relevant in this instance. We have given the Kinyarwanda booth two copies of this document, and what my learned friend proposes to do is to have them read the content of this document into the record.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, and that's exactly we are about to do, and that is what Defence counsel also wants. There is full agreement.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I didn't really get that impression, Your Honour, from Defence counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, yes. All we want to know now is really what this document is, and I simply ask the Prosecution whether the booth has this document so that we can start translating it, and then I got the answer "no" from the booth, but I understand that the Prosecution has given it to the booth.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, we have, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's very good. Now, booth, have you received it now? Yes, I can see the Kinyarwanda booth nodding. Defence, do you have a copy of the document there now? Can we start this exercise? Please go ahead, Mr. Kapaya.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, I wonder whether the witness has a copy of that document.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, could you turn to the second page of that document and look on the left-hand side where it is -- where your name appears. Now, could you tell us whether that signature is yours?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, do you recall the contents -- the circumstances under which this document was prepared?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I do remember.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, in this interview, Mr. Witness --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And here maybe we could take up the point -- the other point raised by the Defence. Now, what do you remember, what kind of occasion was this, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was just after the end of the war. After the end of the war people came and went to the courthouse, and you were summoned because of your property, and you were told that you were guilty of having murdered somebody and you were imprisoned. And when you were imprisoned you stayed imprisoned, whereas the real killers were free and they were all known. Nothing was done to them. Investigations were carried out, and when you were proven to be innocent, you were released. You talked to me about an IPJ, a Rwandan IPJ. I did not understand that you meant the IPJ of the commune. But that was what happened: People wrongly accused you whereas the people who were really guilty were around.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, for the record, could now -- I would request the Kinyarwanda interpreters to read the document, in fact, the entire document before it is translated.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please go ahead.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "Republic of Rwanda, ministry of justice, the prosecutor's office, Kibuye. Year: 1998, the 31st day of August at 0811hours, we, Eric Nkuse, the judicial police inspector of general competencies in the Kibuye préfecture, and acting pursuant to Articles 1 and 2 of the Criminal Procedure Code within the framework of preliminary examinations, are said that today we have here before us (By order of the Court, this name has been extracted and filed under seal) I don't know whether we should give the identity here.

div.stage: Microphone not activated)....video assistant, so will you please, whenever there is a reference to any name in this document, please delete it. You may not translate that, booth. And the court video system has now taken note that this will be deleted, and so will the registry in relation to the records. It will be placed under seal.Yes, please proceed.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "Son of, born on, in the so-so cellule, so-so secteur, préfecture, dash, dash, living in cellule dash, préfecture dash, of Rwandan nationality, married, father of six, owner of a cow, farmer, states as follows: Transcript of the hearing of the suspect:"Q: During the war, the genocide and the massacres, where were you?A: I was here at this location in the secteur. Q: Was there any war activities in your area?A: Yes.Q: Who was the leader during that war? A: It was Rukundakuvuga who is from Kayenzi. He was the one leading the attacks that were launched within the cellule.Q: What was purpose of the war?A: The purpose was to kill people and to destroy houses.Q: Did you see any attacks launched in your area?A: I saw only one attack that was led by that Rukundakuvuga.Q: You did not recognise anybody else among the attackers?A: No, I only recognised Rukundakuvuga. "Q: We know that many people took part in the massacres. Personally, did you see anybody from your area participating in such massacres?A: There was one Habiya Twagiramungu from the Muwanira secteur and of the cellule of Muwanira, the Gitesi préfecture, who died. Q: So you are saying it's only Twagiramungu who participated in the massacres in your secteur? A: No, there many of them.Q: But you only mentioned one person. Who were the others there?A: That was the only one I was able to recognise, sir. Q: And you, what was your behaviour? How did you behave during the war?A: I did not do - I did not harm anybody.Q: But you are accused of having been seen during the war taking part in the attacks and killing people.A: Those are false accusations, sir.Q: What evidence do you have to show that during the war, you did not take part in the massacres?A: You could carry out investigations in our secteur, sir.Q: Who could we question in your area?A: You may question so and so, and so and so, and so and so.Q: Now, do you know Kagogora's wife, and if you do, where did you ever see her during the war?A: I know Kagogora, but I do not know his wife. Q: Do you know Karegeya?A: Yes, I do.Q: What could you tell us concerning Karegeya's death? A: A group of attackers held him at a location where coffee was being decorticated at Buye. Q: And when Karegeya was killed, where were you?A: I was not there.Q: Who killed him, then?A: I do not know.Q: But you are being accused of having killed Karegeya and Kagogora's wife during the war.A: Those are false accusations.Q: What evidence do you have to show that these are false accusations?A: You could ask that question or that question to anybody that lives in Mwendo cellule in the Kayenzi secteur and who now lives in Kigali, you can ask that question.Q: Do you have anything else to add to your statement?A: No. I swear that the present minutes are authentic. Signature." End of translation, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, do you recall taking part in this interview?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: In this interview, the persons you give as responsible for the killings in that cellule are different from the ones you have described in this Tribunal today, correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I have already spoken about Rukundakuvuga, but I did not see the other persons kill anybody, but I saw them in a group of attackers. I saw them loot. And besides, they were not from our cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: In '98, you were asked about the people or the person who killed Karegeya. You said you did not know, whereas today you are telling us it was Bapfakurera or something in this group, correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, now I have conducted my investigations and I know who killed him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: But the circumstances under which you described the arrest of Karegeya in your testimony today is very different from the circumstances you described to the IPJ in Kibuye; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, at that time I hadn't conducted any investigations and I did not know the circumstances of his death. I needed to conduct investigations and do some analysis.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you didn't have to conduct any investigations because you told us here that you saw Bapfakurera and his company taking Karegeya to his death, so there is no question -- the question of you conducting investigations does not arise?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I did not know the name of this person. I just knew him by sight, and he was somebody who comes from a neighbouring secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, this person whom you described in this Tribunal as having taken part in the killing of Karegeya, have you had any contact with him, Bapfakurera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, we are not neighbours. I have no contact with him. He is in -- he lives in a different secteur from mine. I got to know his name because he's a cobbler, a shoemaker. I just knew him by sight, but I did not know his name, but later on I got to know his name.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Do you know whether he has made a confession before the Rwandan courts and do you know whether or not he mentions, as a witness, you in that confession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I do not know this. He is in prison. I do not know what happened to him, but people know that he is the one who committed this crime.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Are you aware that -- whether he has made any confession that he killed Karegeya? To your knowledge, has he confessed the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I am not aware. He is in prison. He is in prison in Gisovu, and I have no contact with him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And you are not a witness to any of this man's confessions before the IPJ or in Gisovu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: The IPJ was in Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: In your statement dated 6 August 2003 you made before the Defence investigators, you state on page 2 -- on the third page, the English translation, last page, on the top you say, "I learned about Karegeya's death, but I was not an eye-witness. I learnt that he had been killed by a group led by Bapfakurera, currently in Gisovu prison."Now, what is the basis of your -- of this statement? After all, you said, "Besides, he pleaded guilty". That's what you say. Now, what is the basis of this information?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I don't know if he pleaded guilty. What I know is that he is in prison in Gisovu and that he is the perpetrator of that crime. I knew he was the leader of the attackers, but prior to that I did not know his name.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, you told the Defence investigators that Bapfakurera pleaded guilty, did you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. I told him that he was in prison. Maybe they know that he pleaded guilty. I wouldn't know. How am I supposed to know?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So they fabricated, your statement; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: They got it wrong, but I know that he is in prison in Gisovu. That's one thing I know.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, can you describe to this Tribunal how the Defence investigators took this statement from you? Can you tell us, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He asked me questions and I answered them. I gave them explanations in relation to the questions that they asked me.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And then you signed that statement. And then they read it over to you, they read the statement over and you signed it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Okay. Now, let's turn to the visit by -- the alleged visit by Mr. Ndindabahizi in your place. When do you place that visit? When did Mr. Ndindabahizi come to Gishaka -- to your place of --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He came at the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: What makes you think that it was in June and not in July or May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, it was not in May. When he came, a few days later we were in July. That's why I'm saying it was in June. Maybe it was towards the end of May.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, how did the people -- how did people know that Ndindabahizi had come to that area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was a Sunday, and to go to his house you have to go through the centre. So people coming from church went through the centre and they were able to see him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, when you say that people said you were responsible for the killings in that cellule, did the people raise up their hands and point you out, or how did Ndindabahizi get that kind of information?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: This was when people were appropriating other people's property. In those days people said, "You have killed somebody." And even if later on the person who is supposed to be the victim is seen alive, they have already taken your property and you have already been accused. So there were people who were killed even though they were innocent.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Let me tell you, Mr. Witness, what the problem Mr. Ndindabahizi found with you was that you were protecting Tutsis in your residence. What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, that was not the reason. It was, rather, because when he came, he found no member of his family who had survived.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You were reputed to be protecting Tutsi, and that is Mr. Ndindabahizi ordered your arrest?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was investigating, and he thought I participated in the killing of his cousins. And if indeed I were guilty, I would not have been a free man, and I would not have lived in that place and -- I would not have lived in that place together with those who had lived there for years.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You were also accused of stealing his land that is why he arrested you, his land and cows?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. If I wanted to appropriate his land, I would have started by killing his child who was with me. How could I have appropriated his land when his child was still alive?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And that is why when you went to Kibuye, you had rested there overnight and came back?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, because he realised that I was innocent. People can lie, but he examined the situation closely and realised that I was innocent. Even children knew how their cows were looted, who looted and under what circumstances.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, you testified that Mr. Ndindabahizi came from the cellule in which you are residence, correct? And that he aware that in April and May, the war was raging on in his cellule of origin, correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, at the beginning of the month of May the war had ended; there were no more killings. When he came, there were no more killings.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Why do you think Ndindabahizi would wait for two months to come to his cellule of origin when he knew that he had Tutsis relatives and Tutsis were being killed in Rwanda? Why taking two months and not just a week or so if you are late?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I think where he was he had friends and the situation was serious. Maybe he was taking care of his friends. I don't know what he was doing where he was because I was not there. I have no way of knowing.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I put to you that Ndindabahizi came to that cellule in April and May and not June, as you allege?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, he did not come in April. He came at the beginning of June, not in April.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, are you aware of the 3rd of May meeting in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: You never heard that in May, on the 3rd May, the prime minister of the republic of Rwanda visited Kibuye and held a meeting in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: From my place to Kibuye is a long distance. Kibuye is a town. Even if it is in the same Gitesi commune, we were on the border with the Mwendo commune. Our secteur is neighbouring to the Mwendo commune. So you see that there is a long distance between our locality to the town, and without the means of transportation, there weren't a lot of vehicles to enable us to get to the town. It was difficult going to town.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Apparently you were the only Rwandan who didn't hear about this meeting at that time.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That objection is sustained.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Objection, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah, that objection is sustained. Next question.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Your Honour, I don't have another question. We wish to produce this document as Prosecution exhibit.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, this will be P. 33, under seal. Could I ask the booth to repeat, please, the date of this document? It was stated in the first line, I think, of the document. Could you kindly indicate to us again, please?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: It is 31st August '98.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah, that is what I want the booth to kindly read out again. Could you do that, please?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Sorry, the year 1998, the 31st day of the month of August.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So I just wanted to have that confirmed. Thank you very much indeed. P. 33.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 33 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: We also now produce the statement by this witness as a Prosecution exhibit for the purpose of bringing out the contradiction. That is the first statement of this witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. That will be P. 34, then, under seal. And that is the statement of 6th August 2003, the French being the original, I assume, Mr. Besnier, so that will be 34A and this English version 34B then, both under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, thank you.

div.stage: EXhibit Nos. P. 34A and P. 34B admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.Any re-examination from the Defence?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I have a few questions for you. You have stated that at the end of May there were no more massacres. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And this is the time you state the Accused came to his native cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was at the beginning of June.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Okay. You have also stated that a minister had a lot of authority over the entire population and he was like a father to them.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And that there were more Tutsis than Hutus in your native area, in the cellule.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And you said when he came he was furious because his relatives had been killed.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Any reaction with regard to other Tutsis who were the majority in the cellule who had been killed before he came?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, he said the following: "Who ordered you to kill these people? Who gave you the orders?"

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: I also want to ask you a few questions about the roadblock erected to get money. You stated initially that the roadblock was erected to get money by two people, by the two people you mentioned, and then later on you said it was to check banditry.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was the bandits, the thieves who erected the barriers, the roadblocks.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Was it to check property taken from the Tutsi or Hutu who were being robbed of their property during the war?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, they wanted money. When they saw somebody who had money who was passing by, and because nobody could protect that person, he was asked to give all his money. They were strong, they were carrying weapons, clubs, spears, and when you see the club, you have to give your money, because you might die in the process if you don't. So you will understand that a Tutsi couldn't go through this roadblock; they were hiding.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Yes. And that is exactly my next question. Why were they afraid to go on these roadblocks, to go through them, if they were to check for money?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: People were passing by and when they got to the roadblock they would take their money, but they were not able to take money from a lot of people because when they realised that that was the purpose of the roadblock, people were going through the bush.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: You also stated that at one point in time you were a member of the cellule committee before the war. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And at the time --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, because I was a trader, I was no longer a member of that committee because I did not have time for these administrative matters.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Okay. And you lost a number of people, including eight nephews; is that what you said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Did you report this matter to any authority or even to the Accused when he came to your cellule in May or beginning of June?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: That is known; there was a trial in the courts of first instance. My brother-in-law survived and he hid in his father-in-law's house, sometimes he would hide in my house. He survived. He remarried and currently has three children.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: How many houses did you have in this cellule? You had a business house in the centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I had my house where I lived, which is not far from the centre, and I also had the shop, and they, too, are separated by a distance of five minutes walk.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And was there a pit by the roadblock at the centre where bodies were thrown?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. There was no pit. There was rather a latrine which was behind my house. There was a pit latrine close to the road, and apart from this latrine there was no other pit.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Were any bodies thrown in this latrine?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And did you sell alcohol in your restaurant?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was a shop, and I used to sell food as well.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Okay. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, we will come back in a moment to hear the last questions, but there is a meeting starting just now so we have to take the last bit in a few minutes. That's why we have to stop now, but we will take the last five minutes of your questioning in about 15 minutes. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, Mr. Witness, we were just about rounding up your testimony, but there are a few questions left from the Judges.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you were the member of the committee of your cellule at the relevant time, is that correct, in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I was no longer a member of the cellule committee.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: But did you remain as a member of the committee of your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No. Before the war, elections took place, and I wasn't elected because I did not have the time to deal with administrative issues, given my trade, my business.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You said that residents of the neighbouring secteur had erected a roadblock in your cellule, is that correct, that Minani?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I spoke of a roadblock which was at a place which I could see; that's the one I mentioned. I couldn't move around to see what was happening elsewhere.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: But this roadblock was at your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Did you take any step to restrain those strangers from erecting the roadblock in your cellule of which you remained as a member of the committee?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I told you that I was no longer a member of the cellule committee. When the war broke out I was no longer a member of the committee for the cellule.Those people were coming from other secteurs, but they were stronger than we were. We didn't have any means of defending ourselves; I'm referring to people who lived in the cellule. The people who came from elsewhere were stronger than us.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Okay. You said that Karegeya was taken away by a man called Bapfakurera in your presence?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, I saw him. Before I didn't know Bapfakurera's name, but later on I informed myself and I realised that the people -- the person who was taking away Karegeya was called Bapfakurera.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Karegeya was your well-wisher, he was your boss, he had given you the land free of cost. Did you take any step to save him from that man?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I had no powers. All I could do was to hide his child; she managed to survive. But the others were stronger than myself; I could do nothing, given the powers they had.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: So, you mean to say that you were weaker, that's why you did not stop the assailants, or the killers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, that's what I mean. They were stronger than I. How can you stop more than a hundred -- twenty attackers who are armed with clubs and spears? How can you stop them?

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, when you were asked by the Prosecution why there was a discrepancy between, on the one hand, the information concerning the Karegeya killing in your statement to investigators and, on the other hand, your information in your '98 interview to the Rwandan prosecutor, you said that you later carried out investigations. Did I understand you correctly?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I was able to obtain information, and that was necessary. When you see someone leading attackers, you should be interested in knowing who that person is, so that later on you can say who that person was exactly, the person leading the attackers.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, when did you proceed to obtain such information?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: When order was re-established, when the authority began to become operational, before one could meet people who were bragging about having done this or that, so when you heard that you would say to yourself, "There's information which is circulating. I should collect it and know what really happened". And that's how I started to carry out my small investigations until I had information which confirmed that the person whom I saw, although I didn't know his name, was indeed the person who was leading the attackers. So now I had his name, the name of the person whom I had seen, although at the time I saw him I didn't know his name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So when did you start your investigations, approximately; in which year?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was after the war. It was around August, after the war. It was at that point in time that one could move about to go where people were meeting. One could hear people bragging about what they had done. You could hear them in bars, and this was how I was able to obtain information. So when this information was gathered and it was confirmed, at that time we were then sure that we had in hand the information we were looking for.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does this imply that you started your investigations in August '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Well, we could hear rumours, but we were not sure that the information was true. I couldn't rush and provide information which I had not checked out. So after his death, I started to collect information. Even though the authorities had not become operational, I started to gather information gradually while awaiting for order to be re-established.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you started gathering information gradually in 1994; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Well, you see, after the death of that person I started gradually to collect information, so you would continue to inform yourself in this manner until you receive all the details so that you have the exact information. That's how I proceeded.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And what interests me now, Mr. Witness, is the time, and I have understood you to the effect that you started this exercise in '94; is my comprehension correct, please? Just yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Yes, immediately after the death of this person. But now I know the truth, and now I know that Bapfakurera was, in fact, the person I saw leading the attackers. People saw him, and they informed me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, when did you receive information that this person, this leader, was in fact Mr. Bapfakurera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: It was when I came back from the prosecutor's office. You know, I was called by the inspector of the judicial police. It's after that that I started to collect information. Even the IPJ came to carry out information. He told me, "Now you can go back home, because I know the truth". At that point in time I myself continued to inform myself and I was able to get to know where the person who had been killed had been taken by Bapfakurera, where Bapfakurera had taken him to kill him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So from '94 to August '98, in spite of investigations, you did not find out the name of the man who took Mr. Karegeya away?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: He was not someone who was always there. At a point in time he fled, but people were saying it was him, others were saying it wasn't him, so there were contradictions, accusations and counter-accusations. He left, and after a moment he came back. He went to Zaire and he came back home. It was after his return that I continued to collect information and we were able to get to know that he was the one, and he was arrested and put in prison.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So how did you first hear his name mentioned as the possible leader in this group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Well, it was being said all the time, but these people who were talking about him didn't know whom I had seen. However, it was when I was able to say that the person who I saw was the cobbler, it's then that they were able to say, "Oh, yes, that person is Bapfakurera", and the members of the population in fact said where he had taken -- he had found Cyprien and where he had taken him to kill him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And when did you obtain this clarity? Which year?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I knew it, but I didn't know his name. I knew he was a cobbler; he was someone who was working and would move to markets to go and work. I knew him, but I didn't know his name. It was only after he came back from exile that I was able to know that that cobbler was in fact Bapfakurera.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, I understand that, Mr. Witness, and when was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, I cannot give you an exact date. That was a long time ago. But it was after I came back from the prosecutor's office.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, in which year; can you help us with that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I think that if you were to look at the report of the interview that we had before the court, you can find the date. I cannot remember the date myself.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, what I want to know from you now is when were you in a position, because of this information concerning the cobbler -- just a moment, just a moment. Listen to the question, because we are not communicating well now, Mr. Witness.Now, the question is as follows: when, which year, were you able, based on the information concerning the cobbler and the fact that the person had returned from another country, to establish that that person was indeed Mr. Bapfakurera? Which year were you able to establish that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: No, actually he hadn't left the country, he had fled to the Nduga area in Gitarama prefecture, and that's where he had fled to. There were some people who had fled towards Zaire, but given his profession, he continued to work within Rwanda itself. I was summoned by the IPJ to the prosecutor's office. After I came back, he himself returned home, and it's at that point in time the IPJ came to our home to carry out investigations. I suspect the IPJ knew it was him, and he said, "I have done my investigations. I know you are innocent, and now I know how Cyprien was killed. You don't have any problem". So he sent me to fetch witnesses; the witnesses met him and gave him the information.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, are you in a position to remember the year in which you found out that it was Mr. Bapfakurera who was the leader? Which year was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: I think that was in 1998.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. If there are no further questions, Mr. Witness, your testimony has come to an end. Thank you very much for having come the long way to testify before the Tribunal, and we wish you a very safe journey home. Please do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DL:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the registry could kindly assist the witness and bring in the next witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good morning, Madam Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, you are a protected witness and will be referred to as Witness DU in these proceedings. You have to tell the truth, and the registry will now take your solemn declaration to that effect.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DU in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, Madam Witness, do you see a document in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, I do indeed have a document here, but I do not know how to read.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: At the bottom of that document there is some kind of a sign or signature. Do you recognise that writing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you write this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does this imply that the information in that document was read out to you and that it is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes. The information contained in this document is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: D. 27, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 27 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Now, Madam Witness, you will be asked questions by the Defence.Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: First of all, Mr. President, for some minutes, really only a few minutes, about two -- three or four minutes, I would like to ask the witness questions about her identity, her origins, and she does not wish to be identified. Consequently, for four to five minutes could we have a closed session so that we could deal with these issues and then immediately thereafter come back to an open session?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, that application will then be granted. Thank you for drawing our attention to the fact that we are talking about five minutes.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 42 to 43] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We can then proceed in open session again. So this implies, Madam Witness, that you have to be careful from now on when you answer the questions. All right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, yes, I've understood that, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember the approximate date of the death of the president of Rwanda in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, I do remember the period of time, but I do not know the exact date.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Even roughly, approximately?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, I don't remember the date at all. I was tilling for a company, and I got to know that the president had died.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What happened to the population, the people in general in the few days following the president's death?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: There was a war.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you be a bit more specific, Madam Witness? You say there was a war; were there any killings? Who was killing and who was being killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: It was the Tutsis who were being killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And by whom were they being killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: It's the Interahamwe who were killing them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: From where did the Hutu killers come from, the Hutu killers who were killing the Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Initially they came from Kayenzi, and they came killing on their way and they finally reached our secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So that means that largely speaking the people of your secteur saw people coming from outside?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Can you please repeat your question, Counsel? It wasn't very clear for the interpreters.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Does this mean that the people who came to kill in your cellule came from other secteurs?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: The people from Buye secteur came by repelling the people who came to attack.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In your particular situation, Madam Witness, since you were a Tutsi, in order to avoid being killed what exactly did you do? Did you go to hide, for instance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, I went into hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you be more specific, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: When my uncle's son had just been killed -- he was my neighbour -- when he was killed, I went into hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you go into hiding alone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I was together with my grandchild.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: With your granddaughter, do you mean?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, my granddaughter.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The interpreter didn't hear the beginning of that question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: She was two months old.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Could counsel be reminded to give the interpreters the break we need for switching from one relay to another system.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Where did you go to hide, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I went to hide in a bush which was not very far from Nyabahanga river.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And your husband, who was Hutu, did he come to see you to supply you with food and other commodities?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, he came to supply me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But you did not hide in the house, did you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, sir, the houses were being searched.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How did the Hutu massacre the Tutsi with weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: They had clubs. They were armed with clubs, with spears, with machetes, and with sharpened sticks.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, your family members of Tutsi origin were also killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: The members of my family, did you say, sir? Yes, sir, they were killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you know -- since you've lived in that area all the time, did you know Mr. Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, I do. Yes, for a long time, when he was a bachelor, actually, but it was -- it had been a long time that I hadn't seen him, since the beginning of the war. It had been a long time since we saw each other last.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, during the war, did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, during the war, did your husband tell you that he saw him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, sir, he saw him after the war.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you be more specific? Your husband told you that he saw Mr. Ndindabahizi during the events or immediately following the events?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: He saw him after the events, that is, around the end of June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did your husband tell you what Ndindabahizi told him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: He came and took me to my hiding place and told me that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi had said that nobody should no longer kill anybody, so that he took me from my hiding place to the house.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So your husband knew that Ndindabahizi had told the population no longer to kill any Tutsi; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: That is correct. He said that nobody should no longer kill and that they had killed enough, and that enough was enough.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, after Ndindabahizi's departure, did your husband come back to tell you that you could safely go back home?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, sir, and immediately I went back home and, since then, no Hutu ran after any Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you take it that Mr. Ndindabahizi contributed to restoring peace in the cellule and in the region?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, sir, security was restored because one could sleep peacefully. One no longer feared because one was no longer being chased around.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: That means that after the arrival of Ndindabahizi in your area security for Tutsis disappeared (sic) ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, there was no insecurity any more. Insecurity had disappeared for the Tutsi. The Tutsi were in peace.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi when you were hiding under the Nyabahanga Bridge, did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, sir, I did not see him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, when your husband told you that he saw Ndindabahizi and that he had contributed in bringing about peace back in the area and that you may cease from hiding, was that a little bit just after he saw Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Well, they met. They met over there in Gitaka.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, when your husband told you what Ndindabahizi said to him, was it just after having seen him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Well, he told me immediately after, indeed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, last question: If I were to put it to you that that meeting such as reported to you by Ndindabahizi -- if I were to suggest to you that meeting as told you by your husband was rather at the beginning of June rather than at the end of June, would you take it that it would rather be at the beginning of June instead of the end of June?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, this is preposterous.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, so this objection is sustained. You can't ask that question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I do not remember any date or month, but I remember that it is -- it was the month of June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Indeed, it was in June. Wasn't it at the beginning of June?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The witness has given her answer.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I do not remember whether it was at the beginning or at the end of that month. I do not remember clearly.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence, please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I have no more questions, Mr. President. The answer --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone is off.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Prosecution?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Good afternoon, madam. You have --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you have never lived in Gasharu cellule, have you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: When your husband came from Gasharu cellule he told you that the war was over, right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And to your knowledge, was it not at the end of June that the war ended?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I did not understand the question, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When -- Madam Witness, when, in your view -- when, in your view, did the war end?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: If my memory serves me right, during the month of June. Apart from the fact that Emmanuel came by, the Tutsi were still being chased, but after his departure, they were not sought after in their houses anymore.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, you were married to a Hutu man, right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, in April up to mid-May, Tutsi women married to Hutu men were not being sought. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: They were sought after.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Isn't it a fact that Hutu women married to Tutsi men -- Tutsi women married to Hutu men were being sought after May -- after May '94, May, June?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: You mean women married to Hutu?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Madam Witness. Tutsi women who were married to Hutu men at the beginning of the war were not targeted for killing. Are you aware of that, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: They were hunted down and, indeed, they were the first to be killed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Now, Madam Witness, what did your husband die of?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: My husband died at around the month of December. The Interahamwe who were hiding in the bush caught him on the Nyabahanga river banks and killed him.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: But your husband was Hutu, madam, why was he killed by Interahamwe?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: He was killed by people who were hiding in the bush. Those people did not want to come out to show themselves and to accuse him of being somebody that was reporting on them.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can you repeat the month when your husband was killed, Madam Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I believe it was in December.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which year?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: It was one year after the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could the interpreters kindly push their button? Thank you. Now, so would this be December '94 or December '95?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: It was one year after the end of the war.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, I suggest to you that you couldn't have hidden in a sorghum field with a two-month old baby with all that cold and rain. What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Well, I was constantly with that child because its mother was at the house and the mother came from time to time to breast-feed. (Inaudible) the fact that the father of the child was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I suggest to you, Madam Witness, that your husband protected you and the small child in your house during the war.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: I was not in the house because from 7 a.m. they came seeking me out at the house as well as the child and they only went away -- they stayed there till about 5 p.m.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Madam Witness, if you were really hiding in that sorghum field didn't the child betray you -- betray your hiding by crying and that kind of -- that kind of thing?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: The child did not cry. It was given can liquid to drink, but since the mother knew where I was, sometimes she came to breast-feed.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: So it's your testimony, Madam Witness, that you never saw or heard Ndindabahizi speak in April, May or June '94, right?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: No, I didn't hear anybody say that he had come to the area.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: And that the information your husband gave you was that Ndindabahizi came after the war was over.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: That's all, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Witness, of what ethnic group was your granddaughter that you were hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: She was Tutsi. The father was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: She was Tutsi because the dead father was Tutsi, that is, the father who was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, the father was Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Madam, could you, for as much as possible, tell us what you mean by "the end of the war", "the end of the war". What do you call "the end of the war"?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: When I talk about the end of the war, I mean that at that time people were no longer being hunted down.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And "the end of the war", where do you place it, immediately after Ndindabahizi came by?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Yes, I confirm that it was at that time that the war ended because after his departure, nobody was killed anymore.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: That would be all, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Madam Witness, your testimony has come to an end. Thank you very much for coming the long way to Arusha to testify. We wish you a very safe journey home. Please, do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you very much. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DU:
sp.p: Most grateful, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Registry, please.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If we could have brought in Witness DV, then. Is there a document concerning DV, for instance, the statement, except for the version in the folder, possibly?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, the registry should have a copy of those documents concerning the particulars of DV.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to with the pseudonym DV in these proceedings. Do you have a document in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, that document, is there a signature on it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I see the signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is it -- is it your signature?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the information contained in that document is correct, is it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Defence Exhibit 28 under seal, then.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D 28 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you have to tell the truth and the Registry will then administer the taking of the solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, please stand up. Raise your right hand and say after me.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DV in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: You may be seated.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you will now first be asked questions by the Defence.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Most obliged, Mr. President. Mr. President, in order to avoid a closed session, I shall ask the witness to write down on a peace of paper the name of the cellule, secteur and the commune in which he lived in 1994, with the assistance of the Registry, of course.

div.stage: WITNESS DV,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you jot down on that piece of paper the name of the cellule where you lived in 1994, the name of the secteur, and the name of the commune.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Most obliged, Mr. President. I need some assistance from the Registry, Mr. President. Now that the witness has the document here, we should draw attention to the name on the document, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you see the name of a location in the document you have?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is this then if it's not a geographical location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I'm sorry, I am mistaken. This is a location indeed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know this location, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, in the first document that was given to you, you indicated the name of the area in which you lived in 1994; isn't that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, we shall refer to that location so that we will now say that that is document 1. Is that understood, Witness? We shall take that document as document 1.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I did not get you. Could you explain this?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, in order not to identify you, we are not going to talk about the cellule where you come from, but we shall refer to it as being the cellule that is mentioned in document 1.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Very well, now I do understand.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
