sp.p: So that we would ask you questions also on the second location, and that second location will be designated as Location 2.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is the distance between location 1, that is, where you lived in the 1994 -- that is, the distance between Location 1 and Location 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: This would be about five or six minutes walk on foot.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, from -- or, rather than going from location 1 and go and see what is happening in location 2, is that possible?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, it is possible to see from location 1 what is happening in location 2, instead of walking.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let us talk about 1994. Could you tell us how you learnt about the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I can tell you. Upon the death of President Habyarimana, I was living in Kibuye. I was studying there. I was in the first year of secondary school. If my memory serves me right, it was on the 7th of April 1994 when the principal of our school told us that President Habyarimana was dead and that there was no security anymore in the country and that we should go home to our respective parents.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what did you do yourself; did you go back to your parents' house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes. On the very same day I went back home.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, in the area where you lived in 1994, what was the security situation after the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: The security situation was not good. People started killing each other. One ethnic group killed the other ethnic group, but not all the members of the various ethnic groups were involved in killing, or some did, some did not participate in such massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is your ethnic group, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I am Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In your native cellule that is Location 1, was there a roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: There was no roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And in location 2, was there a roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, there was a roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, throughout the period of the genocide, were people killed in your cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, people were killed in our cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the ethnic group of those people who were killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: They were Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, tell us about the killers. Do you know the ethnic group of the killers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: The killers were Hutu and Twas.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is it all the Hutu and all the Twa, without any exception, that were involved in killing the Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, sir. They were not all involved in the massacres or participated -- they did not all participate in the massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, so far as your cellule was concerned, the Hutu that killed Tutsi, were they born in that cellule or did they come from other areas?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Well, some were born in the cellule and others came from other cellules.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You, yourself, did you see with your own eyes the killing, one time or several times, of Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Which killing did you witness and who were the victims?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: For example, I witnessed the killing of Nyirabagesera, Josephine by a Hutu. I saw Gatete killing one Mboninma (phonetic).

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You made reference to one Josephine. Do you know her personally?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I knew her.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you related to her?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, this Josephine that you refer to, was she married?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, she was married.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the husband's name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Cyprien Karegeya.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who killed Josephine?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was Ntirihirika who killed Josephine. Ntirihirika is spelt N-T-I-R-I-H-I-R-I-K-A.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, could you please repeat her husband's name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Josephine's husband was called Cyprien Karegeya.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In what circumstances was Josephine killed by this Ntirihirika?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Ntirihirika found Josephine downhill from our house in a banana plantation, where she was hiding. The daughter took one direction and Josephine took one direction. Ntirihirika followed her, caught up with her and killed her with a club. This is the scene that I witnessed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: On which date did this happen?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not recall the date.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If you refer to the death of President Habyarimana, are you able to give us an estimate of the date on which she died, for example, X-number of weeks after the death of the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I think it was towards the end of the month of April, the last few days of the month of April.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did Cyprien Karegeya survive the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He is also dead.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you witness the circumstances under which he died?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, I did not witness his death. I only heard that he died.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And according to the information you got, how did he die?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I heard that he was killed at Gitaka, but it was at the beginning of May that he was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who told you that Cyprien Karegeya was killed in the month of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was the people who lived in my -- within my neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you know a man called Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I know him for having seen him only once.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where and when did you see him this once?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I saw him at Gitaka.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And when was this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was in June.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness. You made reference to Location no. 2; do you recall that? And what were you doing in that location on that day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When I saw Emmanuel Ndindabahizi I was in a small centre where there are shops and I went to buy a few things.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Did you witness Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's arrival?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I found him there, but when I got there at the centre, I found him there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you saying that he had already arrived when you got there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you recall the time when you got to that location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I recall that it was Sunday. People were come back from church and it was in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you able to tell us what this person called Emmanuel Ndindabahizi did or said in this Location no. 2, and what you witnessed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I found him at this centre and he was asking the people who ordered them to kill. And he told them, "Look, it is the same blood that is flowing in the veins of each one -- each and every one of us". And at that stage he arrested somebody that he believed to have participated in the killings and took him away for detention. The people who were present there brought another person that they said was a criminal. His name was Gatete, and Ndindabahizi asked them to take Gatete. Gatete fled and they were not able to arrest him. That is all I know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, very much. How did you know that it was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, since you didn't know him before then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: This is what happened. It was his native cellule and people were saying that Ndindabahizi had arrived in the cellule and it was those members of the cellule who were saying this.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you observe the vehicle in which he arrived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I saw the vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know which vehicle this was, the model, the make?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was a minibus and I cannot remember the colour.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When you arrived was Ndindabahizi already talking to the people? Had he started or he hadn't started talking to them yet?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When I arrived there, Ndindabahizi was talking to the people who were there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Therefore, you did not hear everything that he said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I only heard what he said when I was present there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Since you were an eyewitness, can you repeat what he said to the Court with as much accuracy as possible? Try to remember what he said.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When I got there, he was asking the people present who ordered them to kill the people. At that stage, the people tried to give him an explanation, to give him an indication of their situation. But when I got there he was telling them that, "You should not kill the people. You know it is the same blood which is flowing in the veins of each and every one of us".

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was Ndindabahizi's tone when he was talking to the people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He was sad.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let's get to the facts. Did Ndindabahizi do anything on that day in that locality?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: While I was there, he asked the people the following: "Don't you know people who might have participated in the killings?" And the people told him there is one Gatete, a terrible criminal. And he said, "Bring me this Gatete." And Gatete fled. I know that Ndindabahizi also arrested another person that he believed participated in the killings and he took this person to detention. That is what I know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The second person you are referring, the one he took away for detention, what was his occupation in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I know this person had a bar of banana beer. He was a petty trader at that centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And that person you are referring to, did he hold any administrative position in the cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: To my knowledge, no.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. For more clarification, I'm going to ask you to write the name of this person on a sheet of paper.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: With the assistance of the Registry.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Have you written one or two names here, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I have put two names on the sheet of paper.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And these two names are the persons that you -- who are these two persons, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I don't understand you very well.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thanks.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, indeed, I see you've written two names on this sheet of paper --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: We didn't hear the end of counsel's question.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You have written the name of one person on the sheet of paper, is that it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: This is what I did: I wrote that Ndindabahizi arrested this person, took him to detention. If you so wish, I can write the name of only the person you are interested in.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No, it's okay. We are going to request the Kinyarwanda interpreters to translate what you've written on the sheet of paper so everyone can understand. That's going to be very brief.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: If the interpreters can avoid translating the name itself.

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: On a sheet of paper is the written the following: "He arrested" -- then the name of the person -- "and took him to detention".

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, now I see it's very clear.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you see, yourself, Emmanuel Ndindabahizi take this person into detention?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I was an eyewitness to this event.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And how do you know that he was taking him into detention? They might very well have being going on -- to walk around?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, Ndindabahizi spoke to this person and the told him that he was taking him into detention. He told him, "You have killed people, where did you put them?" He arrested him, took him into detention. And that happened in front of all of us in broad daylight.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And this person you are talking about, did he try to defend himself or resist arrest?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, he did not resist.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know if Emmanuel Ndindabahizi had already come to the region before that visit?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I did not hear anyone talk about his possible visit to the region. It was only on that day that people said he had arrived.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To your recollection, did this visit of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi take place before or after the death of Josephine?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Ndindabahizi came after the death of Josephine.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you able to tell the Court on which date the person who was arrested was detained by Ndindabahizi, and then came back after his detention?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: The person was arrested on Sunday. I cannot recall the date, and on Monday, I saw the person who was arrested. And I'm talking about the Monday immediately following that Sunday, which means the person spent just one day in the cell.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, I still have a few questions. May I continue?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Approximately how many questions? So that we know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Maybe ten minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is this problem again of someone waiting for a meeting at one o'clock. For that reason I think we have to stop now and resume at 2:30. So, Mr. Witness, we will continue with your testimony at 2:30 this afternoon. Thank you, very much. (Court recessed at 1300H)

div.stage: Pages 46 to 58 by Gifty C. Harding)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the Defence had a few questions left for you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, we left off at an incident where you had seen Mr. Emmanuel Ndindabahizi visit a specific place. Do you recall?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Maybe you could recount the episode, because I've forgotten it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: We had concluded with that episode. I want to begin another one. I wanted to know whether you knew if there was a roadblock in the cellule we referred to, which is not the one where your home is situated but it's the cellule in which you saw Emmanuel Ndindabahizi in 1994.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: There was a roadblock there, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know who had erected that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know who was manning the roadblock, that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I would see people there as I passed by. There would be people there as I passed by, but I wouldn't know who was responsible for it, for manning it.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know whether people were killed at that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, I don't know anyone who was killed there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know whether the Tutsis of the area were killed after Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's visit to the area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When Ndindabahizi came many people had been killed, and no one was being killed any more.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: According to you, is there any link between Ndindabahizi's visit to the area and the stoppage of the killings?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Could you please repeat your question?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Between Ndindabahizi's visit and the stoppage of the killings, do you believe there is any link between the two?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I think there is a link, because Ndindabahizi had said that if there were survivors, they should not be killed. People should not be killed, and that whoever had participated in the killings should be prosecuted, so I do believe there is a link.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Now I want to put to you some very personal questions on your personal -- your family relationships.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, here I believe I have no other choice but to request for a closed session, but I'm not quite sure how much time I'll need for these questions to the witness regarding his family. It wouldn't last very long. I think five minutes maximum, Mr. President, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, that's granted, then, and the public has noticed the estimate.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 61 to 78] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So now we will open this session. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to in these proceedings as Witness DB. You have to tell the truth, like all other witnesses, and the registry will now take your solemn declaration. (Declaration made by Witness DB in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, the document you have in front of you there, Mr. Witness, is that your signature on the bottom of that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir, that is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that that information in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, the information is correct, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Exhibit 32 under seal. Thank you. Now you are in open session, Mr. Witness, so take care when you are answering the questions. Do not reveal your activity. Defence please.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 32 admitted, under seal)
WITNESS DB,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Witness, where were you living in April? Where were you living in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I was living in Kibuye, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And where was your family living prior to the events of 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: My family lived in Rubengera town.Q: During the events in 1994, you settled in Kibuye for how long?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I continued to work for about two months, and then I stopped working. I began to rest.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What was your profession, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I was a driver.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you be a bit more specific, Mr. Witness? What do you mean by driver?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I was ... ... driver.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember the date of the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But you recall the events that followed that event, do you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: After his death, there was a war.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were you a witness to any of the massacres?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I was not a witness of the massacres, but I was transporting people wounded. I did not witness any of the killings that were going on.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: During your professional activities, did you ever get to be confronted by any particular difficulties in your work?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I did encounter difficulties.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you tell us what they were, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: At a given point in time, I was sent somewhere in Rubengera to go and buy diesel. I was alone. And when I came back, I was with a medical assistant, and that medical assistant was taken and killed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So there you are, you went to Rubengera.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I had been sent there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You went to fetch fuel for your vehicle, and on this occasion you met someone. Whom did you meet, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Who are you talking about?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You said a moment ago that you were going to buy fuel in Rubengera and that you left alone and that you came back with a medical assistant from the hospital. Can you please be a little bit more clear about the identity of that person, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Do you want me to speak about that assistant?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He was a medical assistant known as Nors.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please spell that name for us, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Nors is spelt N-O-R-S.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please inform us, please, initially you went to Rubengera, and, if I understood you correctly, you went to fetch fuel, and then you came back with Nors?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, what happened on your way back between Rubengera and the Kibuye hospital? When you were on your way back, what happened?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When we were on our way -- when I reached Rubengera I found Nors on the road and he asked me where I was going. I told him that I had come to buy diesel. He told me that he was on sick leave, but that he wanted to go back with me because his sick leave had expired. And so I agreed. When he went to his house to fetch his bag, and when I had bought the fuel, I found him again at the same place with his bag. He got on the vehicle and we left together.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you left Rubengera for Kibuye with Nors, who had with him his bag. Now, did you encounter any difficulties on that trip, the trip between Rubengera and Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, we encountered difficulties on our way back. When we reached a roadblock, which was at Kayenzi, when the people manning the roadblock realised that there was this white person in the vehicle, they told me to come down. They asked him where he came from, where he was going, and what his profession was. And he answered their questions. They threatened him, but I defended him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Something which is not quite clear, you said this white man. Do you mean that Nors was not -- what nationality -- or to what ethnic group did Mr. Nors come from? What country was he from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not know what his country of origin was. He was born in Rwanda by a white father and a Rwandese mother.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In other words, he was a half-caste, was he?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, he was a half-caste.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Let's come back to the Kayenzi roadblock. So on your way from Rubengera to Kibuye you reached the roadblock, and you say that after having been stopped, he was then -- after being arrested, he was, in fact, released?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, he was released.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you then encounter other difficulties?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: We encountered other difficulties, but they were not as serious as those that we had at Kayenzi. When I reached the Kibuye roundabout --

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Please go ahead, Mr. Witness. When you reached the Kibuye roundabout, what happened?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: We found gendarmes there who also asked me to stop. They asked me about the person who was on board my vehicle.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well. So, you finally got to the hospital together with Mr. Nors?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No. The gendarmes stopped us, and they asked me who my passenger was. I said he was a medical assistant at the Kibuye hospital. We remained there for sometime, and the superior officer of the gendarmes came and ordered the others to let us go.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you were finally able to reach the Kibuye hospital, were you? And what happened there at the Kibuye hospital when you got there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Nors explained to the doctors what had happened to him on the way and he told him that he had come to tell him that he had gone beyond his sick leave by three days and that he had come to say so himself -- he had come to tell him himself. He had come to explain himself, so he that wouldn't have been accused of having abandoned his post.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In the days that followed did you come to accompany Mr. Nors back to his home in Rubengera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes. Nors explained to the doctor all the problems that he had on the way and the doctor told him, "You haven't quite recovered. You shouldn't have come back." And Nors said, "But I can't go back home. I don't have any means of transport. What am I going to do?" The doctor allowed him to extend his sick leave so that he can recover fully. So the doctor said, "You wait. When you find a vehicle which can take you back you can leave. For the time being we have a lot of difficulties. We have a lot of people who are unwell."

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was it you who took Nors back to his home in Rubengera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes. It was myself who took him back.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you recall the date on which you took Nors back because he was now having extended sick leave which he was going to enjoy in Rubengera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was the 25th of May -- 26th of May, rather.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You were taking Nors back to his home on the 26th of May in the vehicle -- I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: We were also in the company of the wife of a doctor known as Leonard.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, who -- what enabled you to be so specific about the date on which you took back Nors to his home, together with the doctor's wife, so that Nors can continue with his extended sick leave in Rubengera comfortably?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I remember that date very well, because I was able to read that date on my log-book.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could the Bench and the Prosecution refer to the document attached to the witness document, the witness statement? I believe the registry has distributed that document, which I have here. By your leave, could the registry collect this document? Please show this document first to the witness and then to the Bench. Actually these documents are already in your possession, Mr. President, Your Honours, and the Prosecution also, but in case this is still needed I am giving them out again. Please make sure the witness has a copy.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, we think we can be of some assistance to the Trial Chamber. We are quite happy to stipulate to this document, the date, and whatever is contained therein. There's no -- we look to save time and we have no problems with the document and the attachments. We stipulate to it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Now, but it was good for the Chamber to receive this document because we only have it in the typewritten version in front of us, but now we have it in the handwritten version, which was good. So thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Does the witness have the same document, Mr. Registry?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I have the document. No, I have the logbook, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, on that log-book, Mr. Witness, am I correct in saying that's what enables you to confirm that that trip, during which you took Nors back, indeed, took place on the 26th of May? Yes, it's date says 26th May and the speedometer at departure read 31,424. The name of the driver is placed there. I believe we should not mention this as interpreters in the booth. Then there are other details included in that trip, including the reading of the speedometer at the end of the trip. Yes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, it took place on the 26th of May 1994, and it is mentioned that the purpose of that trip was to take Nors back to Rubengera.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you please, Mr. Witness, speak to us about that trip of the 26th of May 1994 during which you took Mr. Nors back from the Kibuye hospital to Rubengera?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I can talk to you about that trip.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I didn't hear the answer. Let me repeat my question, Mr. Witness. On the 26th of May 1994 you had the assignment of taking Mr. Nors back to his home, together with the wife of one doctor. Now, this is confirmed by the log-book which you gave a copy -- of which you gave a copy to us and a copy which I also gave to the Bench. Can you please tell us about the circumstances surrounding this trip of the 26th of May? My question is quite simple. What happened on this 26th of May between the Kibuye hospital and Rubengera, your destination?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: The doctor told me to take Nors back, and the doctor's wife. And we reached the Kayenzi roadblock, and the people who were at the roadblock took Nors. The first time I had defended him and I was able to get him back, but when I was doing the return trip they refused to accept what I was saying. They insisted that I had told them lies, that he was a Belgian, and they took him. They were saying that he was a Belgian who was an accomplice of the Inkotanyi Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So, they took Mr. Nors out of the vehicle -- no. Did they take him out of the vehicle by force, is that what you're saying, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: They did not physically force him out of the vehicle, but they ordered him to get out of the vehicle and had he not obeyed, they obviously would have forced him, but he came out of the vehicle himself.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did he take his belongings? Did he take his bag with him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, they took his bag.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What about his personal effects?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He had nothing else, apart from his bag.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And you -- he didn't have a watch?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He was wearing a watch. They took his spectacles. They took his shirt and his trousers. He remained practically naked. He was only in his underclothing.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So did they take his watch?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, they took his watch and his glasses, his spectacles, as well as his trousers and his sandals -- his shoes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What did they tell you, Mr. Witness? What did these people tell you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: They removed the tree trunk and the stones which were used to block the road and told me to continue. And when I did not leave they told me that I had to leave. So I left with the vehicle. I went a certain distance and I stopped. They then said, "Oh, he's stopping again." And they said, "Arrest him also."So when I saw them coming towards me -- but I remained there for some time, because I was telling myself that they were going to have pity on the man. And when I saw an attacker come towards me armed with a club I immediately entered the vehicle. He struck me with the club on my back. I started the vehicle. After a certain distance I stopped. The lady said, "But they're going to kill you, because they are not stopping from telling you to continue (sic). So I drove slowly and I stopped at the place -- I stopped close by a eucalyptus tree, and I was able to see them as they were coming from the bush where they had just killed the person. They were content. They were happy as if they had done something good, whereas they had just killed someone. And after that I left. So that is what happened. That is how this person was taken away from me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, Defence, this is, of course, a dramatic event. But we have not heard about the killing of Nors previously in this case, have we? Has that been a subject matter from a previous witness, the killing of Nors?And it is only our recollection which is not satisfactory. Is it a previous witness saying that?Mr. Ndindabahizi was involved in one way or another as regards the killing of Nors, directly?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, I may intervene on this matter. The witness -- Witness CGC, a Prosecution witness indeed testified that Mr. Ndindabahizi allegedly distributed machetes at a roadblock the witness is referring to now, and that immediately after that act, a half-caste was killed at that same roadblock. The killing, or the murder of that half-caste was therefore allegedly the direct consequence of the presence of Mr. Ndindabahizi at the roadblock, as testified to by the witness, CGC, and so we are trying to corroborate the testimony of this witness and what has been said by the previous witness.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I beg your pardon, contradict, is the term used by Defence counsel. Apologies from the interpreter.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, what confused us up here, I think, is that we are not absolutely certain that the name which is now being mentioned is the same as the name we wrote previously, but now I realise this is the same episode.Thank you very much. Yes, please proceed.

div.stage: BY MR. MARÇAIS:Q. I will repeat what you have just said, Mr. Witness.So, you stopped your vehicle; you got down from the vehicle, is that right? You made a few steps backwards to see what was happening and it was at that point in time that you saw the attackers come back. Did you meet them or did you see them coming back?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I saw them coming back, alone without Nors.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you concluded that Nors was dead, because you saw him taken from the vehicle, taken away into the bush and then the assailants, the attackers, came back from the same bush without that same person, Nors?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, he wasn't with them any longer.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was it the first time that this event is being testified to before a legal authority?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, it is not the first time; I already explained this to the office of the prosecutor in Kibuye. I have been asked questions about this matter before.

div.stage: BY MR. MARÇAIS:Q. I have with me -- but it is in Kinyarwanda -- this document was not submitted in time, and this is the letter of denunciation by -- by that person. It is in Kinyarwanda. (By order of the Court this the name has been extracted and filed under seal) I do agree that this letter is being tendered a bit late in the day. If there is no objection, I would like to have it tendered and accepted as a document in this case.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Registry, could you approach the Defence bench, please?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: My learned friend next to me has just informed me that I mentioned the name of the witness, and can that lapsus be corrected, please, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It will be deleted and placed under seal in the transcripts.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Does the booth have a copy of this document?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Apparently so, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, do you have a document in front of you, Mr. Witness, a handwritten document? Just answer yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I have this document in front of me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, do you want this translated and read into the record, Defence?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: That would be great, Mr. President, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So then we will follow the same procedure as earlier today, when the Prosecution tendered a similar document. But be ware then, that you do not read names indicating the identity of the witness. Yes, please, go ahead. So this is a letter dated the 28th of September 1995.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "Mr. So-and-so, son of so-and-so, and so-and-so, Mabanza commune, 20th of September 1995. Subject: Explanations on the murder of Nors -- Joseph Nors. I, the undersigned, was a victim of violence on the 25th of May l994. And on the 26th of May 1994, at the Kayenzi roadblock, I was assaulted by Gaspari Bamuriki, who was in charge of that roadblock, and it was that person that I was able to recognise. There were other persons there whose names I did not know, but I did seek some information concerning their names. They were Bigirimana, Rwibasira, François, Ndigabo, Niyigemana, Capitoro, Simeon, Komeza," and there is another name that is not legible. "They were many, such that there must be other names that I didn't mention, and probably the person in charge of the roadblock could supply, that is," Mr. Bamuriki, Gaspari, who was in charge of that group, actually. "They got him out of the vehicle, they took his bag and took off his shoes, his watch, his spectacles, and searched him. Following that" -- this is illegible. The next sentence is illegible."Subsequently, I saw them bring out clubs to strike me, and I went away and stopped a little bit further down, and I came back on foot and when I got to the place where they were standing, they saw me; they were coming from the bush and they were armed with clubs, swords, spears and sticks and hoes. The person who killed him, his name could be given to you by the person responsible for the roadblock, because he was responsible for his death and he knows the reasons why that person was killed." Nota bene: " Their excuse was, his identity card on which it was said that he had naturalised and there were two stamps to it. Ndikuyeze, as far as he was concerned, on the 25th of May, l994, accused him of being a Belgian whereas he had been a refugee for a long time. He said that he had been a refugee for a long time, and that he was an accomplice to the Belgian criminals. This was what I was able to see. When they took him, I was in the company of a lady called Gahongajire, Gratio." Signature, and end of translation, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I believe the interpreter has only read seven names -- I see seven names. At any rate the document is tendered to be included in the material for this trial.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 33 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That will be Defence Exhibit No. 33 under seal, and the seventh name was not read because it was illegible.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The seventh name, we will see about it.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, following those events, Witness, did you see in the written statement, and in the letter that we have just read, that you carried out your own investigation? Could you shade light on the inquiries that you carried out that enabled you, for example, to establish the letter of the 25th May, and to tell the Defence investigators what you have told them, including what you told them in June 2003 -- in October, rather, in October 2003 -- in August, in August? That was the 6th of August 2003.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Now, I started my investigation, and when I started, there were some people I knew among the attackers, others I did not know, but I inquired about the others whose names that I didn't know. So I supplied all the names of the attackers that I knew -- I already knew, even those that I had not known before hand.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember them? Can you repeat the names to the Court, if we are given leave?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I can repeat the names.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you do so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Bigirimana; one, Rwibasira; two, Ndigabo; three, Ligena; four, Simeon; five -- I do not know his other name. Komeza; six, and Bamuriki; seven, there was also Ndikuyeze, who was in the first group, on the first occasion, that is, but the second time around when they took Nors away, I didn't see him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, it was first the date of the 26th of April, it is on the log book, your log book; you are certain about the date on that basis at which Nors was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I have no doubt about the date because after his murder I took note of that in a personal notebook that I do not have with me here, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You know that -- do you know Mr. Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not know him, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you know that there is a charge against him of incitement to kill Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I heard about it when questions were being put to me, but in my region, in my area I did not hear talk about that.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: It is said that Mr. Ndindabahizi instigated the killing of Tutsi by distributing machetes. Did you hear about that accusation, and did you take that into account?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I did not hear about that accusation, sir. If his name was mentioned, in view of the fact that I did not know him, I would have remembered his name in the investigations I carried out, when I tried to establish the identity of the killers of Mr. Nors.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So that, Witness, could it be said that during your own investigations you were convinced of the innocence of Mr. Ndindabahizi concerning the death of Mr. Nors?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He played no role whatsoever in that murder, because when I carried out my investigations nobody talked about him in connection with what happened at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, in the trip you made from Kibuye to Rubengera, when on the 26th April you were taking Nors back home, did you come across any other roadblocks, that is, on the 26th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, sir. That was the only roadblock that I came across on my trip.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you not come across other roadblocks in that area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Perhaps I came across a group of persons that were on the road, but they hadn't erected a roadblock, so that there was no roadblock. I would say that there were a group of bandits.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: But Ndindabahizi, it is said that Ndindabahizi was at the roadblock on the 26th of May, before your arrival; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I don't know. I don't know, and I did not hear anything about him in connection with that roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So the only roadblock you came across when you left Kibuye towards Rubegera was at Gaseke where Nors was murdered?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I did explain that I saw a group of people armed with sticks and clubs. They didn't ask me to stop. The only roadblock that I noted was that particular roadblock where I was stopped and where the persons in my company were addressed. That was the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: No more questions, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Approximately how long is the cross-examination?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: About ten minutes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please go ahead .

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I be correct, Mr. Witness, that your statement of 28th September 1995, Defence Exhibit No. 33, formed -- the information in your statement of 28th September 1995 formed the basis of the information contained in your statement of 6th August 2003? Would that be a fair assumption?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I did not get the question.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You'd given a statement in 1995, in Rwanda, had you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And based on the information in your statement in 1995, you gave another statement to the Defence team on the 6th of August 2003; is that not the case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It would appear -- unless I look at the first statement, it would seem so.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: We can safely assume, because we have both statements before us, that in your statement of 1995 you made no specific reference to Mr. Ndindabahizi. That is correct, isn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That is correct, I made no mention of his name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And why was it the case then, Mr. Witness, that you felt the need to carry out investigations as you described in your 2003 statement, having been and eyewitness pretty much to the attack on the 26th of May? What necessitated for the investigations; you were there, were you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I carried out investigations because I did not know all the persons that were there at that roadblock, and it was not they that were to give me information. They had no information for me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Precisely. In your 1995 statement you knew the identity of all those who had participated in the attack the year before, did you not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, I was not able to identify all of them, I was only able to identify those that were at the roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And having carried out your investigations in 2003, you are now convinced that Mr. Ndindabahizi had no responsibility whatsoever for anything that took place at that roadblock; is that not correct, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That is correct. If he had any responsibilities at all, his name would have appeared.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I would have mentioned the name on my list.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well. Now, let's go to your logbook. Who had the responsibility of completing the entries in this logbook? Did you do it yourself or did somebody else do it for you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was the doctor that filled this logbook.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The same doctor that filled the logbook all the time, is it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: In his absence there were other people that would fill the logbook. There were other people that filled the logbook.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And the information that is contained in the logbook is derived from where: the mileage, the destination, the date, how is that information derived?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When one was on a mission the logbook was filled accordingly.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, and how is the information derived; who tells them the mileage before the mission and the mileage afterwards? Do you do it or does somebody else do it for you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: The meter was read and the figures taken, and at the next mission the figures were also taken down, and it was from these figures that the logbook was filled. And once -- I mean, if we were not able to put in the figures, it was the responsibility of the doctor to put them in himself.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How far is Kibuye from Rubengera in terms of kilometres?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I think it's about 18 kilometres. It was 20 kilometres before the road was macadamised. I believe that at present it would be 18 kilometres.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In your logbook the trip from Kibuye to Rubengera is indicated as having taken 52 kilometres. Are you really sure that you ended your journey at Rubengera or somewhere else, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When you came back before the end of the mission, you were sent elsewhere. And when you came back only was the mileage noted.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: But you had been attacked on this day, so presumably you went straight back to base after the attack, didn't you, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: No, I did not. I did not go back to base directly. I took the doctor's wife to Rubengera.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you have the original of this logbook? Do you have the original, where this copy --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I gave the -- I had been given the logbook, and I used the sheet of paper on which the mission was spelt out. I've got the logbook, as such as kept by the office.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So the original logbook from which this came is in your office; is that your testimony as at today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, that logbook is right there at the office.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you have a copy of this logbook, this page of this document on your table now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: I do not have that piece of paper. I was given one, but it was taken away.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you very quickly look at the left-hand column on that paper where the dates are entered, very quickly? Do you see from the 21st down to the 25th? Look at those dates; do you see that, sir? Do you see that -- do you see anything wrong with the dates there, the order of those dates? Is there anything wrong with it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, there is something rather funny here; I see it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Tell me, what do you see as funny there? You tell me.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Instead of the 25th, he wrote the 24th.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And then he wrote the 25th, he wrote the 26th, and then wrote the 25th again after that; didn't he? Is that not the case, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: He made the mistake, I did not, and he moreover did the same thing -- the same thing with the driver who replaced me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The only problem, sir -- you keep looking at that paper -- the only problem, sir, is you can see the typeface on the dates 21st, 24th, 25th, 26th, 25th again, is slightly different from every other typeface on that paper; the handwriting is bolder. Can you see that; slightly different? Look at the rest of the page and everything that is written on that document and compare it to the darkness of those dates, sir.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It was Mr. Leonart that inserted the date 26th, and it was the doctor -- now, so far as the 24th is concerned, that is the handwriting of the accountant. It was the accountant that went on up to the 25th.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your explanation is that the difference in the handwriting and the typeface is because this was completed by two different people? Leonart completed the dates and somebody else, the accountant, completed the name of the driver and the destination; is it? Two separate people filled in this document, sir.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, no further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very quickly on this one. Now, regarding the trip from Kibuye to Rubengera during which you took back Mr. Nors back home and the wife of Mr. Leonart, you have 26th of May for two reasons; the first reason was that it was Dr Leonart, as I think you just said --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: This is ridiculous. My learned friend is not the witness, and he has to stop this.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What are the two reasons -- the two reasons why, apart from -- as far as you can remember, you still keep the dates of the 26th of May in 1994? What are the two reasons, apart from what you remember, that justify your jotting in the 26th of May 1994?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you maintain that this last incident took place on the 26th of May, 26th of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, I am saying that it was on the 26th of May.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Apart from your own personal conviction and your recollection, what else is there that allows you to come here and reassert it today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That's because I took notes when Nors was taken away from me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So that you yourself took personal notes and noted the 26th of May; is that correct?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Have you got a question, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Well, I am trying to crosscheck here. I say that it was on the 26th of May that I took Nors to Rubengera and that he spent the night at Kibuye on the 25th of May. He did not spend the night at Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Well, those were your personal notes. Now, your second note, whose handwriting is it that is the person that filled the logbook and inserted on the 26th of May for the trip to take Nors to Rubengera? Who jotted down those figures? I am referring now to the logbook, sir.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Well, it would appear to me that the 26th of May is my own handwriting. As far as the comment is concerned, that is the handwriting of Dr Leonart.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: No further questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the Gaseke roadblock, where is that? Is there a roadblock called the Gaseke roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: It is the same roadblock as Kayenzi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, when you carried out your investigations to find out who these persons at the roadblock actually were, did you ask during your investigations where they got their weapons from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: They brought their weapons from their respective homes. They had used machetes and used clubs. They did not have any new weapons.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That they had the weapons or what? They, they had the weapons. They were holding the weapons.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You just told me that the weapons they had came from their homes; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: That is correct, because those weapons were used, they were not new.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The weapons to kill Nors came from the assailants' homes; is that your testimony?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Yes, sir, from their homes, because they did not have new weapons. I didn't see any new weapons.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, how do you know that these weapons came from their homes and had not recently been provided by someone? Is there anything in your investigation that can tell us anything about that issue?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: When Nors was taken away from me, when they took Nors away from me, they had those weapons. It was during the day, not during the night. It was during the day; I could see them.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness. If there is nothing else, this implies that we have heard your entire testimony. We would wish to thank you very much for having come the long away to Arusha. We wish you a safe journey home and ask you kindly not to discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DV:
sp.p: Thank you very much, also.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the witness could be accompanied, please.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, this log book, what is the status of this document now? Anyone wishing to tender it?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: We would love to, Your Honour. I thought they had done so. I was just going to ask. If they are not going to do it, I will do it.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, sir. It is a document in the case, but this document is in the case. I thought you were talking about his personal notes, his own personal notes. But this, this is very well tendered in. It is part of the material for this case. Are we talking about the same piece of paper? Yes, it has been tendered in as an exhibit.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Received from the Defence in connection with Witness DB is Exhibit 32, which is the particulars, that's 32. Then followed Defence Exhibit 33 -- isn't that true, registry? -- concerning this handwritten document, and these are the two so far. Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, we agree.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So after these two you also want to exhibit this one, I assume?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, that is the log book of the vehicle. It must be tendered, we believe.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are making that request, aren't you?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, it is so admitted.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, Defence -- that was Defence Exhibit 34. Defence, that brings us to witness eight on your list. So thank you to both parties for having completed four witnesses during each of these days, which makes four. But then you drew our attention yesterday to a possible need to prepare the next five witnesses. Now, where are you now, please?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President. We have five witnesses here in Arusha, five witnesses which we have not been able to prepare. Certainly we would have been able to prepare them if we had come here earlier to Arusha, but let me draw your attention to the fact that the Defence session has not allowed us to come here before the 24th of October, which is regrettable. Even those who could have come to Arusha with their own means, I could not have imposed that on the whole team, and so we have not been able to prepare these five witnesses. This is my proposal, Mr. President, that we adjourn until Thursday afternoon. If this is agreeable to the Chamber, we could have a session on Thursday afternoon and Friday. So we will have only tomorrow and the morning of Thursday to prepare the said witnesses, and I believe in one afternoon and one day we will be able to advance and move on with the five witnesses remaining.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And, yes. Now, when you say the afternoon on Thursday, maybe we do not have to start as late as 2:30. Could we push it a little bit forward, a little bit early in the day, say to 1:00, 1:30? And then we could sit from, say, 1:30 to 5:00, or what is your schedule there?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, 1:30 seems to be quite agreeable.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is it fine with everyone? All right, 1:30 on Thursday, then. And thank you for making the point, because that was one of my questions yesterday, why this had not been done last week, and now I understand why the Defence were not in a position to do that. So that was useful information, thank you. All right, this brings us to the end of Tuesday, and we will then meet again on Thursday in the afternoon as just agreed. Thank you very much.Court is adjourned.

div.head: 30 OCTOBER 20031337HCONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Ms. Marianne Ben SalimoMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi:Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Ms. Trish GreigMs. Gifty C. HardingMs. Roxane LaneMr. Rex LearMs. Regina LimulaMs. Judith BaverstockMr. Petrus ChijariraMs. Diane Hermann

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Court is in session. Good afternoon to everyone in the courtroom. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, the first witness is Witness --

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness DC, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What happened to DA?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: DA should arrive today or tomorrow in Arusha, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right, so there is a little change in the sequence there. I wasn't aware of that. So you, Mr. Witness, will be referred to as DC in these proceedings, and you are a protected witness, so please be careful when you answer questions so as not to reveal your identity. You are of course under the obligation to tell the truth, and the registry will now take your solemn declaration.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DC in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.Do you have a piece of paper in front of you, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, there is a document in front of me.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you recognise the signature at the bottom of that page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I know this signature on the document.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is it yours?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, that is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So does this imply, then, that the document contains correct information about your particulars?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: That is correct, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. That will be 35, under seal; Defence Exhibit 35, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 35 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

div.stage: WITNESS DC,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Witness. Could you hear me?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, I should like to know where you used to live in 1994; where was your home in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I lived in the Gatoki secteur, the Rutsiro commune and Rulindo cellule, and the Kibuye préfecture.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Now, tell us where your home was just before you came here to Arusha.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I lived in the Ruhengeri préfecture, more precisely at the *************, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When were you arrested?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I was arrested in 1995; 1995, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: For what reasons were you arrested?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I was arrested for murder.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you plead guilty or not guilty, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I pleaded guilty, sir, and that was even before the prosecutor's office went after me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you sentenced?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, I was sentenced for life.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you make an appeal against that sentence?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No, sir, I did not lodge an appeal, because the law on procedure so far as guilty plea is concerned does not allow that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, Witness, there are several categories of crimes concerning genocide before the Rwandan jurisdiction.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, there are various categories of crimes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How many are there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: There are four different categories of crimes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Which is the most serious category of the crime within the framework that is most serious?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: It was -- it is the first category, sir. There is also the second category, the third category and the fourth category. This is the sequence of the various categories.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And could you tell us in which category you were placed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I was classified in category 1, but since I pleaded guilty, I was reclassified in the second category, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you take part in the Tutsi genocide in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I did take part at -- in that genocide.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you personally commit murder?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I killed some people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you tell us the ethnic group of the victims?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: My victims were known during that period as Tutsi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you tell us why you yourself had to kill Tutsi? For what reason did you kill Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: The reason for which I took part in the massacres, I am not really in a position to explain them to you as such, but I believe that all of that was due to the death of the president of the republic. People committed various criminal acts, and I am one of those that took part in the commission of such criminal acts.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, what was the role of the Rwandan authorities when the massacres started?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: So far as the role of the leaders in Rwanda was concerned, all the leaders that were involved in the massacres, some of the authorities advocated massacre and others did not, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In your cellule, that is where you were, did certain authorities call for massacres?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: In the cellule in which I lived, there was a person that was murdered, only one person, sir, about whom I was informed. If not, I was not a neighbour to the other victims, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you tell us how and when the killing started after the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I took part in massacres in various locations. I took part in massacres that started at the Rutsiro commune on the 11th, on the 11th of April 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were many people killed at Rutsiro commune on the 11th of April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, many people were killed. If I look at the number of victims that fell at the communal office of Rutsiro, but also in other areas of the commune, people were killed, a lot of people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, regarding those people that were killed in Rutsiro, who asked you to kill them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Well, we got to the Rutsiro communal office on the 11th, and at that time people had already killed the priest of the Murunda parish. The authorities arrested those criminals on around the 9th, it was around the 9th that the priest was killed. We got there on the 11th to see who killed the priest, and when we arrived we found some gendarmes on the spot. They had come to protect the Rutsiro communal office. It was those gendarmes that handed over the first person to us; that was the police inspector of Rutsiro commune, and we killed him. It was thus that the massacre started, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, later on did the gendarmes also take part in the massacres on your side?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: As far as the gendarmes were concerned, they handed over the police inspector of the Rutsiro commune and asked us to kill all those people that were in the house housing various art objects. So that in doing so we were assisted by the members of the communal police, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, before the massacres, were there people that assisted you that told you to go out and kill and where to go? Were there such people around you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No, sir. All of that started off with the death of the president.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you take part in the Tutsi attack or the attack of the Tutsis in the Kibuye church -- the attack against the Tutsis in the Kibuye church?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I was there, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: That took place on the 17th at around 11 o'clock.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you take part in the Gatwaro stadium attack of the Tutsis -- against the Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I was also there, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And when did that take place, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: That took place on the 18th at around 1500 hours. That was 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you take part in the attack against the Tutsi in a location called Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know that area called Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I know that location very well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know whether there was a roadblock in Fayer?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No, sir. The roadblock was a little bit before Fayer.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What was your answer now, Mr. Witness? Say that again, please. Just repeat your answer, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Did you want me to repeat the answer concerning the location called Fayer or just what I have just said, sir?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I would like you to repeat the information you just gave about the roadblock in Fayer, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: There was no roadblock at the location called Fayer. The roadblock was a little bit before that, in the Gaseke area in Kayenzi. That was where the roadblock was mounted, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Whilst you were on this assault, did you go home every evening or did you spend the night at another place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: We did not go home. We had accommodation at the Ruganda school, and this was at Kibuye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, did you take part in the attack against the Tutsi at Gitwa?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I took part in the Gitwa massacre; yes, sir, I did. I did play a role because I killed two people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where is the commune in which Gitwa is, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Gitwa is in the Gitesi commune, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When we talk about Gitwa, does it mean a hill, a river or a geographical location? What is Gitwa, precisely?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I believe that it is a hill that is called Gitwa.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is that hill near Karongi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, that hill was on mount -- or is on Mount Karongi, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And at what date did you go to Gitwa, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: As far as Gitwa is concerned, in view of the fact that several days ago we had killed the refugees at the church and of course those that were at the stadium, but I did not know that I was going to be compelled to do it again. In response to questions concerning that location, I believe it was the 22nd, that is, one week after the church and the stadium massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How did you go to Gitwa? Did you go to Gitwa -- what sort of transportation did you use to go to Gitwa?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: There were no vehicles; we couldn't get any vehicles because we were so many. Those people that had access to vehicles were our leaders, for example, the military, some of them. There were also the vehicles belonging to certain businessmen, or, for example, if a bourgmestre had a vehicle. Some of the vehicles would carry personalities who came round to see what happened during the massacres. But so far as we were concerned, we went around on foot.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And where did you go from to reach Gitwa?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: When we went to Gitwa we left from the round table, that is, the Kibuye round table, the turntable, where many people had assembled, then we went to Ruganda and then to the turntable once we left for Gitwa.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, what is the distance from the turntable, the round table, up to the Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I believe that it would take one hour to cover that distance. This is just an estimate on my part.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you go to Gitwa together with other people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How many people, approximately, went with you to Gitwa?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: We were many. Perhaps I can tell you about the people who were just around me during our trip, but we were quite a lot of people.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would you say that you were about 10, or about a 100, about 1,000, according to what you remember?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: At the roundabout, if I were to make an estimate, I believe that we left -- we were about 1,000 people leaving that turntable.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you accompanied by authorities during that trip?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Just certain authorities escorted us.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you specify the authorities? I do not want you to call names. Perhaps you can tell us what functions those authorities exercised?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: As far as their functions are concerned, I couldn't be of any help. But I do remember one person that represented the Kibuye hospital, the counseiller of the city of Kibuye, and one military. Those were the people that escorted us, because we had come from very far and those people escorted us to help us avoid problems. There were other people whose functions I do not remember, I do not know, but I perhaps may remember some of their names.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were other authorities awaiting you at your point of arrival?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes. We found the counseiller of Kagabiro secteur, we found him at Gitwa, that is, before we launched the attack against the victims. We also found the bourgmestre and his advisor there. That was the Gishyita bourgmestre and the counseiller also for Gishyita.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were there other authorities that met you following your arrival?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No, sir. Upon our arrival, we waited for everybody to be gathered before we launched the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I had a machete and a club.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What about the other people who accompanied you, were they also armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes. They were carrying different types of weapons. Some people were carrying guns, others were carrying machetes and clubs.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who was carrying guns?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: It was the soldiers of the time whose names I didn't know, but maybe I could give you the names of one of -- two of those soldiers. The bourgmestre who was present was also carrying a gun, and he was the one who led us on the Gitwa attack in order to help us carry out our task.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who gave you the machetes that you were using?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: We brought machetes with us from our various homes. We had them before the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. We are still dealing with the Gitwa attack. For how long did it last, and did it last several days?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: If I were to look at the date on which I arrived in Kibuye, namely around the 15th or 16th, people continued going to Gitwa up until the end of the massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, but for how long did the attack itself last? I know that there are some people who have said that the attack on Gitwa lasted several days.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Let me speak to you of two days on which I went to Gitwa. I went, for instance, today, then I went back and then the next day I went again. It was during that time that we killed people. This is because in the initial days we were not adequately prepared. The soldiers told us to go back to where we came from because they were going to look for material, and it was the next day that we went back and killed the victims.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To summarise, will one then be correct in saying that the attack lasted two days but that the attack was more intense on the second day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Let's say four or five days, you know, but it was on the last day that we killed the victims.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. But you --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you go home at the end of each day, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes. Those who live around Kibuye would go back to their homes and we would find them again the next morning. As for us who came from far away, we went back to where we were living in Ruganda, and the following morning we would meet again in order to go to launch the attack.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Why do you consider this one attack and not five attacks?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: After killing the victims of Kibuye on the 18th, we remained for some days drinking beer and eating meat, and that means that we resumed the attacks about a week later. So I would say that we launched the attack on Gitwa one week after the attacks on Kibuye town.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Merci.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you yourself present on the day of the main attack on Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Yes, I was present when the Gitwa victims were killed, in other words, the last day of the large-scale attack.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you go back to that place where the large-scale attack took place the following day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: No. We remained in town.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The day following the large-scale attack, to your knowledge, were there any new -- was there any new fighting on Gitwa hill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I wouldn't be able to know. But since there was no one else to kill, why should there have been any fighting? We had killed everybody.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you present on Gitwa the day before the large-scale attack?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I got there, for instance, today, the soldiers told us that we were not able to face the victims because there was a gendarme who had been killed in that location. So they told us, "Go back, we are going to collect other materials". So we came back to the place the next day and we killed the victims.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The day of the large-scale attack, at what time did the fighting begin?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: The fighting began at about 10:00.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who launched the signal for the attack to begin?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: It was the bourgmestre of Gishyita commune who launched the Gitwa attacks.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: At what time did the attack end?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Since I wasn't wearing a watch, I dare say the fighting stopped at 1400H or 1500H hours, 2:00 or 3:00 in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
