It was at that time that I had courage enough to talk about it, when I saw that nobody else wanted to talk about it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good. Now, how many attackers were there at Gitwa hill in total?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I couldn't count them; there were so many.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Previously you referred to more or less than 1,000. Now, at Gitwa hill, were there more or less than 1,000, or was the figure different?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: The attackers that came along with me from Kibuye town were a thousand, but those that came from other areas were many, many. Upon our arrival, I would be aware that we were about 15,000 attackers. This is an approximation because the attackers were many.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: How many times were you in Bisesero attacking?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I took part in only one attack in Bisesero, but, of course, there were other attacks in which I did not take part. We were at Kibuye, and we spent time drinking beer and eating meat. There was a lot to drink and to eat. But the most -- the biggest attack that brought together people from various communes, I took part in that attack in Bisesero.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When was that attack in Bisesero in which you participated?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: It was following the Gitwa attack. I did say that I could not tell the precise date thereof in view of the fact that I was not anticipating responding to questions on that issue. That attack was the last attack at that location where there were many refugees. That was around the end of April. But in May, there were other attacks. The whites came to stop the massacres at Kibuye. Even when they arrived, there were attacks being launched.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I am referring to French people.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So please only answer the questions, will you? So in other words, the answer is, "I was in Bisesero on one occasion towards the end of April." That's the answer, isn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: That is correct, yes: once, in May.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: In May? Did you say in May, now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: During that period. I did not really pay attention to the dates, but I was there during the attack when there were many attackers.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So in other words, your only participation in Bisesero was towards the end of April or in May; you are not certain about the month. Is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I am not sure about the date. All I know is that I was committing crimes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can you tell us what month it was, April or May, or are you uncertain? That is the question, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I know most of the dates of the Kibuye massacres, that is the date before the Gitwa attack. Because after that, we spent the days that came after drinking. It was only later on when questions were being put to me that I started thinking. But I know that in April and May, we went on committing crimes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You were at the roadblock when the half-castes arrived with the car, yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: When I arrived at the roadblock, it was said that the white man had gone through and that his return -- they were waiting for his return.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So did you arrive before the white man arrived or after the white man arrived at the roadblock during the killing episode?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: When I arrived, the white man had gone through; he was already at Kibuye. And when I arrived there, I was told that the white man had left but that he was to be awaited, and that there may be combat and that I should wait for the white man. But upon my arrival, he had already gone through to Kibuye. Upon his return he found me at the roadblock, and I was with the others.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And that is what is interesting now. So my question to you is the following: For how long had you been at the roadblock when the white man returned and was then killed? For how long before his arrival?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: I would say around three hours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.Mr. Witness, your testimony has come to an end. Thank you very much for having come the long way and giving testimony before the Tribunal. We wish you a safe journey home and ask you not to discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DC:
sp.p: Thank you very much, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the witness could be assisted.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Next witness is DM?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President, we have DM. But for the information of sitting, could you be so kind as to indicate the time at which or for how long we are going to hear witnesses?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I mean, we are flexible here, but we could imagine to sit to 5:15, 5:30 today. Would that be -- we could start the next witness, that was the thinking.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness. Can you hear? Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to as Witness DM in these proceedings. You have to tell the truth, and the registry will now administer the taking of your solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: MR. MUSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, please stand up. Raise your right hand and say after me.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DM in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, please listen carefully to the questions and try to answer them as briefly as possible, Mr. Witness.Defence.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, do you have a document in front of you, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature at the bottom of that page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Let me see. I see that the information is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you. Thirty-seven. Defence Exhibit 37, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 37 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence.

div.stage: WITNESS DMfirst having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Witness, where is your commune, where is your secteur, and where is your cellule, that is, your native cellule, secteur, and commune?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I am from the Gitesi commune, Kibuye secteur, and Nyarusange cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Would you tell us, Witness, where you presently live?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I am detained at the **********

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What is your ethnic group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I am Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Why are you detained at the *******, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Because of the massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you remember the date, approximately, of the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He died on the 6th of April, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Year?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you tell us, Witness, what happened during the days following the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Following -- that is, three days after the death of President Habyarimana, there was an upheaval, trouble among the population.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was there any looting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: There was looting. There was massacre, too.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The Hutu were killing the Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you presently in the **********; if so, could you tell us now why you are now detained at the **********?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I'm in prison because I was arrested for having committed murder. I pleaded guilty, and I sought pardon.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you tell us the murders for which you pleaded guilty?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I pleaded guilty for having killed ********* and his child.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: May we have the spelling, please.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you experience other murders?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I witnessed other murders, and I testified concerning those murders, for example, the murder of Benjamin and that of an old lady whose name I do not know. I was able to see the killers, one Habiyambere and one Cyprien Karegeya. I was able to see -- I saw all of those murders, and I have supplied the names of the killers.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, could you go back to the four names and spell them, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Benjamin is spelled B-I-N-J-A-M-I-N (sic) -- B-E.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: We will not ask you to spell the name of the old lady whose name you do not know. What about Habiyambere, could you spell it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I did mention Habiyambere. It is spelled H-A-B-I-Y-A-M-B-E-R-E.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Karegeya, Cyprien, could you spell that, too?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I did mention Cyprien Karegeya, Karegeya is spelled K-A-R-E-G-E-Y-A.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: We shall dwell a little on the murder of the last person killed, that is, Cyprien Karegeya. Could you, Witness, say when this murder took place, approximately?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It was the month of April, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Which year?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Beginning, middle, or end of that month of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Karegeya died at end of April.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At about what time of day was it towards the end of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It was between midday and 2 p.m.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please tell us where that incident occurred, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I could do so.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Please tell us the place, the location.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: You mean the place where Karegeya was killed or the other places where the murders were killed (sic) also?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: We are going to speak about the others later, but I want to know where Cyprien Karegeya was killed at the end of April 1994, between noon and 2 p.m.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was killed at a place known as Gitaka, the Gitaka centre.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: In what secteur is that location?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Gitesi secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you tell us exactly how this incident occurred?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I can do so.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Mr. President, counsel is not waiting for the microphone to be switched back, and we are missing his questions.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I was at home and I was going to Gitaka, and when I reached Gisiza.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There is the pause which causes the problem now. So will you please, Defence counsel, observe this pause, because it's not only the translation, but it's also the fact that the booth has to push the button so that we will hear the floor inside the room again, and all this takes a few seconds. And if you don't wait, we can't hear your voice. Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Let me repeat my question. Can you please tell us how this incident occurred?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Please do, Mr. Witness. Will you please start telling us how it happened?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I left my home and I was going to Gitaka.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. And what happened then? Did you see anyone? Did you see Mr. Karegeya, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I reached Gisiza.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Who did you meet when you got there? Please, can you try and be sequential.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I reached Gisiza and I met a group of men escorting Karegeya. The men had found him in a sorghum field where he was hiding. There was Ahingereje, Ruganamanzi, those were the most important members of that group. We went down together, and we reached Gitaka. And they made him sit in front of Karara's house. Ndagijimana struck him with a club between his shoulders, and the others said, "It's not a good idea to kill him in front of someone else's house. Let's take him behind the houses." They did that, and I followed them.When I got there, they made him sit down on the ground and Misago and another man, Bisagara, struck him with clubs to the head, and he died. After that, we left him there and we went back up.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, let's go back to this instance again. You met the group of attackers who had just flushed him out of his hiding place, you say.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes. They had flushed him out of a sorghum field.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you please repeat the names of the attackers or assailants who had flushed him out of the sorghum field?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I remember Rwasibo, Ahingereje. Rwasibo was the leader. He seemed to me to be the most important individual in the group. He seemed to me to be the leader. And then there was Ruganamanzi as well.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You also mentioned -- well, now, can you spell Rwasibo for us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I do not know how to write. I can write in capital letters; maybe I might know how to write Rwasibo.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Can we agree for the record that it is spelt R-W-A-S-I-B-O? And shall we also agree that the other name was R-U-G-A-N-A-M-A-N-Z-I?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Actually, these names, Ruganamanzi, the name is in the written statement, as well as Rwasibo, Mr. President, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Oh, yes, that's why I am so clever with these names. I'm only trying to assist the court reporters. So then the next name is A-H-I-N-G-E-R-E-J-E, and Misago is easy, M-I-S-A-G-O. So now we have done our job there, and we can proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So you then met attackers who had flushed him out, and he is taken in front of a house, he is made to sit down?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: In front of Mr. Karara's house in Gitaka.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And there one Ndagijimana struck him first?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes. He was the one who struck the first blow by his club while he was sitting in front of Karara's house.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And then you said they took him further away to kill him off completely and that there were two people who struck him then. Now, were you present, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I was there. I went to go and watch.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I was present.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And who are the people who took him a little bit further away into a field in order to kill him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The whole group was there. They made him go down, but when they reached the place it was Rusagara and Misago who struck him, who killed him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Rusagara, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, Rusagara.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And the name Misago is already in the written statement, and we believe that Rusagara is written as it is pronounced.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, what was the motive of the crime? Why was this person killed, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: At that time when a Tutsi was stopped, he was killed. I myself don't know why he was killed. It was during the time of the killings everywhere in the country.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I'm going to repeat the question: who was the leader of this group, of this gang?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It was Rwasibo.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did this group or Rwasibo himself receive any instructions from anyone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No one gave any instructions to these people. They were acting of their own free will, and it is in order for them to loot.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were there any other armed groups who were pursuing Tutsis or seeking them out?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The other people who were seeking out the Tutsis were natives of my cellule. There was an attack aimed at seeking out the Tutsis.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were these gangs pursuing people with the same objective, in other words, for them to be able to loot and kill?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What makes you affirm that the attack on Karegeya took place without any instructions being issued by anyone?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I'm saying that because if there had been orders from somewhere, there would have been a prior meeting and I would have been aware of that meeting.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you know Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I knew him.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you know him before the events of 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Had you known him for a long time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I had known him for a long time.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Since you were young?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: And is it true that you were living in secteurs that were neighbouring one another?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Our secteurs were contiguous. My secteur was his secteur's neighbour, so it was impossible for me not to know him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you ever see him, Mr. Witness, before '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: In 1994 I saw him towards the end of June.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you ever see him before the events starting in April 94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The killings had stopped and no one was killing anyone else.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: My question is: did you ever see Mr. Ndindabahizi before April 94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: When I saw Ndindabahizi, it was towards the end of June in 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was that the first time you ever saw him, or have you seen him before '94, in any of the years preceding '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I would see him before 1994 from time to time; sometimes I would see him, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: How many times have you seen him before '94?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I remember having seen him twice.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You knew him before the events of 1994. Now let's speak about the event of 1994. When, during the events of 1994, did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I saw him towards the end of June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Can you tell the Court under what circumstances you saw him at the end of June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I was at Gitaka during that period of time. We were in the house drinking beer and those who were at the door said Ndindabahizi had arrived. Many people went out to go and see him, including myself. When I got there, he was surround by these people. He was asking the group of people, "Who killed these people around here?" And he went on to say, "Who gave you the orders to kill people?" And the people kept quite. So he called out Karara, he greeted him and put to him that question. "You live here. Who killed your neighbours?" Karara kept quite; he didn't have anything to say. So the question was repeated, "Who killed Karegeya? You see that his house had been destroyed". Karara kept quite. Someone came out of the bar and said in a low voice that there was one Gatete who had killed people. Gatete was called and when Gatete arrived, Ndindabahizi asked him, "Is it really you who exterminated the people here?" Now, when Gatete heard this, he went backwards and ran away. So Ndindabahizi took Karara and said, "Since you haven't said who it is who has killed these people, since you are their neighbour and you see that my cattle have been looted, I'm going to arrest you." And he immediately took him away. Up until today Ndindabahizi has not come back. That was towards the beginning of July, at the time when people who started to flee. And from that time on Ndindabahizi has never come back to our area.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How are you so sure that Ndindabahizi did not come to Gasharu before June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I can assert that because I am a neighbour of his family. When he came, people would speak about it and say he - "Ndindabahizi has arrived". Furthermore, he had given gifts as a cow to his family and people were happy. So I would be able to know because I am a neighbour to his family. In the neighbouring secteur there were his uncles and his cousins, so it wasn't for me to be unaware of his arrival in the area.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Are you sure that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi did not come to Gasharu before Cyprien Karegeya death?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He didn't come there.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How are you so sure, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I'm stating that because that is where I was born. Each time he came, we would be aware of his arrival. The members of his family would go to greet him and he would pass close by my home. Therefore, I couldn't be unaware. People would rush to go and greet him, and he would pass by my home. That is the only proof or evidence that I can give.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, how many times did he come when you used to see him?

div.stage: Before the war he came to our home to give a cow as a gift to his uncle, and then again he gave another cow as a gift to his older brother. I know this because I participated in these events, these festivities. But for the rest of the time, he would be in Kigali.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What became of Rwasibo, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: You are referring to Rwasibo? Rwasibo was at the head of the attack by the group which killed Karegeya. Furthermore, we do not live in the same cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Do you know where Rwasibo is today?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I do not know where he is now. He was never arrested. He was reported missing since the time when people fled.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: How many times did Mr. Emmanuel Ndindabahizi come to Gasharu between April and June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I saw him only once, towards the end of June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What enables you to recall that period of time or that date?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have evidence on that. What enables me to say that it was the end of June is that a few days later it was the beginning of July and people began to flee. This was a few days after his arrival, let's say a lapse of time which was not more than one week. That is what I'm basing my memory on.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was it also the end of the major disturbances that had occurred in the region?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The killings had already stopped because the French had come and they had put an end to the killings and they were taking the Tutsis to a safe place. I don't know where that safe place was, but there were no longer any killings.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: After Ndindabahizi's visit, had the killings already stopped or did they stop upon his arrival?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: The killings had stopped earlier because the killings had come to an end in the middle of May.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. President, this would be the end of my examination.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. We will hear the cross-examination tomorrow morning. Now let us assume that Mr. Phillips or Mr. Kapaya will use not more than, say, 45 minutes; what is the timetable, then for the remaining three witnesses?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, after the cross-examination by the Prosecutor, we will have done with Witness DM and we will have for the Tribunal Witness DO and Witness DR, who we will be able to hear tomorrow. As for Witness DM, if the Chamber so wishes, please look at the name which corresponds with Witness DM, this is No. 14, he may take some time, and I don't believe we'll be able to hear him tomorrow. I was thinking more of Monday for that witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That seems sensible. Now, so, Monday is probably No. 14 then. How do you envisage 15 onwards?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: We were waiting and I think they have arrived while we were sitting this afternoon. We are waiting for 15, 16, 17 -- those are the witness numbers. Witness No. 18, for unfortunately professional reasons, will not be able to be here before the 13th of November as this has already been indicated to the Chamber. The witness -- expert witness Bernand Lugan should come to Arusha on the 17th of Arusha (sic). This makes it possible that we will have the hearing of witnesses 17; we will have one week during which we will not be able to hear witnesses. I think -- for the Chamber to organise itself I think the Chamber needs to be informed of this fact now.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's very helpful. Now, we can come back to this tomorrow, but we appreciate to be notified about this now. Now, there is also maybe a possibility, and that's something the Defence might consider, whether No. 20 could -- may be the last of the real factual witnesses or almost the last, and thereby we could fill the gap maybe. You can discuss that with your client. You can discuss that within the team.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, we just had an observation. We just wondered if there was any pressing reason why we couldn't cross-examine this witness today. We only intend to be ten minutes with him. Unless Your Honour has a pressing engagement, I'm quite happy to finish him today and then you can ask judges' questions tomorrow.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. Unfortunately, we have to take the ten minutes tomorrow. Thank you, very much. Court is adjourned.

div.head: 31 OCTOBER 20030846H CONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Mr. Nouhou M. DialloMs. Marianne Ben SalimoMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi:Mr. Pascal BesnierMr. Guillaume MarçaisCourt Reporters:Ms. Diane HermannMr. Rex LearMs. Regina LimulaMs. Judith BaverstockMr. Petrus ChijariraMs. Trish GreigMs. Gifty C. Harding

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The Court is in session. Good morning to everyone. Good morning, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You will now be cross-examined by the Prosecution.Please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good morning, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you testified yesterday, and indeed it's contained in your statement, that you have pleaded guilty before the authorities in Rwanda. Is that correct, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And the essence of your testimony before this Court yesterday was that the subject of your guilty plea was the killing of Karegeya, amongst other things. Is that not correct, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I also be correct in saying that you testified that you witnessed and participated in the attack on Karegeya in 1994? I can't recall the month now, but just accept whether it's 1994 or not.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You testified yesterday that your guilty plea involved you stating that a man by the name Ndagijimana struck Karegeya in your presence with a club. Is that not so, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, have you been tried by the courts in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have not yet been tried. I'm going to be tried before the Gacaca courts.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And your plea of guilty was made under which provisions? Was that under the Gacaca as well?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, it was in the prosecutor's office.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall when you made that guilty plea, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I wrote a letter to the prosecutor's office on the 13th December 1998.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And thereafter were you, at some stage, interviewed by the prosecutor's office in relation to your confession, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is it your testimony, sir, that in that report to the prosecutor, you outlined that you had participated in the attack on Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you also outlined, to the best of your recollection, sir, that you had witnessed Karegeya being attacked by Ndagijimana with a club in the presence of you and other people, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours would find on your desks a document in Kinyarwanda with a translation in French and a translation in English. So there are three -- or two documents, because the French might be stapled to the Kinyarwanda, but the English is obviously separate. Some of you might have three, some might have two, but you all have the same documents. So do my learned friends.Can I ask the registry to place the Kinyarwanda version in -- before the witness, please. Just the Kinyarwanda one, because he doesn't read English or French, obviously. The top one, the handwritten one, thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you see the document that I've had placed in front of you, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You can see from the title of that document that it is a copy of your confession and guilty plea and request for forgiveness, a report from the office of the prosecutor. Do you see that there, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Let me just check.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I've seen it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It states that your confession date was the 16th of November, 2002, and that you were arrested on the 9th of July, 1998. Is that correct, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: That is a second document. I pleaded guilty the first time and the document was misplaced, and I had to make a second document because they couldn't find the first one. They couldn't find the first document, so it became necessary for me to repeat my confession, and a second document was put together. So what you are saying is true, this document concerns me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes. And this is the second and most recent confession, is it not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, that document relates to me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: If you turn to the first page -- you open the page and turn to the first page, under column 2, it tells us there, sir, does it not, that you confessed to the crime of murder in 1994 in Kibuye préfecture? Does it not, sir?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: If you then turn with me to the third page there in the Kinyarwanda version --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And for those reading in English, it's the second page; I don't know what it is in French.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Could we just have on the record the witness's answer in English, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: He said "yes".

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, we all heard that he said "m-hmm," but we want a translation on record of the "m-hmm".

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Right, very well.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, booth, can you help us with that?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness said "yes".

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: If we then turn to the third page, you list four people who are described there as the victims of your crimes. Is that not the case, sir? Do you see that, sir? Do you --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I see it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you see Mr. Cyprien Karegeya's name there, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I haven't found it yet.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Have you -- is it the case that you haven't found it or is it the case that it's not there, sir? Which is it, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I haven't found it yet.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'll give you all the time you need, sir. Please look.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Did you refer to the third page? I do not read very well, but I cannot see his name on the third page.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Indeed, the name in number one is Uwimana, the second name is Sekaraga, the third name is Alfred.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I can now see the page you are referring to.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you see those names there, sir, all four of them? Do you see those names? Do you see Karegeya's name there, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I haven't found it yet.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Okay. Now, let's turn to the page that talks about your co-perpetrators, then. Now, you mention many of the names that you mentioned in your testimony. Misago, do you see his name in that document at number --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I cannot find his name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Number one on -- I'm terrible for the photocopying, here.Mr. Witness, the pages on those documents are not numbered so I can understand the difficulty you have, so I would ask the registry to show you Mr. Misago's name in the document.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you show him this page? Can you show him this page and bring the document back to me?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Have you seen that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: You told me the name was on the third page, and I was looking for that name on the third page, where the name of Karegeya is; and the other problem is, I don't read well.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Registry, can you just show him the page I've opened for you in this document. Okay?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you see that name there, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I cannot see that name. I cannot say I've seen it when I haven't seen it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Show him this page, sir. Just like that, thank you. Stay there with him, please. I need the document back. Can you just stay there with him, please. I need that document back.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you see that name there, Mr. Witness? Let's do this very quickly, please. Okay?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Has the officer of the registry shown you a page that is open with a name on it, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I cannot see Karegeya's name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The question is whether you can see --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I cannot see the name of Karegeya.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the Prosecutor is trying to ask you whether you can see Misago's name on the top of the page which the registry has placed in front of you. Can you see that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, Misago. Yes, now I can see Misago on this page, Misago, Amon.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can I have the document back, please? Just wait, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm asking the registry to show you the name on the top page that I've opened, and that's the name called Ahingereje, A-H-I-N-G-E-R-E-J-E. Do you see that, sir? Yes, do you see that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I can see Ahingereje's name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Can I have the document back, please, for one last time.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: As I mentioned for the record, the first names was number 22 in the English version; this one is number 13.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And it's spelled slightly different. Your Honour, if I can just show him the same page.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: On the same page, Mr. Witness, the name right under the name you've just identified is Ruganamanzi, R-U-G-A-N-A-M-A-N-Z-I, Ruganamanzi. Do you see that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I can see Ruganamanzi's name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you. Can I have the document back.Do you mention Ndagijimana's name as part of the co-perpetrators of this attack in this document, sir, to the best of your recollection?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It is Ndagijimana who gave the -- who struck him first.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you mention that in your confession statement as part of the co-perpetrators, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I wouldn't, I wouldn't like to waste the Court's time unduly, but I put it to you, Mr. Witness, that that name is not mentioned there as part of the co-perpetrators.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Are you referring to Ndagijimana? I gave that name. Maybe they forgot to put his name there, but I recall that I gave his name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Indeed. Who were the witnesses to this crime, Mr. Witness? Who was present when this crime occurred, sir? Can you help us with that, very quickly?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: In Gitaka, there were people living there, of course. There were people that were there. Karara, for example, we were in front of his house. There was another man called Mwirinde who was trading in that centre, but at that time their shops were not open, but those people were in front of their shops. There was another Nsengimana. There were many people. There was also Jotham Sebarame. I do not remember the other names because it has been a long time.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: May we have the last name spelled, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Will you spell the last name for us, Nyirahamwe (sic) you said? Something to that effect.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Are you referring to people that were present?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Sebarame, spelled S-E-V-A-R-A-M-E (sic).

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: There are two such names, Mr. Mwirinde and Mr. Sebarame. Did you mention any other observers of this crime?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I mentioned Karara and Mwirinde, Mwirinde, Gitan (phonetic). Mwirinde is spelt M-W-I-R-I-N-D-E. I also mentioned Nsengimana. Nsengimana is spelled N-S-E-N-G-I-M-A-N-A. I also mentioned Sebarame. These are the people I remember being present at the time, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In your confession statement to the prosecutor, in the last section, which is a statement from you entitled "Commission of the Offence," you state at length the activities that you were involved in, the date, and the location of your activities at the time, do you not?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: If the registry can assist in showing him what I'm talking about.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, sir, I did talk about the commission of the offence, but I did not give any dates because I couldn't remember those dates.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You say as follows: "I the undersigned," I skip your name, "confess that we were in Nyarusange," the secteur indicated there, with the district, "province, Kibuye, in April 1994, in the company of Bagaruka and other co-perpetrators named above, and we killed a certain Sekaraga," in brackets "illegible," because the translators can't read it.You then describe how you had killed him. You forced him to go to his house, committed suicide by hanging on a rope which someone had given you, and you state there that he preferred to die in that manner for fear of being killed brutally.Now, you then talk about the killing of Uwimana. You describe who you did it with and who asked you to do it. You describe the killing of Habiyambere. You describe how you did it. The child of Alfred, you also tell us how you did it. You talk about a cow that you ate, and the roof of a house that you removed. Absolutely no mention of the things you've talked about in this courtroom between yesterday and today, is there, Mr. Witness? Yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: But you didn't ask me questions on these things. It is true that I ate the cow and that I took off the roof and that I killed those people, but you never asked me questions on these, questions on these issues.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I've noted your answer, thank you.Now, are you -- at the location that you're currently detained at, would I be correct in saying that a man called Seyeze, Ezikias, is also detained with you? S-E-Y-E-Z-E.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: That is correct, Seyeze is at the same prison as myself.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And does this man Seyeze have any relationship with the Accused in this case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: That is his younger brother.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Isn't it true, Mr. Witness, that the man Seyeze is the one responsible for having you come all the way to Arusha to testify in this matter, together with the others that are to come? Is that not correct, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: People came to investigate. They came to question me at the prison, and I gave them answers. But those persons also talked to Seyeze, but I do not know what they said to each other because they came in turns to talk to those people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Right. Why are you willing to accept responsibility for something you did not do, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I said that I played a part in the commission of that offence because I accompanied them when they went to kill those people. But I was also one of the attackers because I had a club. I accompanied the group of killers. We got to Gitaka, and I stayed at the place where those persons were killed. This was why I decided to recognise the crime because I feared that I might be told later that I was also responsible because I was in the company of the killers. This is why I accepted to make that testimony and to confess that I had some responsibility in the commission of that crime.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was -- were you particularly forthright and forthcoming with the prosecutor in Kibuye? Did he believe your confession and accept it, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I told them the truth, and they accepted that I told them the truth, and such a person -- a person whose confession is accepted by the prosecutor's office is given a document that authenticates the fact that his confessions have been accepted by the prosecution's office. I do have such a document with me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Indeed, isn't it the case, Mr. Witness, that the prosecutor made a notation on your confession where he stated that in his opinion, you did not explain the role of each co-perpetrator in the crimes that you seem to have confessed to?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The registry can hand me the Kinyarwanda; I will show him where it is.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is that not the notation that's made in that document? Have you seen it?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sorry, Your Honours, on page 12, it's just below the certification on page 12.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Have you seen that, sir, in Kinyarwanda document on the bottom of that page, his comments? Yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, I can see that notation. Usually when someone makes confessions to the prosecutor's office, sometimes additional questions are put to him. I knew that I had other questions to respond to our Gacaca. Well, I was being told to summarise because they didn't have enough paper, but when I go to Gacaca's jurisdiction, I shall explain everything.And I should like to add something else, if I may. I want to explain that what I said is the truth. If you allow me, I will explain to you why I am insisting about having said the truth.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Witness, I honestly -- I honestly am not interested in your explanation.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What do you want to say about that, Mr. Witness? You can elaborate briefly on it.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Well, in a word or two, I believe that the prosecutor's office accepted that I have spoken the truth, and they gave me a document to that effect. Now, we, the accused, have pleaded guilty, we are very few in the prison. We decided to look for more evidence to submit to the prosecutor's office. We held a meeting, a meeting of people that had pleaded guilty. People had come from all areas of the commune. We went outside the prison, we held a meeting, and we elected a leader, a leader that represented all the accused of all the communes, and we called him the préfet. So the préfet appointed one person per commune, and we called him bourgmestre, the bourgmestre. And in the commune we appointed councillors for each secteur, and each councillor appointed people per cellule, a leader for each cellule, and those people appointed police officers. Now, this is the structure of those that have pleaded guilty, and we held a meeting.Now, the secteurs came together and appointed people for each cell or cellule. Now, that was to ensure that all the accused who pleaded guilty were present in the meetings. We established a list of all the people killed in every cellule. That we did, and after that we spelt out the names of the killers of those people so that we were sure that nobody would say that he did not participate in such or such a killing, because we were there. So that if anybody wanted to lie, we will put the truth into his fruit (sic) and tell him that he was lying, since we committed the crime together. So that is the situation, because you cannot lie in such a situation. If the prosecutor has more questions, I am ready to answer questions because I have pleaded guilty. There are details that I did not mention. Perhaps they could be asked. I'm sure that even Gacaca will have other questions to respond to. This is what I wanted to say. We were telling the truth. We did not want to lie any more. So, this is all I wanted to say.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have no doubt that your explanation has been terribly helpful to the Court.Now, let's go back to the issues at hand. Is it not the case, Mr. Witness, that you and your co-detainees in Gisovu prison, and other prisons in and around Rwanda, have formed a solidarity, a Hutu solidarity; and the object, is it not the case, of that solidarity, Mr. Witness, is to absolve your Hutu brothers who are now in custody before this Tribunal of their crimes? That's what the essence of what you've just told us, isn't it? You now have a préfet amongst yourselves, you have your own bourgmestres, a government in prison, so to speak, and you have all come together, formulated your evidence with a view to assisting those leaders in 1994 of their crimes. That's exactly what you're doing here, is it not, sir? Yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, sir. I have something to say about what you've just said. I pleaded guilty. I spoke the truth. I believe that I cannot speak about the co-perpetrators. If I confessed, I cannot begin to absolve anybody that participated in the criminal activities that we are talking about. As far as the government that you're referring to is concerned, this is not a government. We, rather, tried to establish the truth, and we succeeded in convincing many people to plead guilty. And indeed, before that, it was very difficult for the prosecution to know what really happened.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You did not operate in Gasharu cellule in 1994, Mr. Witness; is that not the case? You were nowhere near that area, yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I arrived at Gasharu on the day Karegeya died.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You haven't answered my question. You, you did not operate your criminal acts, by your own admission, in Gasharu cellule, did you? Yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: This is what I pled. I was not able to protect the victim; moreover, I was still with the killers that killed that person, but I did not assist them. If not, I did not play any other role in Gasharu, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's precisely what I thought you might do, turn around and diminish your role. But yesterday, it was different: You were present enough to know who did what. Today, your role is somewhat diminished, isn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, sir, I'm not diminishing my role. If you ask me questions, I will respond, but -- and I will not leave anything aside. I explained the roles of one and all; I'm prepared to repeat it. I said Ndagijimana, Ndagijimana struck him with a club. It was Ahingereje, Ruganamanzi and Rwasibo who flushed him out. Those were the foremost people responsible.Now, the one that struck him, that was also Misago and Rusagara that also participated in killing him, and I told you I was there. So what did I hide from you?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You learned all those things from your criminal colleagues in prison, did you not, sir, during your discussions with bourgmestres and préfets in Gisovu prison? That's where you learned all this information.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, sir. The bourgmestres in the prison, do not -- they do not counsel the accused; rather, they tell you to say the truth on what you have done. Now, those people were appointed to convince the detainees to speak the truth about the acts they have carried out. Now, the bourgmestre or the préfet cannot advise you not to speak the truth; rather, he would put questions to you to convince you to speak the truth about what you've done, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What position does Augustin Karara, the former bourgmestre of Gitesi commune, hold in that prison cabinet? Help me with that.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No post, sir, did he have.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: What about Rukundakuvuga?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Rukundakuvuga was an ordinary citizen. He had a post -- he has a post in the Gacaca structure.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So if Rukundakuvuga, an ordinary citizen, has a post in the Gacaca structure, how then does a former bourgmestre of Gitesi commune hold no post? You're not being truthful here, Mr. Witness, are you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I don't know the type of post he occupies, but I know that he is responsible for something at the Gacaca structure. I've just spent eight months in Gisovu so that I do not know everything that happened. I said I came at the time the Gacaca structure was set up, and when I arrived I realised that he had a role in that structure, and my secteur is different from his. He didn't even ask me questions about what I did because he did not know what I did. I live in a secteur --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness gave the name of a secteur.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: -- and he lives in the Kayenzi secteur, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That's precisely why you have no -- you can -- you could have no knowledge of the things you testified about yesterday, different secteurs, different locations, different attackers. Is that not the case? Why didn't you mention Rukundakuvuga in your -- as part of your co-perpetrators in your confession, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I did not work with Rukundakuvuga. I did not. In his confessions, he didn't talk about me, and I did not talk about him in my confession.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Precisely. Precisely, Mr. Witness. You didn't work with Rukundakuvuga because if you did, then you would have mentioned Karegeya in your confession. Is that not the case, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: No further questions.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you want to tender anything of this, Mr. Phillips?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm grateful for that intervention, Your Honour. I thought I did. No, I tendered another one yesterday. Your Honour, if I just tender it as the next Prosecution exhibit. I think it's 36 we're on?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In English, A -- sorry, in Kinyarwanda, A; B and C for French and English, in that order.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm grateful.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Under seal. Admitted.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 36A, P. 36B, and P. 36C admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, at this juncture I should like to make an observation. This document was only disclosed to us after the beginning of this hearing. I believe that it is regrettable. We are not here in a theatre where we have coup d'état and surprises. We are here to be serious. The parties should disclose the material they have, and the Prosecutor should be told that when he has important material, he should disclose the material to his learned friends on the Defence. This is the observation I wanted to make, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The observation is noted, Your Honour, but this is an adversarial proceeding, and the whole point of the exercise is to impeach the credibility of the witness. His witness should be forthcoming in telling him the truth.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Besnier, we have noted your remark, and we have also taken into account that this is the second time this happened; you made a similar remark yesterday. The Chamber has discussed the matter.Now, the Prosecutor is, as indicated by Mr. Phillips, under no legal obligation to disclose in advance documents of this character. It is also important, of course, also stressed by the Prosecutor, that in adversarial proceedings, the party be given the possibility, cross-examining the witness, to impeach the credibility -- I don't take a position whether this was actually done in the present case, but now I'm at the general level -- to impeach the credibility by submitting documents which have not previously been made known to the witness. So the Prosecutor is right in that respect.On the other hand, we all think that the Defence remark is legitimate in the sense that once the witness is in the witness box, there is no longer any contact between the witness and any of the lawyers, any of the teams, either on the Prosecution or the Defence side; and for that reason, the element of surprise and the possibility to impeach the witness would not be reduced if the Prosecution were to provide the Defence with documents the Prosecution intends to rely upon when the cross-examining is starting or even once the witness has entered the witness box and therefore is incommunicado for the Defence. So, that would reduce the element of surprise for the Defence without reducing the possibility of the Prosecution to impeach the credibility, and we think that is a practice that should be followed in this case as it has been followed in previous cases. So if that could kindly be observed from now on.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honour, we have an observation to make. It's an observation that centres on the inequality or equality of arms.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The Defence, during the Prosecution's case, adopted the same practice. The same courtesy was not afforded to the Prosecution. It is, for want of a better word, unfair and prejudicial to the Prosecution to be asked to submit documents of their own witnesses. They are calling the witnesses, not my witness. They should be making the disclosure to me because they know, they ought to know the evidence and the documents. We were not afforded the same privilege. They sprang up with documents; I never objected because that is the essence of an adversarial system. The issue you make about the witness being in the box would not be helpful. Learned counsel, with all due respect, would only tailor his examination to suit the evidence there. The whole purpose of it -- and in any jurisdiction in the whole world, it is a noted fact that it is not a disclosure obligation of the party impeaching the witness to disclose the evidence beforehand. It is absolutely unfair.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah. Now, we are well aware, coming from many jurisdictions in the world, of what is the practice in the world, so we do not need to be reminded about that.I also take your point, Mr. Phillips, that when it comes to a document which may affect the way in which the examination-in-chief may be conducted, then certainly you will not be doing that until your cross-examination starts. So that's absolutely -- I totally agree with you there. So in other words, when I made the remark about the moment he -- you may, of course, be able to wait with showing documents to the Defence if that could influence the examination-in-chief of the Defence. That point is taken. But the remainder of the remark remains; that is, namely, that we have now in Trial Chamber I, for at least two years, observed the practice I just outlined, and it's a matter of courtesy. It's not a binding rule. It's not a clear-cut rule, but it facilitates the proceedings in the courtroom.Now, coming, then, to the point of the equality between the parties, I can't -- are there any documents or episodes in particular you want to recall? You will remember -- I don't recall you having made any objections previously in that connection, but that is, as you say, because you accept the adversarial principle.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Of course, of course.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It happened several times, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: With the same sort of documents from the prosecutor's office. There was one that was the subject of a motion that I filed, which I haven't received a decision on.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which document is that or which decision? I thought we were absolutely up to --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The decision on the misconduct of Defence counsel. It was based on a similar practice.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: All right. But what I'm saying now is not particularly dramatic or difficult, it's only a matter of courtesy between the parties.Now, there were no questions -- do you have anything to add, Mr. Besnier?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, I have no difficulty with the ruling. I understand the grounds and I accept it, but I have one question still in my mind. If we have in our possession after this session documents which enable us to challenge the documents produced by the Prosecutor, will we be authorised to produce such documents in the interests of justice?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You will make an application to have it admitted, and then we will deal with it in concreto, case-by-case basis based on the situation.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, am I correct in saying that yesterday you testified to the effect that you were guilty for three murders which you yourself committed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: That is true, but there were some of my co-perpetrators whom I did not mention because there were many. But it is true that I committed these crimes, and I confessed to them.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, am I correct in saying that with regard to other crimes, you testified yesterday that you had played the role of an eyewitness, and that your guilty role was attributed to you mainly because of your passiveness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No one has even accused me of these crimes. I voluntarily provided this information concerning the crimes so that the legal authorities are aware.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Am I correct in saying that for the murder of Cyprien Karegeya you are described as an eyewitness, as a passive witness of the murder, and that you are not yourself accused of having struck any blow?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I do accept my responsibility in that crime because people saw me pass by. I was in the group of attackers. I was armed with a club, and for those who saw me, I was a criminal amongst others. And that is why I am counting myself amongst the attackers who killed Karegeya. And people who were seeing me on the scene -- at the scene of the crime could not say that I was not part of the criminals involved, and that is why I voluntarily gave information regarding that crime so that one is aware of exactly what happened.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: With regard to the murder of Cyprien Karegeya, are there any documents in the possession of the Rwandan courts containing confessions given by you, giving an account of the events?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes, such a document exists.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You will see that this document is attached to your confession, a document which was given to you today.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: But I think I saw Karegeya's name in the documents which were given to me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness -- I do not want to ask a leading question, Mr. President -- but the name of Karegeya does not exist in the documents which you were given today. Does that mean that there were other confessions or other documents bearing the name of Karegeya and which you voluntarily did not wish to submit, so that we have a complete document?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, Mr. Witness, why is Mr. Karegeya's name not mentioned in the present document, the one in front of us? Why is that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I don't know how they omitted mentioning Karegeya's name. I mentioned it. Furthermore, I have in my possession a document which testifies to the fact that I mentioned that name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which document is that, the one you have in your possession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have a document. In fact, it's a copy of my confession that I sent to the prosecutor. The first document which I sent to the prosecutor was lost, and I made a second document. So I do not understand why the name of Karegeya does not appear in that document, whereas I had spoken about him and I gave the names of persons who had killed him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, when you sent that second document to the prosecutor, was that a document containing the names we have in front of us here, but in addition, also Mr. Karegeya's name? Is that your testimony?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I remember that I mentioned Karegeya's name. I was asking the person who was writing for me, because I don't know how to write, to add Karegeya's name. So I don't understand how come he didn't mention Karegeya's name, but I'm positive that in the document I have, that name exists.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. But when you provided this second round of information, did you then give these names, plus Mr. Karegeya's name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I asked the person who was writing for me to also note down Karegeya's name, but I didn't take care to find out whether he'd actually written Karegeya's name. Maybe he forgot to mention Karegeya's name, but I had asked him to do so. I'm positive that I asked him to add Karegeya's name. There were two documents. First of all, there was a document in which my confession appeared, and then there was a document in which I was testifying on persons who killed Karegeya in my presence. Therefore, I did not omit to add Karegeya's name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: But you also mentioned these other names in that connection on that occasion; is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The problem of documents which are disclosed at the last minute is that we are unable to verify their completeness.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, in Rwanda, did you have counsel to assist you in your case?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, I don't have counsel. Actually, my trial has not yet begun.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: So your case has not been brought to completion?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, because I'm going to appear before the Gacaca courts, and these courts have not yet begun their sittings.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At the appropriate moment, nothing will stop you from mentioning the Karegeya affair and the role which you played therein?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: My learned friend should know better, really. You should know better.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was this a question? What is the next question?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Have you been --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I'm sorry, the witness is also speaking.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Counsel, I don't think I understood your question.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: I think I've already put this question. I'll put it again. Have you -- has your case been ruled on definitively in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, I have not gone before the courts as yet.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, was your confession read to you, the one which is before us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, it wasn't read to me.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And how much time did you spend at Gitaka roadblock.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I was not at the Gitaka roadblock. That roadblock was erected in the Gitesi secteur, whereas, I was in Buyea secteur.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And where was Karegeya killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Karegeya was killed in Gitaka behind the buildings.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Which buildings?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It was behind the row of buildings which was somewhat below.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Was one of those buildings Gitanen Karara, the trader's house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No. The first building belonged to Myera and the second to Sebarame.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: I have not understood you very well. Where was the Gitaka roadblock, according to you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: When I arrived in Gitaka in 1994 I saw the roadblock. It was erected between Karara's house and that belonging to Ndabukiye.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: But that is not where Karegeya was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: We had already passed the roadblock and it was behind the buildings, a little bit further away from the roadblock that Karegeya was killed.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: So you never spent any time at this roadblock, then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: You mentioned in your evidence yesterday that after the arrival of the accused in Gitaka, a few days later people began to flee, and you say this was at the end of May or beginning of June. Is that what you said?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I said that I saw Ndindabahizi at the end of June and people began to flee at the beginning of July, the first week of July. I think that's what I explained yesterday, and that's how the events occurred.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: The war was over, wasn't it? So why were people --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes. People were leaving the country. Ordinary citizens were no longer being killed. There was rather a war between the soldiers. The disturbances amongst the population had come to an end and there was only the soldiers that were in confrontation during this time.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Then you also stated -- and correct me if I'm wrong -- that the Accused could not have killed Karegeya because there was no prior meeting.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: My question then is, were there prior meetings in respect of the victims whom you killed or others who were killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, there were no meetings.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Thank you, that's all.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, were you provided with a copy of the confession statement made before the Rwandan Court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I made a confession. I kept a copy and I gave the original to the Prosecutor.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Do you have the original with you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have a copy but the other was sent to the Prosecutor's Office. I'm keeping a copy with me in the prison.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Did you see the name of Karegeya was mentioned in that confession statement? Did you see the name of Karegeya in the copy provided to you by the Rwandan court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I had told them to write down his name and I believe his name is there.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Did you read that name? Did you know that name was there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I don't know how to read. I'm sure his name is there, because I asked that the name be mentioned, so I don't know how it couldn't be written down. I cannot read what was written by hand. When I'm given a document I keep it.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You are unable to read even your own language?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: When it's a typed document I can read it and that's the case if it's in capital letters, but if it's written by hand I am unable to read.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Your confession was recorded in handwriting?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Someone was taking down notes for me. I was asking someone to take notes for me, and the confession was taken down by hand.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: The copy provided to you, is it a handwritten or a typed copy?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I kept a copy but the other one was sent to the Prosecutor. Nobody gave me a copy. In other words, no one sent us a typewritten copy of what we had said. I kept the handwritten version.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: That handwritten version was provided by the Court, by the Rwandan Court?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, no, it's prisoners, it's my fellow-prisoners who wrote for me, and then a copy of that document was sent to the Prosecutor's Office.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, who was the leader of the group that killed Mr. Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I saw Rwasibo, who was conducting himself like a leader.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You formed part of that group, did you, but he was the leader or you were not sure of him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I can consider myself as an observer. I was not with them in the beginning. We met along the way, and I joined the group. We did not discuss the plan together.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Were you -- but you were present when the person was killed. What was the distance between you and the spot where he was killed, physically?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It's a distance that I can cover, if I walk at a fast pace, in five minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Were you five minutes away from the spot where this person was killed? Were you five minutes walking distance away?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: No, I was very close to these persons, about ten metres from these people. I was a bit uphill in relation to where they were. I was not further than ten metres away. And I could see a person and whatever he was doing.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, if Rwasibo was the leader, why is Rwasibo not mentioned in this document with persons present during killing? In other words, the document containing perpetrators and observers, why is his name not mentioned in that document which was shown to you just a few moments ago?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Rwasibo was often mentioned. How did you know him, Mr. President? I'm sure it's because his name is in a document that you have. How then do you explain his presence in the document? I mentioned him in all the documents. I could not have covered up his name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So, did you mention his name when you made your explanation to the Prosecutors and when you confessed to your crimes? Did you mention Rwasibo's name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: At that time I did not mention Rwasibo simply because I was talking about myself. When I gave my testimony perhaps I should have mentioned him in my testimony, but with regard to my confession, the confession is about what I did personally. But the testimony about -- that arose in the second part and his name is mentioned therein. I think there's a portion of my testimony which you did not receive. There were two parts, my confession and then my testimony. It is possible to see it in one portion of the document and not in the other.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, in the testimony before this Court you mentioned Rwasibo. I'm putting to you that there is no mention of Rwasibo in the document we were just provided with. What is your comment to that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I'm saying that in my statement, when I had my statement written, I asked that his name be mentioned. I don't know why they did not write it down. I believe those who recorded my statement did not write it. Sometimes you ask somebody -- you tell somebody something and you ask him to put it in writing and it's possible for that person to forget certain things and to include certain things, that is normal, that is human.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Mwirinde?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: You asked me a question regarding residents of Gitaka, people who were present and who could have seen what happened, and you asked me the names of other persons who were present, people who were observing and who were not killers, and I mentioned his name.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So was he a Hutu or a Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was a Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he present during the event?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Mwirinde was there the day Karegeya was killed and we found him there.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was Mwirinde observing this event, the killing of this person?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was present. When Karegeya was taken away he was in front of his door, but he did not go to the site where he was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Sebarame, was he a Hutu or a Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was a Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did he also observe the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Sebarame saw him, he came and stood about five metres away from me and observed what was going on, and if you asked him the question as to who struck Karegeya, he will tell you because he was present and he saw everything.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who was Nsengimana, was he Hutu or a Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He's Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What was Nsengimana's first name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Nasone (phonetic).

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did he have any nickname?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I don't know his nickname.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: He was present during the killing, was he?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: We left him a bit uphill. He was standing there, but I do not believe that he was present among those that I saw at the killing site. I think he was on the road close to the houses. I don't think he left that place.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And then Sebarame, was he Hutu or Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He's Hutu.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he also present?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was standing about five metres from me and he saw everything.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, in your statement we just received here there is no mention of Mwirinde, Nsengimana, and Nsabimana.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I added this name when you asked me the name of the persons who were present. We did not have enough sheets of paper such that we couldn't put all the names. We had to reduce the names and to write as little as possible. So we mentioned only some names. They asked us questions on events which we experienced which we witnessed, which we saw. We gave the essential parts. We could not have given all the names. I have given this name before you just because you asked me a question regarding those who were present and who witnessed the killing.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you know anyone called Joel Ntabwakule (phonetic) ?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: It's, rather, Joel Ndabukiye, I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is he a Hutu or a Tutsi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He's Hutu. He's detained in the Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he present during the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: He was not present.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Why is he detained?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I don't know. I don't know the reasons for which he is detained.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you know anyone named Emmanuel Ndabukiye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Did you say Emmanuel Ndabukiye? I don't know him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What's the distance, Mr. Witness, between Tabeya and the place where the killing took place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Where the killing took place is called Tabeya but before then it was in the Gitesi commune, and for now, when they are asking their questions about where the killing took place, we used to say in the Gitesi communal, but now that place is called Tabeya.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the place where Karegeya was killed is in Tabeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Now it has become Tabeya, it used to be Gitesi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Mr. Witness, we have concluded your testimony. We would like to thank you for having come the long way to Arusha to testify and wish you a very safe journey home. Please do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the witness could be escorted. Yes, you have anything to add, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have a question, Mr. President.
