sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: I have a question. I have seen Ndindabahizi in this courtroom. Can't you allow me to say hello to him? We haven't seen for a long time. That is my only request. Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That is a request which is now noted and if there is a wish on the part of the Defence to follow-up that request, then it can simply be done by communication through the witness protection unit. Your testimony has come to an end, provided that there is no objection by the Prosecution, and there is none. So that is something that will be followed up administratively and we will see how that develops.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DM:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, please. The next witness is DO.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, it is DO, Mr. President?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to as Witness DO in these proceedings. Do you have a document in front of you there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that your signature at the bottom of that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It is my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, the information is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That leads us to Defence Exhibit 38, under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you have to tell the truth, Mr. Witness, and the registry will administer the taking of your solemn declaration.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DO in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You will now be asked questions by the Defence.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President.

div.stage: WITNESS DO,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Good morning, Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Good morning, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, are you able to tell the Court where you lived in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I lived in the Nyagahenga cellule in the Kahenge secteur and Kibuye préfecture, in the Gitesi commune.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. And before you came to Arusha, Witness, where were you living? Just before you came to Arusha where were you living?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: The same place I've just mentioned. But before coming here I was a detainee in a Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. You are a detainee in the Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, in the Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And do you recall the dates on which you were arrested to be taken to the Gisovu prison?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: 30th November 1994.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What are the charges against you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I'm accused of genocide.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you plead guilty to those crimes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And have you been sentenced for this crime?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No. My case is still before the Prosecutor. It's not yet been brought to the judges.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You admitted having been arrested for genocide. Did you participate in attacks against civilian Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I have a big share of responsibilities.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you able to tell the Court, taking as a reference point the death of President Habyarimana, if you remember that, tell the Court when the attacks against the Tutsis started.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: In our region it was after four days that we started the killings.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How did the killings start? Who gave the signal?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We were very nervous. I did not see any authority, but there were attacks and there were attackers from Mabanza, from Rutsiro, and they told us that, "You have not done anything to date." And I think that is how we started.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You admit having committed crimes against Tutsis. In which secteur did you perpetrate these crimes?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: In three separate secteurs, Gitesi secteur, in Kayenzi, as well as the Ruragwe secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you recall having gone to a cellule called Gasharu during the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, very often. We virtually lived in this cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you going to Gasharu every day?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We didn't go to Gasharu every day, but we used to go there -- we go through the cellule when we were going for attacks, and then we came back to this cellule to have a drink.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And yet the Gasharu cellule is not the cellule in which you have your house. So why do you go there so often?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It's a cellule which is neighbouring to our own. There's a river dividing the two and every day we used to meet in the Gasharu cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was there a trading centre in Gasharu?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, there was a small trading centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what is the name of that trading centre?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It's the Gitaka trading centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During the events that we are discussing, are you able to tell me if there was a roadblock at Gitaka?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: There was.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who was manning this roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: There was a young man called Sumayire Minani and another one called Nbonyubwe.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can witness or the Kinyarwanda interpreters, are you able to spell this name for the Court?

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Minani, M-I-N-A-N-I. Sumayire is S-U-M-A-Y-I-R-E. Nbonyubwe N-B-O-N-Y-U-B-W-E.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let's come back to this roadblock. Do you know if Tutsis were killed on this roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No Tutsi was killed at this roadblock. People were brought from neighbouring hills. Some were killed behind the house and others in other places, but nobody was stopped and killed at the roadblock; to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To your knowledge, did it ever happen that Tutsis were killed within the vicinity of that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It is in the commercial centre that the roadblock was located, and I know people who were killed close to that centre, and I myself played a role in their killing.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You are saying that people were killed. Who was killed during the genocide in that cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: There were many. There was, for example, Nyiranye; a child called Gatemeri; there's Kayoni. There's a child of Rwabyuma, and the little children, two of them of Nzajyinduga; and a woman named Tatiana and her two children; another one called Nyankiko, and others. There's a woman and her child, the woman was called Mukankubito, there was another man called Karegeya who was killed very close to that centre.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I think we have sufficient names for now.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you need to have these names spelled for the record?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. President I was going to ask -- to request the Kinyarwanda interpreters to give us -- to spell those names for us.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Yes, Nkiranuye, N-K-I-R-A-N-U-Y-E; Gatemeri, G-A-T-E-M-E-R-I; Kanyoni, K-A-N-Y-O-N-I; Rwabyuma, R-W-A-B-Y-U-M-A; Nzajyinduga, N-Z-A-J-Y-I-N-D-U-G-A; Thacianne,T-H-A-C-I-A-N-N-E; Nyankiko, N-Y-A-N-K-I-K-O; Mukankubito, M-U-K-A-N-K -U-B-I-T-O; and Karegeya, K A-R-E-G-Y-E-Y-A (sic).

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: We thank the interpreters.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, we are now going to ask you questions on one of the persons -- or, on a few of those names that you have mentioned. Let's start with the person that you call Thacianne.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, it is Thacianne Mukantabana, M-U-K-A-N-T-A-B-A-N-A.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, all those names you have mentioned, did you know them beforehand?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I knew them very well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you on good terms with them before the events?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I had no problems with them.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: We heard only, April 1994, we didn't hear the beginning of counsel's question.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We were surprised -- we were taken by surprise by the events. Immediately after the death of the president, we were very nervous, very exited, and we were afraid at the beginning. We were afraid. We lived harmoniously on the hill, we used to work together, and we were ensuring our own -- our security together, but later when houses -- when they started burning houses in Mabanza, the events went all the way to Ruragwe and people came by saying, "Well, you have not done anything," that is when we started killing, and one person -- you attack a person you knew and you kill him. It is a matter of shame and we are very sad about that. I am very saddened by the crimes that I have committed and I know it will create problems for the courts, and that is why I decided to confess my guilt.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You killed Tutsis, but were you not afraid that the authorities or the police will arrest you and put you in prison during the events?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It took time for us to begin killing, but then later on, when we started killing, what could the authorities do against thousands of people? It was impossible to quieten those people. That was a major problem to the authorities. Those were killings never seen before; unspeakable, but I couldn't see how the authorities could arrest those killings, and had they attempted to stop us, probably the situation would have worsened. Thus, we started killing, it was because we were very nervous. We had become more like beasts. This is the only adjective I could use to describe us.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let us be more precise about Thacianne Mukantabana that you mentioned. Do you remember the date on which she was killed, Thacianne Mukantabana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not remember the date, sir, but I believe that it was in May, at the very beginning of the month of May.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who was there when she was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Let me give you the names of the persons that were with me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are you going to give us names, sir? If so, give us names of the people who were in your group, who could not be witnesses at this time. We shall come back to that.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We were at Gitaka, and when we killed her it was on a Monday. There was a first person, Nsengiyumva -- a gendarme Cyprian Nsengiyumva; there was another Nsengiyumva, alias, Rutomvu; and then there was Ismael Mbarushimana; and I believe that there was also Frouduel Bakinahe; there was also one Mpitabakana.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Still for the Court and the transcripts, could you be so kind as to spell out those names?

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: There was Cyprian Nsengiyumva, N-S-E-N-G-I-Y U-M-V-A; Ismael Mbarushimana,M-B-A-R-U-S-H-I-M-A-N-A; Mpitabakana, M-P-I-T-A-B-A-K-A-N-A; Frouduel Bakinahe, B-A-K-I-N-A-H-E; there was also Mbarushimana, rather, Nsengiyumva, N-S-E-N-G-I-Y-U-M-V-A; Alias Rutomvu, R-U-T-O-M-V-U.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: A general remark. When there is a list of names given by the witness, and the same list is given in a piece of paper, then, I think, the practical way to proceed is to ensure that the court reporter has the same list. For the time being, it would appear that that list has not been distributed to the court reporters. But could that be arranged from now on, that when there are lists of names in the document, then that is being submitted to the court reporters, then we do not have to do the spelling. So that is one issue.The second; once names are being spelt, it is, of course, important to reflect the names and their order as testified to by the witness and not to follow the names in the list if there are differences between the two. I am just making those two general observations. Yes, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, I have taken note of that observation, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, Witness, let us now hear from you, briefly, but accurately, the manner in which Thacianne Mukantabana was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I believe it was around 2 p.m., we were at the Gitaka centre. Cyprian Nsengiyumva, who was a gendarme, and Nsengiyumva, alias Rutomvu, took her to Gitaka -- they found her at Joel Ndabukage's, where she was hiding. I asked them, "We were looking for that person for a long time, where did you find that person?" And the gendarme told me, "You cannot search for these people, I am a soldier I know how to go about it. I cannot tell you where I found her." And the people said, "Well, now we have found her." And when we were going out to kill her, the gendarme said, "Well, wait a minute, she promised to give me something," so that we went away and got to Nyarubuye at one Pascal's house -- Pascal Rwuhara's house, there were the furniture belonging to that lady. We took the furniture and got back to Gitaka. The furniture went to Nyabahiga -- at the gendarme's house. When we wanted to take it to Nyabahinga's house the soldier said -- when we got to Nyabahinga -- we wanted to go to Nyabahinga, but the soldier refused, the gendarme refused. So we stayed at Gitaka, and we took her behind the shops. We didn't go any further, and it was there that we killed her in the company of two of her children and another man who was at Ndabahinga's, he was called Nyugahingu; so that we killed four people on that occasion.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You are saying, firstly -- firstly you found and flushed out Ndabakeke who was at Bukiye's house in hiding?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I was not one of those that flushed the person out. She was brought in by Nsengiyumva, Cyprian, who was a gendarme. With Nsengiyumva, alias, Rutomvu, they were the two that brought her.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you a member of the group that went to take the furniture -- to steal the furniture?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I also went to Nyarubuye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Yes, you went to Nyarubuye to get the furniture. Were you with Thacianne?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, she was with us, with her two children. We went together.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And then you took her back to the Gitaka centre; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Absolutely correct. It was there that we found that Nyankiko, Zachari, that man -- when you get to Gitaka, you go down along rows of shops and just in front of Gatwa's residence, and when you get to a junction, you turn into a street of Rwuberamye's house, that is where the shops were.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, as compared to the roadblock that was at the central of Gitaka, what was the distance at which Thacianne was killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It was the distance of 80 to 90 metres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who were the persons that struck Thacianne Mukantabana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I, personally did. I struck her several times.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: With what type of weapon?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I used a club. There were four people to be killed, but I also had a sword. I did not use the sword, since Nyakiko was bringing about problems, I left after having struck her twice. She was not yet dead, and it was Nsengiyumva, alias, Rutomvu that finished her off whilst I went off to kill the other man who was called Nyankiko.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who ordered you to kill those people in particular -- especially Thacianne and her family, who gave you instructions to kill those people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: You mean at that very instant or just before? In the preceding days, nobody ordered us to do so. I have told you how it all started, but when we were on the spot the most important person was the gendarme, and it was the gendarme who told us, "Don't take her all they way to Nyabahanga, kill her here."

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Didn't you say that Thacianne was being sought after, who was looking for her?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Everybody was looking for her -- everybody. All the population in that area was looking for her. In 1985, there was an incident. There was a teacher called Jaqueline Nyirabakwiza, who was a teacher in primary 5, she had poisoned -- she had poisoned her, and people were saying that it was her that -- it was she that poisoned her, and that is why she was called "Nyiramasitete". And when the war started, they were saying that she has to be found and killed, and that is when -- why Thacianne was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This episode with Jaqueline, in which year was that, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I was in primary 5, I believe it was in 1985.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness. Could you tell me whether you knew one Emmanuel Ndindabahizi before the events that we have just discussed, that is before April l994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I used to know him. I had seen him on two occasions. The first occasion at which I saw him was just before -- just after his wedding. He had come to visit his family while in our area. We were there, we watched his vehicle so that the children do not spoil the tyres. The second time was, I believe, in 1992. He had come to our area in Gitaka; he held a meeting there, and I believe on that occasion, he gave us berets of his party, PSD. We were very happy to join the party. This is how I got to know Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi once again during the war, that is, between the beginning of April l994 and the end of June 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I did not see him during that period, but I heard it said that he had come to our area -- he had come to our area in Gitaka, and that he had arrested one Augustin Karara, who had a shop in the centre. He had arrested him and he had taken him away to imprison him. On that day, I did not move. I believe it was on a Sunday, I was at home, and the other attackers came to see me and they said, "The minister is here, he is very serious." And I asked, "What has happened?" They told me, "Well, he has just arrested Karara." And then I told them, "Well, if you continue to move around like this, you may be arrested yourselves." And we went to a hill, and several moments after that I saw, from one kilometre away, a vehicle pass by Ndabukiye's house. We therefore went to the centre after that, and people told us that Karara had just been arrested, and they did not know what was going to happen to him. This is what happened, but I did not personally see him when he came on that day.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Didn't you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi before Thacianne's death at the Gitaka roadblock that you mentioned?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, sir, I didn't see him. I did not see any other authority as a matter of fact. I didn't see any préfet or bourgmestre. I did not see any such authorities. And, I pleaded guilty, let me state the truth and nothing but the truth, and if I had seen the president I would have said so. So that if we speak the truth it must be the whole truth and supply the names of all the accomplices. So that had I seen him, I would have made a testimony against him, and that would have been done a long time ago, and that is the reason why I am saying he did not do anything in our area. He did not call for massacres to begin.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you know one Cyprian Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I know him very well. He was a neighbour in the Gasharu cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he survive the genocide?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, he died. He was killed, and that is a very well-known fact. He was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When was he killed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: After the murder of Thacianne Mukantabana, that was less than seven days after that murder, it was at that time, I believe, that he was also killed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know how he was killed and who killed him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not know the circumstances under which he died. Karegeya was one of the people sought after. He was very much sought after. I came to Gitaka, at that time Karara just came out of the Jita pub where he was having a drink. He was very sad, and he said, "My friend has been killed." I asked him, "Who is killed? Is it Karegeya?" He said, "Yes, it is Karegeya." I said that since he is dead we no longer had to look for him. He said that he was one of the most important people that actually had been killed. And I said, 'Who killed him?" And he said, "It was attackers that came from Buye."I said, "Didn't you bury him since he was your friend?" He said, "Yes, I did bury him." I said, "Well, well, that is the end of all of that." It was thus that I learnt that he was killed by people from Buye.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: But you were not an eyewitness to that murder? Yes or no will do.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: You mean Karegeya? No. I was not an eyewitness to his murder.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Regarding your testimony here in Arusha, do you believe that you are going to gain anything from it -- from having -- or testifying for Emanuel Ndindabahizi, are you going to gain anything from it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: You mean interest? You see, we in Rwanda only want people to plead guilty if they are guilty, and ask for pardon, because there are people who are wrongly accused. People are said to have played a role whilst one did not see them anywhere. Those people are falsely accused. So, you the Judges must seek the correct information to get to the truth. We are speaking the truth. We are not protecting anyone. We never do so. We speak the truth, the whole truth, because what happened is deplorable, and it's for that reason that if we are to struggle and show the reconciliation of Rwandans, we must speak the truth so that we know where to lay the blame.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you. Now, try to be brief in your responses. I have two more questions for you. In the prison that you are, did you meet people very near Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, who were close to him, and who asked you to testify in his favour?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: You mean people from abroad, or people in the same prison as myself?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, people in the same prison ask yourself, all the detainees; didn't they ask you to lie in favour of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Nobody, sir. We are here speaking the truth about crimes that we personally committed. Nobody close to Emmanuel Ndindabahizi approached me in that respect, and even if they did, I wouldn't accept. There are many people that were compelled to plead guilty, but I personally can never be coerced into doing anything.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In the prisons in which you are, are there Hutu groups that help one another to lie before national or international jurisdictions, and are you not one of the members of those groups?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I don't know of the existence of such groups. All I know is that each and every one speaks out his or her own truth as he or her -- she knows it. If there are any people who are lying, other people will challenge them.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Isn't it correct that among the detainees that confessed some are trying to help or are trying to encourage their friends also to confess; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct, it does happen. We had meetings like the ones we had in gacaca per secteur, per cellule, and people talked about what happened in the cellules, the crimes that were committed, who committed them. They gave the names of the accomplices and everything is said.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: No further questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We will then have the morning break and then the cross-examination thereafter.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Cross-examination, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours, we have a practical problem. We don't have the French court reporter. I don't know how much -- what the implication that has for --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: She is indispensable.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Indispensable; indispensable; okay.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you will now be cross-examined by the Prosecution.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Hello again, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I am going to ask you some questions in relation to your testimony this morning. Mr. Witness, you have testified to your involvement in the killing of some Tutsis in the Kibuye préfecture in 1994, have you not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Amongst the victims of your crimes, do you recall being involved in the killing of a man by the name Higiro, Simeon; H-I-G-I-R-O, Simon?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not know Higiro.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you recall being involved in the killing of the child of Rwabyuma. R-A- - R-W-A-B-Y-A --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let's talk about the -- Higiro, Simon. You have testified that you don't recall being involved in that crime.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I'm going to ask that the registry show you a document. And I want him to be shown the confession statement of a man called Seyeze, Ezechias.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know that person, sir? Just the first document. Excuse me, sir.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your Honours, I am having the documents which you have before you shown to the witness. The front document, which has 61 written at the right-hand corner of it, is the original Kinyarwanda confession, and then there's a French translation. Again, we were unable to get an English translation to this document in time for this hearing. That's the document I refer to, and we all have it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, do you know the man by the name Seyeze, Ezechias, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How do you know this man, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He lives in Gasharu commune in Gitesi secteur.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did you participate in any crimes with this man, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Yes, in front of his house, in front of one man known as -- in front of Kanyoni's house. That man was known as Kanyoni; it was in front of his house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And when you say "in front of his house", who do you refer to, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Actually, I'm talking about Seyeze's house, in front of Seyeze's house. That killing took place in front of his house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did Seyeze take part in that killing, sir, to the best of your knowledge, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, a major role.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Killing of whom, Mr.Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We are talking about Kanyoni. He's the one who brought Kanyoni. He had found him in a beans field.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can we have Kanyoni spelled for the record, please?

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Kanyoni is spelt K-A-N-Y-O-N-I; Kanyoni.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, in the confession that I have asked to be placed before you, Mr. Witness, Seyeze, Ezechias, confessed to you being a collaborator or an accomplice in the killing of a man called Higiro, Simon. Do you see that on the first page, sir? The second page in Kinyarwanda, the second, if you look at -- can you see that, sir, on page 64? Turn three pages in Kinyarwanda to the fourth page and you see your name at the top of the page, sir. If the registry can assist the witness, I'll be grateful. Turn him to the page -- the page that has 64 on it in the bundle with him.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I don't think I have that document here before me. I was given Ndabukiye's document.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you please stay with him, sir? He needs your help.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You see that on page 64 your name is mentioned there?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Okay. Now, let's turn now to page 63, the page before that, sir, in Kinyarwanda. You see the name of the victim there, sir; do you?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, do you understand --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you understand that to mean that Seyeze is accusing you of being an accomplice in the killing of that person, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I can see that, but the problem is to determine whether Kanyoni is a nickname. The circumstances that he is referring to are the same, but I recall that that person was called Kanyoni and that's why I'm saying that I did not participate in Simeon Higiro's death. I do not know whom he is referring to, who he is talking about. I must know whether that person was called Simon Higiro. The person whom he is referring to and who was killed or who died at Gasharu, I don't know. I don't know who he was; I killed many people, I wouldn't know his name. Sometimes the person may have written the nickname without knowing other names, so it's possible that Simon, Simeon -- Simon Higiro and Kanyoni would be one in the same person; it is possible.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I am grateful for that, sir. Now, can you help me? Does the man Seyeze, Ezechias, have any relationship with the Accused person in this case, to your knowledge, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And what is that relationship, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I don't know what the exact relationship is; maybe they are brothers.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Are you speculating? Are you saying you are not sure, or you don't know, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: They have their sister who lives on their land, on their property. I was going to school and I didn't know everybody, nor the relationships that existed between them, but I know that their family relationship is very close.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, if you -- do you recall the people who were present during the incident of Simon Higiro's death, who you say may be or may not be the same person with the nickname? Do you recall those who witnessed this crime, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, there were other people with me. For instance, there was a soldier known as Boniface Mgabo. There was another person, and it was very early in the morning. There was a man known as Uwimana; I don't know his first name. There was Uwimana, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, can you turn with me to the page -- after the page that has your name on it in that document that you referred to?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And if the registry can just ensure he is doing the right thing; he should only have one document with him at the one date. I am talking about page 65, on the right-hand corner.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you see the first name there, sir, and before that name is --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: -- were they witnesses to the crime? Do you see that name, sir? Don't read it out, please, just tell me if you see it.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I can see the name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you confirm that person was a witness to that crime, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I can see names, but these names don't mean much to me. Unless these people come to -- come here, then I would be able to say that person or the other was there. Maybe they were there before I got there. I see that these are women's names. Maybe they saw me, and they fled when I got there. I cannot deny that they may have seen me. It is possible that these people saw me, and I don't see any problem with them mentioning my name because I did commit the crime.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Witness, I know you are very proud of your activities in 1994, but can you just limit your answers, please, to the questions that I ask you. Can we do that? Can we just do that, please?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, look at the third name on that page, please. It is numbered 1, 2, and 3, the third name there. Please don't mention the name; same page, same page, the third name. Do you know that person or do you recall that person being a witness during the killing of Higiro, Simon, name number three; and look at the father's name as well. This person is related to Sim -- Cyprien Karegeya, and it tells you the relationship there on that page. Don't mention the person's name, but just tell me, do you recall whether or not that person was a witness to the killing of Simon Higiro, since you participated? Help me with that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It's possible that this child was in the location, and this is why I am saying that if the child was not very far away, maybe she was able to have seen me. Maybe she could have seen me without me seeing her.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It is actually the person who confesses to that crime that has pointed out this person's name as a witness to his crime, isn't it? Ezechias Seyeze, and he says that you are an accomplice; is that not so, sir? Can you say yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I have made a confession, but I was not able to know who the witnesses to my crime were. I was able to give the names of the co-perpetrators, yes, and that was by chance, because the truth will come out as nothing will be able to be hidden. And since Seyeze was their neighbour, it's obvious that they knew him, and he's the one who is going to help you and I and the Tribunal, to remember the names of those who were present.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, did you see that lady there when the crime was committed? That question can be answered with a yes or a no. Did you see her yourself?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, I didn't see her.

sp.speaker: THE PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you know whether she was there, even if you didn't see her? That can also be answered with a yes or no.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not believe that person was there, no; I don't think so. And I knew her; I knew her.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness, for answering that question. Now, in relation to the killing of the child of Rwabyuma, which you say you recall, do you remember the people who witnessed that crime? And can --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I remember those people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you tell me who those people were, who were present when you -- when you were involved in the killing of Rwayumba's child?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: There was Joël Ndabukiye, one lady known as Madeleine Hitiyaremye. There was another known as Sendiragora and I think there was also Boniface Mgabo. Those are the people I remember having seen at the location during the crime.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Before I ask you my next question, can we have those names spelt into the record please.

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Ndabukiye is spelt N-D-A-B-U-K-I-Y-E; Hitiyaremye is spelt H-I-T-I-Y-A-R-E-M-Y-E; Hitiyaremye; Sendiragora is spelt S-E-N-D-I-R-A-G-O-R-A; Mgabo is spelt M-G-A-B-O.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Witness, were these accomplices or were they witnesses to the crime? Can you make that distinction for us, please, these names which you have just given us?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, no, these were co-perpetrators.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So what about the witnesses, the people who witnessed the killing; do you recall who any of them may have been, sir, the witnesses?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I only remember one person, a girl.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Who is she, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Do you want her name?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, please, sir.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Her name was Julienne Mukamana.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And is that name contained in the document the confession of Joël Ndabukiye that I have just asked to be placed before you, sir, on page 74? Make sure he has -- it is the fourth page in the Kinyarwanda, the fifth page, the fifth page in the Kinyarwanda. Is that name there, sir? Is it the top name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, I want you to look at the third name, the third name on that list, the name Sibomana. Do you know -- do you recall who that person was? Could you tell us if it was a man or woman, one of the witnesses that Joël said witnessed described?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall, sir? If not, just say so.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: All these people don't live very from the place where we killed that child. It's a place from where one can observe the place very easily, the site of -- the scene of the crime.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: But you still haven't answered my question in relation to Sibomana. Do you recall who he was or don't you, sir? Can we just cross that bridge first sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He was a simple citizen who had -- who had come to live in Gasharu cellule, but he was not a native of that place.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you describe his age to me? Was he young, was he middle-aged, was he an old man? Can you help me with that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He was a man more than 40 years old and he had children in primary school.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you knew this man before the events of 1994, did you, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I knew him very well.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Registry. You can sit down now, and if you can take the document away from the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I now want to ask you questions in relation to the killing of Mukantabana, Thacianne. Do you understand that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Is it your testimony, sir, that you were involved in the attack on this lady and her child or children, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I am amongst the people who killed them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Had this woman and her child offended you, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No. It's like the other people who had been killed; these people had done nothing to me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Were you arrested in relation to her death, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Witness, who else was involved, apart from yourself, in the killings that you were involved in, in 1994? Was Joël Ndabukiye involved with you, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, prior to the genocide of 1994, Mr. Witness, what was your profession, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I was a farmer, but before that in 1988 when I was in secondary school, I left secondary school in 1990 and I came to remain at home. And when the war began I was a farmer. I had just spent four years in that profession of farmer or cultivator.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And Joël Ndabukiye, sir, before the genocide of 1994, can you tell me what he did for a living, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He was headmaster of a primary school.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Was Seyeze Ezechias involved in the killings with you at this time, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I accused him of having participated in the crimes concerning Simon Higiro, the one you referred to as Sakanyoni. I am the one who accused him, and he confessed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know what profession or job he did, sir, before the genocide, this man Seyeze Ezechias, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He was a cultivator also, a farmer.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, have you confessed your crimes before the courts in Rwanda, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: From the 30th of December 1994, the day on which I was arrested, until today, I have confessed to that crime. I have requested the forgiveness of Rwandans, the international community, as well as the victims and their families.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And would I be correct in saying, sir that you would have confessed to killing at least -- maybe I should ask you, Mr. Witness. How many people have you confessed to killing, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: They are very many, more than 20 people that I killed or in whose deaths I was involved. But if there was a particular location, I was responsible for having killed six people. So I myself must confess to having participated in a crime during which these six people died, and I needed to denounce those who participated in the killings, because we formed a single group of evildoers, people who participated in that crime, even if I had only killed two people out of the six.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I be correct in saying that Mukantabana and her children or child, as you say, had been hiding in the home of Joël Ndabukiye before her death, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, that's where she was hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How was it that Joel then decided to betray her and subsequently became involved in her death, sir? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, Joël didn't participate in the killing of that woman, but as I have already told you, I asked the gendarme to tell me how he had found the woman, and he told me, "You were unable to find her, so I can't reveal to you my secret how I work." And until today I do not know who told the gendarme that this woman was hiding in Ndabukiye -- Joël Ndabukiye's house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Pardon me, Witness, for that error. So is it your testimony that Joël Ndabukiye was involved in some killings with you but not in the killing of Thacianne? Is that your testimony, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, he didn't play any role in Thacianne's killing, no role whatsoever.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The man --

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That again, who did not play any role, Mr. Witness, in her death? Who did not play any role, did you say just now, in her death?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I am speaking about Joël Ndabukiye, in other words, the person in whose house the woman was hiding.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, you also testified about the events that led to the death of Cyprien Karegeya. Do you recall telling us about that? Do you recall that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I haven't yet told you how he was killed. I don't know who his killers were, but I know where they came from, and this was told to me by Karara Augustin.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I see. Now talking about Karara Augustin, do you recall whether or not he was a witness to any of the crimes that you committed, sir, and if so, which one?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I was living with that person together with other people who were living at Gitaka. And when we brought her, he was a witness, he was looking on. All the people who were living in Gasharu, anyone who you would ask questions about me would tell you the truth, and he cannot have been unaware of what happened in his cellule and the crimes that were committed in his cellule, and he must have been a witness because he was there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Did Karara Augustin, to your mind, hold any official position in the local administration in Gasharu during the genocide, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I think he was a responsable. If not, he must have been a member of the cellule committee in 1994, during the period of the events.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And what, to your knowledge, very, very briefly, would be the duties of the responsable de cellule or a member of the committee at the time, if you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Those were people who were responsible for solving problems arising between the inhabitants, and when they failed to do so, they referred the problem to the secteur. Furthermore, they are responsible for the development of the cellule by involving the population in the implementation of development projects.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: So if crimes were committed in Gasharu cellule, would it have been the functions of the responsable to report them to the conseiller or would it not?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can you then help us with this: how was it, then, that this person, this responsable, was then aware of your crimes and did not prevent them, sir, or report them?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: It's true that if there are attackers who attack a cellule, the responsable should refer the matter to the higher authorities, but I described to you what we were like. Some authorities could do nothing against us. We could even attack them. Now, without even talking about the responsable, even the conseiller couldn't approach these people who were killing. They could do nothing, they could say nothing. For instance, Karara; there were young people who came to destroy houses in Gitaka, and when he tried to stop them they wanted to kill -- to beat him, and I told you that he was my neighbour, so they made him pay a fine of 30 litres of beer. So people became afraid, and the authorities remained silent in the face of all these crimes because they were afraid.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: How then was it, Mr. Witness, that Ndindabahizi was able to order Karara's arrest, as you say, in the month of June? Can you explain that for me, please, in the light of your --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: What I know is that these young men who were with me during the attacks told me he came, he arrested Karara and put him in jail, and that he put him in jail because he suspected that he killed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well. Now, if, according to you, none of the authorities could stop the killings at the time, how then did the killings stop, or did they go on forever, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I think that the killings stopped when the soldiers on the front line realised that they had lost the war. They fled and we members of the population fled. In fact, we perpetrated these killings in a record time. We had virtually finished in the month of May. There were a few survivors, and, to tell you the truth, when we left the country, when we fled the country there was no one else to be killed. And they told us something which I'll tell you. When the French came, someone came and told us, "Be careful. These French have sophisticated equipment which can track down criminals". So we got afraid and -- we got afraid and we stopped committing the crimes. There were some survivors who passed in front of us and we left them alone because we thought the French were going to track us down. And that is how the killings stopped.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And it is your testimony that you never saw with your eyes Emmanuel Ndindabahizi throughout the genocide in Kibuye, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In your statement dated the 7th of October 2002 to my learned friends for the Defence, you mention six names who you describe as people who had accompanied you -- in other words, accomplices -- during the killings. Do you recall doing that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recall if you mentioned all six people in your confession statement to the Rwandese authorities, or did you just mention some of them? Did you mention all of them, as you have done here, in your confession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: My case file is very voluminous. Possibly all the names have been mentioned. If I were with someone in a certain place it is possible that I went with him to commit another crime, but when they were asking us the questions they asked us to list the names that we remember, and they told us that later on if we remembered some other names, we should come and add them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Can I have the registry show the witness a copy of his confessional statement in Kinyarwanda, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I'm having them hand over to you -- can I see it; yes, correct -- the voluminous document that you have described in Kinyarwandan.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And it is the last document I am going to refer to, Your Honour. It has got his name in front of it and it has got a French translation as well.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you see the document that I have had placed in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I have the document.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you recognise it as a copy of your file before the prosecutor in Kibuye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, that indeed is my case file.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Witness, I want you to -- with the help of the registry, I want you to turn to -- it is all numbered -- if you turn to page 22 of that document, the Kinyarwanda document, and the name under 5 which in the French translation can be found on page 19, No. 5 as well on page 19 of the French. You see that name there, Kampira Deboura; do you see that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I can see that name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Do you know that person, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I know this person.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: You have described her as having witnessed some of the crimes that you committed, have you not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes. Regarding Kampira Deboura, she knows the crime I committed against her because I killed her son, I can no longer remember his name.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That is indeed correct, sir. Now, can you turn with me to page 27 of that document, and can the registry assist him; 27 of the handwritten document, and I will try and find it in French. I think in French it is on page 22 and 23. The name against No. 20 in that document is the name Nkurunziza Joël, N-K-U-R-U-N-Z-I-Z-A, Joël. Do you recall that? Do you see that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Again you have described this person as being a witness to some of your crimes. Do you recall saying that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, on 21 you also describe the spouse of Joël Nkurunziza as being a witness to some of your crimes. Do you see that, sir? Just look under Joël's name, and you see the other entry there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, which crimes or crime did Joël and his spouse witness, sir? Can you help me with that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: They witnessed the killing of two children of Nyirahembe and the killing of an old woman whose name I cannot recall. So, it is the killing of two children of Nyirahembe and an old woman.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Nyirahembe is spelt how for the record, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Nyirahembe is N-Y-I-R-A-H-E-M-B-E.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did you in addition refer to an old man or an old woman?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, an old woman who sought refuge in Nyirahembe's house.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, do you know -- in your confessional statement you describe one of your accomplices by the name Sendiragora Uwimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I collaborated a lot with this person, and I know him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: That is on page 16 of the handwritten Kinyarwanda document and on page 13 of the French.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, can you tell me if this man Sendiragora has any relationship with the accused person in this case, and, if so, can you tell me what that relationship is, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not know the relationship between the two. I don't even know where this person comes from. I know he is a young boy who was keeping cattle in the area. I don't know any relationship between him and the Accused in this case.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Finally, Mr. Witness --

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Registry, that is enough for that document. Can I have the document back.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Finally, Mr. Witness. Do you know whether or not the prosecutor in Kibuye accepted your confession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not have the confirmation. After I sent my confession, the Prosecutor received them, but then he was transferred. Following that, I sought to find out what had happened to my case, and lately after people were invited to participate in a meeting to be told about what should be done in the country, I raised the question as to what had happened to my case file. I was told to refer the query to the prosecutor's office and that my case file was still with them.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Indeed there is a notation on your confessional file which indicates that the prosecutor has accepted your confession and has categorised the crimes in this confession under the first category. Does that surprise you, sir? That is on --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: There is no problem with that. In my confession -- in my confessions I wanted to bring out the things that we had done. I have committed a lot of crimes. That is why I cannot but plead guilty. I wanted to ask for forgiveness, and I find it necessary -- I find it normal that I'm classified in the -- in category 1. I have committed a lot of crimes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Your killings were operated in units, following your testimony; that's what you say. Is it possible for someone who was not in your unit of attackers to be involved in a particular area, or how were those units arranged? How did you operate?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: We could start with our cellule, form a group of ten persons, leave the cellule, and when we get to another cellule we are told, "There's a person hiding in such-and-such a person's house". In our group we would take a decision to go, and after killing that person we could go to another cellule and that we might meet another group which would tell us that there's another -- "There's somebody hiding in X or Y's house", then we go after this person. That is how we used to operate.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Mr. Witness, for answering my questions.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have no further questions, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Thank you, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have to enter the documents as Prosecution exhibits. The first one is the first one I used, Seyeze Ezechias, which would be the next exhibit. Can the registry help me with the numbers, please.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: P. 37, says the registry.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: 37A, and B for the French, and when we get the English I would have that as C. The next one will be Joël Ndabukiye's, which will be P. 38A, B and C. Then the final one will be the one for this witness, which will be P. 39A, B, and C when we get the English translation. I am grateful.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I lost you there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sorry.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: The first one was No. 61?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The one that has 61, yes, on it.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. That is P. 37A and B, and C later on.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: EXhibit P. 37A, P. 37B and P. 37C admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What is the next one?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: The next one is the one that has 70 on it, starts 70 on the end. Ndabukiye.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes. Did you use that one?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Okay. So that will be P. 38.

div.stage: EXhibit P. 38A, P. 38B and P. 38C admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And then the one -- the bulky one, which is the one for this witness, will be P. 39. In that order.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I am grateful.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: I think we will place all three of them under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Okay.

div.stage: EXhibit P. 39A, P. 39B and P. 39C admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Just one or two questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you recall that the Prosecutor asked you a question on the killing of the child of Rwabyuma?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you admitted having committed that crime?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The Prosecutor referred to witnesses who witnessed that killing, and as witness you mentioned Mukamana Julien. Do you remember that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I said so.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And then the Prosecutor referred to one Sibomana. You did say that he lived in the neighbourhood, in the region; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During the killing of the children was Sibomana present? Did you see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Since I was with Ndabukiye, Ndabukiye was mentioning the names of these persons. I am sure that I saw Mukamana Julien, he came from Kirambo to hide in that locality. But regarding Sibomana and the other name that I saw, it was -- the crime site is close to the house, it is possible that they were there. And I brought out this child from a banana plantation, everyone could see us, and I see that what these witnesses are saying is -- is true.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, the question is simple; you can give a yes or no answer. Did you, yourself, see Sibomana at that time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: During that crime, I did not see him.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Does the witness still have the Prosecution exhibit that is the confession, that is the bulky document?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, do you now have that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Page 1, that indeed is your name on that page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes. I can see that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you recall the date on which you made that confession?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, I have no clear recollection of that, but I believe it must have been last year. This document was put together last year. At the very beginning when I wrote down my confessions, this was in 1994; that I remember.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: This document that you have in front of you, was it written based on your confessions of 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: In 1994 I was arrested by soldiers. The genocide survivors pointed me out and said he's -- that I am a criminal. That is how I was arrested. I was detained in the Gitarama prison, where I stayed for four years. When I got to Gisovu I felt it necessary to plead guilty and to make my confessions. That is when I started drafting my confessions. I think what is contained in this document reflects what I did, but it was later on, when I did some soul-searching based on the questions that I asked myself, I decided to confess.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Can you please move on to page 8 of that document in Kinyarwanda, that is the figure which is at the top right-hand side of the document. Are you with me, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you read out the name against the entry No. 24 on that page?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Mukantabana, Thacianne.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Would that mean that before you came to this courtroom, Witness, that you had confessed to the killing of Mukantabana Thacianne?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Yes, that is the person that I killed. He is among one of my -- he is among my first victims.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Do you know Nzaminduga -- Nzajyinduga?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I know Nzajyinduga.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Is there a relationship between the children that we referred to a while ago and Nzajyinduga?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: These are the grandchildren of Nzajyinduga.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know if there is any blood relationship between the children of Nzajyinduga and Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, she is an old woman, and I wouldn't know of any relationship between her and the Accused.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Witness. No further questions.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, what did Karara tell you about the killing of Karegeya?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: As I explained earlier on, soon upon my arrival at Gitaka they was drinking beer in Gitan's beer bar. When I got there he was sad and told me that "They've killed my friend. It's over". The question I asked him was to know who the killers were. He answered that it was not necessary to answer that question, that he was killed by people who came from Buye. That is what I know about the death of Karegeya. He was killed by people who came from Buye.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Is it your testimony that no Tutsi were killed at the roadblock at Gitaka?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No Tutsi was killed there. The people that were killed there came from other hills, and they were going by and they went by and were killed elsewhere. For example, the woman I talked about did go through there. She was going to Ruhara's, Pascal Ruhara's, and upon her return she also went through there, that location. We did not arrest anybody at that roadblock.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: How long were you at this roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I was not there for a long time at that roadblock. I wouldn't say that I was all the time at that roadblock. People were brought and went through in our presence. So far as I was concerned, I went through when I was on the way for an attack, and I came back only for a drink.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And you said attackers came from Rubanga, Rutsiro and Ruragwe, and you were told that you had done nothing and that is how the killing started. Who told -- who were telling you that nothing had been done in order for you to start the killings?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Among the people who came there were people who were usually called Abakiga. We were scared of those people; they had intimidated us. Some people had taken refuge at Kirambo, and those people, the Abakiga, came to kill them and threaten -- and to retaliate against us if we did not take part in the massacres. I can't tell you the names of these Abakiga. They went through and went to Bisesero and elsewhere. So far as we were concerned, we stayed in our given location.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you went to kill Mukantabana, a schoolteacher; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You said after giving the two blows you went away. You left her and you went away to kill other persons. Why didn't you finish her finally?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I did so because that man who was also called or known as Nyankiko wanted to confront the person that had taken Mukantabana, and when I saw that I came to help, and the woman was finished off by other people who were around.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This person, Nyankiko, who was killed after your blows concerning Tatiana, what was his first name? We are waiting for the translation of Zacharia.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: It's Nyankiko, Zacharia.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, Rwasibo, do you know that name?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I know him. That was Rwasibo, Augustine.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he involved in any particular killing, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Indeed we worked together in several places.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he involved in the killing of Tatiana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Perhaps he stayed in Gitaka, but among the people that I remember, I can only remember six persons, so that was a sizeable attack. Now, what I did was that I tried to observe people, I tried to remember people who took part in the attack. If I knew that he participated in the attack I would have said so. Perhaps he was in Gitaka but that he didn't come to the location at which we were and at which we killed the people that I talked about.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was Rwasibo involved in the killing of Karegeya, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I believe that Rwasibo is from Kayenzi. People could move from one secteur to the other for attacks. If somebody mentioned him as having been in Buye, perhaps he was there. As I said, and as Karara told me, those who killed him came from Buye. I don't know how he got to Buye, perhaps he was one of the killers.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You do not know; isn't that the situation, Mr. Witness? You do not know whether he was involved in the Karegeya event? That's your explanation, isn't it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I don't know. I could have confirmed it if I were there at the killing.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you know someone called Emmanuel Ndabakuye -- Emmanuel Ndabakiye?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do not know that name, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So you name -- you know the name Joel Ndabukiye but not the name Emmanuel Ndabukuye. Am I right now?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I rather know the name of his son, that is Emmanuel. I know the one called Ndabukiye, Joel.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You know Joel Ndabukiye. Have you ever heard of anyone called Emmanuel Ndabukuye -- Ndabukiye.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No sir. In our area we only had one Ndabukiye and that was Joel.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which area was that -- no, you don't have to answer that question. Now, do you know anyone called Appollinaire Bugisiga?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I do know him.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: He was a farmer. He was a farmer.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Was he involved in the killing of Tatiana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: No, sir, I didn't see him at the place Tatiana was killed.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Mr. Witness, we have -- we have now --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: -- come to the end of your testimony. We would like to thank you for having come the long way to testify before the Tribunal. We wish you a very safe journey home, and please do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DO:
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. President, and Your Honours.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: If the Registry could assist us and then bring in the next witness. At least we can start with that witness, I think. That's DR, is it? Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You would be referred to as Witness DR in these proceedings. Do you have a piece of paper in front of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I see a document in front of me, and I see on this document the letters DR.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you also see your signature there?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I see my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that mean that the information in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That brings us to Defence Exhibit 39, under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You will now be asked questions by the Defence, Mr. Witness. The Registry will first make sure that you undertake to tell the truth and will administer the solemn declaration.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DR in Kinyarwanda)
WITNESS DR,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Witness, good afternoon. We are just entering the afternoon. Good afternoon as we enter the afternoon. Could you tell us your commune, your secteur and your native cellule?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I'm from the Kibuye préfecture, Gitesi commune, and Gitarama secteur, Kigesi cellule.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At this time where do you live?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I live at the same place that I have just indicated.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: More precisely, do you presently live in Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: At present I am in detention at the Gisovu prison, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Which is your ethnic group?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I am Hutu, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: At what date would you place the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: President Habyarimana died on the 6th, but I only learnt about it in the morning of the 7th.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Which month, which year?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: It was the month of April 1994, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What happened in the days following the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: In a very few number of days after the death of President Habyarimana nothing much happened in my area, but at about the 12th, I saw many Tutsi taking refuge in Kibuye from Mabanza.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What did you yourself do in April 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: In April 1994, after the days I have just said, I lost my brother-in-law who used to live in Ruhengeri and I was not able to go to Ruhengeri, but later on I was able to go to Ruhengeri. And when I came back I realised that the people that had taken refuge at the stadium had died and those that had taken refuge in the church were also killed. There were dead bodies almost everywhere.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You went back home after the burial of your brother-in-law. At what date was that, approximately?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I do not clearly remember the date, but it was between the 20th and the 25th of April 1994, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you say as from the end of April 1994 and May -- April and May 1994 what you were doing in terms of activities?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: At the end of April and during the month of May, I stayed at home; I did not go anywhere. But at the end of May, a roadblock was set up in our area and myself, just as anybody else, was asked to take part in the manning of that roadblock until such a time as the French arrived and after they had said that they were going to ensure security.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: When were you arrested, Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I was arrested on the 9th February 1995; the 9th of February 1995.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Why, to your knowledge, are you still in detention?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I am presumed to have taken part in the genocide, just as the others that are detained along with me.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Did you plead guilty?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I recognised having been at the roadblock I am being accused of having been at the roadblock. I am also accused of have a grenade in my possession, which I confessed, but I used the opportunity also to testify on the events that took place at that roadblock.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Very well, let us come back to the roadblock. To your knowledge, when was that roadblock erected; when was it built?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I do not clearly remember the date, but I would say that it was at the end of the month of May or at the beginning of the month of June.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Could you be more precise as to the precise location of that roadblock? Where was it erected precisely?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The roadblock was set up in front of the Nyabahanga River bridge.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Who erected that roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: That roadblock was set up by the conseiller of the Gitarama secteur -- which is my secteur -- Gitarama secteur by the name of Ngerabayeyi, Etienne. Ngerabayeyi is spelt N-G-I-G-A-B-Y-E-Y-E -- N-G-E-R-A-B-A-Y-E-Y-I.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: You were one of the people manning the roadblock, were you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: That is correct. I was one of those members of -- one of the groups manning the roadblock. We were being relayed by another group.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Now, at the date that roadblock was set up, what was the purpose of the roadblock, to your mind?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The instructions given us by the conseiller who set up that roadblock were given out when I was there. He asked the -- those in charge of the Kigesi cellule, that is the person called Pierre Damien Nsegureze (phonetic), to look for people of integrity to man that roadblock for the purpose of intercepting Hutu refugees on their way to Cyangugu and Kibuye in their flight from the RPF soldiers. So that a camp was created in Nyamuyeve (phonetic) to be able to list the names of the people concerned in order to prevent them from getting into Kibuye. The other reason of the roadblock was of course to monitor the number of people going through the roadblock in vehicles to see whether they have ID cards, and if by any chance the people at the roadblock had any doubts about their identity of such-and-such a person that was believed to a member of the RPF or to be an Inkotanyi, that person was to be arrested and taken to the competent authority.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: What does Inkotanyi mean?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The Inkotanyi were the RPF soldiers that were fighting against the Rwandan Armed Forces during that period.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: As far as you are concerned, you are a member of one of the groups that worked in turn at that roadblock, manning it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Absolutely true, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Were you armed?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: At the beginning when we used to man that roadblock, it was Bonaventure, Niyikula who was armed with a gun. The others were armed with machetes, sticks, clubs, but then later on I was given by Bonaventure Niyikula, I received a grenade. I asked him for the grenade because I needed it, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: We shall come back to the grenade. So that the arms, the weapons you had were machetes. Where did the machetes come from?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Well, each one brought a machete from home, because in Rwandan culture each person has a machete at home, and women are not authorised to touch their husband's machete, and the child neither. The children are not authorised to touch the women's machetes. A young adolescent would first of all buy a hoe and a machete, so that in our culture the machete is a symbol. It's a cultural symbol. Each and everyone does have a machete.

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: The other people in the machete -- in the roadblock, were they armed, and if so, with what types of weapons?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: They had machetes. They had clubs, big sticks, sir.

div.stage: Pages 52 to 57 by Gifty C. Harding)1300H

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Was there any distribution of arms at the roadblock?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: No, sir, no weapons were distributed at the roadblock. Up to the time the roadblock was dismantled, no weapons were distributed there.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Would this be a convenient time to break for the day?

sp.speaker: MR. MARÇAIS:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Because then we could continue on Monday at two o'clock in the afternoon. Since the military trial is scheduled for the morning on Monday, we will then move on to the afternoon shift in the Ndindabahizi, in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Certainly, Mr. President. Probably this is the right time for me to come up with some information concerning the rest of the proceedings.I believe we have heard 12 witnesses this week, and next week we could bring in five new witnesses. But for the week beginning on Monday, the 10th November to the 17th November, we believe that we will not be able to bring in witnesses, Mr. President, the reason being that certain witnesses, for professional reasons, cannot make the trip before the 17th, 17th of November. These are DD and the expert herself (sic). You wanted to know yesterday afternoon whether Mr. Ndindabahizi could not appear during the week of the 10th of November before the expert. We looked into this matter with Mr. Ndindabahizi, and Mr. Ndindabahizi believes that he should not testify before the expert. I believe that we share his opinion, sir. There are two reasons for that. The first reason is that it is a matter of pragmaticism (sic). We focussed a lot on the witnesses to date. I was not able to meet my client; I spent most of my time with the witnesses. Next week I will not be able to meet my client, either, because we will be in the courtroom, and we are not authorised to see them during the weekends.There is also a reason concerning the structure of the proceedings, and as a matter of logic, he will have to look at the whole structure of the trial and he will have to answer some questions from the experts.
