There was the MRND government, and up to '91 there was a government in which you had only two political parties that only was there for three months in 1991, and now you have a government where there is an agreement between political parties where now we have four, five parties within that government, that is, from 1991 to 1993. Now, these political parties that took part in that government of the MRND, for example, they were there with their own identities as parties, they were there upon agreement with the government. Now, these are three governments, and I was in there, I performed my functions, and nothing ever changed. Now, I do not know whether the functions I had were absolutely related to the policies of those governments. If not, I should have been changed each and every time the government changes. Whereas in those governments the political parties that agreed to run the country -- and those political parties did not abandon their programs, their various programs and their status -- they were there on the basis of government status and together to run a government that is patronised, that is sponsored by the MRND, so that there were groups of parties and the opposition within one government.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Very well, but the question is very broad as you put it to me; I do not know how to tackle it to be as clear as I could be, as I am trying to do. I did not decide -- to come to your precise question, I did not decide to serve in a government, a government came and found me in service. I tried to manage the situation, and that is all.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: All right.Now, I put it to you, Mr. Witness, that Mr Ndindabahizi used undue influence to remove the MP who was elected by the party and install you as a reward for supporting him in his various activities in Gitesi commune. What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Now, that is a question that should not be put to me, because I did not appoint myself. Perhaps the question should be put to Ndindabahizi himself. All I know is that I do not see any reason why this innuendo should be there to -- or any influence should be exercised so that I get that post. I do not see any reason for that.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: I am sorry, Your Honours, there are documents I want to tender as evidence. There are two. One is the witness statement document by this witness that is dated 15th and 16th May 1996.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So that would be P. 41, under seal.

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: French and English; English being A, French B, yes?

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: (Exhibit Nos P. 41A and P. 41B admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: The second one is the minutes in Kinyarwanda, which were read on the record.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yes, and then we need the entire document, both the letter and the minutes, and that will be P. 42, again under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 42 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.And finally, the piece of paper that contains a name, which was shown to the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: P. 43, under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 43 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. KAPAYA:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Just a few questions, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Witness, in May 1994 were there any military confrontations between the Rwandan armed forces and the RPF forces --

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The witness's microphone, please.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And I add, on Rwandan soil.

sp.speaker: THE ENGLISH INTERPRETER:
sp.p: I am sorry, can the witness repeat the answer? His microphone was not on during the first part of it. Pardon me, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The war with the RPF started in April, continued up to July 1994. It was taking place within different areas in Rwanda.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That is correct. During the 3 May meeting in Kibuye, do you know if Mr. Ndindabahizi spoke as a minister or as a member of the PSD?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: When I made my statement about his declaration, I said that he spoke on behalf of the PSD; he was a representative of the PSD party.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did it appear surprising to you that this particular PSD member would support a government that he belonged to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Pardon me?

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did it appear surprising to you or bizarre or shocking that this member of the PSD, that is to say Ndindabahizi, supported the government that he belonged to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: That question seems difficult to me; I don't understand.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I'll rephrase. Was Mr. Ndindabahizi a member of the transitional government?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During the public meeting, should he oppose the government that he belonged to?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: No, that would have been impossible.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During the meeting of 3 May did Emmanuel Ndindabahizi personally, directly or indirectly say things that would encourage the massacres in Kibuye, the massacres of civilian Tutsis?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Indirectly or directly? I don't understand. I don't have what he said. I don't have -- I don't see what he said before me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Earlier the Prosecutor asked you who designated you to be in the National Assembly. You said there were two people; yes or no?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, that is what I have just said; correct, indeed.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The first person, if I understood, was Emmanuel Ndindabahizi; the second was the person -- was it the person that the Prosecutor showed you a name on a piece of people?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, it's the same person whose name I saw on a paper.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you ever meet this second person after Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's visit?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, we often met.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During those meetings with that second person, did that second person tell you that Emmanuel Ndindabahizi pressured him by underscoring the ethnic group of his wife?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I was called by the prosecutor of the republic of Kibuye to talk about Ndindabahizi. I was in the same jail with this person whose name was shown to me. He was also in contact with the prosecutor. I am sure that those statements never made it to the prosecutor of the republic's office. If that had taken place, it must have vexed them. I think that they would have talked -- confronted us about this story if that had happened, or such a statement would have appeared in our depositions before the prosecutor of the republic, because we lived together, that person and I, in 1994. We lived through difficult times. Even when he exiled to Zaire, he left his property with me. When he came back, he stayed for some time outside the country and then he was arrested. We lived together. I made these statements when we were together in the prison in Kibuye. So what I have just here -- heard, perhaps that happened, perhaps these are inventions. Nevertheless, I am not aware of such pressure of which you speak. What else? If there was pressure to designate me, it wouldn't have been necessary in 1994; couldn't have declared that. They wouldn't have gone to -- from Kibuye to see him. I think that's the only answer that I can give you to this question.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That is very clear.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. I have no further questions.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: You talked about seeing the Accused in 1994, in the month of June, that he passed through his own area and came to your house, and he had arrested another ***********************. What was the nature of the allegations that the Accused made against that person, and when your investigations were made and *******, what were your findings about who the culprit was, about the allegations made by the Accused? Is the question clear?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour, I understand. ***********, I didn't find any guilt with respect to the allegations as they were communicated to me from Ndindabahizi. Only I did that after a meeting and after a discussion -- after a discussion, and after an exchange of ideas with Ndindabahizi who had brought him, because he left him in jail ********But during the discussions -- I then had discussions with Ndindabahizi, so we were able to talk about the situation with regard to this person. ************88On the other hand, I tried to conduct an investigation into what this person had told me, and that investigation that I conducted, I was not able to complete it because it was very difficult, it was very complicated. So I let it go until the situation became more calm, so such an investigation could take place.

div.stage: Microphone not activated) ... allegations which were made by the Accused against this person, what did the Accused tell you about what that person was alleged to have done?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The Accused -- the Accused had suspended his activities *****, and there was a murder of a person and he was supposed to protect that person, and he must have had a friendship with Ndindabahizi or been a member of his family, but he didn't sufficiently protect a person who was murdered. And we found that those few facts were not sufficient for that person to be arrested, to say that he didn't protect somebody who was murdered, when he himself was not implicated in the murder. Just to say that he didn't protect somebody, given the situation in the country, I said, "Frankly that is not sufficient to put somebody behind bars."

div.stage: Microphone not activated) ... and the person who was murdered?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: It was a cousin of Ndindabahizi, cousin -- at any rate relatives of his cousins, cousins who were massacred, or their entire families.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: My next question relates to the meetings of 29th and 30th April. You testified that one of them was a communal meeting and another one was a central meeting and they related to security in your area. Now, you testified that in those meetings the Accused was not spoken about because there was no need, there was nothing anybody could do -- correct me if I am misquoting you. So my question is this. This was -- the Accused was a minister in the government of the day, ********, he was a native and people were dying -- you say they started dying in April, continued through May -- didn't you see a need *********to at least approach him to bring him on top of issues in your area?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. I did not contact him. First, we must consider the relationships between civil servants, especially given my position and his position, and given his position, it was difficult for me to be able to contact him for anything, unless I could individually contact him since he was a minister to help me, to try to help me calm the situation. But on a functional level, it was very difficult. Communications could not permit such a thing. You spoke about the meeting of the 29th; indeed it took place. It was with the members of the conseiller and members of the security council in the préfecture to see what we could do about the killings, see what measures we could take to try to reduce or completely stop these massacres. If he was in Kibuye at that time, if we had the opportunity to receive him in Gitesi, we would have invited him, as a minister, to our meeting for his support, but he was not at that meeting. The meeting took place. If he had been there, he would have participated as a minister native to that commune. We would have invited him and I don't think he would have refused the invitation, and we would have launched him through contributions. The next day there was a cooperation meeting in the secteur. If we had contacted him a bit before, if he had visited us before, indeed, I would have asked for his contribution to talk to the population of the area of which he was a native, but I didn't even think of that.

div.stage: Microphone not activated) ... Kibuye, 3rd of May meeting, I believe that was just a few days after the meeting you had in your area. Did you have an opportunity to talk to him about it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: No, the way they were escorted with the presidential guard made it difficult to individually contact a person. I didn't have any particular meetings with him. He came; we had the meeting together and his escorts of the presidential guard took him away. He had very tight security around him.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: And did he in his address to this meeting talk about the security situation in his native area, generally in the préfecture and in his native area --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: -- considering that he commended that particular area for the killings that took place?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes. During the meeting of the 3rd, during his speech he did not mention the security situation in his native area, not even in his cellule, or secteur, or commune in general; there was no mention of that. As you have noticed, he generally spoke of the party and its position within the government that was there. He -- the president thanked the people in Kibuye. That is why when I explained myself, I said that the president in his address was not really discouraging what was going on. He really was trying to further what was going on. That is why in my commentary, when he said that, "You've worked well", he really meant that he was thanking the crimes that were going on. I didn't see in the president's speech anything that was discouraging what was going on.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, in 1990, before your appointment as bourgmestre, did you have any political affiliation with the president at that period in time?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. At that time there was only one political party, and in fact, all Rwandans had to, without choice, adhere to that party, and so I was a member of it.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness; good afternoon, Your Honours. Mr. Witness --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, yesterday during your testimony, you talked about the fact that whilst you were detained at the Kibuye prison, you saw new co-prisoners that hailed from Gitesi commune, the area of Gitesi. Do you recall saying that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I did not say that that prisoner was from Gitesi.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I don't think you understood my question, and I'll repeat it. During your testimony yesterday, sir, you testified that you and other prisoners often discussed the fact that Mr. Ndindabahizi was being accused of crimes. Do you recall telling us that yesterday, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I remember saying that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And as far as you know, sir, are you able to confirm whether or not people who were accused or suspected of committing crimes in Gitesi commune were often detained at the Kibuye prison following the genocide? Can you help me with that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Some were detained at Kibuye prison, others at Gisovu prison.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I be correct in saying, sir, that many of those who committed crimes in Gitesi commune and who were now detained at Gisovu prison were transferred there, and by "there" I mean Gisovu prison, following the closure of Kibuye prison. Would I be correct in saying that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I cannot confirm that. I was not present during their transfer, but I do know that the detainees were transferred to different prisons.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Are you able to confirm whether or not, to your knowledge, the Kibuye prison is still operational to date? Can you help me with that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Since that prison closed, I never went back to Kibuye. I believe that that prison is indeed closed, but when there are sick prisoners who come to the hospital in Kibuye or when prisoners come to appear before the court, and that's a small number of prisoners, I believe that they are detained in that same Kibuye prison. But officially that prison was closed.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, sir. Sir, I want to show you a list of names and I want you to look at these names and tell me whether or not you are able to confirm if any of these people, to your knowledge, was detained at the prison in Kibuye whilst you were held there, sir. Do you see the list that has been placed before you, sir? Please don't mention any, any of the names on that list, please. Are we agreed on that? Please don't mention the names.Can you confirm for me, sir, if, to your knowledge, any of those mentioned on that list was detained at the Kibuye prison on or around the same time that you were detained, sir? Please don't mention the name.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I can see one of these names.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, using the numbers that I have indicated next to the names, can you please identify the person by the number and not the name, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The person whose name I recognise is No. 2.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Now, let's talk about No. 2. Would I be correct in saying, sir, that the person you identify in No. 2 was detained in Kibuye prison around about the same time that you were detained there, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Whilst I was detained at Kibuye prison, that person was also detained at the same prison. When I was released from the prison, he was still there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Now, as part of your testimony yesterday, sir, you also testified about a supervisor who you claimed boasted about some things that he had done whilst you were all -- whilst you, sir, was detained at the prison. Do you recall telling us about that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I said that I saw a person who was boasting for doing something amongst the supervisors of the prison.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, can you help me with this: In your testimony yesterday you stated that there were other people present in the courtyard when the supervisor boasted about the things you told us about. Now, was this person present with you at the time, sir, the person at No. 2?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I believe that that person who is listed here at No. 2 was not present.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, do you know if there is a relationship between the supervisor who you wrote his name down on a piece of paper, which is now Defence Exhibit 45, and the person you have identified as being on No. 2? Do you know if there is a relationship, a family relationship, between them, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I heard people say that No. 2 on this list was the brother-in-law of the person whose name I wrote down on the piece of paper.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: It is therefore your testimony that in all the time you spent with No. 2 at the prison, he never alluded to the fact that he had a relationship with the person on Defence Exhibit 45, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The person at No. 2 never talked to me about that subject. I never heard him say anything about that.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Now, following your release from the prison, would I be correct in saying, sir, that you never reported the events concerning the person identified in Defence Exhibit 45 and yourself, you never reported that incident to any of the law enforcement authorities?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I never met with any authority. As regards what that person may have said or done, that is to say the person whose name I wrote down on that piece of paper that was because nobody asked me any questions regarding that subject.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Would I also be correct in saying, sir, that you never discussed the events concerning the person you identified on Defence Exhibit 45 with the man you have indicated on No. 2 of the piece of paper I have just given you, sir? Would I be correct in saying that too, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I remember that when I spoke with such and such a person regarding the testimony, especially my friends, sometimes we spoke about those events, but not with many people.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I am sorry, sir, I don't understand your reply, and that is probably because you don't understand my question. So I would ask it again: The events that you told us about, the boasting by the person you wrote down for us yesterday, can you confirm, sir, whether or not following that event, the boasting event, you discussed it with the person you identified on No. 2 of the piece of paper? Just a simple yes or no is fine.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I never spoke to that person regarding that subject, because I often -- I did not often meet him.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, sir. So would I be correct in assuming, for the record, that the first time you have discussed the boasting event is before this Tribunal, and in your statement, of course, to the Defence?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Counsel, could you please repeat that question for me? It is not very clear for me.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, sir. Would I be correct in saying say, sir, that perhaps the first time that you have told anyone or discussed the events concerning the supervisor boasting about what he said was in this courtroom yesterday?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: No, it wasn't the first time that I spoke about it. I told you before that I spoke with some of my friends about this after I was released.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Very well, sir. Now, in your testimony yesterday, and I am moving to a separate issue now, you described the Accused as a minister being a man who is educated, a person who works on behalf of the people and, therefore, he cannot distribute machetes. Because he is such an important person, he wouldn't be someone who would distribute these things. I am quoting from a draft transcript of 5th November 2003, in English, page 3.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Which court reporter?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Shannon Eboe-Osuji.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Sir, do you recall saying those words yesterday, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I said those things.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, would you expect, however, a minister, as you described, an educated man, a minister who works on behalf of people, as you put it, would you expect such a person to renounce and condemn the killings of innocent civilians?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I think that it is one of his obligations, that is to say, to defend all innocent people if they are victims of any type of aggression.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Now, yesterday -- moving to a separate topic now -- you testified that the market at Kibilizi was not functioning for the better part of the events of 1994, and that the market resumed its operations in June, when Opération Turquoise came to the area. Do you remember telling us that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Now, is it your testimony, sir, that Hutus who were not in hiding were not able to purchase any commodities throughout the hundred days during which the genocide was perpetrated at Kibilizi market?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I explained that the markets, churches, were not working because you wouldn't see many crowds, many people in the streets, either going to market or going to one church or the other.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: But in your testimony yesterday, sir, you testified that as far as you were concerned, and I quote directly from the same transcript at page 3, "I would say that the massacres ended towards the month of April 1994". Then you go on to explain how you came to that conclusion. Sir, if, in your opinion, the massacres in and around Mabanza commune had ended at the end of April 1994, why then would the commercial centre of Kibilizi remain closed until the French arrived in June? Can you help us with that, please, and the churches and the offices and everything?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Even if in Mabanza and around Rubengera where I lived the massacres stopped at the end of the month of April, I explained that one of the reasons was that the Tutsis who were being hunted down had gathered at the communal office where they had gone to seek refuge. This was around the 13th or 14th. Those Tutsis were sent to Kibuye so that they could be protected. To tell you the truth, there were no longer any Tutsi in that area, expect, rather, for those who were identified later on when the French arrived. They had been hiding at their friends' houses and they were -- they asked to go out when the French arrived, or sometimes the French found them when they were hiding. But there were no more massacres. You couldn't see any more Tutsis. Many houses were destroyed, the others were gathered at the communal office, and you could see them at Kibuye at the Gatwaro stadium. They left that stadium when some of them started to be killed. These were refugees from Busesero. Busesero was not in Mabanza but in Gitesi, in Gishyita. Interahamwe, who were going to kill them, you could see them come through in buses. They went through Mabanza coming from Gisenyi. They came through Mabanza to Bisesero. The massacres continued elsewhere, but in Mabanza, as far as I know, there were no more massacres.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Thank you for that. Finally, sir, is it your testimony that you were detained for some four years before your release?

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Counsel, could you repeat that question?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Well, it's difficult to say that it's really four years because ****************- that is approximately four years. Yes, you're right.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And, at the end of that period, you were delighted to be absolved of the allegations, were you not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Well, just like anyone who gets out of prison, I was happy. I was happy to no longer be in there.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And just like anyone who is detained falsely, you were, quite rightly, able to feel some resentment to those who detained you, are you not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Yes, I resented being detained, and that was unjustified, but I didn't feel any hate, because in everyone's life there are times when you have to undergo injustice or where you are a victim of injustice. But the people who were investigating my file found that I was innocent. I don't hate them for that. That is what happened at the time, and that is just how life goes.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: In fact, isn't it the case, sir, that you have no doubts that there are several other people, Hutus like yourself, who are in exactly the same position, wrongly incarcerated? Would I be correct in saying that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: That is correct. People were arrested en masse. Hutus were gathered together and put into prison. What is interesting, though, is that after investigating, examining the situation of each individual, those who are found innocent are released.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I thank you very much for being so kind to answer my questions.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: I have no other questions for this witness other than to enter the document before him as the next Prosecution exhibit.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much. Prosecution Exhibit 44 under seal.

div.stage: EXhibit No. P. 44 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No re-examination? Thank you.

sp.speaker: THE KINYARWANDA INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone, please.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This person who may wrongly have accused Mr. Ndindabahizi of something, do you have an explanation why he did so, the person who boasted about what he had done?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: The reason for that is that all of the authorities, during the genocide, are considered as criminals by the IBUKA association. There are strategies used to find prosecution witnesses against those different authorities. I can confirm that this person is one of those. This person was someone who was trained, if you will, to accuse Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Is that person a member of Ibuka, to your knowledge?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: All survivors have to be a member of this association.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You say "have to be." Is it obligatory?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: They are asked to join the association, and they are even courted to become members of the association.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did this person, when he spoke with you, mention the organisation, or is this an inference that you are making, that it was that organisation being behind this?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I don't know of all the members, the list of members of Ibuka, but we do know that all of the survivors of the genocide are a part of this association.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Did he tell you himself why he made the false accusation?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: He did not tell me why. He wasn't a particular friend of mine. As I said, he said this in a public setting, in the courtyard of the prison, where other detainees were around me. In fact, I have no particular friendship with that particular person.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Yesterday you said that, "He told us that lies were said about Mr. Ndindabahizi, and the supervisor suggested that somebody had encouraged him," that is the supervisor, "to make false testimony. He mentioned names. He said he had mentioned names of people to be killed and distributed weapons." What did you mean by that, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I wanted to tell Chimba about that person who had accused Ndindabahizi wrongly on certain facts.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What I didn't understand was the following sentence: "He mentioned names. He said he had mentioned names of people to be killed and distributed weapons." Can you explain that a little bit further, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Well, I, neither, didn't understand your question, sir, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I'm simply reading out a sentence from the draft transcript yesterday. Now, that sentence is attributed to you. So what I'm doing is to read out what you said in court yesterday in order to understand you a bit more fully. That's the communication going on between the two of us now.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Perhaps I don't understand you, because in my statement I did not talk about a list of persons.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, in the English version, in what I just mentioned to you now in English, I also did not talk about the list. So there is a translation problem between the two of us. Let us try again. Now, what you said yesterday, according to the transcript, is as follows: "The supervisor told us that somebody had encouraged him to make false testimony. The supervisor mentioned names," he must be the supervisor, "he mentioned names. He said that he had mentioned names of people to be killed and distributed weapons."

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: I said that the supervisor had been requested to testify against Ndindabahizi for having distributed arms for Tutsis to be killed, and that Ndindabahizi is said to have encouraged or sensitised people, too, and encouraged them to kill Tutsi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And did he inform you about the particulars of this? In other words, did the supervisor give you any further details about what he had said when he gave false testimony?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Well, those are things that the supervisor said in public. What pains me more was that the supervisor said that Ndindabahizi was wrongly accused, without showing (unintelligible) at that time that he did not see him, and also because during those difficult times, the person concerned was hiding at Karara's.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Mr. Witness. There are no further questions to you. We would like to thank you for having come the long way to testify before the Tribunal. We wish you a very safe journey home. Please do not discuss your testimony with anyone. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DR:
sp.p: Thank you very much, Mr. President, and I wish you more courage for your task that is very useful for all Rwandans. Thank you again.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DQ:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You are a protected witness and will be referred to as Witness DQ. In these proceedings you have to tell the truth. And the registry will now take your solemn declaration.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DQ in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you have a document in front of you there. Is it your signature at the bottom of that document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DQ:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information contained in that document is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DQ:
sp.p: That is quite correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Defence Exhibit 46 and received.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: You will now be asked questions by the Defence, first.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President. Mr. President, the Tribunal has seen that we wanted to hear DQ before DP, who was here, because of technical reasons. Now I would like to appeal that the testimony of DQ be heard entirely in closed session. This is a very vulnerable witness. He worked in some official course in Rwanda and he exercised those functions that will be the subject of my examination-in-chief. The risks are many in that exercise so that I would like to plea that you grant this sitting in camera throughout the examination-in-chief.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Any problems from the Prosecution?Let me say that we do not have a summary in English of the witness's previous statement. We do not have that in front of us here. Usually we have that provided by the Defence. Here, it's coming from the registry. Thank you.Any problems with closed session? Comments?

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: My learned friend and I have discussed this matter. I have no objections.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: No objections. I have looked through this document now and I realise the need for such a request, which is now granted. So from now on, we will move into a closed session, and I must ask the public kindly to leave the gallery, because we have to protect the identity of this witness by an in camera hearing.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [pages 11 to 37] was extracted and sealed under separate cover, as the session was heard in camera)

div.head: 7 NOVEMBER 20031440H CONTINUED TRIAL
div.stage: Before the Judges:Erik Møse, PresidingKhalida Rachid KhanSolomy Balungi BossaFor the Registry:Ms. Marianne Ben SalimoMr. Sheha MussaFor the Prosecution:Mr. Charles Adeogun-PhillipsMr. Wallace KapayaMr. Peter TafahFor the Accused Emmanuel Ndindabahizi :Mr. Pascal BesnierCourt Reporters:Mr. Rex LearMs. Shannon Eboe-OsujiMs. Trish GreigMs. Gifty HardingMr. Petrus Chijarira

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Good afternoon to everyone in the courtroom. Good afternoon, Mr. Witness.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Now, you are a protected witness and will be referred to as DP during these proceedings. You have to tell the truth and the registry will now take your solemn declaration to that effect.

div.stage: Declaration made by Witness DP in Kinyarwanda)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you have a document in front of you there, Mr. Witness?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I have the particular -- do you mean the particulars?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's exactly the one. Now, is it your signature at the bottom of that page, please?

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Does that imply that the information is correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, that is my signature. Yes, the information is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: This is then Defence Exhibit 47 under seal. Thank you.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 47 admitted, under seal)Defence, please.
WITNESS DP,first having been duly sworn,testified as follows:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, I have three questions on the identity of the witness. I should like to seek leave for a closed session, so that I put these questions that affect his identity. It will not take three minutes.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Granted. So we will have a closed session of about a couple of minutes.

div.stage: At this point in the proceedings, a portion of the transcript [page 3] was extracted and sealed under separate cover as the session was heard in camera)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Witness DP, from now on we are in open session again, so now you have to be careful when you answer questions so as not to reveal your identity.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. President, for that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness, now during the sitting when I refer to your functions I will talk about the profession that you said you were exercising in 1994 during the closed session. Is that acceptable?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, still in 1994, how did you learn about the death of President Habyarimana?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I learnt about it over the radio when I went back home in the evening, at about 8:30 p.m. or 9 p.m.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you in your native commune that you told us when you learned about the death of the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I was in Kigali. I was residing in Kiyovu where my house -- my official residence was Kiyovu.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you tell us, in a few words, what happened in Kigali in your neighbourhood following the death of the president?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: As soon as we learned about the death of the president it was said over the radio that there was a curfew, and we were compelled to stay at home without going out. Then, at around midnight, we heard gunshots and we, of course, remained in our houses for about almost a week. And it was on the 12th of April that we were able to leave Kigali, and I was on my way to Gisenyi to my parents' house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why did you decide to leave Kigali?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We wanted to run away from the fighting. It was only on the 12th that we were able to leave Kigali, because the situation had subsided.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: The 12th of what month?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: The 12th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What form of transport did you go out of Kigali?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I had my own car.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And you said that you wanted to go where, which city?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: To Gisenyi, at my parents. First of all I went to see my in-laws, who lived in Gitarama.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, Witness. Where did you stay in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: With my in-laws.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you meet people that you knew before in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Members of my in-laws, the family of my in-laws, yes, and in the evening Mr. Ndindabahizi came to see me at my in-laws' and told me that the interim government had just decided to reopen the banks to be able to pay depositors their money and pay for the food supplies of the army.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Let's go back a little. Did you know Emmanuel Ndindabahizi before that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I had known him in 1973 when we were together at university.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you see him again since then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I only saw him again, practically, when he came to see me in Gitarama. It was on the 12th of April in the evening. Before that I had heard he was appointed director of cabinet and I did not see him at the Ministry of Finance, of course.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. On the 12th of April, in the evening, at what time, approximately, did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi? Do you remember that?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I believe it was 7 p.m., 7:30 p.m.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you meet him by chance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, for me it was by chance. I don't even know how he knew I was there, because we just arrived in Gitarama. I don't know how he learnt about being in Gitarama.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he come to see you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, yes, because it was his mission to come and tell me that I was summoned by the government to go back to work.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Could you give us more details concerning the reasons why he was himself in Gitarama -- Ndindabahizi I mean?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It was because the interim government had decided to set up in Gitarama and to get away from the fighting in Kigali. They had set up their headquarters in Murambi first.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you know the date that the interim government took seat in Murambi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We heard it over the radio while we were still in Kigali. It was around the 9th of April, we were told that they were sworn in in the Hotel de Mille Collines& was all we knew. It was broadcast over the radio.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. And on this 12th of April in the evening at around 1900 hours, what did Ndindabahizi tell you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, he told me the interim government had decided to reopen the banks and that -- because my functions, precedingly, the government had decided to enroll me to work with the other members of the bank who were also called in.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you obey?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I couldn't refuse because it was a decision of the government, all the more so as there was nothing else I could do.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: On that 12th of April, how long did you stay in the company of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, he didn't stay for a long time. He only stayed for about five minutes and left.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you start working on the 12th of April or later on?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It was later on; on the 13th in the morning, at around 8 a.m., they came to fetch me from my house, from my in-laws. Then we went to Murambi, that is the headquarters of the interim government.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Who came to fetch you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It was a driver -- no, it was a soldier. I do not remember his name anymore.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Well, we may not find it important. I wanted to know if it was Ndindabahizi himself.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, it was not Ndindabahizi himself. I do not remember the person as such. At any rate, when they came to fetch me we found Colonel Bagosora within the government. We were told that he was responsible for supervising the entire operation now.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let us go step-by-step, Witness. On the 13th of April, in the morning, they came to fetch you, and where did they take you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: To the headquarters of the government at Murambi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, who were you introduced to on the 13th of April in the morning to start you off?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: First of all we met the governor of the national bank who was with the accountant-general at the national bank, Mr. -- well, I can't remember his name at this time. And we were told that he was responsible for the team that was to run operations in the national bank.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, how did you settle down? Were you given an office in Murambi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, not in Murambi. We were with Colonel Bagosora, and the guard for the funds were -- I mean for the funds were and we therefore went to the secondary offices of the commercial bank in Gisarme.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you meet Emmanuel Ndindabahizi on the 13th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: On the 13th of April, in the morning, he was there, but as the rest of the operation was therefore without him, he went back to his office in the Ministry of Finance.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, I didn't get this quite clearly. Counsel asked you whether you were given an office at Murambi and then you provided an answer with reference to Colonel Bagosora, but I didn't get the gist of your answer. Can you repeat that answer, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Very well. Now, there were no offices because in principle we were supposed to work in the banks. So that we left with Colonel Bagosora to visit the offices in the commercial bank, down in the bank in Kigali, and inspect the situation, as far as the coffers of the banks were concerned.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Still on the 13th of April, to make this point clearer. The purpose of your mission, was it to find you an office or was there any other thing, because you are talking about your mission with Colonel Bagosora?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Now, the purpose was firstly to see whether the coffers of the two banks were safe and comfortable so that we could deposit funds that we got from Kigali in them for operations. We saw that they were rather empty, so we had to go back to Kigali, but they could take some funds. We brought back some funds for deposit at Kigarama.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What are these funds you are talking about?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: First of all, the funds came from the general accountant -- the general cashier, the funds that were in circulation, and a bundle of bank notes that were not in circulation to supply the main cashier, if she needed some.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Did you meet Mr. Ndindabahizi on the 13th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, only except on the 13th in the morning. After that, we did not see him for the rest of the day, because we went to Kigali. We came back with the funds to deposit the funds in the bank. We didn't go back to Murambi on that day.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: But in the morning time.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, in the morning.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Perhaps we can try to reconsider what happened on the 13th of April. Now, you went to Murambi on the 13th of April in the morning, is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: To inspect the premises.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You also met Emmanuel Ndindabahizi on the 13th on the morning, is that correct? Then you met Colonel Bagosora, is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: That is correct.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Then, together with Colonel Bagosora, you went to scout for a safe place to keep your funds, is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you find the described coffers?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, we found two coffers at the Kigali bank and at the commercial bank, at the two banks.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well, still on the 13th of April. Now, after having found the coffers to deposit money, what did you do?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Then, of course, we organised our departure from Kigali to go and secure the funds and, of course, the documents that were necessary, the accounting documents.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And in Kigali, where were the funds kept?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: They were in the coffers of the Rwandan national bank.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Have you actually transported the funds from Kigali to Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, we transported them under the escort of soldiers that Colonel Bagosora had obtained from the Kigali camp.

div.stage: Pages 1 to 7 by R. Lear)1500HBY MR. BESNIER:

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: How long did the operation to transfer the funds last?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Indeed, it ran up to the 14th because we had to go back on the 14th as well.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did it run for two days?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, two days.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That operation ended on the 14th of April; is that correct?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, that is correct, on the 14th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, during the course of the day of 13th April, did you see, apart from the morning, did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi once again?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, because we never went back to Murambi. After having deposited the funds, I went back directly to my in-laws' house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And where did your in-laws live?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Near the town there. Very near the stadium -- rather, very near the Gitarama market and near Kabugaye (phonetic), called Giahogwo (phonetic).

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. This is as far as the 13th of April is concerned. Now, the 14th of April, did you meet Emmanuel on the 14th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: The 14th of April, neither, because they came to fetch us very early. We didn't have time to go back to Murambi except in the evening when we finished the operation, when we went to get something to drink at very near the Goma headquarters.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And when you took your break after that, did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I caught sight of him in Murambi. I caught site of him. We were not together. I caught sight of him at the time when we went for a drink.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. I take it on the 14th of April the transfer of funds was finished. Now, what was your job after the 14th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Let's say the 15th, because the operations began on the 15th of April, and on account of my qualifications and my functions, I was to prepare vouchers for payments for the national treasury, the treasury of Rwanda.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you have an office at that time, as of the 15th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, we didn't have any permanent office, because sometimes we were at the Kigali bank, sometimes at the commercial bank. We didn't have a fixed office as such.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you perform the same duties? Did you have the same functions? For how long did you operate in those functions from the 15th of April?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Up to the time that we left the country for Goma, sir, that is around the 14th of July.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you stay in Gitarama since the -- from the 15th of July -- from the 15th of April to 15th of July?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, Gitarama fell, so we left Gitarama at around the 30th of May.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Could you very quickly and very simply, Witness, tell us what your work in Gitarama consisted in?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: The work I did in Gitarama consisted in the execution of payment of vouchers from the general treasurer, so that I established the payees and they were usually the suppliers, and of course the payment of salaries for civil servants.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Shall I take it that you were responsible for preparing payments for some suppliers for the state?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, the vouchers for the payment I did not pay. The payment was done by the chief cashier of the state.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, who were the suppliers that you paid? What do they supply you with?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Food supplies, especially for the army that was engaged with RPF; that is, engaged in combating RPF.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you responsible for buying arms for the army that was incumbent?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Before, that was one of my attributions. But at that particular time, one couldn't pay for anything except in foreign currency, and we used only Rwandan francs at that time.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you are now in Gitarama, are you, from the 15th of April to when?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Up to the 30th of April.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: That's when Gitarama falls?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: That's when we left Gitarama.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And then from the 13th of May, where were you then, just to get the overview?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We settled down in Gisyeni.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And then --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We left Gisyeni on the 14th of July to take refuge in Goma.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. We'll take it that you were responsible for preparing vouchers for payment vouchers. Now, Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, was he your hierarchical supervisor in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, he was not my hierarchical boss. He was minister for lands and responsible for the national bank. My hierarchical boss was director of the national bank.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you regularly in contact with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, actually, he asked me to update him about the situation as far as the treasury was concerned, because he needed that to be able to establish contracts because the government had decided to give advance payment to suppliers because the bank wasn't functioning anymore. So the government decided to give advances to suppliers so that Ndindabahizi needed an update on the situation, the financial situation. So every day I had to update him so far as the accounting situation was concerned.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you said that he was not your boss. Mr. Ndindabahizi was not your boss.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: So, I do agree with that, but he had asked me, as minister responsible for my department, because I couldn't find the governor all the time. It was, rather, the minister of finance who was more directly concerned. I saw the governor, I told him what the situation was, but I reported that to the minister because the minister needed that information to establish contracts and to evaluate the level of funds. He also was to pay the civil servants; that is, the civil servants: the teachers, health personnel, legal personnel, and sometimes the gendarmes and soldiers.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You are saying that you gave information under the directions of the governor of the --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, the governor also had asked me to give him such information.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Who was you're -- I need a clarification. Who was your immediate boss? Was it the governor or the director of finance, or both?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, it was the governor. But he was in touch with Ndindabahizi because he was the one that needed the information, so that I should give it to him directly.

sp.speaker: JUDGE BOSSA:
sp.p: Are you referring to the governor of the bank of Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Of the National Bank of Rwanda. And his name was N-T-I-R-U-M-B-A-B-A-Z-I. And that was the governor of the Bank of Rwanda.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: And who was above the governor of the Bank of Rwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: As I said before, it was the minister of finance as being the responsible minister for that portfolio.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: When we ask questions again, it's not because we haven't understood the previous answer. It's because we want to place it in context. Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, thank you, Mr. President.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Starting on the 15th of April 1994, did you regularly work with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, in fact, we did. Well, he would come to ask me for that information or sometimes I would go to give him in Murambi such information.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When you say that one of the two of you would travel to see the other, from where?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, I would go from the bank, the Bank of Kigali, to Murambi, and he would come from Murambi, either at Kigali -- at the Kigali bank or Bank of Commerce, because I used to work in those two places, either one or the other.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the distance between the banks that you spoke of and Murambi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Between the Bank of Kigali and the Bank of Commerce, there's not even one kilometre distance between the two, and from the bank of commerce to Murambi, there's a distance of not even two kilometres.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Are those three places in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, they were in the city of Gitarama.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Sir, to assist us, can you briefly describe the nature of Emmanuel Ndindabahizi's work in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: As I said, he was in charge of signing contracts with suppliers. He also had to look at the state of accounts to see what the spending situation could be, and to spend, he could only see what had been deposited by the state into the coffers. We had 2 billion 700 million Rwandan francs at the time in the coffers. When the money became insufficient, he negotiated special advances with the national bank. He only did that once. Because the Rwandan government no longer had any income, any revenue, and so he had to go to the system. When the overdraft was completely gone, he had to look for other situations. And this was provided for in law.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Given the event in your country in 1994, was the minister of finance's work real work or was it just a facade?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, he did do real work. Depositors were able to have their money because banks were open. Civil servants could get their salaries, at least those who could get to Gitarama could, so I would say his work was -- did consist in some real things.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you have an office in Murambi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, with his immediate associates, collaborators.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he receive many visitors in his office?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Certainly, I'm sure. Each time we would go to see him there, there were people looking for him, especially suppliers, food suppliers. Others were looking for advances; others were looking for past payments. That means he was constantly being looked for, as people were looking for solutions for payment.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, you yourself, how often did you meet with him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: As I said earlier, it was once or twice a day: once to give him the information on the state of the accounts, and perhaps in the evening when we would go to have a drink in a bar that was very close to the government headquarters.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you be more specific? In one day how many times would you see him, on average?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: On average, once or twice a day, not more.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In a week's time, how many days of the week would you see him, on average?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, excluding the weekends -- we were working. On the weekends we didn't have any free time, but we did try to rest. Except we couldn't when we were really demanded. So it was mostly during the week, and I know that sometimes he went on mission to Nairobi and he left the work to his collaborators, the treasurer and the budget director.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You said -- that in mid-May he left?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, he went to Nairobi for a few days, about a week. In mid-May he went there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the objective of that mission in mid-May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I think that he had a meeting with the PTA, of the PTA, there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the PTA?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It's the Preferential Trade Area of East Africa. It included Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Zambia, I believe. There were about seven countries from central and eastern Africa.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To the best of your memory, how long did he spend away?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I think it was about seven days he was away in that meeting. I think it was around the 17th of May, if I'm not mistaken. Six or seven days he was away.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Outside of that trip, did Mr. Ndindabahizi voyage often, did he leave often?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, only when the government would decide to have meetings in Kibuye or Gikongoro. I don't remember the exact date, but in the evenings he would always come back to Gitarama in such cases.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, these seven days, how do you count them? You mention -- will you relate these seven days to the date of 17th of May, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: This was in mid-May, mid-May 1994. It was between the 15th -- he left between the 15th and 17th. And the meeting took place during about a week's time. But I can't give you the exact dates.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the commencement of the seven day's period was between the 15th and the 17th of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I think it was the 17th, the 17th, I believe.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So the departure was on the 17th?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It's been ten years, Mr. President; I'm trying to remember the date.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: We really appreciate that, of course, of course.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, you mean to say that Mr. Ndindabahizi left Gitarama on 15th of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, approximately on those dates. I don't -- I can't say it was precisely the 15th because if I was to try to confirm that, wouldn't be telling the truth, because I don't actually know exactly.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: But you left Gitarama on the 13th of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: What I do know, it was in mid-May.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: When did you leave Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: To go where?

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: You left Gitarama on 13th of May, didn't you say?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Me? No, I don't recall saying that. Myself?

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: On 13th of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, Your Honour, it was the 30th, 30th of May that we left to Gisenyi.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: It is very often difficult to hear the difference between 13th and 30th. Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Let's go back over this, briefly. So Mr. Ndindabahizi left for about a week around mid-May. We agree on that point?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, Counsel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did he go back to Gitarama after?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I saw him after his return.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, during his absence, did you remain in Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, we never left Gitarama. Well, we did later to go to Gisyeni, as I mentioned.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Now, besides that trip in mid-May, did Mr. Ndindabahizi leave Gitarama to go to another préfecture as far as you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I think he went to a meeting convened by the prime minister in different préfectures, especially in Kibuye. I think that he also went to Gikongoro, but I can't remember the dates.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Let's speak about these meetings -- or this meeting. Did he leave? Well, how long did he leave?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It was during the day. It was just a day, during the day.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, let's speak of other absences that you might have noticed. Did he -- did he ever leave besides these times that you mentioned?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I don't think so because we would regularly contact each other, until the point where it was unsafe to remain in Gitarama, because the RPF became stronger and stronger there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: These two one-day trips, Mr. Witness, do you remember when they took place? Let's start with the meeting in Kibuye. Do you know when that meeting took place, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I really don't remember the dates, but I do know that it was in May.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Do you remember whether it was the beginning, middle or end of May?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I think the Kibuye meeting was in early May.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: What about Gikongoro, then?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Gikongoro, I'm not sure. What I do know is that the prime minister convened meetings during the month of May. They were bundled together, but I don't remember the exact dates.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So your recollection is that also the Gikongoro meeting took place in May; is that so?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I do believe so, but I'm not entirely sure. I do know that the Kibuye meeting was in early May.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Lets go back to Gitarama. When you worked with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi, did you have a specific meeting time during the days with him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, we didn't have, really, working -- specified working hours. He only would come to see me when he needed to or wanted to. Perhaps it was at ten o'clock in the morning or maybe later in the afternoon when I would find him there. And he didn't have any schedule when he came to see me. We never had specific meeting times.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: To meet him, did you have to make an appointment?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I did not. He had a small office in Murambi. He was with his employees there. They were makeshift offices.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you meet Ndindabahizi himself or would you deal with state affairs with his collaborators?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, that information was given directly by me to Mr. Ndindabahizi.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Outside of the absences that you spoke about, was Mr. Ndindabahizi there every time you went to see him at his office?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Most of the time I went there he was there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Was he there even when you would show up unexpected to see him?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, he was. He was so busy that he could rarely get away.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In spite of being busy, would it have been possible, during the month of April or May, for Mr. Ndindabahizi to leave for private issues without you knowing about it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I don't know. I didn't see him every hour of every day. It would be pretentious to claim that I did.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you ever know or learn that Mr. Ndindabahizi left his duties as minister of finance to distribute -- to go and distribute machetes in Kibuye, his native préfecture?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I never learned of such a situation. That would be surprising to me, especially because I know Ndindabahizi very well. When we were together in '73 in Butare there were Hutu and Tutsi tensions, and he never had any animosity whatsoever against the Tutsis. I don't know, but based on what I know about him, I don't think that he would be capable of doing such things.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Now, besides his moral qualities, do these things seem physically or practically possible in your mind?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, given the position of a minister, it seems unthinkable that a minister would distribute machetes to the population. Perhaps a conseiller could do it, but a minister, would he really go out and do that? Personally -- this is my personal opinion -- I don't think so.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Leave your personal opinion aside. Let's concentrate on the facts. Can you say whether practically, would Mr. Ndindabahizi have the means and time to organise a trip to Kibuye to distribute machetes, given what you know?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Materially that would seem impossible to me, especially given the distance between Kibuye and Gitarama, and given his work and his workload in Gitarama. I don't know if he could be in the two places at the same time, but it seems very improbable to me that he could be.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, what is the distance between Kibuye and Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I don't remember exactly. It's pretty far, and the roads were not good.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: But I don't know the exact distance, especially since I've never been to Kibuye.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Can you give us an approximate distance?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: A hundred or so kilometres. I'm not really sure.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was the state of the road between Kibuye and Gitarama in 1994?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, it was still under repair. All I know is that it was not easy to get there.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Very well. Sir, can you repeat, when did you leave Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We left Gitarama on the 30th of May.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Because of the RPF advance. We were told to pack up our things and leave as quickly as possible. On that day the RPF began to attack the market, and so we had to quickly prepare ourselves to leave.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where did you go after you left Gitarama?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: We went directly to Gisenyi with part of the funds. We only had one truck. When we arrived in Gisenyi, I returned back with two soldiers to get the rest of the money.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Where did the government set up shop in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: At the Meridien Hotel.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And where did you stay when you were in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I went to my in-laws. It was two kilometres from Gisenyi, so I would just go to their house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: One clarification, there was one thing that is not clear. Who did -- where did you live in Gitarama and where did you live in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: In Gitarama -- oh, no, rather in Gitarama it was at my in-laws'. At Gisenyi it was with my own parents.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, from time to time, but we saw less of each other than in Gitarama. But I would see him, because next to the Meridien Hotel there was an MRND office, and that's where people went to get passports quickly, because the situation was becoming serious and people were getting passports to be able to leave the country.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What was your work in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It was the same as it was before, the exact same job.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: And what was Ndindabahizi's work in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: In principle, he had to do the same thing, but the situation changed. There was practically chaos, save what you can. Very few suppliers were paid, because the situation became very grave indeed. It was chaos.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: During that period, starting from the 30th of May in Gisenyi, how often did you see Emmanuel Ndindabahizi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, I would say not very often, perhaps once every three days, perhaps once every two days. Not more than that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: When did you leave Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I spent the night at home, and on the 14th of July when I went to the office I saw that everything had been packed up. I followed suit, so I left on the 14th of July in the morning, but there were so many vehicles on the road it took us two days to go to Goma. When we arrived to Goma, it was two days later.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Were you with Emmanuel Ndindabahizi when you left Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I was with my son, my wife, and other children had left on a bus which was transporting funds, in a bus or a truck. I was in my own car. That's why it took me two days to get across.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did Ndindabahizi stay in Gisenyi?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No. When I arrived to Goma he was already there, and he had already set up there in Goma.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Does that mean that he left before you to Goma?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: In principle, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Thank you, sir. I don't have many more questions for you. Perhaps just one or two remaining questions.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I would ask the Registry for assistance for my last two questions, as I would like to distribute a document.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: I have given you a document, sir. Do you have it before you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you tell me, do you recognise this document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I hadn't seen it before till I was at the place I'm staying.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: You mean the place you are staying here in Arusha?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes. I hadn't seen it before that.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is this document? Can you describe it for us? What is it used for? What is it?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: It is a document giving advice to witnesses on how they should behave themselves before the Tribunal.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you look at page 9 of this document, please?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, sir. Yes, I've found page 9.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: What is page 9?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: This looks like a floor plan of a courtroom in -- of the Tribunal.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: On this floor plan, can you find the place where you are seated?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I'm No. 2, at No. 2.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do you see what is indicated at No. 4?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I see that the Accused is seated there at No. 4.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: In this courtroom can you see where the Accused is?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I see him behind you, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Before coming into this courtroom, did you know where the Accused was?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, I saw this document in the house where I was staying.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: That's not my question, sir. What I mean is, by reading this floor plan, would you have an idea of where the Accused would be seated in the courtroom?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Not at first sight, no, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Regarding this floor plan, would you have an idea if whether -- where the Accused is sitting; to the right of you, behind you, to the left of you?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Well, I would have to look at how the courtroom is situated to know what side is right and left.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Well, now that you are in this courtroom, and after looking at this floor plan --

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: I see that he is on the right-hand side.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you identify the Office of the Prosecutor?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes. It's at No. 5, I believe. Yes, at No. 5, to my left.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you identify the Bench?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, the Judges are just in front of me.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Can you see the seat of the Accused?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, it's to my right, at No. 4.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Did you find this document when you came to the safe house?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I found it when I arrived at the safe house. There was a document in French and another one in Kinyarwanda.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: This document is also in Kinyarwanda?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Do all the witnesses get this document?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes. It's in the living room over there at the safe house.

sp.speaker: MR. BESNIER:
sp.p: Mr. President, I have no further questions. I would, however, request that this document be tendered as the next Defence exhibit. Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE KHAN:
sp.p: Mr. Witness, the Accused is at your left or at your right? Mr. Ndindabahizi is sitting at your left?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: No, my left, my left. I mixed the two up. I'm sorry. No, at my left, and the other is on my right.

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: So this is, then, Defence Exhibit 48.

div.stage: EXhibit No. D. 48 admitted, under seal)

sp.speaker: MR. PRESIDENT:
sp.p: Thank you very much.Prosecution, please.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Witness, and good to see you again.Witness, I'm going to ask you some questions about your testimony in this courtroom, and if I ask you any questions that may seek to identify you or you feel uncomfortable with, please let me know, because some of them impact on the work that you did in 1994. Do you understand that, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, I do understand that, Prosecutor.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: Prior to the genocide of 1994, you were employed at the same institution that you have testified to this afternoon, were you not, sir?

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, yes. I've been working there since 1974, in actual fact.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And you, in 1994, held the same position that you testified to in this courtroom earlier today? Just a yes or no; don't repeat the position, please.

sp.speaker: WITNESS DP:
sp.p: Yes, the same position as I occupied since June 1993, I believe.

sp.speaker: MR. ADEOGUN-PHILLIPS:
sp.p: And the institution that you worked for was what we, in my language, we call the bankers' bank, was it not, sir?
